courses.description: Introduction to the study of the African continent, its peoples, history, and contemporary problems of development in a globalized world, including a survey of the African past, society and culture, and contemporary political, economic, and social issues.
courses.subject: AAAD
courses.title: Introduction to Africa (3)

courses.description: The course tracks the contours of life, societies, cultures, and history in the Atlantic African Diaspora from origins in Atlantic Africa to the present. Emphasis on forces that have created African American and African Diaspora peoples in North America, South America, and the Caribbean.
courses.subject: AAAD
courses.title: Introduction to African American and Diaspora Studies (3)

courses.description: By examining ethnographic texts, students will learn about topics in African studies such as systems of thought, aesthetics, the economy, politics, social organization, identity, and the politics of representation.
courses.subject: AAAD
courses.title: Ethnography of Africa (3)

courses.description: Special emphasis on postemancipation developments.
courses.subject: AAAD
courses.title: African American History since 1865 (3)

courses.description: An examination of the individual and collective experiences of black women in America from slavery to the present and the evolution of feminist consciousness.
courses.subject: AAAD
courses.title: Black Women in America (WMST 266) (3)

courses.description: A survey of African American political development from emancipation to the present. The course examines the dynamics of minority group politics with African Americans as the primary unit of analysis. Students consider African American politics in domestic and global contexts and issues of local, regional, national, and international relevance.
courses.subject: AAAD
courses.title: African American Politics (3)

courses.description: This course will analyze the role of the African American in motion pictures, explore the development of stereotypical portrayals, and investigate the efforts of African American actors and actresses to overcome these portrayals.
courses.subject: AAAD
courses.title: The African American in Motion Pictures: 1900 to the Present (3)

courses.description: An interdisciplinary course designed to provide a broad survey of the black experience in the Americas with special emphasis on postemancipation developments.
courses.subject: AAAD
courses.title: Blacks in the West (3)

courses.description: Explores the experiences of Africans in European colonies in locations such as colonial Mexico, Brazil, the Caribbean, and mainland North America. Lecture and discussion format. The major themes of inquiry include labor, law, gender, culture, and resistance, exploring differing experiences based on gender, location, and religion.
courses.subject: AAAD
courses.title: The African Diaspora in the Colonial Americas, 1450– 1800 (3)

courses.description: This course looks at blacks in the British world to 1833, with particular attention on the 13 colonies and the lands that would eventually form the Dominion of Canada.
courses.subject: AAAD
courses.title: Blacks in British North America to 1833 (3)

courses.description: Explores the role that the cultural realm plays in legitimizing, reproducing, resisting, and uncovering dominant structures of power in Africa.
courses.subject: AAAD
courses.title: Politics of Cultural Production in Africa (3)

courses.description: An introduction to African music new and old, focusing on the continent’s distinctive techniques and concepts, and on its musical interactions with the rest of the world. The politics of music making in various historical settings will be explored. Prior musical experience is helpful, but not required.
courses.subject: AAAD
courses.title: Music of Africa (3)

courses.description: See ARTH 387 for description.
courses.subject: AAAD
courses.title: 20th-Century African American Art (ARTH 387) (3)

courses.description: This course will focus upon the expression of African Americans in the United States in the 20th century.
courses.subject: ARTH
courses.title: 20th-Century African American Art (AAAD 330) (3)

courses.description: This course will allow students to research, analyze, and engage pressing political, economic, and social issues confronting black people in North America and elsewhere in the diaspora.
courses.subject: AAAD
courses.title: African America: Contemporary Issues (3)

courses.description: The course provides an examination of the ways that the past plays out in the present. Specifically this course examines memorials, monuments, and museums that remember and reinvent slavery and race in the United States and throughout the rest of the Diaspora.
courses.subject: AAAD
courses.title: Remembering Race and Slavery (3)

courses.description: Examines the sociopolitical dimensions of African Diaspora art and culture with a focus on African Americans in the 20th century.
courses.subject: AAAD
courses.title: Diaspora Art and Cultural Politics (3)

courses.description: This course explores the intersection of law and societal developments drawing from the disciplines of history, political science, anthropology, feminist legal studies, and constitutional law. The themes of the course will vary depending on the training, research interests, and geographical concentration of the faculty teaching the course.
courses.subject: AAAD
courses.title: Law and Society (3)

courses.description: Examines the emergence and impact of Hip Hop music and culture and its broad influence in mainstream culture, as a global phenomenon and as a vehicle embodying formative ideas of its constituent communities.
courses.subject: AAAD
courses.title: The History of Hip Hop Culture (3)

courses.description: This course explores the history and contemporary politics of HIV/AIDS in African communities and across the Diaspora. The differing trajectories of the epidemic on the continent, in the West, and in the Caribbean and Latin America will be explored.
courses.subject: AAAD
courses.title: HIV/AIDS in Africa and the Diaspora (3)

courses.description: Seminar focuses on history, politics, and economic development challenges of a single region or major country of the African continent, with emphasis on contemporary issues. Region, country, and topics vary by semester and instructor.
courses.subject: AAAD
courses.title: Regional Seminar in African Studies (3)

courses.description: This course is an introduction to the languages of Africa. No linguistics background is required. Topics include classification, characteristic linguistic features of Africans languages, and their role in their respective societies.
courses.subject: AAAD
courses.title: Introduction to the Languages of Africa (3)

courses.description: Examines the ideas of the scholar W. E. B. DuBois, theologian Howard Thurman, and political theorist Malcolm X. Major issues will be conceptualized from the distinct perspectives represented by those leaders.
courses.subject: AAAD
courses.title: DuBois, Howard Thurman, and Malcolm X (3)

courses.description: Prerequisites, AAAD 101 and 130. Permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisites. In this seminar students will examine primary documents of engaged scholarshipwritten by Africans and peoples of African descent in the Americas, Europe, and elsewhere in the African Diaspora.
courses.subject: AAAD
courses.title: Intellectual Currents in African and African Diaspora Studies (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, LGLA 101. Continues the introduction of the essential elements of Lingala structure and vocabulary and aspects of African cultures. Aural comprehension, reading, speaking, and writing are stressed.
courses.subject: LGLA
courses.title: Elementary Lingala II (3)

courses.description: This course reinforces language learning ability, communicative proficiency in the culture of the Lingala-speaking people through gradual exposure to more challenging tasks, with emphasis on poetry and prose reading, and creative writing.
courses.subject: LGLA
courses.title: Intermediate Lingala IV (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, SWAH 401. Continues the introduction of essential elements of Kiswahili structure and vocabulary and aspects of African cultures. Aural comprehension, reading, speaking, and writing are stressed.
courses.subject: SWAH
courses.title: Elementary Kiswahili II (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, SWAH 403. Fourth-semester Kiswahili, designed to increase reading and writing skills. Introduction of more compound structures. Emphasis on literature, including drama, prose and poetry, and creative writing. Aural comprehension and speaking skills stressed.
courses.subject: SWAH
courses.title: Intermediate Kiswahili IV (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, SWAH 405. Permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisite. This course reinforces and expands the grammatical, cultural, and communicative competence achieved in SWAH 405.
courses.subject: SWAH
courses.title: Advanced Plus Kiswahili VI (3)

courses.description: This course is for students who have already acquired the basics of Wolof to reinforce their ability to learn speaking, listening and understanding, writing, and reading Wolof. Evidence of basic knowledge of Wolof is required.
courses.subject: WOLO
courses.title: Elementary Wolof II (3)

courses.description: An introduction to the United States Air Force organization and mission.
courses.subject: AERO
courses.title: United States Air Force Today (1)

courses.description: Readings and research of topics regarding the United States Air Force.
courses.subject: AERO
courses.title: Independent Study (1–3)

courses.description: Examines general aspects of air and space power through a historical perspective from post–Cold War military operations through the Global War on Terror.
courses.subject: AERO
courses.title: The Evolution of United States Air Force Air and Space Power (1)

courses.description: Prerequisites, AERO 101, 102, 201, and 202. A continuation of AERO 301. Class participation, comprehension, and written communication skills will be stressed.
courses.subject: AERO
courses.title: Contemporary Leadership and Management (3)

courses.description: Survey and analysis of the major issues affecting officers in the Air Force. Lectures and discussions center on gaining insight into the military officer, military law, ethics, law of armed conflict, and preparing for active duty as a second lieutenant. Class participation, comprehension, written and oral communication skills are stressed.
courses.subject: AERO
courses.title: The Military and Contemporary Society (3)

courses.description: This course uses changes in the American family over the past century as a way of understanding larger processes of social change.
courses.subject: AMST
courses.title: First-Year Seminar: The Family and Social Change in America (3)

courses.description: Designed to help prepare students for future study abroad opportunities and travel, service, and work in a global environment, the seminar focuses on critical differences, including transportation and other forms of infrastructure, that impact navigating places, people, and information. Individual competitive global travel proposals will be developed and presented.
courses.subject: AMST
courses.title: First-Year Seminar: Navigating the World through American Eyes (3)

courses.description: Special topics course. Content will vary each semester.
courses.subject: AMST
courses.title: First-Year Seminar: Special Topics (3)

courses.description: Interdisciplinary examination of two centuries of American culture, focusing on moments of change and transformation.
courses.subject: AMST
courses.title: The Emergence of Modern America (3)

courses.description: A study of interdisciplinary methods and the concept of American studies with an emphasis on the historical context for literary texts.
courses.subject: AMST
courses.title: Literary Approaches to American Studies (3)

courses.description: A study of interdisciplinary methods and the concept of American studies with an emphasis on historical and cultural analysis.
courses.subject: AMST
courses.title: Historical Approaches to American Studies (3)

courses.description: Introduces students to the disciplines comprising American Indian studies and teaches them how to integrate disciplines for a more complete understanding of the experiences of American Indian peoples.
courses.subject: AMST
courses.title: Approaches to American Indian Studies (3)

courses.description: An examination of Southern cultural identity, literary imagination, and sense of place with an emphasis on the fiction, folklore, foodways, art, architecture, music, and material culture of the American South.
courses.subject: AMST
courses.title: Approaches to Southern Studies: The Literary and Cultural Worlds of the American South (3)

courses.description: See HIST 234 for description.
courses.subject: AMST
courses.title: Native American Tribal Studies (ANTH 234, HIST 234) (3)

courses.description: Special topics in American studies.
courses.subject: AMST
courses.title: Topics in American Studies (3)

courses.description: An interdisciplinary exploration of Native America during the “long 1960s” (1954– 1973), this course focuses on how American Indian experiences intersected with and diverged from those of non-native groups via topics such as the youth movement, women’s rights, nationalism, civil rights, radical protest, and creative expression.
courses.subject: AMST
courses.title: The Long 1960s in Native America (3)

courses.description: Analyzes material culture created by Native artists throughout the United States and portions of Canada. Examines the role of art and artists and how material culture is studied and displayed. Students study objects, texts, and images, exploring mediums such as painting, sculpture, basket making, beadwork, and photography.
courses.subject: AMST
courses.title: American Indian Art and Material Culture through Interdisciplinary Perspectives (3)

courses.description: An interdisciplinary seminar that explores stylistic choices and representational modes available to LGTBQ artists in the United States since 1950. We will relate shifts in cinematic and literary representations and aesthetic strategies to developments in political, social, and economic life.
courses.subject: AMST
courses.title: LGTBQ Film and Fiction from 1950 to the Present (3)

courses.description: This course will examine the history and meaning of food in American culture and will explore the ways in which food shapes national, regional, and personal identity.
courses.subject: AMST
courses.title: Food in American Culture (FOLK 375) (3)

courses.description: See AMST 375 for description.
courses.subject: FOLK
courses.title: Food in American Culture (AMST 375) (3)

courses.description: Examines the role of memory in constructing historical meaning and in imagining the boundaries of cultural communities. Explores popular rituals, artifacts, monuments, and public performances.
courses.subject: AMST
courses.title: Myth and History in American Memory (3)

courses.description: Explores history and theory of volunteerism and service learning in America. Includes a weekly academic seminar and placement in a service learning project.
courses.subject: AMST
courses.title: Service Learning in America (3)

courses.description: We will engage such topics as race, immigration, cultural tourism, and memory to consider conceptions of the South. Students will research a subject they find compelling and write a 20to 25-page paper.
courses.subject: AMST
courses.title: Senior Seminar in Southern Studies (3)

courses.description: This course emphasizes the complexities of human shelter in the United States. We learn housing types, explore their social uses and meanings, and evaluate critical issues, such as affordability and gentrification.
courses.subject: AMST
courses.title: You Are Where You Live: The American House in Critical Perspective (3)

courses.description: Seminar will explore the unique worlds of Southern material culture and how “artifacts” from barns to biscuits provide insight about the changing social and cultural history of the American South.
courses.subject: AMST
courses.title: No Place like Home: Material Culture of the American South (FOLK 488) (3)

courses.description: Graduate or junior/senior standing. Examines American civilization by studying social and cultural history, criticism, art, architecture, music, film, popular pastimes, and amusements, among other possible topics.
courses.subject: AMST
courses.title: Advanced Seminar in American Studies (3)

courses.description: This course takes a specific topic to explore in depth, and through this investigation critically examines contending perspectives on the field. topics will change depending on faculty interest.
courses.subject: AMST
courses.title: Readings in American Studies (3)

courses.description: This course, explores the application of digital technologies to the materials, questions, and practices of humanities scholarship, particularly as related to enduring topics in American studies scholarship and community engagement. students will work on group digital history projects in collaboration with local cultural heritage organizations.
courses.subject: AMST
courses.title: Digital Humanities/Digital American Studies (3)

courses.description: see Hist 878 for description.
courses.subject: AMST
courses.title: Readings in Native American History (HIST 878) (3)

courses.description: field/topical/research seminar. instructors use this course to offer instruction in particular topics or approaches. specific course descriptions are available each semester on the departmental web site.
courses.subject: AMST
courses.title: Special Topics in American Studies (3)

courses.description: See ENGL 202 for description.
courses.subject: FOLK
courses.title: Introduction to Folklore (ANTH 202, ENGL 202) (3)

courses.description: See ENGL 202 for description.
courses.subject: ANTH
courses.title: Introduction to Folklore (ENGL 202, FOLK 202) (3)

courses.description: See ANTH 428 for description.
courses.subject: FOLK
courses.title: Religion and Anthropology (ANTH 428, RELI 428) (3)

courses.description: See ANTH 484 for description.
courses.subject: FOLK
courses.title: Discourse and Dialogue in Ethnographic Research (ANTH 484, LING 484) (3)

courses.description: See AMST 488 for description.
courses.subject: FOLK
courses.title: No Place like Home: Material Culture of the American South (AMST 488) (3)

courses.description: Course considers how Southern writers employ folklore genres such as folk tales, sermons, and music and how such genres provide structure for literary forms like the novel and the short story.
courses.subject: FOLK
courses.title: Southern Literature and the Oral Tradition (3)

courses.description: See HIST 670 for description.
courses.subject: FOLK
courses.title: Introduction to Oral History (HIST 670) (3)

courses.description: Introduces students to the uses of interviews in historical research. Questions of ethics, interpretation, and the construction of memory will be explored, and interviewing skills will be developed through field work.
courses.subject: HIST
courses.title: Introduction to Oral History (FOLK 670) (3)

courses.description: A field-based exploration of the pragmatic, ethical, and theoretical dimensions of ethnographic research, addressing issues of experience, aesthetics, authority, and worldview through the lens of cultural encounter. field research required.
courses.subject: FOLK
courses.title: Art of Ethnography (ANTH 860) (3)

courses.description: Adopting a long view of human societies, students examine responses to crises engendered by political, economic, and environmental factors. Perspectives on societal change—apocalyptic, transformational, and resilient—undergo scrutiny.
courses.subject: ANTH
courses.title: First-Year Seminar: Crisis and Resilience: Past and Future of Human Societies (3)

courses.description: Can we truly access, understand, and represent the lives of others? In this class, students take on these questions by taking up the practice of ethnography, a research method consisting of entering into a community, interacting with its members, observing social life, asking questions, and writing about these experiences.
courses.subject: ANTH
courses.title: First-Year Seminar: The Lives of Others: Exploring Ethnography (3)

courses.description: Folk, outsider, visionary: these terms invoke artistry that unfolds outside of mainstream artistic traditions. This seminar explores these worlds of self-taught art, addressing issues of inspiration, authenticity, and cultural (mis)representation.
courses.subject: ANTH
courses.title: First-Year Seminar: Windows of Mystery and Wonder: Exploring Self-Taught Art (3)

courses.description: Special topics course; content will vary each semester.
courses.subject: ANTH
courses.title: First-Year Seminar: Special Topics (3)

courses.description: Fall component of a two-semester course. A seminar that explores issues of social and cultural diversity. Students must be residents of UNITAS residence hall.
courses.subject: ANTH
courses.title: UNITAS (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, ANTH 92. Permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisite. Spring component of a two-semester course. Students engage in service learning through APPLES and produce a final product that thoughtfully reflects on their experience. Students must be residents of UNITAS residence hall.
courses.subject: ANTH
courses.title: UNITAS (3)

courses.description: An introduction to anthropology, the science of humans, the culture-bearing animal. Topics considered: human evolution and biological variations within and between modern populations, prehistoric and historic developments of culture, cultural dynamics viewed analytically and comparatively.
courses.subject: ANTH
courses.title: General Anthropology (3)

courses.description: An introduction to non-Western cultures studied by anthropologists. Includes an indepth focus on the cultural and social systems of several groups.
courses.subject: ANTH
courses.title: Introduction to Cultural Anthropology (3)

courses.description: An introduction to archaeology through the study of towns and cities built by the ancient peoples of the Americas. The focus is on historical processes by which these centers arose.
courses.subject: ANTH
courses.title: Ancient Cities of the Americas (3)

courses.description: Globalization as a cultural and economic phenomenon, emphasizing the historical development of the current world situation and the impact of increasing global interconnection on local cultural traditions.
courses.subject: ANTH
courses.title: Local Cultures, Global Forces (3)

courses.description: Evolutionary and ecological approach to understanding the human species’ past and contemporary human variation. Emphasis on evolutionary processes, biological adaptation, and biocultural interactions with diverse environments.
courses.subject: ANTH
courses.title: Human Evolution and Adaptation (3)

courses.description: Introduction to world prehistory and archaeological methods. Examines the development of human society from the emergence of modern human beings 100,000 years ago through the formation of ancient civilizations.
courses.subject: ANTH
courses.title: Introduction to World Prehistory (3)

courses.description: In this course we compare a variety of healing beliefs and practices so that students may gain a better understanding of their own society, culture, and medical system.
courses.subject: ANTH
courses.title: Comparative Healing Systems (3)

courses.description: Anthropological perspectives on foodways. This course examines the biological basis of human diets as well as the historical and cultural contexts of food production, preparation, presentation, and consumption.
courses.subject: ANTH
courses.title: Anthropological Perspectives on Food and Culture (3)

courses.description: Explores the tremendous diversity that exists within and across American Indian nations, together with the concerns, issues, and challenges that shape the futures American Indians are charting for themselves.
courses.subject: ANTH
courses.title: American Indian Societies (3)

courses.description: See GLBL 210 for description.
courses.subject: ANTH
courses.title: Global Issues in the 20th Century (GEOG 210, GLBL 210, HIST 210, POLI 210) (3)

courses.description: See GLBL 210 for description.
courses.subject: GEOG
courses.title: Global Issues in the 20th Century (ANTH 210, GLBL 210, HIST 210, POLI 210) (3)

courses.description: Introduction to method and theory in archaeology. An examination of how archaeologists make inferences about past societies, including reconstruction of culture histories; lifeways; ideologies; and social, political, and economic relationships.
courses.subject: ANTH
courses.title: Principles of Archaeology (3)

courses.description: A survey of prehistoric art in Africa, the Americas, Australia, and Europe.
courses.subject: ANTH
courses.title: Prehistoric Art (3)

courses.description: An examination of the prehistory of Andean South America (Ecuador, Peru, and Bolivia) from first colonization 12,000 years ago to the fall of the Inca Empire in 1532 CE.
courses.subject: ANTH
courses.title: Archaeology of South America (3)

courses.description: See HIST 234 for description.
courses.subject: ANTH
courses.title: Native American Tribal Studies (AMST 234, HIST 234) (3)

courses.description: Course examines human adaptations to environments across Africa. Focuses on livelihood systems such as farming, herding, and hunting/gathering.
courses.subject: ANTH
courses.title: Human Ecology of Africa (3)

courses.description: Action research is a strategy for answering important questions, solving problems, and generating meaningful and democratic relationships. Through this course students will learn action research through academic and experiential techniques.
courses.subject: ANTH
courses.title: Action Research (3)

courses.description: The history of North American Indian cultures from 10,000 BCE to the time of the European colonization as reconstructed by archaeological research. Special emphasis on the eastern and southwestern United States.
courses.subject: ANTH
courses.title: Archaeology of North America (3)

courses.description: Introduces anthropological approaches to identity. Explores the relationship of identity, cultural contexts, and social life. Emphasizes contemporary global cultural interchange and visual media as tools of self-expression.
courses.subject: ANTH
courses.title: Culture and Identity (3)

courses.description: Examines what it means to be male, female, and other gendered categories in different societies. Focus on institutions, groups, and individuals that both shape and challenge how gender is understood, organized, and enacted.
courses.subject: ANTH
courses.title: Gender and Culture (WMST 277) (3)

courses.description: A cross-cultural look at gift giving, commodities, and status symbols. Course explores branded commodities, materialism as a factor in cultural change, global consumer culture, and local alternatives.
courses.subject: ANTH
courses.title: Culture and Consumption (3)

courses.description: Restricted to anthropology majors. Examines major theoretical perspectives that anthropologists have used to explain cultural diversity, social organization, and relations among societies. The class will offer a historical look at how anthropology developed its commitment to holism and ethnography and how contemporary debates have reshaped the field.
courses.subject: ANTH
courses.title: Anthropological Perspectives on Society and Culture (3)

courses.description: Permission of the instructor. Reading or study under a faculty member whose interests coincide with those of the individual student.
courses.subject: ANTH
courses.title: Independent Reading or Study in Anthropology II (1–3)

courses.description: Open only to and required of anthropology majors in their junior or senior year. Historical and contemporary issues and directions in the discipline as reflected in various concepts, theories, and research strategies.
courses.subject: ANTH
courses.title: Directions in Anthropology (3)

courses.description: Biological anthropology theory and practice, including human natural history, human genetics, epigenetics, and evolution; primatology; paleoanthropology; human biological variation; human biology and ecology; natural selection and adaptation in human evolution; and evolutionary, ecological, and biocultural perspectives on health and disease.
courses.subject: ANTH
courses.title: Biological Anthropology Theory and Practice (3)

courses.description: This class explores some of the historical, biological, economic, medical, and social issues surrounding globalization and health consequences.
courses.subject: ANTH
courses.title: Global Health (3)

courses.description: Critical exploration of current debates in the anthropology of Third World development, the production of global inequality, and the construction of parts of the world as underdeveloped through discourses and practices of development.
courses.subject: ANTH
courses.title: Anthropology of Development (3)

courses.description: This course explores how anthropological perspectives might take understandings of democracy in new and unanticipated directions. Using examples from across the globe students will investigate the forces and impacts of democracy. Through hands-on assignments, students will implement a local research project related to the theme of democracy.
courses.subject: ANTH
courses.title: Anthropology of Democracy (3)

courses.description: Examines economic and cultural diversity of Latin America. Using case studies, class focuses on community social organization, work habits, family life and cosmologies, and the problem of inclusion in national cultures.
courses.subject: ANTH
courses.title: Latin American Economy and Society (3)

courses.description: The past in Southeast Asia’s present, focusing on global, national, and local processes; individual and collective memory; and the legacies of violent death.
courses.subject: ANTH
courses.title: Memory, Massacres, and Monuments in Southeast Asia (ASIA 375) (3)

courses.subject: ANTH
courses.title: Ind Read Or Study Anthro Lecture

courses.description: An examination of the laboratory techniques used by archaeologists to analyze artifacts and organic remains, including the analysis of stone tools, pottery, botanical remains, and bone.
courses.subject: ANTH
courses.title: Laboratory Methods in Archaeology (3)

courses.description: The study of human skeletal remains from archaeological contexts. The collection and interpretation of quantitative and qualitative data is emphasized to assess the relationship between past biology, environment, culture, and behavior.
courses.subject: ANTH
courses.title: Bioarchaeology (3)

courses.description: Religion studied anthropologically as a cultural, social, and psychological phenomenon in the works of classical and contemporary social thought.
courses.subject: ANTH
courses.title: Religion and Anthropology (FOLK 428, RELI 428) (3)

courses.description: This course examines the intersections between migration processes and the political, economic, and social dimensions of health and well-being among migrants, their families, and their communities.
courses.subject: ANTH
courses.title: Migration and Health (3)

courses.description: This course examines poverty, inequalities, and health from a global and historical perspective. We will study the role of sociopolitical context, individual behavior, and human biology, and will pay particular attention to the roles of psychosocial stress, material conditions, and policy in shaping health differences within and between populations.
courses.subject: ANTH
courses.title: Poverty, Inequality, and Health (3)

courses.description: Anthropological investigations of work and the relationship between work, family life, and community in contemporary societies in the United States, Asia, and Latin America, within the framework of globalization.
courses.subject: ANTH
courses.title: The Anthropology of Work (3)

courses.description: Considers how archaeological evidence is used to understand the movement of Africans and their descendants across the globe, with an emphasis on the transformation of societies on the African continent and in the Americas.
courses.subject: ANTH
courses.title: The Archaeology of African Diasporas (3)

courses.description: Examines how human-environmental adaptations shape the economic, social, and cultural lives of hunter–gatherers, pastoralists, and agriculturalists. Approaches include optimal foraging theory, political ecology, and subsistence risk.
courses.subject: ANTH
courses.title: Ecological Anthropology (3)

courses.description: This course examines cultural understandings of health, illness, and medical systems from an anthropological perspective with a special focus on Western medicine.
courses.subject: ANTH
courses.title: Medicine and Anthropology (FOLK 470) (3)

courses.description: Study of cultural variation in styles of speaking applied to collection of ethnographic data. Talk as responsive social action and its role in the constitution of ethnic and gender identities.
courses.subject: ANTH
courses.title: Discourse and Dialogue in Ethnographic Research (FOLK 484, LING 484) (3)

courses.description: See ANTH 484 for description.
courses.subject: LING
courses.title: Discourse and Dialogue in Ethnographic Research (ANTH 484, FOLK 484) (3)

courses.description: Restricted to junior and senior anthropology majors; generally the course is limited to 18 students. The subject matter will vary with the instructor. Each course will concern itself with a study in contemporary anthropology and new directions in research or applications.
courses.subject: ANTH
courses.title: Undergraduate Seminar in Anthropology (3)

courses.description: Anthropological examination of processes of globalization and transnationalism, with special attention to transnational migration, emergence of transnational (“global”) institutions, commodity flows, and dissemination of ideologies, cultural frameworks, and media imagery.
courses.subject: ANTH
courses.title: Globalization and Transnationalism (3)

courses.description: See LING 523 for description.
courses.subject: ANTH
courses.title: Phonological Theory I (LING 523) (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, LING 520, or SPHS 530 or 540. Permission of the instructor for undergraduates. Introduction to the principles of modern generative phonology. Methods and theory of phonological analysis.
courses.subject: LING
courses.title: Phonological Theory I (ANTH 523) (3)

courses.description: Analysis of the social-environmental crisis and approaches to redress it, particularly those that posit ecological and cultural transitions beyond current globalization models. Participants will construct their own scenarios for transitions to sustainable and pluralistic societies. The course will have an in-built, collective research component. Intended for upper-division undergraduates.
courses.subject: ANTH
courses.title: Planetary Crises and Ecological and Cultural Transitions (3)

courses.description: Cultural perspectives on science and technology at a global scale, including research settings and social contexts, knowledge claims and material practice, and relations between scientific worldviews, social institutions, and popular imagination.
courses.subject: ANTH
courses.title: Anthropology of Science (3)

courses.description: Subject matter will vary with instructor but will focus on some particular topic or anthropological approach. Course description is available from the departmental office.
courses.subject: ANTH
courses.title: Special Topics in Anthropology II (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, AntH 701. Permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisite.
courses.subject: ANTH
courses.title: Sociocultural Theory and Ethnography (3)

courses.description: review of the recent history of archaeology and contemporary approaches to archaeological interpretation.
courses.subject: ANTH
courses.title: Archaeological Theory (3)

courses.description: Permission of the department. directed course preparation and review of teaching techniques, films, and other aids.
courses.subject: ANTH
courses.title: The Concept of Teaching General Anthropology (3)

courses.description: see folK 860 for description.
courses.subject: ANTH
courses.title: Art of Ethnography (FOLK 860) (3)

courses.description: topic determined by instructor and announced in advance.
courses.subject: ANTH
courses.title: Seminar in Selected Topics (1–4)

courses.description: Permission of the instructor. topic determined by instructor and announced in advance.
courses.subject: ANTH
courses.title: Reading and Research (1–4)

courses.description: Permission of the instructor. topic determined by instructor and announced in advance.
courses.subject: ANTH
courses.title: Reading and Research (1–4)

courses.description: individual research in a special field under the direction of a member of the department.
courses.subject: ANTH
courses.title: Master’s Thesis (3–6)

courses.description: See CHEM 420 for description.
courses.subject: APPL
courses.title: Introduction to Polymer Chemistry (CHEM 420) (3)

courses.description: See CHEM 473 for description.
courses.subject: APPL
courses.title: Chemistry and Physics of Surfaces (CHEM 473) (3)

courses.description: Permission of the instructor. Special reading and research in archaeology under the supervision of a selected instructor. May be taken twice.
courses.subject: ARCH
courses.title: Independent Study in Archaeology (1–6)

courses.description: Content varies by semester.
courses.subject: ARTH
courses.title: First-Year Seminar: Special Topics (3)

courses.description: This course provides an introductory survey of some of the major traditions of art making throughout the world, from prehistory to the present.
courses.subject: ARTH
courses.title: World Art (3)

courses.description: This is the second semester of the two-semester survey course including Western art from the Renaissance to the modern period. ARTH 151 is not a prerequisite for ARTH 152.
courses.subject: ARTH
courses.title: History of Western Art II (3)

courses.description: This course introduces the arts of the Islamic lands from the seventh-century rise of the Umayyad dynasty of Syria to the 16th-century expansion of the Ottoman Empire.
courses.subject: ARTH
courses.title: Introduction to Art and Architecture of Islamic Lands (Eighth–16th Centuries CE) (ASIA 154) (3)

courses.description: See ARTH 154 for description.
courses.subject: ASIA
courses.title: Introduction to Art and Architecture of Islamic Lands (Eighth–16th Centuries CE) (ARTH 154) (3)

courses.description: This course introduces the arts of the Islamic lands from the seventh-century rise of the Umayyad dynasty of Syria to the 16th-century expansion of the Ottoman Empire.
courses.subject: ARTH
courses.title: Introduction to Art and Architecture of Islamic Lands (Eighth–16th Centuries CE) (ASIA 154) (3)

courses.description: A critical and historical introduction to film from a visual arts perspective. The course surveys the history of film from its inception to the present, drawing upon both foreign and American traditions.
courses.subject: ARTH
courses.title: The Film Experience: Introduction to the Visual Study of Film (3)

courses.description: This course surveys American art and architecture, analyzing paintings, sculpture, buildings, and popular imagery produced between the early colonial period and World War I.
courses.subject: ARTH
courses.title: Introduction to American Art (3)

courses.description: This course explores the art and culture of sub-Saharan Africa on the levels of both production and consumption both locally and globally.
courses.subject: ARTH
courses.title: African Art and Culture (3)

courses.description: Required preparation, any introductory art history course or permission of the instructor. Understanding the meaning of medieval art by examining the iconography of selected important works.
courses.subject: ARTH
courses.title: Medieval Iconography (3)

courses.description: This course focuses on the relationship between the national and international and art and politics within Latin American modernist movements from ca. 1900 to 1960.
courses.subject: ARTH
courses.title: Latin American Modernisms (3)

courses.description: Required preparation, any introductory art history course or permission of the instructor. This course explores the visual culture patronized by the Mughal dynasty in India from the 11th to the 17th centuries.
courses.subject: ARTH
courses.title: Arts under the Mughal Dynasty in India (ASIA 273) (3)

courses.description: See ARTH 273 for description.
courses.subject: ASIA
courses.title: Arts under the Mughal Dynasty in India (ARTH 273) (3)

courses.description: Required preparation, any introductory art history course or permission of the instructor. Major figures, movements, and themes of modernism from cubism and the emergence of abstraction to the transfer of artistic energy and innovation to the United States after World War II.
courses.subject: ARTH
courses.title: Modernism II: 1905–1960 (3)

courses.description: An introduction to African American art and artists and their social contexts from early slavery.
courses.subject: ARTH
courses.title: African American Art Survey (AAAD 237) (3)

courses.description: This course examines fashion and the political, social, and cultural discourses, conditions, and institutional formations used in the creation of varied social and personal identities.
courses.subject: ARTH
courses.title: Fashioning Identities (3)

courses.description: Required preparation, any introductory art history course or permission of the instructor. The early Christian origins of art and architecture in domestic and public contexts of the 200–600 CE Christian communities; the 18thand 20th-century adaptation of early Christian art.
courses.subject: ARTH
courses.title: Early Christian Art and Modern Responses (3)

courses.description: This course explores the art of the late medieval period in Byzantium and the Latin West.
courses.subject: ARTH
courses.title: Late Medieval Art (3)

courses.description: Required preparation, art history major and sophomore standing or permission of the instructor. Introduces students to research in art history. Seminar involves a multi-stage research project beginning with close analysis of an art object and culminating with a research paper. Topics are drawn from ancient/medieval, early modern, and modern/ contemporary art.
courses.subject: ARTH
courses.title: Undergraduate Research Seminar (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, ARTH 157 or 267. Permission of the instructor. This course investigates mural painting and state patronage in post-Revolutionary Mexico, from 1921 to 1945, when artists engaged politics in monumental public works. Focuses on the murals of Diego Rivera, José Clemente Orozco, and David Alfaro Siqueiros, as well as on the relationship between art and politics.
courses.subject: ARTH
courses.title: The Mexican Mural Renaissance, 1921–1945 (3)

courses.description: Required preparation, any intermediate art history course or permission of the instructor. This thematic course explores how objects and monuments are viewed, experienced, and used in a ritual context in South Asia.
courses.subject: ARTH
courses.title: Art and Visual Culture of South Asia (ASIA 456) (3)

courses.description: Required preparation, any intermediate art history course or permission of the instructor. A focused study of sculpture during the Archaic period in Greece.
courses.subject: ARTH
courses.title: Archaic Greek Sculpture (CLAR 461) (3)

courses.description: Required preparation, any intermediate art history course or permission of the instructor. Chronological survey of major developments in book painting during the European Middle Ages from 300 to 1450 CE.
courses.subject: ARTH
courses.title: History of the Illuminated Book (3)

courses.description: An examination of the interaction of artists, criticism, and the market with larger political and social developments in France, with an emphasis on primary sources.
courses.subject: ARTH
courses.title: Art, Politics, and Society in France, 1850–1914 (HIST 468) (3)

courses.description: Introduces careers in museums and other cultural institutions. Readings and interactions with museum professionals expose participants to curation, collection management, conservation, exhibition design, administration, publication, educational programming, and fundraising.
courses.subject: ARTH
courses.title: Introduction to Museum Studies (3)

courses.subject: ARTH
courses.title: Advanced Readings Topics in the History of Art (3)

courses.description: study selected topics in the history of Chinese art and architecture.
courses.subject: ARTH
courses.title: Seminar in Chinese Art and Architecture (3)

courses.description: Class examines how to advance and sustain artistic production, focusing not only on being a successful artist, but also on the importance of creativity and hard work in any successful venture.
courses.subject: ARTS
courses.title: First-Year Seminar: The Artistic Temperament (3)

courses.description: This course will explore concepts of making art in both practice and in theory. Driven by foundational theoretical texts that have influenced 20th-century art and culture, the course explores art as content and meaning, and art’s relationship to form, everyday life, and visual culture.
courses.subject: ARTS
courses.title: Idea and Form (3)

courses.description: Studio course investigates concepts and strategies of two-dimensional image making. Introduces design elements of visual language (line, shape, value, texture, color). Considers the cultural codes that accompany visual information and how they combine with organizational structures to determine a variety of effects, influence responses, and inform meaning. Foundation requirement for studio majors.
courses.subject: ARTS
courses.title: Core Concepts: Image (3)

courses.description: Studio course introduces concepts and strategies of working in three dimensions. Projectbased coursework develops understanding of ideation process and creative problem solving. Ideas about sculpture are further expanded by considering works by contemporary artists. Students develop aesthetic sensibility, analytical capacity, and fundamental skills in sculptural media. Foundation requirement for studio majors.
courses.subject: ARTS
courses.title: Core Concepts: Space (3)

courses.description: Working out of an observational tradition, this course provides an introduction to the concepts and techniques of drawing. Paying attention to both representation and interpretation, the course is designed to develop fundamental skills, aesthetic sensibility, analytical capacity, and creative problem solving in two-dimensional media.
courses.subject: ARTS
courses.title: Basic Drawing and Composition (3)

courses.description: Focusing on creative digital and analog photography, this course provides an introduction to the concepts and techniques of lens-based media.
courses.subject: ARTS
courses.title: Basic Photography (3)

courses.description: This foundation course introduces concepts and techniques of temporal art making. Through projects designed to develop an understanding of the creative language unique to digital media, students will learn various software programs and basic digital strategies to realize time-based works of art. Foundation requirement for studio majors.
courses.subject: ARTS
courses.title: Core Concepts: Time (3)

courses.description: Prerequisites, ARTS 102 and 104. Permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisites. Introduction to the techniques of two-dimensional thought and process through the application of various painting media.
courses.subject: ARTS
courses.title: Painting I (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, ARTS 103. Permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisite. Introduction to the techniques of three-dimensional thought and process through the application of the various sculpture media.
courses.subject: ARTS
courses.title: Sculpture I (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, ARTS 103. Permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisite. An investigation of clay as a sculptural medium; developing technical skills, aesthetic awareness, and historical perspective.
courses.subject: ARTS
courses.title: Ceramic Sculpture I (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, ARTS 104. Development of proficiency in figure drawing through the use of various drawing and painting materials (study from the model).
courses.subject: ARTS
courses.title: Life Drawing I (3)

courses.description: Prerequisites, ARTS 101, 102, 103, and 106. Required for studio art majors with at least 15 hours of course work in the major. This class addresses questions of artistic identity and professional development for the art major.
courses.subject: ARTS
courses.title: Studio 15: Art Majors Seminar (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, ARTS 202. Continuation of ARTS 202.
courses.subject: ARTS
courses.title: Intermediate Painting (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, ARTS 105. Continuation of ARTS 105.
courses.subject: ARTS
courses.title: Intermediate Photography (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, ARTS 213. Continuation of ARTS 213.
courses.subject: ARTS
courses.title: Intermediate Ceramic Sculpture (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, ARTS 214. Continuation of ARTS 214.
courses.subject: ARTS
courses.title: Life Drawing II (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, ARTS 104. Continuation of ARTS 104.
courses.subject: ARTS
courses.title: Intermediate Drawing (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, ARTS 208. Permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisite. Lithography is an intermediate printmaking class. The course provides basic technical introduction to stone and plate lithography. Students will investigate artistic strategies to forge visual literacy in print media.
courses.subject: ARTS
courses.title: Lithography (3)

courses.description: Required preparation, any intermediate studio art course or permission of the instructor. Selected topics.
courses.subject: ARTS
courses.title: Special Topics in Studio Art (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, ARTS 302. Permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisite. Continuation of ARTS 302. May be repeated for credit.
courses.subject: ARTS
courses.title: Advanced Painting (1–6)

courses.description: Prerequisite, ARTS 313. Permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisite. Continuation of ARTS 313. May be repeated for credit.
courses.subject: ARTS
courses.title: Advanced Ceramic Sculpture (1–6)

courses.description: Prerequisites, ARTS 208 and any two of 328, 338, or 348. Permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisites. This course is appropriate for students who have had a minimum of three semesters of prior printmaking experience. Students submit a proposal outlining technical and artistic goals for the semester.
courses.subject: ARTS
courses.title: Advanced Printmaking (1–6)

courses.description: Required preparation, any intermediate studio art course or permission of the instructor. Advanced consideration of selected topics in studio art.
courses.subject: ARTS
courses.title: Special Topics in Studio Art (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, ARTS 300. Recommended for juniors or seniors. Allows studio art majors to pursue unpaid practicums or internships for credit. Examples include working as a studio assistant or working in art-related fields, such as galleries, design firms, architectural firms, and nonprofit arts organizations. Work undertaken must comply with Federal criteria governing unpaid internships.
courses.subject: ARTS
courses.title: Studio Art Practicum or Internship (3)

courses.description: Restricted to senior studio art majors. This course is the capstone course for the studio art major. Topics covered include issues of professional development, curatorial practice, and presentation of works of art in exhibition. The culminating project is mounting the Senior Exhibition.
courses.subject: ARTS
courses.title: Senior Seminar (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, ARTS 305. Permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisite. May be repeated for credit.
courses.subject: ARTS
courses.title: Advanced Photography (3)

courses.description: Permission of the instructor. For students wishing to pursue additional media or thematic study beyond the advanced level. Students register with section numbers designated for faculty. May be repeated for credit.
courses.subject: ARTS
courses.title: Independent Study in Studio Art (1–9)

courses.subject: ARTS
courses.title: Master'S Project In Studio Art Lecture

courses.description: Prerequisite, ARAB 101. Introduction to Modern Standard Arabic, including the Arabic script, basic grammar, and vocabulary, and developing skills in reading, writing, listening, and speaking.
courses.subject: ARAB
courses.title: Elementary Arabic II (4)

courses.description: Introduction to the cultures of the Arab world and of the Arabs in diasporas: art, literature, film, music, dance, food, history, religion, folklore, etc.
courses.subject: ARAB
courses.title: Introduction to Arab Cultures (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, ARAB 203. A proficiency based course centered on reading, writing, speaking, and listening to Modern Standard Arabic with an emphasis on understanding the application of grammatical structures and vocabulary development.
courses.subject: ARAB
courses.title: Intermediate Arabic II (4)

courses.description: Prerequisite, ARAB 204. Intensive grammar review and composition to improve accuracy and develop writing skills in Modern Standard Arabic.
courses.subject: ARAB
courses.title: Arabic Grammar and Composition (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, ARAB 305. Intensive reading of a variety of texts; films, oral presentations, and writing; extensive vocabulary development.
courses.subject: ARAB
courses.title: Advanced Arabic II (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, ARAB 204. Arabic recitation offered in conjunction with selected content courses. Weekly discussion and readings in Arabic relating to attached content courses.
courses.subject: ARAB
courses.title: Arabic Languages across the Curriculum Recitation (1)

courses.description: Prerequisite, ARAB 306. Classical and/or modern readings in Arabic, according to the students’ interest.
courses.subject: ARAB
courses.title: Readings in Arabic II (3)

courses.description: Examines alternative interpretations of Arab history, culture, and identity that challenge our understanding of contemporary Arab cultures. Traces how Arab writers and filmmakers simultaneously engage and subvert questions of identity and representation.
courses.subject: ARAB
courses.title: Dissident Voices in Arab Cultures (3)

courses.description: See RELI 681 (only when offered in Arabic) for description.
courses.subject: ARAB
courses.title: Readings in Islamicate Literatures (ASIA 681, RELI 681) (3)

courses.description: See RELI 681 for description.
courses.subject: ASIA
courses.title: Readings in Islamicate Literatures (ARAB 681, RELI 681) (3)

courses.description: Elements of Indian culture and history are illuminated through works chiefly in the art film genre. Basic film theory is also introduced to help students read the text of film.
courses.subject: ASIA
courses.title: First-Year Seminar: India through the Lens of Master Filmmakers (3)

courses.description: This seminar explores the history of tea culture in Japan, particularly the emergence in the 16th and 17th centuries of the ritualized practice often referred to in English as the “tea ceremony” (chanoyu). Practitioners included merchants, Buddhist monks, warlords, European Jesuits, and professional tea masters.
courses.subject: ASIA
courses.title: First-Year Seminar: Japanese Tea Culture (3)

courses.description: Special topics course. Content will vary each semester.
courses.subject: ASIA
courses.title: First-Year Seminar: Special Topics (3)

courses.description: See HIST 134 for description.
courses.subject: ASIA
courses.title: Modern East Asia (HIST 134, PWAD 134) (3)

courses.description: See HIST 134 for description.
courses.subject: PWAD
courses.title: Modern East Asia (ASIA 134, HIST 134) (3)

courses.description: See RELI 181 for description.
courses.subject: ASIA
courses.title: Later Islamic Civilization and Modern Muslim Cultures (RELI 181) (3)

courses.description: Surveys important developments in modern Islamic civilizations, from 1453 to today. Among the topics covered are the Ottoman Empire; the rise of Islamic modernism, reformism, and fundamentalism; the Palestinian/Israeli controversy; the Islamic Revolution in Iran; the Taliban; 9/11 and Muslim responses.
courses.subject: RELI
courses.title: Later Islamic Civilization and Modern Muslim Cultures (ASIA 181) (3)

courses.description: This course will offer students an opportunity to study selected, socially engaged Iranian films. By watching, contextualizing, and discussing films that explore cultural and historical issues affecting modern-day Iran, we will discover themes of politics, religion, gender, class, and history.
courses.subject: ASIA
courses.title: Introduction to Iranian Cinema (3)

courses.description: This course explores the development of the Indian cinema, with particular emphasis on the Hindi-Urdu films produced in Mumbai (Bollywood).
courses.subject: ASIA
courses.title: Bollywood Cinema (3)

courses.description: The course explores major periods and trends in Israeli cinema. Focus is given to issues pertaining to gender, ethnicity, and the construction of national identity.
courses.subject: ASIA
courses.title: Israeli Cinema: Gender, Nation, and Ethnicity (3)

courses.description: This course examines popular culture in Southeast Asia as a response to colonialism, nationalism, modernization, the state, and globalization. Topics include theater, film, pop songs, television, rituals, and the Internet.
courses.subject: ASIA
courses.title: Popular Culture in Modern Southeast Asia (CMPL 252) (3)

courses.description: See CMPL 255 for description.
courses.subject: ASIA
courses.title: The Feast in Film, Fiction, and Philosophy (CMPL 255) (3)

courses.description: Comparative and interdisciplinary study of feasting and its philosophical underpinnings, with special attention to the multiple purposes and nuances of food and feasting in literature, film, and the visual arts.
courses.subject: CMPL
courses.title: The Feast in Film, Fiction, and Philosophy (ASIA 255) (3)

courses.description: Examines Western views of India and Indian culture and how these views differ from the way Indians in India and Indian immigrants in the West understand themselves and express their relationship to India through novels and travelogues.
courses.subject: ASIA
courses.title: India through Western Eyes (3)

courses.description: See HIST 276 for description.
courses.subject: ASIA
courses.title: The Modern Middle East (HIST 276) (3)

courses.description: This course introduces students to the recent history of the Middle East, including a comparison of the Middle East to the United States.
courses.subject: HIST
courses.title: The Modern Middle East (ASIA 276) (3)

courses.description: See HIST 281 for description.
courses.subject: ASIA
courses.title: The Pacific War, 1937–1945: Its Causes and Legacy (HIST 281, PWAD 281) (3)

courses.description: See HIST 281 for description.
courses.subject: PWAD
courses.title: The Pacific War, 1937–1945: Its Causes and Legacy (ASIA 281, HIST 281) (3)

courses.description: See RELI 287 for description.
courses.subject: ASIA
courses.title: Modern Japanese Religions (RELI 287) (3)

courses.description: Graduate standing in religious studies or permission of the instructor. topics vary.
courses.subject: RELI
courses.title: Topics in the Study of Religion (3–9)

courses.description: This course is designed to examine Jewish life in Arab lands in the last century by examining culture, language, and the communal life that the Arab-Jews shared with their neighbors.
courses.subject: ASIA
courses.title: The Arab-Jews: Culture, Community, and Coexistence (3)

courses.description: See ARTH 456 for description.
courses.subject: ASIA
courses.title: Art and Visual Culture of South Asia (ARTH 456) (3)

courses.description: See ECON 469 for description.
courses.subject: ASIA
courses.title: Western and Asian Economic Systems (ECON 469) (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, ECON 310 or 410. Policy seminar on the systemic factors distinguishing Western economies from their rivals in the former Soviet bloc and Asia, focused on conflict resolution and global integration.
courses.subject: ECON
courses.title: Western and Asian Economic Systems (ASIA 469) (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, CHIN 101. Continued training in listening, speaking, reading, and writing on everyday topics. Four hours per week.
courses.subject: CHIN
courses.title: Elementary Chinese II (4)

courses.description: Prerequisite, CHIN 203. Secondyear level of modern standard Chinese. Four hours per week.
courses.subject: CHIN
courses.title: Intermediate Chinese II (4)

courses.description: Prerequisite, CHIN 111. Designed for students who already understand and speak some Chinese. The training in the course centers on reading and writing. This course is taught in Chinese. CHIN 212 is equivalent to CHIN 203 and 204. Three hours per week.
courses.subject: CHIN
courses.title: Intermediate Written Chinese (3)

courses.description: This course shows how Chinese historical legends define and transmit the values, concepts, figures of speech, and modes of behavior that constitute Chinese culture.
courses.subject: CHIN
courses.title: Introduction to Chinese Culture through Narrative (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, CHIN 305. Permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisite. This course provides training in advanced conversation and composition with readings that cover a range of topics on Chinese society, economics, history, politics, etc. Three hours per week.
courses.subject: CHIN
courses.title: Advanced Chinese II (3)

courses.description: The rise of China has altered the economic and political order of the post–Cold War world. This course examines the historical context and trajectory of China’s rise, its internal dynamics, and the challenges it poses to the rest of the world.
courses.subject: CHIN
courses.title: The Rise of China: A Global and Multidisciplinary Approach (3)

courses.description: Through analysis of the role movies play in the formation of popular perceptions of the past, this course provides an introduction to the history of the Qin and Han dynasties.
courses.subject: CHIN
courses.title: History as Fiction or Fiction as History? Early Chinese History in Film and Literature (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, CHIN 102, CHIN 111, or JAPN 102. An introduction to the basic skills of brush writing and the cultural, historical, and artistic aspects of Chinese calligraphy.
courses.subject: CHIN
courses.title: Chinese Culture through Calligraphy (3)

courses.description: Introduces students to Chinese and Taiwanese cultural understandings of human relations to the natural environment. Analyzes classical and modern environmental literature (poetry, essays, fiction, and philosophy) and evaluates how contemporary building practices, governmental policies, and green technologies may be influenced by diverse Chinese philosophical traditions.
courses.subject: CHIN
courses.title: Chinese Environmental Literature (3)

courses.description: This course introduces traditional Chinese theater from its earliest development to modern times by examining the interrelation of its elements—music, dance, poetry, and illustration—with performance footage, visual art, and dramatic texts.
courses.subject: CHIN
courses.title: Chinese Traditional Theater (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, CHIN 407. Readings selected from high quality authentic texts of modern Chinese, including newspaper articles and published writings of literary, cultural, and social interest relating to modern Chinese society. This course is taught in Chinese, with further training in speech and writing.
courses.subject: CHIN
courses.title: Readings in Modern Chinese II (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, CHIN 313. Fourth course for heritage students, comparable to fourth year of the regular sequence. Focuses on reading and writing skills in modern Chinese, using authentic reading materials. Three hours per week.
courses.subject: CHIN
courses.title: Advanced Reading and Composition (3)

courses.description: Preor corequisite, CHIN 407 or 414. The goal of this course is to improve students’ overall language proficiency using Chinese for business purposes. They will develop enhanced skills of reading business journalism and case studies and writing business letters or email messages.
courses.subject: CHIN
courses.title: Business Communication in Chinese (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite or corequisite, CHIN 408 or 414. Introduction to the classical Chinese language through reading short essays and poems. Instruction focuses on the similarities and differences between classical and modern Chinese in sentence structure and vocabulary.
courses.subject: CHIN
courses.title: Literary Chinese (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, HEBR 101. Continued instruction in the essential elements of modern Hebrew structure and vocabulary and aspects of modern Israeli culture. Aural comprehension, reading, speaking, and writing are stressed.
courses.subject: HEBR
courses.title: Elementary Modern Hebrew II (JWST 102) (4)

courses.description: Prerequisite, HEBR 203. Continued instruction in the essential elements of modern Hebrew structure and vocabulary and aspects of modern Israeli culture. Aural comprehension, reading, speaking, and writing are stressed. An introduction to representative literary works is included.
courses.subject: HEBR
courses.title: Intermediate Modern Hebrew II (JWST 204) (4)

courses.description: Prerequisite, HNUR 101. Continued instruction in modern spoken and written Hindi-Urdu. Sessions include speaking and listening drills, skits, role-play, and discussion of video and audio materials.
courses.subject: HNUR
courses.title: Elementary Hindi-Urdu II (4)

courses.description: Prerequisite, HNUR 203. Continued second year of instruction in modern spoken and written Hindi-Urdu. Students practice writing short essays and letters and continue to develop mature oral competency in Hindi-Urdu.
courses.subject: HNUR
courses.title: Intermediate Hindi-Urdu II (4)

courses.description: This course introduces the Urdu alphabet (Nastaliq). Prior knowledge of spoken Urdu or Hindi is required; entry to this class is by placement only.
courses.subject: HNUR
courses.title: Introduction to the Urdu Script (Nastaliq) (1)

courses.description: Prerequisite, HNUR 305. Third year of instruction in spoken and written Hindi-Urdu with an emphasis on the reading and analysis of poetry.
courses.subject: HNUR
courses.title: Advanced Hindi-Urdu II (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, JAPN 101. Continued beginning course of modern Japanese with text and supplementary materials. Approximately 150 additional kanji are introduced. Focus on basic sentence pattern exercises, speaking and writing practice, and creative application. Participation in relevant extracurricular activities encouraged.
courses.subject: JAPN
courses.title: Elementary Japanese II (4)

courses.description: Explores the artistic traditions of Japanese performers known as geisha. Sources include woodblock prints, novels, photographs, academic studies, and popular Japanese and American films.
courses.subject: JAPN
courses.title: Geisha in History, Fiction, and Fantasy (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, JAPN 203. Continued emphasis on situational expressions, mastery of basic structures, and approximately 150 to 200 new kanji. Conversation practice, reading and writing of passages, and creative application expected. Participation in relevant extracurricular activities encouraged.
courses.subject: JAPN
courses.title: Intermediate Japanese II (4)

courses.description: Prerequisite, JAPN 305. A study of geography, history, social structures, customs, and traditions of Japan through written and spoken materials. Advanced expressions, vocabulary, and approximately 150 additionalkanji are learned. Class conducted in Japanese. Participation in relevant extracurricular activities encouraged.
courses.subject: JAPN
courses.title: Topics in Japanese Society and Culture (3)

courses.description: Students in this course will analyze the impact disease has on Japanese culture, society, and nation (and the cultures, societies, and nations impacted by Japan) at different historical moments.
courses.subject: JAPN
courses.title: Six Diseases That Changed Japan (3)

courses.description: Focusing on literary, philosophical, and media works, this course will first examine Japanese colonialism from 1895 to 1940 and then the postcolonial effects of that colonialism within Japan after 1945.
courses.subject: JAPN
courses.title: Colonial East Asia/Postcolonial Japan (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, JAPN 306. Students will learn a history of postwar Japanese music as an integral part of Japanese society and culture, and try to understand what messages each song attempts to communicate.
courses.subject: JAPN
courses.title: Making Music in Japan (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, JAPN 306. Students will learn about business culture in Japan, including customs and rules, in order to broaden their understanding of Japanese culture and people, while improving their language skills.
courses.subject: JAPN
courses.title: Understanding Japanese Business Culture and Its Practice (3)

courses.description: See LING 563 for description.
courses.subject: JAPN
courses.title: Structure of Japanese (LING 563) (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, JAPN 102 or LING 101. Introductory linguistic description of modern Japanese. For students of linguistics with no knowledge of Japanese and students of Japanese with no knowledge of linguistics.
courses.subject: LING
courses.title: Structure of Japanese (JAPN 563) (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, KOR 101. Develops speaking and listening skills for everyday communication, reading skills for simple narratives and descriptive texts, and understanding for core grammatical patterns.
courses.subject: KOR
courses.title: Elementary Korean II (4)

courses.description: This course will provide an introduction to Korean studies and examine contemporary issues in Korean society through policies and systems in education, social and cultural trends and phenomena, and globalism.
courses.subject: KOR
courses.title: Education and Social Changes in Contemporary Korea (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, KOR 204. Develops and applies comprehensive grammatical knowledge and vocabularies in complex listening, speaking, reading, and writing contexts. Emphasis on Korean cultural and historical understanding.
courses.subject: KOR
courses.title: Intermediate Korean II (4)

courses.description: Prerequisite, KOR 305. Advanced study of written and spoken Korean language and Korean culture. Three hours per week.
courses.subject: KOR
courses.title: Advanced Korean II (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, PRSN 101. Introduction to the spoken and written Persian (Farsi) language.
courses.subject: PRSN
courses.title: Elementary Persian II (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, PRSN 203. Secondyear instruction in the spoken and written Persian (Farsi) language.
courses.subject: PRSN
courses.title: Intermediate Persian II (3)

courses.description: Open to all undergraduates. This course is the prerequisite to most higher courses in biology. An introduction to the fundamental principles of biology, including cell structure, chemistry, and function; genetics; evolution; adaptation; and ecology. (See department concerning Advanced Placement credit.) Three lecture hours a week.
courses.subject: BIOL
courses.title: Principles of Biology (3)

courses.description: Open to all undergraduates. This course is the prerequisite to most higher courses in biology. An introduction to the fundamental principles of biology, including cell structure, chemistry, and function; genetics; evolution; adaptation; and ecology. (See department concerning Advanced Placement credit.) Three lecture hours a week.
courses.subject: BIOL
courses.title: Principles of Biology (3)

courses.description: Open to all undergraduates. An overview of basic human molecular and cellular biology in the setting of common human diseases. The course emphasizes how an understanding of disease mechanisms provides the knowledge base for informed use of modern health care. Does not count as a course in the major.
courses.subject: BIOL
courses.title: Biology of Human Disease (PATH 128) (3)

courses.description: See GEOL 159 for description. Does not count as a course in the major.
courses.subject: BIOL
courses.title: Prehistoric Life (GEOL 159) (3)

courses.description: Prerequisites, BIOL 101 and CHEM 101 or 102. A grade of C or better in BIOL 101 and CHEM 101 or 102 required. Principles governing the ecology and evolution of populations, communities, and ecosystems, including speciation, population genetics, population regulation, and community and ecosystem structure and dynamics. Three lecture hours and one recitation-demonstration-conference hour a week.
courses.subject: BIOL
courses.title: Ecology and Evolution (4)

courses.description: Prerequisites, BIOL 101 and CHEM 101 or 102. A grade of C or better in BIOL 101 and CHEM 101 or 102 is required. Structure and function of nucleic acids, principles of inheritance, gene expression, and genetic engineering. Three lecture hours and one recitation-demonstration-conference hour a week.
courses.subject: BIOL
courses.title: Molecular Biology and Genetics (4)

courses.description: Prerequisite, BIOL 202. Fundamentals of cell structure and activity in relation to special functions, metabolism, reproduction, embryogenesis, and with an introduction to the experimental analysis of cell physiology and development. Three lectures and one recitation-demonstration-conference hour a week.
courses.subject: BIOL
courses.title: Cellular and Developmental Biology (4)

courses.description: Prerequisites, BIOL 201 or 202, and MATH 232 or 283. Introduction to quantitative biology with emphasis on applications that use mathematical modeling, linear algebra, differential equations, and computer programming. Applications may include neural networks, biomechanics, dispersion, and systems of biochemical reactions. Three lecture hours and three computer laboratory hours.
courses.subject: BIOL
courses.title: Mathematical Methods for Quantitative Biology (4)

courses.subject: BIOL
courses.title: Fundamentals of Human Anatomy and Physiology (4)

courses.description: Prerequisites, BIOL 101 and 101L. Designed for students with an interest in natural sciences. An introduction to the principles of botany including structure, function, reproduction, heredity, environmental relationships, evolution and classification of plants. Three lectures and three laboratory hours a week.
courses.subject: BIOL
courses.title: Plant Biology (4)

courses.description: Prerequisites, BIOL 101 and 101L. Introduction to animal behavior with emphases on the diversity and adaptation of behavior in natural conditions. Three lecture hours a week.
courses.subject: BIOL
courses.title: Animal Behavior (3)

courses.description: Prerequisites, BIOL 101 and 101L. Introduction to animal behavior with emphases on the diversity and adaptation of behavior in natural conditions. Three lecture hours a week.
courses.subject: BIOL
courses.title: Animal Behavior (3)

courses.description: Permission required. 3.0 or higher in course taught. Experience includes preparations, demonstrations, assistance, and attendance at weekly meetings. Apprentices will not be involved in any aspects of grading. May be repeated for credit.
courses.subject: BIOL
courses.title: Teaching Apprentice in Biology (1)

courses.description: Permission required. 3.0 in course taught. Experience includes weekly meetings, preparations, demonstrations, instruction, and grading. May be repeated for credit. Six hours per week.
courses.subject: BIOL
courses.title: Teaching Assistant in Biology (2)

courses.description: Prerequisite, BIOL 201 or 202. Permission of the instructor. Biology majors only. The sponsored, off-campus work must involve at least 135 hours. Does not count as a course in the major.
courses.subject: BIOL
courses.title: Undergraduate Internship in Biology (3)

courses.description: Permission of the instructor. APPLES service-learning component for students enrolled in biology courses. Does not count as a course in the major.
courses.subject: BIOL
courses.title: Service Learning in Biology: APPLES (1–2)

courses.description: Prerequisite, BIOL 201 or 202. Permission of the instructor. Junior and senior biology majors only. The work must involve at least 135 hours of research effort in which students learn to ask appropriate questions and place results in a suitable framework.
courses.subject: BIOL
courses.title: Undergraduate Research in Biology (3)

courses.description: Prerequisites, BIOL 202 and 205. Permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisites. This course covers the molecular mechanisms of human diseases, including genetic diseases, infectious diseases, immunodeficiencies, nutritional disorders, cancer, metabolic diseases, cardiovascular diseases, and neurological disorders.
courses.subject: BIOL
courses.title: Molecular Basis of Disease (3)

courses.description: See MASC 401 for a description.
courses.subject: BIOL
courses.title: Oceanography (ENVR 417, GEOL 403, MASC 401) (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, BIOL 201 or 202. Permission of the instructor. Majors only. Overall 3.0 GPA required. Laboratory study addressing biological questions. Requires final written report. Repeatable for six credit hours. One through five hours counts as a lecture course. Six hours (or BIOL 211 and three hours of BIOL 395) counts as a lecture/laboratory course.
courses.subject: BIOL
courses.title: Undergraduate Research in Biology (1–3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, BIOL 201 or 202. Permission of the instructor. Majors only. Overall 3.0 GPA required. Laboratory study addressing biological questions. Requires final written report. Repeatable for six credit hours. One through five hours counts as a lecture course. Six hours (or BIOL 211 and three hours of BIOL 395) counts as a lecture/laboratory course.
courses.subject: BIOL
courses.title: Undergraduate Research in Biology (1–3)

courses.description: Prerequisites, two of the three biology core courses: BIOL 201, 202, and/or 205. This course will develop the knowledge and skills teachers need to implement inquiry-based biology instruction: rich, conceptual knowledge of biology and mastery of inquiry-based teaching methods. Does not count as a laboratory course.
