courses.subject: BIOL
courses.title: Principles and Methods of Teaching Biology (4)

courses.description: See PATH 426 for description.
courses.subject: BIOL
courses.title: Biology of Blood Diseases (PATH 426) (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, BIOL 205. Permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisite. An introduction to the biology and pathophysiology of blood and the molecular mechanisms of some human diseases: anemias; leukemias; hemorrhagic, thrombotic, and vascular disorders; and HIV disease/AIDS.
courses.subject: PATH
courses.title: Biology of Blood Diseases (BIOL 426) (3)

courses.description: see CHeM 430 for description.
courses.subject: BIOL
courses.title: Introduction to Biological Chemistry (CHEM 430) (3)

courses.description: Prerequisites, BIOL 202 and CHEM 261. Permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisites. Advanced studies in molecular biology from an experimental approach.
courses.subject: BIOL
courses.title: Molecular Biology (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, BIOL 205 or 252. Permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisite. Principles of development with special emphasis on gametogenesis, fertilization, cleavage, germ layer formation, organogenesis, and mechanisms, with experimental analysis of developmental processes. Three lecture hours a week.
courses.subject: BIOL
courses.title: Vertebrate Embryology (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, BIOL 205 or 252. Permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisite. Principles of development with special emphasis on gametogenesis, fertilization, cleavage, germ layer formation, organogenesis, and mechanisms, with experimental analysis of developmental processes. Three lecture hours a week.
courses.subject: BIOL
courses.title: Vertebrate Embryology (3)

courses.description: Prerequisites, BIOL 202 and 205. Selected examples will be used to illustrate how basic research allows us to understand the mechanistic basis of cancer and how these insights offer hope for new treatments.
courses.subject: BIOL
courses.title: Cancer Biology (3)

courses.description: Prerequisites, BIOL 101 and 101L, and either PHYS 104 or 116 and either PHYS 105 or 117. An examination of the physiology of animals using a comparative approach. Both invertebrate and vertebrate animals are discussed in order to elucidate general principles.
courses.subject: BIOL
courses.title: Comparative Physiology (3)

courses.description: Prerequisites, BIOL 101 and 101L, and either PHYS 104 or 116 and either PHYS 105 or 117. An examination of the physiology of animals using a comparative approach. Both invertebrate and vertebrate animals are discussed in order to elucidate general principles.
courses.subject: BIOL
courses.title: Comparative Physiology (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, BIOL 205. Permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisite. The neurobiological basis of animal behavior at the level of single cells, neural circuits, sensory systems, and organisms. Lecture topics range from principles of cellular neurobiology to ethological field studies.
courses.subject: BIOL
courses.title: Behavioral Neuroscience (3)

courses.description: Prerequisites, BIOL 201 and 202. Permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisites. Introduction to mechanisms of evolutionary change, including natural selection, population genetics, life history evolution, speciation, and microand macroevolutionary trends. Three lecture hours plus two hours of laboratory/recitation per week.
courses.subject: BIOL
courses.title: Evolutionary Mechanisms (4)

courses.description: Prerequisite, BIOL 201 or 202. Permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisite. Evolutionary history of the vertebrates. Emphasis on anatomical, physiological, behavioral adaptations accompanying major transitions: the move from water to land, the development of complex integrating systems.
courses.subject: BIOL
courses.title: Evolution of Vertebrate Life (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, BIOL 201 or 202. Permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisite. Evolutionary history of the vertebrates. Emphasis on anatomical, physiological, behavioral adaptations accompanying major transitions: the move from water to land, the development of complex integrating systems.
courses.subject: BIOL
courses.title: Evolution of Vertebrate Life (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, BIOL 395. Permission of the instructor. Majors only. An overall 3.0 grade point average required. Laboratory study on a selected topic and directed readings. A final written report is required each term. May be repeated. This course is offered for pass/fail credit only.
courses.subject: BIOL
courses.title: Undergraduate Research in Biology (1–3)

courses.description: Prerequisites, BIOL 202, COMP 116, and STOR 155. Permission of the instructor for graduate students. Computational techniques for the analysis of large-scale genomics data. Databases and online genomic resources. Programming for standard file processing and development of analysis pipelines. Course includes a computational laboratory.
courses.subject: BIOL
courses.title: Computational Analyses and Resources in Genomics (4)

courses.description: Prerequisite, BIOL 205 for undergraduates. Permission of the instructor. Introduction to various types of light microscopy, digital and video imaging techniques, and their application in biological sciences.
courses.subject: BIOL
courses.title: Light Microscopy for the Biological Sciences (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, BIOL 201. Permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisite. The application of biological science to the conservation of populations, communities, and ecosystems, including rare species management, exotic species invasions, management of natural disturbance, research strategies, and preserve design principles.
courses.subject: BIOL
courses.title: Conservation Biology (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, BIOL 201. Permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisite. The application of biological science to the conservation of populations, communities, and ecosystems, including rare species management, exotic species invasions, management of natural disturbance, research strategies, and preserve design principles.
courses.subject: BIOL
courses.title: Conservation Biology (3)

courses.description: Permission of the instructor for undergraduates. Current and significant problems in genetics. May be repeated for credit.
courses.subject: BIOL
courses.title: Seminar in Genetics (GNET 625) (2)

courses.description: See GNET 632 for description.
courses.subject: BIOL
courses.title: Advanced Molecular Biology II (BIOC 632, GNET 632, MCRO 632) (3)

courses.description: Permission of the instructor for undergraduates. May be repeated for credit. Current and significant problems in plant molecular and cell biology are discussed in a seminar format.
courses.subject: BIOL
courses.title: Seminar in Plant Molecular and Cell Biology (1)

courses.description: See MASC 504 for description.
courses.subject: BIOL
courses.title: Biological Oceanography (ENVR 520, MASC 504) (4)

courses.description: Prerequisite, BIOL 201. Permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisite. May be repeated for credit.
courses.subject: BIOL
courses.title: Seminar in Ecology (ECOL 669) (1–3)

courses.subject: BIOL
courses.title: Senior Hnrs Thesis In Biology Lecture

courses.description: Permission of the instructor. Advanced seminar in comparative animal behavior. May be repeated for credit.
courses.subject: BIOL
courses.title: Seminar in Comparative Animal Behavior (NBIO 857) (1-2)

courses.description: Prerequisite, biol 451. Permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisite. Advanced seminar in comparative physiology.
courses.subject: BIOL
courses.title: Seminar in Comparative Physiology (NBIO 858) (1-2)

courses.description: Graduate standing or permission of the instructor. A course to provide public lecture experience to advanced biology students. students present individual research seminars based upon their dissertation projects. lecturesare critiqued by fellow students and biology faculty. required of all candidates for the degree in biology.
courses.subject: BIOL
courses.title: Graduate Seminar in Biology (1)

courses.description: Prerequisite, MATH 110. The first course in a two-semester sequence. See also CHEM 102. Atomic and molecular structure, stoichiometry and conservation of mass, thermochemical changes and conservation of energy.
courses.subject: CHEM
courses.title: General Descriptive Chemistry I (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, MATH 110. The first course in a two-semester sequence. See also CHEM 102. Atomic and molecular structure, stoichiometry and conservation of mass, thermochemical changes and conservation of energy.
courses.subject: CHEM
courses.title: General Descriptive Chemistry I (3)

courses.description: Prerequisites, CHEM 101 and 101L. Cor better required in CHEM 101. The course is the second in a two-semester sequence. See also CHEM 101. Gases, intermolecular forces, solutions, reaction rates, chemical equilibria including acid-base chemistry, thermochemistry, electrochemistry.
courses.subject: CHEM
courses.title: General Descriptive Chemistry II (3)

courses.description: Prerequisites, CHEM 101 and 101L. Cor better required in CHEM 101. The course is the second in a two-semester sequence. See also CHEM 101. Gases, intermolecular forces, solutions, reaction rates, chemical equilibria including acid-base chemistry, thermochemistry, electrochemistry.
courses.subject: CHEM
courses.title: General Descriptive Chemistry II (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, CHEM 102 or 102H. Cor better required in prerequisite. Analytical separations, chromatographic methods, spectrophotometry, acid-base equilibria and titrations, fundamentals of electrochemistry.
courses.subject: CHEM
courses.title: Modern Analytical Methods for Separation and Characterization (2)

courses.description: Prerequisite, CHEM 102 or 102H. Cor better required in prerequisite. Analytical separations, chromatographic methods, spectrophotometry, acid-base equilibria and titrations, fundamentals of electrochemistry.
courses.subject: CHEM
courses.title: Modern Analytical Methods for Separation and Characterization (2)

courses.description: Prerequisite, CHEM 102 or 102H. Cor better required in prerequisite. Analytical separations, chromatographic methods, spectrophotometry, acid-base equilibria and titrations, fundamentals of electrochemistry.
courses.subject: CHEM
courses.title: Modern Analytical Methods for Separation and Characterization (2)

courses.description: Prerequisite, CHEM 102 or 102H. Cor better required in prerequisite. Chemical periodicity, introductory atomic theory and molecular orbital theory, structure and bonding in solids, descriptive nonmetal chemistry, structures and reactions of transition metal complexes, applications of inorganic complexes and materials.
courses.subject: CHEM
courses.title: Introduction to Inorganic Chemistry (2)

courses.description: Prerequisite, CHEM 102 or 102H. Cor better required in prerequisite. Molecular structure and its determination by modern physical methods, correlation between structure and reactivity and the theoretical basis for these relationships, classification of reaction types exhibited by organic molecules using as examples molecules of biological importance.
courses.subject: CHEM
courses.title: Introduction to Organic Chemistry I (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, CHEM 261 or 261H. Cor better required in prerequisite. Continuation of CHEM 261, with particular emphasis on the chemical properties of organic molecules of biological importance.
courses.subject: CHEM
courses.title: Introduction to Organic Chemistry II (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, CHEM 261 or 261H. Cor better required in prerequisite. Continuation of CHEM 261, with particular emphasis on the chemical properties of organic molecules of biological importance.
courses.subject: CHEM
courses.title: Introduction to Organic Chemistry II (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, CHEM 261 or 261H. Cor better required in prerequisite. Continuation of CHEM 261, with particular emphasis on the chemical properties of organic molecules of biological importance.
courses.subject: CHEM
courses.title: Introduction to Organic Chemistry II (3)

courses.description: Required preparation, one CHEM course 420 or higher and permission of the instructor. For advanced chemistry and applied sciences majors conducting on-campus research. Students prepare a report for their faculty supervisor and present their work at a poster session. May count only once as a chemistry elective.
courses.subject: CHEM
courses.title: Research in Chemistry for Undergraduates (3)

courses.description: Required preparation, one CHEM course 420 or higher and permission of the instructor. For advanced chemistry and applied sciences majors conducting on-campus research. Students prepare a report for their faculty supervisor and present their work at a poster session. May count only once as a chemistry elective.
courses.subject: CHEM
courses.title: Research in Chemistry for Undergraduates (3)

courses.description: Prerequisites, CHEM 241, 251, 262, and 262L. Permission of the instructor. This course explores secondary school chemical education through current chemical education theory and classroom teaching. Students will develop a comprehensive approach to teaching chemistry content through student-centered activities.
courses.subject: CHEM
courses.title: Instructional Methods in the Chemistry Classroom (4)

courses.description: Prerequisite, CHEM 261 or 261H; preor corequisites, CHEM 262 or 262H, and 262L or 263L. Chemical structure and nomenclature of macromolecules, synthesis of polymers, characteristic polymer properties.
courses.subject: CHEM
courses.title: Introduction to Polymer Chemistry (APPL 420) (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, CHEM 421 or 422. Solidstate properties of polymers; polymer melts, glasses and crystals.
courses.subject: CHEM
courses.title: Polymer Materials (3)

courses.description: Prerequisites, BIOL 101, CHEM 262 or 262H, and 262L or 263L. The study of cellular processes including catalysts, metabolism, bioenergetics, and biochemical genetics. The structure and function of biological macromolecules involved in these processes is emphasized.
courses.subject: CHEM
courses.title: Introduction to Biological Chemistry (BIOL 430) (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, CHEM 430. Biological membranes, membrane protein structure, transport phenomena; metabolic pathways, reaction themes, regulatory networks; metabolic transformations with carbohydrates, lipids, amino acids, and nucleotides; regulatory networks, signal transduction.
courses.subject: CHEM
courses.title: Metabolic Chemistry and Cellular Regulatory Networks (3)

courses.description: Prerequisites, CHEM 241 (or 241H), 241L (or 245L) and 262 (or 262H) and 480 (or 481). Spectroscopy, electroanalytical chemistry, chromatography, thermal methods of analysis, signal processing.
courses.subject: CHEM
courses.title: Intermediate Analytical Chemistry (2)

courses.description: Prerequisites, CHEM 241 (or 241H), 241L (or 245L) and 262 (or 262H) and 480 (or 481). Spectroscopy, electroanalytical chemistry, chromatography, thermal methods of analysis, signal processing.
courses.subject: CHEM
courses.title: Intermediate Analytical Chemistry (2)

courses.description: Prerequisite, CHEM 480 or 481. Fundamental theory of gaseous ion chemistry, instrumentation, combination with separation techniques, spectral interpretation for organic compounds, applications to biological and environmental chemistry.
courses.subject: CHEM
courses.title: Mass Spectrometry (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, CHEM 451. A detailed discussion of ligand field theory and the techniques that rely on the theoretical development of ligand field theory, including electronic spectroscopy, electron paramagnetic resonance spectroscopy, and magnetism.
courses.subject: CHEM
courses.title: Electronic Structure of Transition Metal Complexes (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, CHEM 451. Introduction to the physical techniques used for the characterization and study of inorganic compounds. Topics typically include nuclear magnetic resonance spectroscopy, vibrational spectroscopy, diffraction, Mossbauer spectroscopy, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy, and inorganic electrochemistry.
courses.subject: CHEM
courses.title: Physical Methods in Inorganic Chemistry (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, CHEM 262 or 262H. Modern topics in organic chemistry.
courses.subject: CHEM
courses.title: Intermediate Organic Chemistry (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, CHEM 262 or 262H. Modern topics in organic chemistry.
courses.subject: CHEM
courses.title: Intermediate Organic Chemistry (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, CHEM 466. Spectroscopic methods of analysis with emphasis on elucidation of the structure of organic molecules: 1H and 13C NMR, infrared, ultraviolet, ORD-CD, mass, and photoelectron spectroscopy. CHEM 446 and 467 may not both be taken for academic credit.
courses.subject: CHEM
courses.title: Advanced Organic Chemistry II (2)

courses.description: Prerequisite, CHEM 466. Modern synthetic methods and their application to the synthesis of complicated molecules.
courses.subject: CHEM
courses.title: Synthetic Aspects of Organic Chemistry (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, CHEM 470. The structural and energetic nature of surface states and sites, experimental surface measurements, reactions on surfaces including bonding to surfaces and adsorption, interfaces.
courses.subject: CHEM
courses.title: Chemistry and Physics of Surfaces (APPL 473) (3)

courses.description: Prerequisites, CHEM 102 or 102H, PHYS 116; preor corequisites, MATH 383 and PHYS 117. Cor better required in chemistry course prerequisites. Thermodynamics, kinetic theory, chemical kinetics.
courses.subject: CHEM
courses.title: Physical Chemistry I (3)

courses.description: Prerequisites, CHEM 102 or 102H, PHYS 116; preor corequisites, MATH 383 and PHYS 117. Cor better required in chemistry course prerequisites. Thermodynamics, kinetic theory, chemical kinetics.
courses.subject: CHEM
courses.title: Physical Chemistry I (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, CHEM 481. Introduction to quantum mechanics, atomic and molecular structure, spectroscopy, and statistical mechanics.
courses.subject: CHEM
courses.title: Physical Chemistry II (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, CHEM 481. Introduction to quantum mechanics, atomic and molecular structure, spectroscopy, and statistical mechanics.
courses.subject: CHEM
courses.title: Physical Chemistry II (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, CHEM 486. Interaction of radiation with matter; selection rules; rotational, vibrational, and electronic spectra of molecules; laser based spectroscopy and nonlinear optical effects.
courses.subject: CHEM
courses.title: Introduction to Molecular Spectroscopy (3)

courses.description: Graduate standing required.
courses.subject: CHEM
courses.title: Seminar in Materials Chemistry (2)

courses.description: Prerequisite, CHeM 430. Applicationof chemical principles and tools to study and manipulate biological systems; in-depth exploration of examples from the contemporary literature. topics include new designs for the genetic code, drug design, chemical arrays, single molecule experiments, laboratory-based evolution, chemical sensors, and synthetic biology.
courses.subject: CHEM
courses.title: Chemical Biology (2–4)

courses.description: Graduate standing required. literature survey dealing with topics in protein chemistry and nucleic acid chemistry.
courses.subject: CHEM
courses.title: Seminar in Biological Chemistry (2)

courses.description: Graduate standing required. Colloquium of modern analytical chemistry topics presented by graduate students and select invited speakers.
courses.subject: CHEM
courses.title: Literature Seminar in Analytical Chemistry (2)

courses.description: Permission of the instructor. research-level survey of topics in inorganic chemistry and related areas.
courses.subject: CHEM
courses.title: Special Topics in Inorganic Chemistry (0

courses.description: Graduate standing required.
courses.subject: CHEM
courses.title: Literature Seminar in Inorganic Chemistry (2)

courses.description: Graduate standing required. one afternoon meeting a week and individual consultation with the instructor.
courses.subject: CHEM
courses.title: Seminar in Organic Chemistry (2)

courses.description: Graduate standing required. two hours a week.
courses.subject: CHEM
courses.title: Seminar in Physical Chemistry (2)

courses.description: Prerequisite, CHeM 921, 931, 941, 951, 961 or 981.
courses.subject: CHEM
courses.title: Doctoral Dissertation (3–9)

courses.description: See RELI 110 for description.
courses.subject: CLAR
courses.title: The Archaeology of Palestine in the New Testament Period (JWST 110, RELI 110) (3)

courses.description: An introduction to Mediterranean archaeology through the examination of archaeological sites from the Neolithic period (ca. 9000 BCE) to the Roman Empire (fourth century CE). The sites, geographic and cultural areas, and chronological periods of study vary depending on instructor. Does not satisfy classical archaeology major requirements.
courses.subject: CLAR
courses.title: Ancient Cities (3)

courses.description: A survey of the cultures of the ancient Near East, Mesopotamia, Anatolia (modern Turkey) and the Levant, from the first settled villages of the ninth millennium to the Persian conquest of Babylon in 539 BCE.
courses.subject: CLAR
courses.title: Archaeology of Ancient Near East (3)

courses.description: See ARTH 262 for description.
courses.subject: CLAR
courses.title: Art of Classical Greece (ARTH 262) (3)

courses.description: See RELI 375 for description.
courses.subject: CLAR
courses.title: The Archaeology of Cult: The Material Culture of Greek Religion (RELI 375) (3)

courses.description: See ARTH 461 for description.
courses.subject: CLAR
courses.title: Archaic Greek Sculpture (ARTH 461) (3)

courses.description: See RELI 512 for description.
courses.subject: CLAR
courses.title: Ancient Synagogues (JWST 512, RELI 512) (3)

courses.description: See RELI 512 for description.
courses.subject: JWST
courses.title: Ancient Synagogues (CLAR 512, RELI 512) (3)

courses.description: topics vary from year to year.
courses.subject: CLAR
courses.title: Seminar in Archaeology (3)

courses.description: This first-year seminar will involve a close reading of Homer’s Iliad and Odyssey and Vergil’s Aeneid, and as a transition from Homer to Vergil, students will also read the tragedies of Sophocles from fifth-century Athens.
courses.subject: CLAS
courses.title: First-Year Seminar: Three Greek and Roman Epics (3)

courses.description: What can be learned from Greek tragedy about human nature? This firstyear seminar will serve, first of all, as an introduction to Euripidean drama in its cultural and historical setting in fifth-century Athens.
courses.subject: CLAS
courses.title: First-Year Seminar: Women and Men in Euripides (3)

courses.description: Systematic study of the formation of medical terms from Greek and Latin roots, to build vocabulary and recognition. For general etymology see CLAS 125.
courses.subject: CLAS
courses.title: Medical Word Formation and Etymology (3)

courses.description: An introduction to the mythology of the ancient Greek and Roman world. Readings may include selections from Homer, Hesiod, Greek tragedy, and Vergil.
courses.subject: CLAS
courses.title: Classical Mythology (3)

courses.description: An introduction to the civilization of the Roman Empire through study of the literature, history, and archaeology of its most colorful period.
courses.subject: CLAS
courses.title: The Age of the Early Roman Empire (3)

courses.description: Study of athletics as a unifying force in ancient society, emphasizing the Olympic games and other religious festivals. Consideration of athletic professionalism, propaganda, and social trends using literary and archaeological sources.
courses.subject: CLAS
courses.title: Athletics in the Greek and Roman World (3)

courses.description: Junior standing required. All departmental majors will jointly explore the history, archaeology, art, and literature of one or more geographical regions of the Mediterranean. Several oral and written reports; seminar format.
courses.subject: CLAS
courses.title: Junior Seminar (3)

courses.description: Permission of the instructor. Graduate students and senior classics majors. Intensive interdisciplinary introduction to women in antiquity, using literary, historical, and visual materials.
courses.subject: CLAS
courses.title: Approaches to Women in Antiquity (3)

courses.description: Comprehensive coverage of basic grammar and syntax in two semesters, preparing students for reading Plato or Xenophon in GREK 203 (and with the instructor’s permission, New Testament Greek in GREK 205).
courses.subject: GREK
courses.title: Elementary Classical Greek II (4)

courses.description: Prerequisite, GREK 203.
courses.subject: GREK
courses.title: Greek New Testament (3)

courses.description: Readings from one or more Greek tragedies.
courses.subject: GREK
courses.title: Advanced Greek II (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, GREK 221. Readings in Herodotus, Thucydides, Plato, or other authors. With permission of the department, this course may be repeated for credit.
courses.subject: GREK
courses.title: Classical Greek Prose (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, GREK 221 or 222.
courses.subject: GREK
courses.title: Readings in Greek Literature of the Fourth Century (3)

courses.description: The basic elements of Latin grammar, practice in reading and writing Latin, introduction to Roman civilization through a study of the language of the Romans.
courses.subject: LATN
courses.title: Elementary Latin I (4)

courses.description: The basic elements of Latin grammar, practice in reading and writing Latin, introduction to Roman civilization through a study of the language of the Romans.
courses.subject: LATN
courses.title: Elementary Latin II (4)

courses.description: Review of fundamentals. Reading in selected texts such as Catullus, Ovid, Cicero, or others.
courses.subject: LATN
courses.title: Intermediate Latin I (3)

courses.description: Review of fundamentals. Reading in selected texts such as Catullus, Ovid, Cicero, or others.
courses.subject: LATN
courses.title: Intermediate Latin II (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, LATN 204. Careful reading of selected works of Cicero, exercises in Latin composition.
courses.subject: LATN
courses.title: Cicero: The Man and His Times (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, LATN 221 or 222.
courses.subject: LATN
courses.title: Readings in Latin Literature of Later Antiquity (3)

courses.description: study of the forms of lyric and elegiac poetry with special attention to Catullus, Horace, tibullus, or Propertius.
courses.subject: LATN
courses.title: Roman Lyric and Elegiac Poetry (3)

courses.description: topics vary from year to year. 993 Master’s Thesis (3-6).
courses.subject: LATN
courses.title: Latin Seminars (3)

courses.description: This course will explore communication models for collective leadership involving youth and adults in vulnerable communities. Partnering with local youth-focused organizations, students will work in teams to research and design community-based change projects.
courses.subject: COMM
courses.title: First-Year Seminar: Collective Leadership Models for Community Change (3)

courses.description: This seminar explores how we come to understand what places are and how they are meaningful. We will look at places “rhetorically”: how they were designed to persuade those who inhabit them, how we actually experience them, and how we make sense of them in our individual lives.
courses.subject: COMM
courses.title: First-Year Seminar: Understanding Place through Rhetoric (3)

courses.description: This is a course in learning to think more critically, speak more persuasively, and argue more effectively by focusing on practical skill development in reasoning and debate.
courses.subject: COMM
courses.title: First-Year Seminar: Think, Speak, Argue (3)

courses.description: Special topics course. Content will vary each semester.
courses.subject: COMM
courses.title: First-Year Seminar: Special Topics (3)

courses.description: Theory and extensive practice in various types of speaking.
courses.subject: COMM
courses.title: Public Speaking (3)

courses.description: An introduction to communication theory, research, and practice in a variety of interpersonal and organizational contexts. This course examines the role of communication in both personal and professional relationships.
courses.subject: COMM
courses.title: Introduction to Interpersonal and Organizational Communication (MNGT 120) (3)

courses.description: An introduction to communication theory, research, and practice in a variety of interpersonal and organizational contexts. This course examines the role of communication in both personal and professional relationships.
courses.subject: COMM
courses.title: Introduction to Interpersonal and Organizational Communication (MNGT 120) (3)

courses.description: Permission of the instructor for nonmajors. Prerequisite for all production courses. Introduces students to basic tools, techniques, and conventions of production in audio, video, and film.
courses.subject: COMM
courses.title: Introduction to Media Production (3)

courses.description: An introduction to the critical analysis of film, television, advertising, video, and new media texts, contexts, and audiences.
courses.subject: COMM
courses.title: Introduction to Media History, Theory, and Criticism (3)

courses.description: An introduction to the design, aesthetics, and analysis of various forms of digital media. Hands-on experience with different modes of creation, including graphics, Web-based communication, and social media.
courses.subject: COMM
courses.title: Introduction to New Media (3)

courses.description: As the introductory course in performance studies, students will explore and experiment with performance as ritual, performance in everyday life, and the performance of literature.
courses.subject: COMM
courses.title: Introduction to Performance Studies (3)

courses.description: Examines the basic nature and importance of rhetoric and argumentation. Attention is devoted to interpreting the persuasive function of texts and their relation to modern forms of life.
courses.subject: COMM
courses.title: Rhetoric and Public Issues (3)

courses.description: Permission of the instructor for nonmajors. Analysis of issues, use of evidence, reasoning, brief making, and refutation. Argumentative speeches and debates on legal cases and on current issues. Designed for prospective law students, public policy students, speech teachers, and college debaters.
courses.subject: COMM
courses.title: Argumentation and Debate (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, COMM 120. Permission of the instructor for nonmajors. Introduction to the theory and practice of communication in the small group setting. Topics may include group development, conformity and deviation, gender, problem solving, and power and leadership.
courses.subject: COMM
courses.title: Small Group Communication (MNGT 223) (3)

courses.description: See COMM 223 for description.
courses.subject: MNGT
courses.title: Small Group Communication (COMM 223) (3)

courses.description: Examines multiple relationships among gender, communication and culture. Explores how communication creates gender and shapes relationships and how communication reflects, sustains, and alters cultural views of gender.
courses.subject: COMM
courses.title: Introduction to Gender and Communication (WMST 224) (3)

courses.description: See COMM 224 for description.
courses.subject: WMST
courses.title: Introduction to Gender and Communication (COMM 224) (3)

courses.description: Prerequisites, COMM 130 and 140. Grade of C or better in COMM 130. Permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisites. The material, processes, and procedures of audio, video, and film production; emphasis on the control of those elements of convention that define form in the appropriate medium. Lecture and laboratory hours.
courses.subject: COMM
courses.title: Audio/Video/Film Production and Writing (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, COMM 160. Permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisite. This course addresses the relationship between performance and power, focusing on topics concerned with the potential for performance to contribute to social change.
courses.subject: COMM
courses.title: Introduction to Performance and Social Change (3)

courses.description: Introduces students to performance as a way of studying culture in all of its creative, dynamic forms, including family stories, joking, rituals, and practices of everyday life. The course emphasizes field methods and experiential research.
courses.subject: COMM
courses.title: Introduction to Performance and Culture (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, COMM 120. Permission of the instructor for nonmajors. Examines contemporary theory and practice of influencing others’ attitudes, beliefs, and actions. Focuses particularly on analyzing and developing persuasive messages.
courses.subject: COMM
courses.title: Persuasion (3)

courses.description: Introduction to basic paradigms of thinking about cultural difference, encouraging students to examine how these paradigms shape how we think, act, and imagine ourselves/others as members of diverse cultures.
courses.subject: COMM
courses.title: Cultural Diversity (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, COMM 120. Permission of the instructor for nonmajors. The course explores the historical and theoretical developments in the research and practice of organizational communication.
courses.subject: COMM
courses.title: Introduction to Organizational Communication (MNGT 325) (3)

courses.description: See COMM 325 for description.
courses.subject: MNGT
courses.title: Organizational Communication (COMM 325) (3)

courses.description: An introduction to screenwriting for film and television.
courses.subject: COMM
courses.title: Introduction to Writing for Film and Television (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, COMM 330. Students complete the feature-length screenplay started in COMM 330 by finishing and rewriting it in a workshop setting. All students must have already completed an outline and the first 15 to 17 pages of their work.
courses.subject: COMM
courses.title: Writing the Feature Film (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, COMM 330. Students in this class will live the life of a writing staff on a just-picked-up, fictional, one-hour television series. As if on a real series, they will individually and cooperatively create story ideas, treatments, and outlines, as well as write scenes, acts, and entire scripts.
courses.subject: COMM
courses.title: Writing the One-Hour TV Drama (3)

courses.description: Introduces students to the history, methods, and central intellectual questions of cultural studies.
courses.subject: COMM
courses.title: Practices of Cultural Studies (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, COMM 160; DRAM 135, 145, or 150; EXSS 191; or PHYA 224. This course provides a performance-based instruction in the development of mask, puppet, and performing object skills.
courses.subject: COMM
courses.title: The Constructed Actor: Masks and Objects in Performance (3)

courses.description: Explores the discourse of dissident voices in American society, particularly as they speak about grievances pertaining to race, gender, the environment; focuses on rhetorical strategies that initiate and sustain social movements.
courses.subject: COMM
courses.title: The Rhetoric of Social Movements (3)

courses.description: A special topics course on a selected aspect of communication studies.
courses.subject: COMM
courses.title: Special Topics in Communication Study (3)

courses.description: Permission of the department. Majors only. 2.5 cumulative grade point average required. Individualized study closely supervised by a faculty advisor and by the departmental coordinator of internships. Cannot count toward the COMM major.
courses.subject: COMM
courses.title: Internships (1–3)

courses.description: Permission of the department. Majors only. 3.0 cumulative grade point average and 3.5 communication studies grade point average required. For communication studies majors who wish to pursue independent research projects or reading programs under the supervision of a selected instructor. Intensive individual research on a problem designed by instructor and student in conference.
courses.subject: COMM
courses.title: Independent Study and Directed Research (1–3)

courses.description: This viewing and research-intensive course examines the history of American narrative film through the screenwriter’s experience, using a decade-by-decade approach to examine the political, social, global, psychological, religious, and cultural influences on the art, process, and careers of screenwriters.
courses.subject: COMM
courses.title: History of American Screenwriting (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, COMM 130. Grade of C or better in COMM 130. Permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisite. Advanced analysis and application of the principles and methods of audio production.
courses.subject: COMM
courses.title: Advanced Audio Production (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, COMM 131. Required course for the minor in writing for the screen and stage. Conceiving and outlining a feature length screenplay.
courses.subject: COMM
courses.title: Intermediate Scriptwriting (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, COMM 140. Permission of the instructor for nonmajors. Examination of communication processes and cultural significance of film, television, and other electronic media.
courses.subject: COMM
courses.title: Media and Popular Culture (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, COMM 120. Permission of the instructor for nonmajors. Critical examination of alternative theories of leadership and trends in the study of leadership; focuses on the communicative dimensions of leadership.
courses.subject: COMM
courses.title: Communication and Leadership (3)

courses.description: Prerequisites, COMM 224 and 372. Permission of the instructor for nonmajors. Course examines the speeches and other texts that announced and embodied the goals and political strategies of multiple branches of three waves of feminist activism in the United States.
courses.subject: COMM
courses.title: Gender, Communication, and Culture (3)

courses.description: Prerequisites, COMM 120 and 325. Permission of the instructor for nonmajors. Provides a critical exploration of organizational communication theory, research, and application, examining the factors involved in the functioning and analysis of complex organizations.
courses.subject: COMM
courses.title: Organizational Communication (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, COMM 325. Permission of instructor for students lacking the prerequisite. The study of organizational culture operates on a set of assumptions distinct from traditional management perspectives. This course explores the cultural perspective as an alternative approach to understanding organizational communication processes.
courses.subject: COMM
courses.title: Critical-Cultural Approaches to Organizational Communication (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, COMM 325. A critical examination of the theory, research, and practice of organizational ethics.
courses.subject: COMM
courses.title: Organizational Ethics (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, COMM 131, 330, ENGL 130, or 132H. Students practice the craft of screen adaptation by conceptualizing, outlining, and writing scenes based on material from another medium (both fiction and nonfiction). Work is presented, discussed, and performed in a workshop environment. Topics include compression of time, composite characters, creation of new scenes, and fidelity to the original work.
courses.subject: COMM
courses.title: Introduction to Screen Adaptation (3)

courses.description: See DRAM 131 for description.
courses.subject: COMM
courses.title: Writing for the Stage and Screen (DRAM 131) (3)

courses.description: Sophomores only. A course in reading and writing fiction. Close study of a wide range of short stories; emphasis on technical problems. Class criticism and discussion of student exercises and stories.
courses.subject: ENGL
courses.title: Introduction to Fiction Writing (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, COMM 140. Study of the development of the art of film from the end of World War II to the present day by examining individual films and filmmakers and the emergence of national cinemas through interaction among aesthetic, social, economic, and technological factors.
courses.subject: COMM
courses.title: History of Film II, 1945 to Present (3)

courses.description: This course is designed to introduce students to the field of global cinema and, thence, to the methods of comparativist film study.
courses.subject: CMPL
courses.title: Introduction to Global Cinema (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, COMM 160. Permission of the instructor for nonmajors. Explores through performance contemporary poetry, fiction, nonfiction, and feminist thought by women of color in the United States.
courses.subject: COMM
courses.title: Performance of Women of Color (WMST 561) (3)

courses.description: See COMM 561 for description.
courses.subject: WMST
courses.title: Performance of Literature by Women of Color (COMM 561) (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, COMM 170. Permission of the instructor for nonmajors. Investigates the theoretical definitions and uses of rhetorical interpretation and action in spoken, written, visual, material practices, discourses, and events.
courses.subject: COMM
courses.title: Rhetorical Theory and Practice (3)

courses.description: Examines American cultural myths about war generally and specifically about the causes of war, enemies, weapons, and warriors, and the way these myths constrain foreign and defense policy, military strategy, and procurement.
courses.subject: COMM
courses.title: War and Culture (PWAD 574) (3)

courses.description: See COMM 574 for description.
courses.subject: PWAD
courses.title: War and Culture (COMM 574) (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, COMM 170. The power of the presidency depends in part upon the president’s ability to rally public opinion, which depends upon the president’s ability to use the “bully pulpit.” This course examines the hurdles presidents face and the steps presidents take to shape opinion.
courses.subject: COMM
courses.title: Presidential Rhetoric (3)

courses.description: This course will examine how tropes of “race” are symbolically invented and experienced psychologically and emotionally. This course assesses how “race” reflects and shapes cultural politics.
courses.subject: COMM
courses.title: Making and Manipulating “Race” in the United States (3)

courses.description: Permission of the department. Majors only. 3.0 cumulative grade point average and 3.5 communication studies grade point average required. For the communication studies major who wishes to pursue an advanced independent research project under the supervision of a selected instructor. Intensive individual research on a problem designed by instructor and student in conference.
courses.subject: COMM
courses.title: Advanced Independent Study/Directed Reading (1–3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, COMM 120. Permission of the instructor for nonmajors. Course focuses on how communication is used to build and sustain interpersonal relationships. Forms and functions of communication are examined as a means of testing and defining relationships.
courses.subject: COMM
courses.title: Theories of Interpersonal Communication (3)

courses.description: The primary focus of hate speech is on the ways that interactants manipulate hatred to accomplish a variety of social and personal goals. The pursuit of this focus will allow thestudent to appreciate the operation of hatred in a variety of contexts. Often taught as a service-learning course.
courses.subject: COMM
courses.title: Hate Speech (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, COMM 230. A workshop in the production of video and/or film nonfiction or documentary projects. The course will focus on narrative, representational, and aesthetic strategies of documentary production.
courses.subject: COMM
courses.title: Documentary Production (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, COMM 442. Permission of the instructor for nonmajors. This course will explore various specific topics, theories, and methodologies in cultural studies.
courses.subject: COMM
courses.title: Special Topics in Cultural Studies (3)

courses.description: Prerequisites, COMM 230 and one of COMM 534, 635, 646, 653, or 654. Recommended preparation, several production courses above COMM 230. Course provides a structured environment, instructor and peer feedback, along with production and postproduction resources for completing an advanced near-to-graduation media project. Projects can be narrative, documentary, experimental, or interactive, with a running time for videos of no longer than 20 minutes.
courses.subject: COMM
courses.title: Advanced Projects (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, COMM 140. Permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisite. Primary subjects will be popular culture and media technology, and guiding questions will be organized around the relationships of each to commerce and/as social change.
courses.subject: COMM
courses.title: Cultural Politics of Global Media Culture (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, COMM 230. Permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisite. This course allows students to create video productions that play with forms that lie outside of mainstream media.
courses.subject: COMM
courses.title: Experimental Video (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, COMM 130 with a grade of C or better, or COMM 150. Permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisite. In this course students learn a wide range of video postproduction techniques working mostly with the application After Effects.
courses.subject: COMM
courses.title: Motion Graphics, Special Effects, and Compositing (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, COMM 160. Course provides a workshop setting for the process of creation, dramaturgy, development, analysis, and critique of graduates’ and undergraduates’ original performance work, focusing on the needs of each project in progress.
courses.subject: COMM
courses.title: Advanced Projects in Performance Studies (3)

courses.description: This course explores the intersection of ethnographic theory/practice and discourses of sustainable community change with the aim of making appropriate and effective contributions to community development.
courses.subject: COMM
courses.title: The Ethnographic Return (3)

courses.description: Permission of the instructor for nonmajors. A special topics course on a selected aspect of communication studies. May be repeated.
courses.subject: COMM
courses.title: Advanced Topics in Communication Studies (3)

courses.description: Graduate standing required. introduction for graduate students to the current literature and critical perspectives in the areas of media and cultural studies.
courses.subject: COMM
courses.title: Cultural Studies (3)

courses.description: A variable topic seminar that permits faculty and graduate students the opportunity to explore significant historical and emerging issues in the field of communication.
courses.subject: COMM
courses.title: Seminar in Interpersonal and Organizational Communication (3)

courses.description: Application of historical research techniques to problems in the mass media. exact topic is announced before classes begin. May be repeated.
courses.subject: COMM
courses.title: Seminar in the History of Media (3)

courses.description: Considers place in relation to space and time. Primary concentration on implications of theorizing place as communicative practice rather than communicative context.
courses.subject: COMM
courses.title: Rhetorics of Space and Place (3)

courses.description: Permission of the instructor. individual research on a problem defined by the graduate student and graduate faculty member in conference. May be repeated.
courses.subject: COMM
courses.title: Directed Research (3)

courses.description: This course advances graduate students’ exposure to academic resources and common norms, practices, and procedures related to academic professionalism in Communication studies.
courses.subject: COMM
courses.title: Proseminar in Professional Development (1)

courses.description: focuses on the development of a master’s project or a major paper other than a thesis.
courses.subject: COMM
courses.title: Non-Thesis Option (3–9)

courses.description: The nature of computers, their capabilities, and limitations. How computers work, popular applications, problem-solving skills, algorithms and programming. Lectures and laboratory assignments.
courses.subject: COMP
courses.title: Fluency in Information Technology (3)

courses.description: Introduction to computer use. Approaches to problem solving; algorithms and their design; fundamental programming skills. Students can receive credit for only one of COMP 110, 116, or 121.
courses.subject: COMP
courses.title: Introduction to Programming (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, MATH 231. An introduction to programming for computationally oriented scientists. Fundamental programming skills, using MATLAB or Python. Problem analysis, algorithm design, plotting and visualizing data, with examples drawn from simple numerical and discrete problems. Students can receive credit for only one of COMP 110, 116, or 121.
courses.subject: COMP
courses.title: Introduction to Scientific Programming (3)

courses.description: Permission of the instructor. Special topics in computing targeted primarily for students with no computer science background. This course has variable content and may be taken multiple times for credit. As the content will vary with each offering, there are no set prerequisites, but permission of the instructor is required.
courses.subject: COMP
courses.title: Topics in Computing (3)

courses.description: A broad introduction to instructional technology and computer science issues in society: Internet history, privacy, security, usability, graphics, games, computers in the media, development, economics, social media, AI, IP, computer and Internet ethics, global ethics, current legal issues, etc. Frequent guest speakers. Lecture course of 100+ students.
courses.subject: COMP
courses.title: Computers and Society (3)

courses.description: A broad introduction to instructional technology and computer science issues in society: Internet history, privacy, security, usability, graphics, games, computers in the media, development, economics, social media, AI, IP, computer and Internet ethics, global ethics, current legal issues, etc. Frequent guest speakers. Lecture course of 100+ students.
courses.subject: COMP
courses.title: Computers and Society (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, COMP 380 or 382. Permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisite. Explores Internet history and cyberphilosophy; online identify construction, community, communication, creativity; bodies/ cyborgs; intelligence and AI. Students perform independent research into and analyze virtual worlds, social media, anonymous bulletin boards, mobile media, and more, and create digital art and literature. Seminar-style; students collaborate on designing and leading class.
courses.subject: COMP
courses.title: Advanced Cyberculture Studies (3)

courses.description: Elective topics in computer science for computer science majors. May not be used to satisfy any degree requirements for a computer science major. This course has variable content and may be taken multiple times for credit.
courses.subject: COMP
courses.title: Computer Science Elective Topics (3–12)

courses.description: Prerequisites, COMP 410, 411, and at least two three-credit COMP courses numbered 426 or higher. Organization and scheduling of software engineering projects, structured programming, and design. Each team designs, codes, and debugs program components and synthesizes them into atested, documented program product.
courses.subject: COMP
courses.title: Software Engineering Laboratory (4)

courses.description: Students develop a software program for a real client under the supervision of a faculty member. Projects may be proposed by the student but must have real users. Course is intended for students desiring practical experiences in software engineering but lacking the experience required for external opportunities. Majors only. Pass/Fail.
courses.subject: COMP
courses.title: Software Engineering Practicum (1–3)

courses.description: Required preparation, a first formal course in computer programming (e.g., COMP 110, COMP 116). Advanced programming: object-oriented design, classes, interfaces, packages, inheritance, delegation, observers, MVC (model view controller), exceptions, assertions.
courses.subject: COMP
courses.title: Foundation of Programming (4)

courses.description: Prerequisite, COMP 401. The analysis of data structures and their associated algorithms. Abstract data types, lists, stacks, queues, trees, and graphs. Sorting, searching, hashing.
courses.subject: COMP
courses.title: Data Structures (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, COMP 401. Digital logic, circuit components. Data representation, computer architecture and implementation, assembly language programming.
courses.subject: COMP
courses.title: Computer Organization (4)

courses.description: Prerequisites, COMP 410 and 411. Application-level protocols HTTP, SMTP, FTP, transport protocolsTCPandUDP,andthenetwork-levelprotocolIP.Internet architecture, naming, addressing, routing, and DNS. Sockets programming. Physical-layer technologies. Ethernet, ATM, and wireless.
courses.subject: COMP
courses.title: Internet Services and Protocols (3)

courses.description: Prerequisites, COMP 110 or 401, and COMP 283 or MATH 381. Introduction to the theory of computation. Finite automata, regular languages, pushdown automata, context-free languages, and Turing machines. Undecidable problems.
courses.subject: COMP
courses.title: Models of Languages and Computation (3)

courses.description: Permission of the director of undergraduate studies. Computer science majors only. Work experience in nonelementary computer science. May be repeated for up to six credits.
courses.subject: COMP
courses.title: Computer Science Internship (3)

courses.description: Permission of the director of undergraduate studies. Computer science majors only. For advanced majors in computer science who wish to conduct an independent study or research project with a faculty supervisor. May be taken repeatedly for up to a total of six credit hours.
courses.subject: COMP
courses.title: Independent Study in Computer Science (1–3)

courses.description: Prerequisites, COMP 410 and 411. Design and construction of compilers. Theory and pragmatics of lexical, syntactic, and semantic analysis. Interpretation. Code generation for a modern architecture. Run-time environments. Includes a large compiler implementation project.
courses.subject: COMP
courses.title: Compilers (3)

courses.description: Prerequisites, COMP 410 and 411, and COMP 283 or MATH 381. Placement of data on secondary storage. File organization. Database history, practice, major models, system structure and design.
courses.subject: COMP
courses.title: Files and Databases (3)

courses.description: Prerequisites, COMP 410, and COMP 283 or MATH 381. Principles of securing the creation, storage, and transmission of data and ensuring its integrity, confidentiality, and availability. Topics include access control, cryptography and cryptographic protocols, network security, and online privacy.
courses.subject: COMP
courses.title: Introduction to Computer Security (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, COMP 411. This course is an introduction to digital logic as well as the structure and electronic design of modern processors. Students will implement a working computer during the laboratory sessions.
courses.subject: COMP
courses.title: Digital Logic and Computer Design (4)

courses.description: Prerequisites, COMP 410, and COMP 283 or MATH 381. Formal specification and verification of programs. Techniques of algorithm analysis. Problem-solving paradigms. Survey of selected algorithms.
courses.subject: COMP
courses.title: Algorithms and Analysis (3)

courses.description: Prerequisites, COMP 410, and COMP 283 or MATH 381. Bioinformatics algorithms. Topics include DNA restriction mapping, finding regulatory motifs, genome rearrangements, sequence alignments, gene prediction, graph algorithms, DNA sequencing, protein sequencing, combinatorial pattern matching, approximate pattern matching, clustering and evolution, tree construction, hidden Markov models, randomized algorithms.
courses.subject: COMP
courses.title: Bioalgorithms (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, COMP 410 or 411. Concepts of computer game development and their application beyond entertainment to fields such as education, health, and business. Course includes team development of a game.
courses.subject: COMP
courses.title: Serious Games (3)

courses.description: Permission of the director of undergraduate studies. Computer science majors only. Practical extension of computer science knowledge through industrial work experience. Pass/Fail only. Does not count in the computer science major or minor.
courses.subject: COMP
courses.title: Co-op Experience (6–12)

courses.description: See MATH 662 for description.
courses.subject: COMP
courses.title: Scientific Computation II (ENVR 662, MATH 662) (3)

courses.description: Prerequisites, CoMP 524 and 550. Principles and practices of software engineering. object-oriented and functional approaches. formal specification, implementation, verification, and testing. software design patterns. Practicum.
courses.subject: COMP
courses.title: Software Design and Implementation (3)

courses.description: Prerequisites, CoMP 530 and 550. verification of concurrent systems. synchronization; mutual exclusion and related problems, barriers, rendezvous, nonblocking algorithms. fault tolerance: consensus, byzantine agreement, self-stabilization. broadcast algorithms. termination and deadlock detection. Clock synchronization.
courses.subject: COMP
courses.title: Distributed and Concurrent Algorithms (3)

courses.description: Prerequisites, CoMP 411 and PHys 352. Architecture and implementation of modern single-processor computer systems. Performance measurement. instruction set design. Pipelining. instruction-level parallelism. Memory hierarchy. i/o system. floating-point arithmetic. Case studies. Practicum.
courses.subject: COMP
courses.title: Computer Architecture and Implementation (3)

courses.description: Prerequisites, MAtH 233 and 416. 3d differential geometry; local and global shape properties; visual aspects of surface shape. taught largely through models and figures. Applicable to graphics, computer vision, human vision, and biology.
courses.subject: COMP
courses.title: Visual Solid Shape (3)

courses.description: Prerequisites, CoMP 550 and MAtH 547. Permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisitues. introduction to the design, programming, and control of robotic systems. topics include kinematics, dynamics, sensing, actuation, control, robot learning, tele-operation, and motion planning. Applications will be discussed including industrial, mobile, assistive, personal, and medical robots.
courses.subject: COMP
courses.title: Robotics (3)

courses.description: Prerequisites, CoMP 431 and 530. Audio/video coding and compression techniques and standards. Media streaming and adaptation. Multicast routing, congestion, and error control. internet protocols rsvP, rtP/rtCP. integrated and differentiated services architecture for the internet.
courses.subject: COMP
courses.title: Multimedia Networking (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, CoMP 775. lecture and seminar on recent advances in image segmentation, registration, pattern recognition, display, restoration, and enhancement.
courses.subject: COMP
courses.title: Recent Advances in Image Analysis (3)

courses.description: Graduate computer science majors or permission of the instructor. seminar on teaching, short oral presentations, and writing in computer science.
courses.subject: COMP
courses.title: Technical Communication in Computer Science (1)

courses.description: Permission of the instructor. seminars in various topics offered by members of the faculty.
courses.subject: COMP
courses.title: Research Seminar in Computer Science (1–21)

courses.description: Permission of the instructor. directed reading and research in selected advanced topics.
courses.subject: COMP
courses.title: Reading and Research (1–21)

courses.description: Permission of the department.
courses.subject: COMP
courses.title: Computer Science Master’s Project (Non Thesis Option) (3–21)

courses.description: Permission of the department.
courses.subject: COMP
courses.title: Master’s Thesis (3–6)

courses.description: The course seeks to help students find ways to articulate their own motivations for dress and then apply the ideas they have discovered to the ways in which individuality as well as group attitudes are expressed through clothing.
courses.subject: DRAM
courses.title: First-Year Seminar: Psychology of Clothes: Motivations for Dressing Up and Dressing Down (3)

courses.description: This course examines how the theatrical designer uses scenery, costumes, and lighting to help create a production. Students will apply these techniques in creating their own design projects.
courses.subject: DRAM
courses.title: First-Year Seminar: Spectacle in the Theatre (3)

courses.description: This course explores the political and social ramifications of documentary theatre in the United States. Students will investigate a local community of their choosing and create an interview-based performance.
courses.subject: DRAM
courses.title: First-Year Seminar: Documentary Theatre (3)

courses.description: A survey of plays from the Greeks to the present, analyzed through such elements of the dramatic text as action, character, structure, and language.
courses.subject: DRAM
courses.title: Perspectives in Drama (3)

courses.description: A survey of the interrelationships of acting, directing, designing, and playwriting through the study of major periods of theatrical expression and representative plays.
courses.subject: DRAM
courses.title: Perspectives in the Theatre (3)

courses.description: A survey of non-Western drama and theatre with emphasis on the historical and aesthetic development of those regions.
courses.subject: DRAM
courses.title: Perspectives in World Drama (3)

courses.description: DRAM 120 is the first course in the major and the minor in dramatic art. Development of the skill to analyze plays for academic and production purposes through the intensive study of representative plays.
courses.subject: DRAM
courses.title: Play Analysis (3)

courses.description: Introduction to basic processes and techniques of acting for the stage.
courses.subject: DRAM
courses.title: Acting for Nonmajors (3)

courses.description: Fundamental principles underlying the effective use of voice and speech in performance.
courses.subject: DRAM
courses.title: Voice Training I (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, DRAM 120. Introduction to acting tools, emphasizing playing actions and pursuing an objective within personalized given circumstances. Performance work drawn from short scripted, improvised, and contemporary scenes.
courses.subject: DRAM
courses.title: Beginning Acting for the Major (3)

courses.description: General survey of materials, equipment, and processes used in technical theatre.
courses.subject: DRAM
courses.title: Stagecraft (3)

courses.description: Students cannot receive credit for both DRAM 164 and 165. A study of principles and techniques for stage, film, and television makeup, including corrective makeup, old age, 3-D, casting for prosthetic pieces, and methods for creating fantasy forms. Also applicable to film and television.
courses.subject: DRAM
courses.title: Stage Makeup (1–3)

courses.description: DRAM 191 or 192 required for dramatic art majors. Permission of the instructor for nonmajors. Introduction to equipment, procedures, and personnel in the design and execution of plans for scenery, lighting, properties, and sound for theatrical productions.
courses.subject: DRAM
courses.title: Technical Methods: Scenery (3)

courses.description: DRAM 191 or 192 required for dramatic art majors. Permission of the instructor for nonmajors. Introduction to equipment, procedures, and personnel in the design and execution of costumes for theatrical productions.
courses.subject: DRAM
courses.title: Technical Methods: Costume (3)

courses.description: Permission of the instructor for nonmajors. Required for the dramatic art major. Practicum in production with PlayMakers Repertory Company in costuming, scenery, lighting, sound, or theatre management.
courses.subject: DRAM
courses.title: Production Practicum (3)

courses.description: Permission of the department. May be repeated for credit. Restricted to juniors and seniors majoring in dramatic art. Intensive individual work in major areas of theatrical production: design, technical, directing, acting, playwriting, management.
courses.subject: DRAM
courses.title: Dramatic Art Projects (1–3)

courses.description: Permission of the department. A practical course in writing for the stage with studio productions of selected works.
courses.subject: DRAM
courses.title: Playwriting I (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, DRAM 120. Survey of theatre practice and writing from 1700 to 1920.
courses.subject: DRAM
courses.title: Theatre History and Literature II (3)

courses.description: Evolution of modern British drama from 1956 through the present.
courses.subject: DRAM
courses.title: Modern British Drama (3)

courses.description: This course investigates the history and legacy of African American drama through the study of its literary texts, performance styles, and cultural history.
courses.subject: DRAM
courses.title: African American Theatre (3)

courses.description: This course investigates Irish drama from the 1990s to the present, exploring how issues and themes of globalization, gender, race, nation, and identity, among others, translate from text to performance.
courses.subject: DRAM
courses.title: Contemporary Irish Drama (3)

courses.description: The study of a topic in dramaturgy, theatrical design, or theatrical production. Content and instructor will vary. May be repeated for credit.
courses.subject: DRAM
courses.title: Special Topics in Dramatic Art (0

courses.description: This course considers the anatomy and diversity of the American musical, exploring its history and aesthetics and employing an interdisciplinary approach to examining and celebrating its shows, sounds, stars, structures, styles, and sensibilities, within the genre’s dominant contexts of Broadway, Hollywood, and Utopia.
courses.subject: DRAM
courses.title: “Corner of the Sky”: The American Musical (3)

courses.description: This course examines the lives of African American women through theatre, heightening awareness, understanding, and appreciation of theatre as a tool for social change and eradicating stereotypes. Themes and production aesthetics will be explored in their social and historical contexts.
courses.subject: DRAM
courses.title: African American Women in Theatre (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, DRAM 231. A practical course in writing for the theatre, taught at an advanced level.
courses.subject: DRAM
courses.title: Playwriting II (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, DRAM 250. Permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisite. Development of the actor’s technique in verse drama with emphasis on scansion and textual analysis as guidelines for actions, characterization, and given circumstances. Scene and monologue work drawn from the works of Shakespeare.
courses.subject: DRAM
courses.title: Advanced Acting for the Major (3)

courses.description: Permission of the department. Individual programs or internship in acting, directing, design, management, and playwriting under the guidance of professional practitioners in conjunction with PlayMakers Repertory Company or other professional theatre organizations.
courses.subject: DRAM
courses.title: Professional Theatre Laboratory (1–12)

courses.description: Permission of the department. A study of the basic principles and practices of modern stage management.
courses.subject: DRAM
courses.title: Stage Management (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, DRAM 473. Permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisite. Beginning instruction in pattern making through draping on a dress form for theatrical costume.
courses.subject: DRAM
courses.title: Costume Construction II (1–3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, DRAM 192. Permission of the instructor. Taught in a four-semester rotation. May be repeated for credit for a total of six hours for undergraduates and 12 hours for graduate students. Series of topics in costume for use in design and production for the stage.
courses.subject: DRAM
courses.title: Costume Seminars I: Dyeing and Painting (1–3)

courses.description: Permission of the instructor. Study of costume design for students concentrating in costume production.
courses.subject: DRAM
courses.title: Advanced Costume Design I (1–3)

courses.subject: DRAM
courses.title: Honors Proj In Dram Ii Lecture

courses.description: Admission to the M.f.A. Acting program required. intensive professional training for the actor. Must be taken fall and spring.
courses.subject: DRAM
courses.title: Acting I (3)

courses.description: Admission to the second year of the M.f.A. Acting program required. Advanced professional training for the actor. Must be taken fall and spring.
courses.subject: DRAM
courses.title: Acting II (3)

courses.description: Admission to the M.f.A. Acting program required. development of the individual actor’s voice and speech. Must be taken fall and spring.
courses.subject: DRAM
courses.title: Voice I (3)

courses.description: Admission to the second year of the M.f.A. Acting program required. expansion of the individual’s vocal versatility in performance. Must be taken fall and spring.
courses.subject: DRAM
courses.title: Voice II (3)

courses.description: Admission to the M.f.A. Acting program required. development of the actor’s body as an expressive instrument. Must be taken fall and spring.
courses.subject: DRAM
courses.title: Movement I (3)

courses.description: Admission to the second year of the M.f.A. Acting program required. Advanced projects in movement. special sessions in tumbling and stage combat. Must be taken fall and spring.
courses.subject: DRAM
courses.title: Movement II (3)

courses.description: Admission to the M.f.A. Acting program required. rehearsal and performance of special ensemble projects. Must be taken fall and spring. May be repeated for credit.
courses.subject: DRAM
courses.title: Rehearsal and Performance I (1-6)

courses.description: Admission to the second year of the M.f.A. Acting program required. Practical application of techniques in rehearsal and performance in studio and main stage production. Must be taken fall and spring. May be repeated for credit.
courses.subject: DRAM
courses.title: Rehearsal and Performance II (1–6)

courses.description: Costume graduates only. Advanced construction techniques with an emphasis on bodice development.
courses.subject: DRAM
courses.title: Special Studies: Costume Production III: Tailoring (

courses.description: Prerequisite, drAM 474. Continued study of draping theatrical costumes with advanced shapes.
courses.subject: DRAM
courses.title: Costume Construction IV: Advanced Draping (1–3)

courses.description: Prerequisites, drAM 473, 474, 760, and 762. Using combination of patternmaking and dressmaking techniques to achieve unusual shapes in theatrical costume.
courses.subject: DRAM
courses.title: Costume Construction V (1–3)

courses.description: Permission of the instructor. Advanced study of historical pattern, costume crafts, or costume shop management through directed study. May be repeated for credit.
courses.subject: DRAM
courses.title: Period Pattern I: Pre-Victorian (1–3)

courses.description: Admission to the second year of the M.f.A. Costume program required. Advanced practical work in the costume shop. Must be taken fall and spring.
courses.subject: DRAM
courses.title: Costume Laboratory II (3)

courses.description: Costume graduates only. Continuation of practical work through production assignments.
courses.subject: DRAM
courses.title: Costume Laboratory IV (3)

courses.description: technical graduates only. Additional study of technical and engineering problems in production.
courses.subject: DRAM
courses.title: Technical Direction II (3–6)

courses.description: Admission to the third year of the M.f.A. technical Production program required. An advanced study of the management, technical, and engineering problems involved in theatrical production. Must be taken fall and spring.
courses.subject: DRAM
courses.title: Advanced Technical Direction II (1–6)

courses.description: technical graduates only. Continuation of advanced scenic construction techniques with specific project or production responsibility in the area of scenic construction.
courses.subject: DRAM
courses.title: Special Studies: Technical Production (1–6)

courses.description: Permission of the instructor\. This course acquaints the student with professional practice in lighting design through lecture by faculty and visiting professionals and through evaluation of lighting designs executed by students and critiqued by professionals.
courses.subject: DRAM
courses.title: Advanced Lighting Design (3)

courses.description: Admission to the M.f.A. program in technical Production required. An examination of professional theatre practice through contact with students, staff, faculty, and visiting artists in technical theatre. Generally taken fall and spring. May be repeated for credit.
courses.subject: DRAM
courses.title: Seminar in Professional Practice: Technical Production (1–21)

courses.description: technical graduates only. Continuation of practical work in scene shop.
courses.subject: DRAM
courses.title: M

courses.description: Continuation of advanced practical work in scene shop.
courses.subject: DRAM
courses.title: M

courses.description: This course offers students a survey of mutually supportive developments of literature and the visual arts from classical antiquity until around 1700.
courses.subject: CMPL
courses.title: Great Books I: Visual Arts and Literature from Antiquity to 1750 (3)

courses.description: This course examines comparative literary texts in literature and political philosophy in the context of developments in political thought and practice from classical Greece through the French Revolution.
courses.subject: CMPL
courses.title: Great Books I: Politics and Literature from Antiquity to 1750 (3)

courses.description: An introduction to some of the major texts of 19thand 20th-century literature, focusing on periods of romanticism, realism, and modernism and with some attention given to parallel developments in the arts and philosophy.
courses.subject: CMPL
courses.title: Great Books II (3)

courses.description: The desert-island scenario involves a sophisticated and culturally central thought experiment in which the constraints of history and society are suspended and human nature is exposed in its essence. This course considers the permutations of this scenario in film and fiction from around the world.
courses.subject: CMPL
courses.title: Global Crusoe: The Desert-Island Idea in Film and Fiction (3)

courses.description: Familiarizes students with the theory and practice of comparative literature. Against a background of classical poetics and rhetoric, explores various modern literary theories, including Russian formalism, Frankfurt School, feminism, psychoanalysis, deconstruction, new historicism, and others. All reading in theory is paired with that of literary texts drawn from a wide range of literary periods and national traditions.
courses.subject: CMPL
courses.title: Introduction to Literary Theory (3)

courses.description: Traces the development of European short fiction from the 12th through the 17th centuries, taking brief looks backward toward the ancient world and forward to the modern short story.
courses.subject: CMPL
courses.title: Myth, Fable, Novella: The Long History of the Short Story (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, ENGL 105. Research-intensive course that explores how the Romantic movement beginning in 18th-century Europe has shaped the world we experience now. Topics vary and include revolutionary republicanism; slavery and abolition; quests for originality, expressiveness, and spiritual renovation; critiques of progress and modern urban culture; and revaluations of the natural world.
courses.subject: CMPL
courses.title: Transnational Romanticism: Romantic Movements in Europe and the Americas (3)

courses.description: An examination of central trends in 20th-century narrative.
courses.subject: CMPL
courses.title: Approaches to 20th-Century Narrative (3)

courses.description: This seminar allows comparative literature majors to work on an independent project to synthesize their curricular experience, and it introduces them to current, broadly applicable issues in comparative literature.
courses.subject: CMPL
courses.title: Senior Seminar (3)

courses.description: traces major strains in literary criticism and theory from classical antiquity to the 18th century, pairing primary critical texts with contemporary literary examples and modern day theoretical responses. Authors read include: Plato, Aristotle, Aristophanes, Horace, Augustine, and burke; Homer, ovid, virgil, dante, and Pope; and Auerbach, derrida, ricoeur, and benjamin.
courses.subject: CMPL
courses.title: History of Literary Criticism I: The Origins of Theory and Criticism (3)

courses.description: How do computers change the study of literature? How do images tell stories? How is writing evolving through photo essays, collages, and digital video? Students investigate these and related questions.
courses.subject: ENGL
courses.title: First-Year Seminar: Computers and English Studies (3)

courses.description: This class will investigate the forms and cultural functions of science fiction using films, books, and computer-based fictional spaces (Internet, video games, etc.).
courses.subject: ENGL
courses.title: First-Year Seminar: Future Perfect: Science Fictions and Social Form (3)
