courses.description: This course will focus on issues of intellectual freedom and censorship, with particular attention to the ways in which these issues are racialized.
courses.subject: ENGL
courses.title: First-Year Seminar: Banned Books (3)

courses.description: This course is a cross-cultural and intermedial exploration of the imagery of the Great City in high modernist works of literature, art, and film.
courses.subject: ENGL
courses.title: First-Year Seminar: The Cities of Modernism (3)

courses.description: This course focuses on the fiction of Jane Austen and its representations in film.
courses.subject: ENGL
courses.title: First-Year Seminar: Jane Austen, Then and Now (3)

courses.description: This college-level course focuses on written and oral argumentation, composition, research, information literacy, and rhetorical analysis. The course introduces students to the specific disciplinary contexts for written work and oral presentations required in college courses. Students may not receive credit for both ENGL 102 and 105.
courses.subject: ENGL
courses.title: English Composition and Rhetoric (3)

courses.description: This college-level course focuses on written and oral argumentation, composition, research, information literacy, and rhetorical analysis. The course introduces students to the specific disciplinary contexts for written work and oral presentations required in college courses. Students may not receive credit for both ENGL 102 and 105.
courses.subject: ENGL
courses.title: English Composition and Rhetoric (3)

courses.description: Required of English majors. Survey of medieval, Renaissance, and neoclassical periods. Drama, poetry, and prose.
courses.subject: ENGL
courses.title: British Literature, Medieval to 18th Century (3)

courses.description: Representative authors from the time of European colonization of the New World through the 20th century.
courses.subject: ENGL
courses.title: Introduction to American Literature (3)

courses.description: Novels and shorter fiction by Defoe, Austen, Dickens, Faulkner, Wolfe, Fitzgerald, Joyce, and others.
courses.subject: ENGL
courses.title: Introduction to Fiction (3)

courses.description: The literature of the present generation.
courses.subject: ENGL
courses.title: Contemporary Literature (3)

courses.description: A course designed to develop basic skills in reading poems from all periods of English and American literature.
courses.subject: ENGL
courses.title: Introduction to Poetry (3)

courses.description: Drama of the Greek, Renaissance, and modern periods.
courses.subject: ENGL
courses.title: Introduction to Drama (3)

courses.description: Course emphasizes literature, critical thinking, and the writing process. Students learn how thinking, reading, and writing relate to one another by studying poetry, fiction, drama, art, music, and film.
courses.subject: ENGL
courses.title: Writing about Literature (3)

courses.description: A study of approximately six major American authors drawn from Emerson, Thoreau, Hawthorne, Melville, Stowe, Whitman, Clemens, Dickinson, Chesnutt, James, Eliot, Stein, Hemingway, O’Neill, Faulkner, Hurston, or others.
courses.subject: ENGL
courses.title: Major American Authors (3)

courses.description: Studies in African American, Asian American, Hispanic American, Native American, Anglo-Indian, Caribbean, gay-lesbian, and other literatures written in English.
courses.subject: ENGL
courses.title: Literature and Cultural Diversity (3)

courses.description: Sophomores only. A course in reading and writing poems. Close study of a wide range of published poetry and of poetic terms and techniques. Composition, discussion, and revision of original student poems.
courses.subject: ENGL
courses.title: Introduction to Poetry Writing (3)

courses.description: A course in reading and writing creative nonfiction, prose based in fact, but treated in a literary manner, e.g., personal essays, travel narratives, science and nature writing, immersive interviews and profiles, reportage, and belles-lettres. Composition, class discussion, and revision of work written for this class.
courses.subject: ENGL
courses.title: Introduction to Creative Nonfiction (3)

courses.description: Introduces students to concepts in queer theory and recent sexuality studies. Topics include queer lit, AIDS, race and sexuality, representations of gays and lesbians in the media, political activism/literature.
courses.subject: ENGL
courses.title: Introduction to Gay and Lesbian Culture and Literature (WMST 140) (3)

courses.description: See ENGL 140 for description.
courses.subject: WMST
courses.title: Introduction to Gay/Lesbian Literature (ENGL 140) (3)

courses.description: This course will be a basic introduction to literatures in English from Africa, the Caribbean, South Asia, Canada, Australia, New Zealand, and other Anglophone literary traditions.
courses.subject: ENGL
courses.title: World Literatures in English (3)

courses.description: This course offers an introduction to the technical, formal, and narrative elements of the cinema.
courses.subject: ENGL
courses.title: Film Analysis (3)

courses.description: This course offers an introduction to the technical, formal, and narrative elements of the cinema.
courses.subject: ENGL
courses.title: Film Analysis (3)

courses.description: Examines the ways culture shapes and is shaped by film. This course uses comparative methods to contrast films as historic or contemporary, mainstream or cutting-edge, in English or a foreign language, etc.
courses.subject: ENGL
courses.title: Film and Culture (3)

courses.description: Introductory course on popular literary genres. Students will read and discuss works in the area of mystery, romance, westerns, science fiction, children’s literature, and horror fiction.
courses.subject: ENGL
courses.title: Popular Genres (3)

courses.description: Readings in and theories of science fiction, utopian and dystopian literatures, and fantasy fiction.
courses.subject: ENGL
courses.title: Science Fiction/Fantasy/Utopia (3)

courses.description: Studies in classic and contemporary mystery and detective fiction.
courses.subject: ENGL
courses.title: Mystery Fiction (3)

courses.description: From its origins in Gothic and pre-Gothic literatures and arts, this course examines the complexities and pleasures of horror. Topics include psychology, aesthetics, politics, allegory, ideology, and ethics.
courses.subject: ENGL
courses.title: Horror (3)

courses.description: Sophomore English majors only. This course (or ENGL 121) is required of English majors. Introduces students to methods of literary study. Students learn to read and interpret a range of literary works, develop written and oral arguments about literature, and conduct literary research.
courses.subject: ENGL
courses.title: Introductory Seminar in Literary Studies (3)

courses.description: An introduction to the study of creativity and aesthetic expression in everyday life, considering both traditional genres and contemporary innovations in the material, verbal, and musical arts.
courses.subject: ENGL
courses.title: Introduction to Folklore (ANTH 202, FOLK 202) (3)

courses.description: A survey of representative comedies, tragedies, histories, and romances by William Shakespeare.
courses.subject: ENGL
courses.title: Shakespeare (3)

courses.description: Poetry and prose from the late Elizabethan years through the “century of revolution” into the Restoration period after 1660: Donne, Jonson, Bacon, Herbert, Burton, Browne, Marvell, Herrick, and others.
courses.subject: ENGL
courses.title: Literature of the Later Renaissance (3)

courses.description: Intensive study, focused on gender issues of criticism and writing.
courses.subject: ENGL
courses.title: Literature and Gender (WMST 263) (3)

courses.description: Considers texts in a comparative ethnic/race studies framework and examines how these texts explore historical and contemporary connections between groups of people in the United States and the Americas.
courses.subject: ENGL
courses.title: Literature and Race, Literature and Ethnicity (3)

courses.description: This interdisciplinary course will examine what it means to grow up Latina/o through an exploration of childhood narratives, linguistic debates, education policies and legislation, and censored books.
courses.subject: ENGL
courses.title: Growing Up Latina/o (3)

courses.description: An introduction to key topics that focus on questions of representation at the intersections of medicine, literature, and culture.
courses.subject: ENGL
courses.title: Medicine, Literature, and Culture (3)

courses.description: An introduction to key topics that focus on questions of representation at the intersections of medicine, literature, and culture.
courses.subject: ENGL
courses.title: Medicine, Literature, and Culture (3)

courses.description: Exploration of different forms of life writing such as autobiography, biography, and autoethnography. Readings will include theories of autobiography and selected literature.
courses.subject: ENGL
courses.title: Life Writing (3)

courses.description: An investigation of children’s picture books within the context of illustrated texts in Britain and America.
courses.subject: ENGL
courses.title: Children’s Picture Books: Texts and Illustration (3)

courses.description: Advanced practice with business and professional oral and written discourse. Special attention to disciplinary rhetoric, style, genre, format, and citation.
courses.subject: ENGL
courses.title: Advanced Expository Writing for Business (3)

courses.description: Advanced practice with legal oral and written discourse. Special attention to disciplinary rhetoric, style, genre, format, and citation.
courses.subject: ENGL
courses.title: Advanced Expository Writing for Law (3)

courses.description: An introductory course in descriptive English linguistics that studies the sounds, word-building processes, and sentence structures of current English as well as general notions of correctness and variation.
courses.subject: ENGL
courses.title: Grammar of Current English (3)

courses.description: A study of the development of English from its Proto-Indo-European origins to modern English, with emphasis on how events and contacts with other languages influenced the vocabulary of English.
courses.subject: ENGL
courses.title: History of the English Language (3)

courses.description: This class studies composing in a variety of modes, including visuals, moving images, gestures, sounds, and words. Students develop projects using image, audio, and video editors, examining how multimedia fits within the history of rhetoric and writing and relates with concerns such as purposes, audiences, contexts, arguments, genres, and mediums.
courses.subject: ENGL
courses.title: Multimodal Composition (3)

courses.description: An introduction to Chaucer’s major poetry: Troilus and Criseyde, the “dream” poems (e.g., Parliament of Fowls) and The Canterbury Tales.
courses.subject: ENGL
courses.title: Chaucer (3)

courses.description: This course explores the wide range of drama produced in England between the 1570s and 1640s, including work by Shakespeare and his many rivals.
courses.subject: ENGL
courses.title: Shakespeare and His Contemporaries (3)

courses.description: This course focuses on both the novels of Jane Austen and their fate since publication in the early 19th century. They have inspired countless imitations, over 150 sequels and continuations, and more than 30 full-length films. We will trace the transmission and transformation of the original texts across time and cultures.
courses.subject: ENGL
courses.title: Studies in Jane Austen (3)

courses.description: Selected topics or authors in American literature from the period of European colonization of the New World through the onset of the Civil War.
courses.subject: ENGL
courses.title: American Literature before 1860 (3)

courses.description: Instructors choose authors or topics from the period 1900 to 2000. The course may be organized chronologically or thematically but is not intended as a survey.
courses.subject: ENGL
courses.title: American Literature, 1900–2000 (3)

courses.description: The development of the American novel from the late 18th century through the 20th century. May proceed chronologically or thematically.
courses.subject: ENGL
courses.title: The American Novel (3)

courses.description: Content of course varies with instructor, but students are given a sense of the chronological, stylistic, and thematic development of American poetry over two centuries.
courses.subject: ENGL
courses.title: American Poetry (3)

courses.description: Poetry in English from the middle of the 19th century to the present, approached historically, thematically, technically, politically, and aesthetically; concentration on analysis, comparison, and synthesis.
courses.subject: ENGL
courses.title: 20th-Century British and American Poetry (3)

courses.description: Students will read novels in English, including Joyce, Woolf, and Proust, to explore how writers from across cultures created new strategies to represent the late 19thand 20th-century worlds of imperialism, science, and experiment.
courses.subject: ENGL
courses.title: The British Novel from 1870 to World War II (3)

courses.description: Course studies contemporary British and American fiction through representative works. Intellectual and aesthetic, historical and cultural emphases. May include works from the Anglophone diaspora.
courses.subject: ENGL
courses.title: British and American Fiction since World War II (3)

courses.description: This course examines factors shaping British/Commonwealth literature in the 20th century, especially the world wars and the dismantling of the British Empire. We will investigate themes of both nostalgia and anticipation: ways of remembering the past of England and the Empire, and of describing the future of British culture(s).
courses.subject: ENGL
courses.title: 20th-Century British Literature and Culture (3)

courses.description: This course covers writings by Asian American women and examines issues of gender, race, and sexuality.
courses.subject: ENGL
courses.title: Asian American Women’s Writing (3)

courses.description: Theories of feminist criticism in relation to general theory and women’s writing.
courses.subject: ENGL
courses.title: Feminist Literary Theory (WMST 363) (3)

courses.description: Survey of writers and literary and cultural traditions from the beginning of African American literature to 1930.
courses.subject: ENGL
courses.title: African American Literature to 1930 (3)

courses.description: Survey of writers and literary and cultural traditions from 1930 to 1970.
courses.subject: ENGL
courses.title: African American Literature, 1930–1970 (3)

courses.description: This interdisciplinary course explores how issues of health, medicine, and illness are impacted by questions of race in 20th-century American literature and popular culture. Specific areas covered include pain, death, the family and society, reproduction, mental illness, aging, human subject experimentation, the doctor-patient relationship, pesticides, and bioethics.
courses.subject: ENGL
courses.title: Race, Health, and Narrative (3)

courses.description: An introduction to Southern literature, with emphasis on 20th-century fiction, poetry, drama, and essays. Representative authors include Faulkner, Wolfe, Williams, Warren, Hurston, Wright, Ransom, Tate, Welty, Chappell, McCullers, O’Connor.
courses.subject: ENGL
courses.title: Southern American Literature (3)

courses.description: The study of fiction, poetry, plays, and essays by Southern American women writers of the past 200 years, continuing to the present.
courses.subject: ENGL
courses.title: Southern Women Writers (WMST 374) (3)

courses.description: This course considers a range of texts, including children’s literature, to focus on the aesthetic, historical, and social factors grounding depictions of childhood. Other material includes literature and visual texts in various forms. The course stresses original student research.
courses.subject: ENGL
courses.title: Depictions of Childhood in Literature and the Visual Arts (3)

courses.description: A broad survey of the cultures of the Celtic-speaking areas, notably Ireland, Wales, Scotland, and Brittany, with special emphasis on language and literature.
courses.subject: ENGL
courses.title: Introduction to the Celtic Cultures (3)

courses.description: A study of Canadian literature in English from the late 18th century to the present, with emphasis on 20th-century writing and on the novel.
courses.subject: ENGL
courses.title: Canadian Literature (3)

courses.description: An intensive study of a single writer, group, movement, theme, or period.
courses.subject: ENGL
courses.title: Studies in Literary Topics (3)

courses.description: This course considers learning to write from three vantage points: personal, social, and contextual. Emphasis on theory, reflective practice, and pedagogy for peer tutoring.
courses.subject: ENGL
courses.title: Investigations in Academic Writing (3)

courses.description: Focuses on particular forms, authors, or issues in the period.
courses.subject: ENGL
courses.title: Contemporary Approaches to 18th-Century Literature and Culture (3)

courses.description: Poetry and prose of the Victorian period, including such writers as Tennyson, the Brownings, Arnold, the Brontës, Dickens, G. Eliot.
courses.subject: ENGL
courses.title: English Literature, 1832–1890 (3)

courses.description: A junioror senior-level course devoted to in-depth exploration of an author, group of authors, or a topic in American literature from 1900 to 2000.
courses.subject: ENGL
courses.title: American Literature, 1900–2000—Contemporary Issues (3)

courses.description: Multidisciplinary, thematic investigations into topics in literature and environment that cut across boundaries of history, genre, and culture. Junior/senior level.
courses.subject: ENGL
courses.title: Literature and Environment (3)

courses.description: A study of rhetorical theories and practices from classical to modern times. Emphasis is on translation of theories into instructional practice for teaching in the college writing classroom.
courses.subject: ENGL
courses.title: Rhetorical Theory and Practice (3)

courses.description: A study of literary works written in English concerning World War I, or the Spanish Civil War and World War II, or the Vietnam War.
courses.subject: ENGL
courses.title: War in 20th-Century Literature (PWAD 659) (3)

courses.description: This course explores Latina/o literature about photography in relation to photography by “queer” Latina/o artists and through this double focus poses certain questions about identity, subjectivity, and culture.
courses.subject: ENGL
courses.title: Queer Latina/o Photography and Literature (WMST 666) (3)

courses.description: Course introduces graduate students to methodologies of research in the field of rhetoric and Composition. emphasis is on theoretical and practical concerns that improve teaching and help develop research agendas.
courses.subject: ENGL
courses.title: Research Methods in Composition and Rhetoric (3)

courses.description: study of english from its Proto-indo-european origins through the 18th century focusing on historic events and the major changes to the structure and usage of english they occasioned.
courses.subject: ENGL
courses.title: History of the English Language (LING 814) (3)

courses.description: A study of select works of renaissance literature, both dramatic and nondramatic, in its intellectual, social, political, or religious context.
courses.subject: ENGL
courses.title: Renaissance Literature in Context (3)

courses.description: sections: 1) blake, wordsworth, Coleridge, 2) byron, shelley, Keats. examination of the major romantic poets, supplemented by readings in other romantic authors.
courses.subject: ENGL
courses.title: Studies in English Literature, 1780–1832 (3)

courses.description: in-depth exploration for doctoral students of selected topics or authors in American literature from 1860 to 1900.
courses.subject: ENGL
courses.title: Seminar in American Literature, 1860–1900 (3)

courses.description: doctoral-level seminar in the selected topics or authors.
courses.subject: ENGL
courses.title: Seminar in the American Novel (3)

courses.description: An intensive study of a major writer or text, a group of writers or texts, or an important trend, tradition, or literary period.
courses.subject: ENGL
courses.title: Seminar in African American Literature (3)

courses.description: topics vary according to the needs and interests of the individual student and the professor directing the reading and writing project.
courses.subject: ENGL
courses.title: Directed Readings (3)

courses.description: The basic question examined in this course will be the costs and benefits of the United States policy of drug prohibition. As a seminar the class will consist of discussions and debates.
courses.subject: ECON
courses.title: First-Year Seminar: The Costs and Benefits of the Drug War (3)

courses.description: This is a special topics course. Content will vary each semester.
courses.subject: ECON
courses.title: First-Year Seminar: Special Topics (3)

courses.description: Introduction to fundamental issues in economics including competition, scarcity, opportunity cost, resource allocation, unemployment, inflation, and the determination of prices.
courses.subject: ECON
courses.title: Introduction to Economics (3)

courses.description: Introduction to fundamental issues in economics including competition, scarcity, opportunity cost, resource allocation, unemployment, inflation, and the determination of prices.
courses.subject: ECON
courses.title: Introduction to Economics (3)

courses.description: Permission of the director of undergraduate studies. Majors only. A supervised internship appropriate for experiential education in economics. Cannot count toward the economics major. Pass/Fail only.
courses.subject: ECON
courses.title: Internship (3)

courses.description: Analysis of the ways in which consumers and business firms interact in a market economy. Students may not receive credit for both ECON 310 and 410.
courses.subject: ECON
courses.title: Microeconomics Theory and Applications (MNGT 310) (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, ECON 325. Permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisite. A comprehensive survey of commercial venturing throughout the lifecycle of a venture from initial conception to execution and exit. Outlines strategies of entrepreneurs to develop ventures in different commercial markets.
courses.subject: ECON
courses.title: Business Venturing Workshop (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, ECON 310 or 410. Industry structure and its relation to performance; market imperfections; description and analysis of antitrust and regulation. Students may not receive credit for both ECON 345 and 445.
courses.subject: ECON
courses.title: Public Policy toward Business (MNGT 345) (3)

courses.description: See ECON 345 for description.
courses.subject: MNGT
courses.title: Public Policy toward Business (ECON 345) (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, ECON 310 or 410. An economic analysis of workplace issues, including worker quits, layoffs and unemployment, discrimination and affirmative action, and the setting of pay, fringe benefits, and working conditions. Students may not receive credit for both ECON 380 and 480.
courses.subject: ECON
courses.title: The Economics of Labor Relations (MNGT 380) (3)

courses.description: See ECON 380 for description.
courses.subject: MNGT
courses.title: The Economics of Labor Relations (ECON 380) (3)

courses.description: See PHIL 384 description.
courses.subject: ECON
courses.title: Introduction to Philosophy, Politics, and Economics (PHIL 384, POLI 384) (3)

courses.description: See PHIL 384 for description.
courses.subject: POLI
courses.title: Introduction to Philosophy, Politics, and Economics (ECON 384, PHIL 384) (3)

courses.description: Permission of the department required; one course in economics strongly recommended. This interdisciplinary gateway course provides an introduction to subjects and quantitative techniques used to analyze problems in philosophy, political science, and economics.
courses.subject: PHIL
courses.title: Introduction to Philosophy, Politics, and Economics (ECON 384, POLI 384) (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, ECON 327 or PLCY 326. Students spend a minimum of eight weeks in an entrepreneurial environment taking on significant responsibilities and working on a specific project that results in a rigorous agreed-upon deliverable.
courses.subject: ECON
courses.title: Practicum in Entrepreneurship (3)

courses.description: Comprehensive introduction to statistics, including descriptive statistics and statistical graphics, probability theory, distributions, parameter estimation, hypothesis testing, simple and multiple regression, and use of powerful statistical estimation software.
courses.subject: ECON
courses.title: Elementary Statistics (3)

courses.description: Comprehensive introduction to statistics, including descriptive statistics and statistical graphics, probability theory, distributions, parameter estimation, hypothesis testing, simple and multiple regression, and use of powerful statistical estimation software.
courses.subject: ECON
courses.title: Elementary Statistics (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, MATH 231 or STOR 113. The determination of prices and the distribution of income in a market system. Students may not receive credit for both ECON 310 and 410.
courses.subject: ECON
courses.title: Intermediate Theory: Price and Distribution (3)

courses.description: Prerequisites, MATH 110 and 130. Requires a grade of Cor better in MATH 130 or placement by the department. Limits, derivatives, and integrals of functions of one variable. Students may not receive credit for both MATH 231 and MATH 241.
courses.subject: MATH
courses.title: Calculus of Functions of One Variable I (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, MATH 110. An introduction to multivariable quantitative models in economics. Mathematical techniques for formulating and solving optimization and equilibrium problems will be developed, including elementary models under uncertainty.
courses.subject: STOR
courses.title: Decision Models for Economics (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, MATH 231 or STOR 113. The determination of prices and the distribution of income in a market system. Students may not receive credit for both ECON 310 and 410.
courses.subject: ECON
courses.title: Intermediate Theory: Price and Distribution (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, MATH 110. An introductory survey of differential and integral calculus with emphasis on techniques and applications of interest for business and the social sciences. This is a terminal course and not adequate preparation for MATH 232. A student cannot receive credit for this course after receiving credit for MATH 231 or 241.
courses.subject: MATH
courses.title: Calculus for Business and Social Sciences (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, ECON 410. An introduction to contemporary macroeconomic concepts and analysis. Topics include the level, fluctuations, and growth of national income, and monetary and fiscal policies designed to achieve economic goals. Students may not receive credit for both ECON 320 and 420.
courses.subject: ECON
courses.title: Intermediate Theory: Money, Income, and Employment (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, ECON 420. An examination of financial institutions and markets, their role in economic conditions, and the use of macroeconomic policies in affecting those conditions. Students may not receive credit for both ECON 320 and 423.
courses.subject: ECON
courses.title: Financial Markets and Economic Fluctuations (3)

courses.description: A survey of the fundamental forms of economic thought from the scholastics through Keynes.
courses.subject: ECON
courses.title: History of Economic Doctrines (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, ECON 410. Application of economic analysis to the taxing and spending functions of government. Students may not receive credit for both ECON 340 and 440.
courses.subject: ECON
courses.title: Analysis of Public Finance (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, ECON 410. A rigorous economic analysis of environmental issues, with particular emphasis on the problem of designing appropriate institutions and regulations under private information and the interaction between economic and ecological systems. Topics include emission fees and marketable permits, pollution models, carbon regulation, and ecosystem service markets.
courses.subject: ECON
courses.title: Environmental Economic Theory (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, ECON 410. An introduction to international trade, the balance of payments, and related issues of foreign economic policy.
courses.subject: ECON
courses.title: International Economics (EURO 460, PWAD 460) (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, ECON 410. Permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisite. Economic and political aspects of European economic integration, the EC customs union, barriers to integration, convergence vs. divergence of inflation rates and income levels, enlargement of the EC.
courses.subject: ECON
courses.title: European Economic Integration (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, ECON 410. Permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisite. An introduction to the economic characteristics and problems of the less developed countries and to the theories and policies applicable to the developing economy.
courses.subject: ECON
courses.title: Economic Development (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, ECON 410. An introduction to the field of labor economics with emphasis on how the interactions between firms and workers influence wages, employment, unemployment, and inflation. Students may not receive credit for both ECON 380 and 480.
courses.subject: ECON
courses.title: Labor Economics (3)

courses.description: topic varies from semester to semester. Permission of the instructor.
courses.subject: ECON
courses.title: Research Course (1–3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, ECON 410. A treatment of topics in microeconomic theory not normally covered in ECON 410.
courses.subject: ECON
courses.title: Advanced Microeconomic Theory (3)

courses.description: Prerequisites, ECON 410 and MATH 233. Permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisites. Topics in noncooperative and cooperative game theory are covered, along with a selection of applications to economics in areas such as industrial organization, international trade, public finance, and general equilibrium.
courses.subject: ECON
courses.title: Game Theory in Economics (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, MATH 232 or 283. Vector algebra, solid analytic geometry, partial derivatives, multiple integrals.
courses.subject: MATH
courses.title: Calculus of Functions of Several Variables (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, ECON 420. This course will emphasize theoretical and empirical topics such as growth, labor search, Phillips curves, stagflation, and optimal government policy.
courses.subject: ECON
courses.title: Advanced Macroeconomic Theory (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, ECON 460. Analysis and interpretation of selected problems and policy issues. Content varies, but attention is given to such topics as trade barriers, trade patterns, floating exchange rates, and international monetary policy.
courses.subject: ECON
courses.title: Advanced International Economics (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, ECON 400. Statistical methods in the construction, estimation, testing, and application of linear economic models; computer programs and interpretation of their output in empirical analysis of common economic theories.
courses.subject: ECON
courses.title: Economic Applications of Statistical Analysis (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, ECON 400. Statistical methods in the construction, estimation, testing, and application of linear economic models; computer programs and interpretation of their output in empirical analysis of common economic theories.
courses.subject: ECON
courses.title: Economic Applications of Statistical Analysis (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, MAtH 233 or 283. Algebra of matrices with applications: determinants, solution of linear systems by Gaussian elimination, Gram-schmidt procedure, eigenvalues. MAtH 416 may not be taken for credit after credit has been granted for MAtH 547.
courses.subject: MATH
courses.title: Linear Algebra for Applications (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, ECON 410. Permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisite. Analyzes the family with respect to the marriage market; divorce; reproductive behavior; the baby black market; intra-family allocation of goods, time, and power; labor supply; migration; and family policy.
courses.subject: ECON
courses.title: Economics of the Family (3)

courses.description: See PHIL 698 for description.
courses.subject: ECON
courses.title: Philosophy, Politics, and Economics II: Capstone Course (PHIL 698, POLI 698) (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, eCon 710. General equilibrium and welfare economics, game theory and oligopoly, information economics.
courses.subject: ECON
courses.title: Advanced Microeconomic Theory II (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, eCon 720. Growth models, general equilibrium approach to monetary theory; input-output; disequilibrium theory; extensions of Keynesian and classical models.
courses.subject: ECON
courses.title: Advanced Macroeconomic Theory II (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, eCon 770. one semester coverage of basic econometrics. topics include: regression under ideal and nonideal conditions; special models, including simultaneous equations models; and applications and econometric computer programs.
courses.subject: ECON
courses.title: Econometrics (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, eCon 810. Permission ofthe instructor for students lacking the prerequisite. This course is a continuation of eCon 810. topics covered will be chosen from those listed, but not covered in eCon 810.
courses.subject: ECON
courses.title: Game Theory II (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, eCon 720. Permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisite. optimal policy under uncertainty, financial intermediation and monetary control, channels of monetary influence, monetary policy and inflation, rules versus authority.
courses.subject: ECON
courses.title: Monetary Policy (1–3)

courses.description: Prerequisites, eCon 710 and 771. Permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisites. Measurement and modeling of the demand for medical care, the demand for and supply of health insurance, and the incorporation of health, medical care, and health insurance in determining both short and long run labor supply.
courses.subject: ECON
courses.title: Health Economics (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, eCon 870. Covers stationary univariate and multivariate time series models, spectral analysis methods, nonstationary models with time trends, unit roots and cointegration, and special topics such as conditional volatility, the Kalman filter, and changes of regime.
courses.subject: ECON
courses.title: Time Series Econometrics (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, eCon 870. limited dependent variable models such as binary outcome models, multinomial outcome models, and censored and truncated outcome models. Count data models. duration models. Panel data analysis.
courses.subject: ECON
courses.title: Microeconomics (3)

courses.description: Permission of the instructor. individual research in a special field under direction of a member of the department.
courses.subject: ECON
courses.title: Seminar (1–21)

courses.description: Permission of the instructor. discussion of current research in microeconomic theory and industrial organization. oral and written reports on dissertation research. May be repeated for credit.
courses.subject: ECON
courses.title: Dissertation Workshop in Microeconomic Theory (1–3)

courses.description: Permission of the instructor. discussion of current research in macroeconomics and monetary economics. oral and written reports on dissertation research. May be repeated for credit.
courses.subject: ECON
courses.title: Dissertation Workshop in Macroeconomics (1-3)

courses.description: Examines fundamental processes governing the movement and transformation of material and energy in environmental systems. Focuses on the role of these processes in environmental phenomena and how society perturbs these processes. Integrates methods from a range of scientific disciplines. Three lecture hours and three computer laboratory hours a week.
courses.subject: ENEC
courses.title: Introduction to the Environmental Sciences (4)

courses.description: Prerequisite, MATH 231; corequisite, MATH 232. A quantitative introduction to selected topics in environmental sciences with an emphasis on developing and solidifying problemsolving skills.
courses.subject: ENEC
courses.title: Introduction to Environmental Science Problem Solving (3)

courses.description: This course will provide an intellectual focus on the interface between environment and society by examining the relationship among science, policy, and actual management practices on a chosen topic.
courses.subject: ENEC
courses.title: Environmental Seminar (1–3)

courses.description: The course familiarizes students with the natural history, ecology, and physical and chemical characteristics of the coral reef environment. Policy and management issues are also examined.
courses.subject: ENEC
courses.title: Coral Reef Ecology and Management (1)

courses.description: Prerequisites, MATH 231, ENEC 201 and 202. Permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisites. Examines the regional to global flow of materials and energy through materials extraction, processing, manufacturing, product use, recycling, and ultimate disposition, including its relevance in policy development. Reviews natural cycles in the environment, basic physics, and the technology of energy production.
courses.subject: ENEC
courses.title: Energy and Material Flows in the Environment and Society (3)

courses.description: An overview of science, social science, and humanities perspectives on community sustainability.
courses.subject: ENEC
courses.title: Principles of Sustainability (PLAN 330) (3)

courses.description: This course gives students an overview of environmental law and some practical experience in environmental policy making.
courses.subject: ENEC
courses.title: Environmental Law and Policy (3)

courses.description: Introduction to the ecology of agricultural practices and the impact of food production on the environment. Particular attention will be paid to the constraints on agriculture which must be overcome to feed the planet’s growing population.
courses.subject: ENEC
courses.title: Agriculture and the Environment (3)

courses.description: Introduction to the ecology of agricultural practices and the impact of food production on the environment. Particular attention will be paid to the constraints on agriculture which must be overcome to feed the planet’s growing population.
courses.subject: ENEC
courses.title: Agriculture and the Environment (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, ECON 101 This course develops a set of core principles that are essential to understand and evaluate environmental policy and renewable resource use. These principles are primarily economic, but our discussion will also include insights from politics and ethics.
courses.subject: ENEC
courses.title: Environmental Economics (3)

courses.description: Permission of the instructor. This course provides an internship with a local organization on the topic of community sustainability, and explores the intellectual basis of public engagement.
courses.subject: ENEC
courses.title: Internship in Sustainability (3)

courses.description: Permission of the instructor. Research in an area of environmental science or environmental studies.
courses.subject: ENEC
courses.title: Research in Environmental Sciences and Studies for Undergraduates (1–21)

courses.description: See ENVR 403 for description.
courses.subject: ENEC
courses.title: Environmental Chemistry Processes (ENVR 403) (3)

courses.description: The impact of building on the environment and health will be examined by looking at the major areas of: land use planning, water resource use, energy, materials, and indoor environment.
courses.subject: ENEC
courses.title: Community Design and Green Architecture (PLAN 420) (3)

courses.description: See MASC 441 for description.
courses.subject: ENEC
courses.title: Marine Physiological Ecology (MASC 441) (3)

courses.description: Prerequisites, CHEM 251 or 261, MATH 231, PHYS 115 or 119. Permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisites. Principles of chemistry, biology, and geology are applied to analysis of the fate and transport of materials in environmental systems, with an emphasis on those materials that form the most significant cycles. Three lecture hours and one laboratory hour a week.
courses.subject: ENEC
courses.title: Biogeochemical Processes (GEOL 450, MASC 450) (4)

courses.description: Prerequisite, BIOL 101. Explores the ecological concepts underlying ecosystem management (e.g., genetic and species diversity, stability, resilience, landscape ecology, etc.), the tools used in the approach, and case studies of how communities are implementing ecosystem management.
courses.subject: ENEC
courses.title: Ecosystem Management (3)

courses.description: Advanced topics from diverse areas of environmental science and/or environmental studies are explored.
courses.subject: ENEC
courses.title: Special Topics in Environmental Science and Studies (1–12)

courses.description: See GEOL 511 for description.
courses.subject: ENEC
courses.title: Stable Isotopes in the Environment (GEOL 511) (3)

courses.description: Prerequisites, MATH 231, 232, and 233; PHYS 118 and 119. Recommended preparation, MATH 383. Develops explanatory and predictive models of the earth’s climate. The level is introductory and the emphasis is on modeling past climate with the hope of understanding its future.
courses.subject: ENEC
courses.title: Principles of Climate Modeling (3)

courses.description: Required preparation, previous course work in ecology. Permission of the instructor. Topics vary but focus on interdisciplinary problems facing humans and/or the environment. May be repeated for credit.
courses.subject: ENEC
courses.title: Current Issues in Ecology (3)

courses.description: See HIST 159 for description.
courses.subject: EURO
courses.title: 20th-Century Europe (HIST 159) (3)

courses.description: See POLI 239 for description.
courses.subject: EURO
courses.title: Introduction to European Government (POLI 239) (3)

courses.description: A treatment of the political institutions and processes of western European democracies, with special attention to France, Germany, England, and Italy.
courses.subject: POLI
courses.title: Introduction to European Government (EURO 239) (3)

courses.description: See POLI 442 for description.
courses.subject: EURO
courses.title: International Political Economy (POLI 442) (3)

courses.description: See ECON 460 for description.
courses.subject: PWAD
courses.title: International Economics (ECON 460, EURO 460) (3)

courses.description: Survey of the discipline of exercise and sport science. Analysis of the nature and importance of physical activity, knowledge base of the discipline, and careers in physical activity professions.
courses.subject: EXSS
courses.title: Foundations of EXSS (3)

courses.description: Elective, open to all students. This course examines basic wellness concepts in the areas of physical fitness, nutrition, disease prevention, mental health, drug abuse, and human sexuality. Emphasis is on the individual’s responsibility for his/her own health.
courses.subject: EXSS
courses.title: Personal Health (3)

courses.description: The study of the structure of the human body with special emphasis on the musculoskeletal, articular, and nervous systems. Prosected cadaver materials are utilized to study the skeletal muscles and body viscera.
courses.subject: EXSS
courses.title: Human Anatomy (3)

courses.description: A comprehensive introduction to psychological and sociological factors that relate to sport involvement and performance. Issues include psychological aspects of elite athletes, motivation and performance, intervention and performance enhancement, anxiety and skill performance, racial and gender discrimination in sport, and violence in sport.
courses.subject: EXSS
courses.title: Sport Psychology (3)

courses.description: (3). Prerequisite, PHYA 224. An intensive study of modern dance technique and philosophy, focusing on the physical principles of movement and their choreographic application. One hour seminar and four and one-half hours laboratory.
courses.subject: EXSS
courses.title: Theory and Practice of Modern Dance Technique—Elementary-Level Elective

courses.description: A professional preparation course in the skills, knowledge, safety, and teaching progressions of soccer, tennis, and volleyball.
courses.subject: EXSS
courses.title: Analysis of Sport Skills II (3)

courses.description: Students develop a working knowledge of theories, principles, and operating procedures involved in managing programs, staff, and facilities in the health/fitness industry, including management, marketing, operations, legal aspects.
courses.subject: EXSS
courses.title: Fitness Management (3)

courses.description: In this course, students are introduced to the policies and problems of organizing and administering sport, recreation and physical education programs in public and private settings.
courses.subject: EXSS
courses.title: Introduction to Sport and Recreation Administration (3)

courses.description: This course will analyze and produce skills essential to the revenue production and sales process commonly found in the sport business. In this class students will develop an understanding and appreciation for the sales and revenue-production process related to a sport franchise and/or organization.
courses.subject: EXSS
courses.title: Sport Sales and Revenue Production Seminar (3)

courses.description: Prerequisites, EXSS 175 and 288. Permission of the instructor. This course is designed to introduce the undergraduate athletic training student to the athletic training profession and to provide the basic knowledge and skills necessary to recognize, evaluate, and treat injuries to the head and face, cervical spine, thoracic region, abdominal/urogenital region, and extremities.
courses.subject: EXSS
courses.title: Fundamentals of Athletic Training (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, EXSS 175. BIOL 252 may be accepted as a prerequisite with the permission of the instructor. A lecture course in elementary physiology, covering the various systems of the body.
courses.subject: EXSS
courses.title: Human Physiology (3)

courses.description: Preor corequisite, EXSS 175. Theory and practice of basic first aid, cardiopulmonary resuscitation, and the acute care of athletic injuries.
courses.subject: EXSS
courses.title: Emergency Care of Athletic Injuries and Illnesses (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, EXSS 221. This course is designed to introduce students to marketing within the sport industry, including the unique aspects of the sport product and sport consumer markets.
courses.subject: EXSS
courses.title: Fundamentals of Sport Marketing (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, EXSS 221. This course is designed to develop practical competencies necessary for effectively managing sport facilities and events while providing students with experiential learning opportunities inside and outside the classroom.
courses.subject: EXSS
courses.title: Sport Facility and Event Management (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, ECON 101. Recommended preparation, EXSS 221. This course provides an understanding of the financial and economic growth of sport, economic theory applied to the sport industry, and the basic principles and methods of sound fiscal control.
courses.subject: EXSS
courses.title: Finance and Economics of Sport (3)

courses.description: Recommended preparation, EXSS 221. This course provides a foundation in general legal concepts and familiarizes students with those areas they are most likely to encounter as managers in the sports and fitness industry.
courses.subject: EXSS
courses.title: Legal Aspects of Sport (3)

courses.description: This course will provide students an introduction to practical entrepreneurial business tools for starting a new business (or for use in an existing organization) in the sport industry.
courses.subject: EXSS
courses.title: Sport Business Venture (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, EXSS 276 or NUTR 240. The role of nutrition in maximizing physical performance, promoting health, and controlling body weight. Includes individual nutritional assessments.
courses.subject: EXSS
courses.title: Sports Nutrition (3)

courses.description: Prerequisites, EXSS 175, 265, 288, and 366. This is an advanced athletic training course, designed to provide the athletic training student with knowledge and skills necessary for treating injuries.
courses.subject: EXSS
courses.title: Therapeutic Modalities (3)

courses.description: Prerequisites, EXSS 175, 265, 288, and 276. Advanced course focusing on understanding instrumentation used in assessing internal injury related to sport. Pharmacology, drug testing, psychosocial interventions, and selected emergency procedures pertaining to athletic injury are also presented.
courses.subject: EXSS
courses.title: General Medicine in Athletic Training (3)

courses.description: Prerequisites, EXSS 175, 276, and MATH 110. Instructor may approve equivalents for EXSS prerequisites. Students must take laboratory section along with class. The application of physiological principles to sport and physical activity. Both immediate and chronic adaptations to exercise are studied. Two lecture and two laboratory hours a week.
courses.subject: EXSS
courses.title: Physiological Basis of Human Performance (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, EXSS 175. Provides an understanding of the neuromuscular factors controlling movement and how changes in these factors lead to learning physical skills. Promotes the application of neuromuscular control and learning principles to the teaching of physical skills with examples from fields such as athletic training, physical therapy, coaching, and medicine.
courses.subject: EXSS
courses.title: Neuromuscular Control and Learning (3)

courses.description: Prerequisites, EXSS 175 and MATH 110. Permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisites. The study and analysis of human movement including fundamental aspects of the musculoskeletal and articular systems. Principles of biomechanics, including application to neuromuscular fitness activities, aerodynamics in sport, hydrodynamics, rotary motion, throw-like and push-like patterns, and analysis of projectiles.
courses.subject: EXSS
courses.title: Biomechanics of Sport (3)

courses.description: Prerequisites, EXSS 175, 265, and 288. This field experience offers implementation of theories and practices of athletic training and sports medicine under the supervision of a certified athletic trainer.
courses.subject: EXSS
courses.title: Athletic Training Clinical (1)

courses.description: Required preparation, any two EXSS courses with grades of B or better. Permission of the instructor. Individually designed indepth study in an area of interest within exercise and sport science. Available to both majors and nonmajors under the supervision ofselected EXSS faculty members.
courses.subject: EXSS
courses.title: Independent Studies in Exercise and Sport Science Elective (1–3)

courses.description: Prerequisites, EXSS 175 and 276. This is an intermediateto upper-level course designed to provide students with theoretical and practical knowledge of the physiological, biomechanical, functional, and administrative aspects of designing and supervising conditioning programs for various populations.
courses.subject: EXSS
courses.title: Theory and Application of Strength Training and Conditioning for Fitness Professionals (3)

courses.description: Prerequisites, EXSS 175, 276, 366, and 368. An upperlevel course designed to provide students who have a health profession background with the theoretical and practical knowledge related to the Performance Enhancement Specialization for athletes.
courses.subject: EXSS
courses.title: Performance Enhancement Specialization for Health Professionals (1)

courses.description: Prerequisites, EXSS 221 and at least two of the following: 322, 323, 324, 326. Permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisites. This field experience offers implementation of theory and the practical application of sport administration in a sport organization worksite, under the direct supervision of a business professional.
courses.subject: EXSS
courses.title: Field Experience in Sport Administration (1–3)

courses.description: Prerequisites, EXSS 220, 385, 408, 410L, and 412. Recommended preparation, EXSS 360–site dependent. Current CPR certification and student liability insurance is required. Introductory practical experience to enable student to apply knowledge and skills in a worksite under direct supervision of certified professionals.
courses.subject: EXSS
courses.title: Practicum in Physical Fitness and Wellness (1–2)

courses.description: required preparation, undergraduate statistics course. Applied statistical analysis - interpretation of data from exercise and sport science. emphasis: choosing method of analysis, using statistics software to run analyses. Major topics: experimental and nonexperimental research design, sampling, hypothesis testing, power calculation, t-tests, AnovA, correlation, simple and multiple regression, and chi square.
courses.subject: EXSS
courses.title: Applied Statistics and Research Methods in Exercise and Sport Science (3)

courses.description: required preparation, any undergraduate statistics course. builds heavily upon material presented in eXss 700. Planning, conducting, and reportingof research. Thesis writing and writing for publication. Problem-solving and practical experience in applied statistical analysis, interpretation, and presentation of data from the field of exercise and sport science.
courses.subject: EXSS
courses.title: Applied Statistics and Research Methods Laboratory (3)

courses.subject: EXSS
courses.title: Sports Medicine Analysis: Special Problems Related to Sports Medicine (3)

courses.description: Graduate standing in exercise and sport science or permission of the instructor. The study of administrative structures and financial concerns of collegiate athletic programs. An intensive study of nCAA regulations is included.
courses.subject: EXSS
courses.title: Organizational and Financial Management of Sport (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, eXss 740. The implementation of theories and practices in a professional setting under the direction of a competent practitioner.
courses.subject: EXSS
courses.title: NCAA Governance and Compliance (3)

courses.description: successful completion of first year in sport administration graduate program. An introduction of organizational leadership concepts in a practical applied context. students will lead class discussion tying relevant current events with leadership theory.
courses.subject: EXSS
courses.title: Sport Administration Leadership Seminar II (1)

courses.description: required preparation, completion of a graduate level exercise physiology course. Graduate standing required. This course deals with current and rapidly developing aspects of the exercise physiology field. specifically enhancing and adding to the content area of basic physiology acquired in eXss 780.
courses.subject: EXSS
courses.title: Advanced Topics in Exercise Physiology (3)

courses.description: Graduate standing or permission of the instructor. The study of special topics directed by an authority in the field.
courses.subject: EXSS
courses.title: Special Topics in Exercise and Sport Science (1–3)

courses.description: Graduate standing in exercise and sport science or permission of the instructor. individually designed research projects conducted by students under the direction of a graduate faculty member.
courses.subject: EXSS
courses.title: Research in Exercise and Sport Science (1–3)

courses.description: Assignments to this class are made for students with special needs in physical activities focusing primarily on acute and chronic physical limitations. Activities are assigned commensurate with interests and abilities. Students can enroll in only one LFIT course during their career at Carolina.
courses.subject: LFIT
courses.title: Lifetime Fitness: Adapted Physical Activity (1)

courses.description: This course is an introduction to fitness and wellness, and includes developing personal fitness programs and instruction in physical activity. The activity portion of the course includes various forms of aerobics. Students can enroll in only one LFIT course during their career at Carolina.
courses.subject: LFIT
courses.title: Lifetime Fitness: Aerobics (1)

courses.description: This course is an introduction to fitness and wellness, and includes developing personal fitness programs and instruction in physical activity. Activity portion of the course includes basketball, volleyball, and indoor soccer. Students can enroll in only one LFIT course during their career at Carolina.
courses.subject: LFIT
courses.title: Lifetime Fitness: Indoor Sports (1)

courses.description: This course is an introduction to fitness and wellness, and includes developing personal fitness programs and instruction in physical activity. The activity portion of the course promotes cardiovascular fitness through jogging. Students can enroll in only one LFIT course during their career at Carolina.
courses.subject: LFIT
courses.title: Lifetime Fitness: Beginning Jogging (1)

courses.description: This course is an introduction to fitness and wellness, and includes developing personal fitness programs and instruction in physical activity. Activity portion for students who can complete 30 minutes of jogging. Students can enroll in only one LFIT course during their career at Carolina.
courses.subject: LFIT
courses.title: Lifetime Fitness: Intermediate Jogging (1)

courses.description: This course is an introduction to fitness and wellness, and includes developing personal fitness programs and instruction in physical activity. Activity portion of course includes ultimate frisbee, flag football, and soccer. Students can enroll in only one LFIT course during their career at Carolina.
courses.subject: LFIT
courses.title: Lifetime Fitness: Outdoor Sports (1)

courses.description: This course is an introduction to fitness and wellness, and includes developing personal fitness programs and instruction in physical activity. The activity portion of the course includes badminton, tennis, and racquetball. Students can enroll in only one LFIT course during their career at Carolina.
courses.subject: LFIT
courses.title: Lifetime Fitness: Racquet Sports (1)

courses.description: This course is an introduction to fitness and wellness, and includes developing personal fitness programs and instruction in physical activity. The activity portion of the course includes swimming skills for beginners. Students can enroll in only one LFIT course during their career at Carolina.
courses.subject: LFIT
courses.title: Lifetime Fitness: Beginning Swimming (1)

courses.description: This course is an introduction to fitness and wellness, and includes developing personal fitness programs and instruction in physical activity. The activity portion of the course promotes cardiovascular fitness through swimming. Students can enroll in only one LFIT course during their career at Carolina.
courses.subject: LFIT
courses.title: Lifetime Fitness: Swim Conditioning (1)

courses.description: This course is an introduction to fitness and wellness, and includes developing personal fitness programs and instruction in physical activity. The activity portion of the course promotes cardiovascular fitness through walking. Students can enroll in only one LFIT course during their career at Carolina.
courses.subject: LFIT
courses.title: Lifetime Fitness: Walking (1)

courses.description: This course is an introduction to fitness and wellness, and includes developing personal fitness programs and instruction in physical activity. The activity portion includes basic techniques of weight training. Students can enroll in only one LFIT course during their career at Carolina.
courses.subject: LFIT
courses.title: Lifetime Fitness: Weight Training (1)

courses.description: This course is an introduction to fitness and wellness, and includes developing personal fitness programs and instruction in physical activity. The activityportion includes basic instruction in both yoga and pilates. Students can enroll in only one LFIT course during their career at Carolina.
courses.subject: LFIT
courses.title: Lifetime Fitness: Yoga and Pilates (1)

courses.description: This course is an introduction to fitness and wellness, and includes developing personal fitness programs and instruction in physical activity. The activity portion includes basic instruction in cycle fitness. Students can enroll in only one LFIT course during their career at Carolina.
courses.subject: LFIT
courses.title: Lifetime Fitness: Cycle Fitness (1)

courses.description: This course is an introduction to fitness and wellness, and includes developing personal fitness programs and instruction in physical activity. The activity portion will provide soccer instruction and game play. Students can enroll in only one LFIT course during their career at Carolina.
courses.subject: LFIT
courses.title: Lifetime Fitness: Soccer (1)

courses.description: This course is an introduction to fitness and wellness, and includes developing personal fitness programs and instruction in physical activity. The activity portion of the course includes basic instruction in tennis. Students can enroll in only one LFIT course during their career at Carolina.
courses.subject: LFIT
courses.title: Lifetime Fitness: Tennis (1)

courses.description: This course is an introduction to fitness and wellness, and includes developing personal fitness programs and instruction in physical activity. The activity portion of the course includes basic instruction in ultimate frisbee. Students can enroll in only one LFIT course during their career at Carolina.
courses.subject: LFIT
courses.title: Lifetime Fitness: Ultimate Frisbee (1)

courses.description: This course is an introduction to fitness and wellness, and includes developing personal fitness programs and instruction in physical activity. The activity portion of the course includes basic instruction in sand volleyball. Students can enroll in only one LFIT course during their career at Carolina.
courses.subject: LFIT
courses.title: Lifetime Fitness: Sand Volleyball (1)

courses.description: Assignments to this class aremade for students with special needs in physical education focusing primarily on acute and chronic physical limitations. Activities are assigned commensurate with interests and abilities. Students are required to present an exercise prescription from a physician including prescribed activities and limitations.
courses.subject: PHYA
courses.title: Adapted Physical Activity (1)

courses.description: Provides a cardiovascular fitness program incorporating physiologically safe dance and exercise movements to music. It develops strength, flexibility, and improved cardiorespiratory efficiency.
courses.subject: PHYA
courses.title: Beginning Aerobics (1)

courses.description: Beginning physical fitness program based on the model used by the United States Army Physical Fitness Academy and designed to improve aerobic and anaerobic strength, endurance, and overall physical fitness.
courses.subject: PHYA
courses.title: Beginning Basic Training (1)

courses.description: Stresses swing motion and the basic fundamentals. Techniques of the full swing and the short game are presented. Rules and etiquette are covered. Students who shoot 115 or less for 18 holes are not eligible for this beginner course.
courses.subject: PHYA
courses.title: Beginning Golf (1)

courses.description: The purpose of this course is to provide students with the opportunity to develop cardiovascular fitness through a popular activity. Selection of proper clothing and equipment, the physiological effects of a jogging program, care and prevention of common injuries, and the mechanics of jogging are presented.
courses.subject: PHYA
courses.title: Beginning Jogging (1)

courses.description: Required preparation, ability to swim 500 yards continuously and retrieve a 10-pound object from a depth of seven feet. This course will prepare individuals to effectively assume the duties and responsibilities of lifeguards at swimming pools and at protected (nonsurf ) open water beaches.
courses.subject: PHYA
courses.title: Lifeguard Training (1)

courses.description: Required preparation, strong swimming skills. This course prepares students for participation in recreational diving: both skin diving and scuba. Lectures cover physiology of diving, first aid, and decompression. It can lead to certification if students attend open water training dives conducted at the semester’s end. An additional fee is required.
courses.subject: PHYA
courses.title: Scuba (1)

courses.description: Basic soccer skills are presented including dribbling, shooting, passing, heading, trapping, and tackling. Position play and strategies for basic offense and defense are learned as well as rules and terminology. Conditioning is achieved through drills and game play.
courses.subject: PHYA
courses.title: Beginning Soccer (1)

courses.description: The basic step patterns of popular social dances, such as fox trot, waltz, cha-cha, swing or shag, hustle, tango, and others are taught. Confidence in the ability to lead or to follow is developed. Social enjoyment of dance is emphasized.
courses.subject: PHYA
courses.title: Beginning Social Dance (1)

courses.description: The course consists of swimming skills for students with limited water experience. These skills include water adjustment, floating, kicking, front crawl stroke, rhythmic breathing, and elementary backstroke. Emphasis is on efficient movement through the water. Basic water safety procedures are included.
courses.subject: PHYA
courses.title: Beginning-Level Swimming (1)

courses.description: Basic skills are learned including forehand and backhand groundstrokes, the volley, and the serve. Rules, terminology, and basic game strategy will be taught. Through play, an increased level of fitness and skill will be gained to promote participation in tennis throughout life.
courses.subject: PHYA
courses.title: Tennis (1)

courses.description: The purpose of this course is to introduce students to the sport of triathlons integrating the discipline of running, cycling, and swimming. The course is physically challenging and provides information on transitions and maintenance of equipment, as well as setting up a training program.
courses.subject: PHYA
courses.title: Triathlon Training (1)

courses.description: Basic techniques and knowledge of variable resistance and free weight systems are taught. Fitness evaluation and individual workout programs are included. Development of muscular strength and endurance is stressed. Physiological principles of fitness and their relationships to weight training are also emphasized.
courses.subject: PHYA
courses.title: Beginning Weight Training (1)

courses.description: This course will combine instruction in, and practice of, a sport or physical activity that can be sustained in later life, together with instruction in lifelong health.
courses.subject: PHYA
courses.title: Brazilian Jiu Jitsu (1)

courses.description: This course is designed to cover the study and practice of special topics directed by an authority in the field. Subject matter will vary per instructor and topic.
courses.subject: PHYA
courses.title: Special Topics (1)

courses.description: For the dancer with a solid understanding of the basics of ballet and several years’ dance training. It emphasizes more sophisticated steps in longer combinations.
courses.subject: PHYA
courses.title: Intermediate Ballet (1)

courses.description: Students will work to develop greater technical skill and continue a more advanced exploration of modern dance principles of effort-shape through center work and phrases of greater length and complexity in the center and across the floor. At least two years of modern dance training are recommended.
courses.subject: PHYA
courses.title: Intermediate Modern Dance (1)

courses.description: Basic skills are reviewed and refined. Dead ball situations are studied, especially corner kicks and direct and indirect free kicks. Different systems of play are introduced and evaluated. Positional play is stressed in the development of advanced defensive and offensive tactics.
courses.subject: PHYA
courses.title: Intermediate Soccer (1)

courses.description: All aspects of leading group fitness activities will be explored and applied, including components of an aerobic exercise class, modifications for individual needs and special populations, health screening, fitness testing.
courses.subject: PHYA
courses.title: Leading Group Fitness Activities (1)

courses.description: For the dancer with substantial background in ballet. Speed, endurance, multiple turns, beats, and complicated combinations are emphasized.
courses.subject: PHYA
courses.title: Advanced Ballet (1)

courses.description: This course is designed for the dancer with a solid understanding of the principles underlying modern dance and several years of dance training. It focuses on longer and more complicated phases of movements.
courses.subject: PHYA
courses.title: Advanced Modern Dance (1)

courses.description: Prerequisite, PHYA 227. Nationally recognized scuba certification may substitute for prerequisite. The course will follow the PADI Advanced Open water course curriculum which contains five specialty dives focusing on deep, night, peak performance buoyancy, underwater navigation, and underwater naturalist.
courses.subject: PHYA
courses.title: Advanced Open Water Scuba Diving (1)

courses.description: An analysis of the techniques, methods, and motives of group and community leaders. Special attention is focused upon the roles of organizational structure, personnel policies, and in-service training programs.
courses.subject: RECR
courses.title: Introduction to Leadership and Group Dynamics (3)

courses.description: An examination of the relationship between globalization and localization in order to think about how we, as individuals and groups, can make a difference in the world.
courses.subject: GEOG
courses.title: First-Year Seminar: Local Places in a Globalizing World (3)

courses.description: See GEOG 120 for description.
courses.subject: PWAD
courses.title: World Regional Geography (GEOG 120) (3)

courses.description: Explores how everyday culture helps create the landscapes and places in which we live and what these landscapes tell us about ourselves.
courses.subject: GEOG
courses.title: Cultural Landscapes (3)

courses.description: Open to junior and senior geography majors. Geography internships combine substantive geographic work experience with an academic project designed to integrate theory and practice. Field work is included.
courses.subject: GEOG
courses.title: Internship (3)

courses.description: Permission of the instructor. For students who wish to participate in departmental research programs. May be taken twice.
courses.subject: GEOG
courses.title: Undergraduate Research in Geography (3)

courses.description: Permission of the instructor. Special reading and research in geography under the supervision of a selected instructor. Course may not be taken more than twice.
courses.subject: GEOG
courses.title: Independent Study (1–21)

courses.description: This course provides an introduction to the application of statistical methods to geographic problems and to statistical packages in their solution. Attention given to spatial data analysis and sampling methods.
courses.subject: GEOG
courses.title: Quantitative Methods in Geography (3)

courses.description: An investigation of the physical processes that produce and change climates across space and time. Emphasis is placed on recent and predicted patterns of climate change.
courses.subject: GEOG
courses.title: Climate Change (3)

courses.description: An interdisciplinary exploration of urban social problems, bridging the literature on urban geography with that on urban politics. Students will be required to complete 30 hours of service for an organization that works on an urban social issue.
courses.subject: GEOG
courses.title: Urban Political Geography: Contested Places and Politics (3)

courses.subject: GEOG
courses.title: Cultural Ecology of Agriculture, Urbanization, and Disease (3)

courses.description: 577 Advanced Remote Sensing (3).
courses.subject: GEOG
courses.title: Introduction to GIS (PLAN 491) (3)

courses.description: See GEOG 491 for description.
courses.subject: PLAN
courses.title: Introduction to GIS (GEOG 491) (3)

courses.description: See PLAN 591 for description.
courses.subject: GEOG
courses.title: Applied Issues in Geographic Information Systems (PLAN 591) (3)

courses.description: Are technological choices open to democratic participation? Through a novel research workshop format, this graduate and undergraduate course explores political and geographical dimensions of technological change around key environmental issues—energy, water, and waste.
courses.subject: GEOG
courses.title: Technology and Democracy Workshop (3)

courses.description: History and philosophy of the geographic discipline, with particular emphasis on developments in recent decades.
courses.subject: GEOG
courses.title: Contemporary Geographic Thought (3)

courses.description: examination of the major processes controlling environmental cycling of material and energy at the landscape level, and development of a quantitative understanding of the physical and ecosystem processes responsible for landscape pattern and evolution.
courses.subject: GEOG
courses.title: Advanced Physical Geography—Biogeoscience (3)

courses.description: An in-depth seminar devoted to contemporary faculty research topics in earth system science and biophysical geography. topics and instructors vary.
courses.subject: GEOG
courses.title: Research Seminar in Earth System Science and Biophysical Geography (3)

courses.description: An in-depth seminar devoted to contemporary readings in social geography. topics and instructors vary.
courses.subject: GEOG
courses.title: Seminar/Readings in Social Geography (3)

courses.description: required preparation, two courses in the one hundred bracket or permission of the instructor.
courses.subject: GEOG
courses.title: Special Work in Geography (1–21)

courses.description: Discussions are centered on the most pressing issues of our time: environmental deterioration and construction of a sustainable (livable) world during and after the depletion of traditional energy resources.
courses.subject: GEOL
courses.title: First-Year Seminar: Energy Resources for a Hungry Planet (3)

courses.description: Major geologic events: earthquakes, volcanic activity, mountain formation, plate tectonics, and erosion. Landscape development by glaciers, streams and groundwater, ocean currents and waves, wind. Not open to students with credit in or currently enrolled in GEOL 105, 109, or 110. Optional laboratory: GEOL 101L. PX credit for GEOL 101+101L.
courses.subject: GEOL
courses.title: Introductory Geology (3)

courses.description: Major geologic events: earthquakes, volcanic activity, mountain formation, plate tectonics, and erosion. Landscape development by glaciers, streams and groundwater, ocean currents and waves, wind. Not open to students with credit in or currently enrolled in GEOL 105, 109, or 110. Optional laboratory: GEOL 101L. PX credit for GEOL 101+101L.
courses.subject: GEOL
courses.title: Introductory Geology (3)

courses.description: Fossils and the origin and evolution of life, including microand macroevolution, mass extinctions, the evolution of dinosaurs and humans, and scientific perspectives on multicultural creationism. Optional laboratory, GEOL 101L. PX credit for GEOL 159+ 101L.
courses.subject: GEOL
courses.title: Prehistoric Life (BIOL 159) (3)

courses.description: See MASC 101 for description.
courses.subject: GEOL
courses.title: The Marine Environment (MASC 101) (3)

courses.description: Earth is changing catastrophically through volcanoes, earthquakes, hurricanes, and meteoric impacts. Explore the causes and effects of these phenomena and their impact on human development. Not open to students with credit in or currently enrolled in GEOL 101, 109, or 110. Optional laboratory: GEOL 101L. PX credit for GEOL 105+101L.
courses.subject: GEOL
courses.title: Violent Earth (3)

courses.description: Interactions between earth systems. Topics include plate tectonics, climate change, history of life, and biogeochemical cycles. This course is restricted to science majors only. Optional laboratory: GEOL 101L. PX credit for GEOL 110+101L.
courses.subject: GEOL
courses.title: Earth and Climate for Science Majors (3)

courses.description: Required preparation, one introductory geology course numbered below GEOL 202, except firstyear seminar. History of the earth (including its oceans, atmosphere, and life forms) as deciphered from the geologic record. Birth of continents/oceans; evolution and extinction of life forms; the changing global environment.
courses.subject: GEOL
courses.title: Earth Systems History (3)

courses.description: Required preparation, one geology course numbered below GEOL 202, except first-year seminar. Considers the distribution, extraction, economics, and demand for mineral resources. Treats the impact of the mineral industry on industrial and preindustrial economies, economic factors, maldistribution and depletion of resources, and the environmental impact of the mineral extraction industry.
courses.subject: GEOL
courses.title: Energy Resources (3)

courses.description: Permission of the instructor. Research in geology under the supervision of a selected instructor. Approved learning contract required. May be repeated up to four times for a maximum of 12 credits.
courses.subject: GEOL
courses.title: Undergraduate Research in Geology (1–4)

courses.description: Prerequisites, GEOL 101 or 110, and GEOL 301. Introduction of principles involved in description and classification of sedimentary rocks and stratigraphic units as well as stratigraphic correlation. Students will be introduced to relationships of processes, depositional environments, and sedimentary facies.
courses.subject: GEOL
courses.title: Sedimentology and Stratigraphy (4)

courses.description: See MASC 401 for description.
courses.subject: GEOL
