courses.title: Oceanography (BIOL 350, ENVR 417, MASC 401) (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, GEOL 301. Permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisite. Studies of the origin and evolution of igneous and metamorphic rocks, including microscopic, X-ray, and field methods; volcanology; plate-tectonic interpretation of rock sequences. Three lecture and three laboratory hours a week.
courses.subject: GEOL
courses.title: Petrology and Plate Tectonics (4)

courses.description: Prerequisites, GEOL 101/101L, 103, 105/101L, 109/101L, or 110; and at least two of the four geology core courses: GEOL 301, 401, 402, and 404. This course develops the knowledge and skills teachers need to implement inquiry-based earth science instruction: conceptual knowledge of earth sciences and mastery of inquiry instructional methods. Students study inquiry in cognitive science and learning theory. This course is a requirement for the UNC–BEST program in geological sciences.
courses.subject: GEOL
courses.title: Principles and Methods of Teaching Earth Science (4)

courses.description: Prerequisites, GEOL 101, 213, 401; MATH 231. Permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisites. Descriptive account of global seismology, earthquake distribution, and focal mechanics. Principles of geometrical optics and applications to imaging the earth’s interior. Principles of seismic prospecting of hydrocarbon and geothermal reservoirs.
courses.subject: GEOL
courses.title: Principles of Seismology (3)

courses.description: See ENEC 450 for description.
courses.subject: GEOL
courses.title: Biogeochemical Processes (ENEC 450, MASC 450) (4)

courses.description: Prerequisite, Geol 159 or biol 101. Permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisites. introduction to the principles, methods of analysis, and major controversies within paleontology. examination of the fossil record and its application to problems in evolutionary biology, paleoecology, paleoclimatology, and general earth history.
courses.subject: GEOL
courses.title: Invertebrate Paleontology (BIOL 478) (4)

courses.description: See MASC 505 for description.
courses.subject: GEOL
courses.title: Chemical Oceanography (ENVR 505, MASC 505) (4)

courses.description: Prerequisites, CHEM 102; GEOL 101, 105, or 110; and MATH 231. Permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisites. Introduction to the application of chemical principles to geological problems. Topics include thermodynamics, kinetics, and isotope geochemistry.
courses.subject: GEOL
courses.title: Geochemistry (MASC 553) (3)

courses.description: Required preparation, introductory courses in geology and physics. Course is aimed at understanding the physical properties and processes controlling volcanism and magma transport. Topics covered include volcanic processes from the formation of magma in the upper mantle to violent eruption at the surface. Emphasizes dynamic processes and underlying mechanisms.
courses.subject: GEOL
courses.title: Physical Volcanology (3)

courses.description: Prerequisites, GEOL 101, 301, 401, and 402. Permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisites. Students study the origin, migration, and entrapmentof hydrocarbons in sedimentary basins and learn how several areas of the geosciences are integrated to locate and produce hydrocarbons. Students learn about these topics while analyzing a real subsurface data set.
courses.subject: GEOL
courses.title: Petroleum Geoscience (4)

courses.description: Prerequisites, Geol 417, 430, 502, 503. Permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisites. focuses on biological-physical couplings that shape coastal environments (i.e. coastal ‘ecomorphodynamics’) and determine how these environments change with climate and land use. environments include: barrier islands, open ocean coastlines, and tidal wetlands. Grading based on presentations, participation, and a research proposal.
courses.subject: GEOL
courses.title: Advanced Coastal Environmental Change (3)

courses.description: Prerequisites, CHeM 102, Geol 301, 402, and 404. survey of isotopic studies in geology; geochronology, crustal evolution, heat flow, paleotemperatures, origin of ore deposits.
courses.subject: GEOL
courses.title: Isotope Geochemistry (3)

courses.description: Internship in a sponsoring organization whose work or mission is meaningfully connected to a global studies topic.
courses.subject: GLBL
courses.title: Global Studies Internship (1)

courses.description: Permission of the instructor. Reading and research on special topics in global studies.
courses.subject: GLBL
courses.title: Independent Study (1–12)

courses.description: Survey of international social, political, and cultural patterns in selected societies of Africa, Asia, America, and Europe, stressing comparative analysis of 20th-century conflicts and change in different historical contexts. LAC recitation sections offered in French, German, and Spanish.
courses.subject: GLBL
courses.title: Global Issues in the 20th Century (ANTH 210, GEOG 210, HIST 210, POLI 210) (3)

courses.description: This academic course is mandatory for Phillips Ambassadors.
courses.subject: GLBL
courses.title: Phillips Ambassadors Program (3)

courses.description: Eight evening guest lectures, with a discussion session after each, on eight issues in current foreign policy. May be repeated for credit.
courses.subject: GLBL
courses.title: Great Decisions (1)

courses.description: This class combines fieldwork, oral history, and service learning in a course that examines concepts of globalization, migration, and transnationalism, and their intersections with anthropological theory and practice.
courses.subject: GLBL
courses.title: Latin American Migrant Perspectives: Ethnography and Action (3)

courses.description: Topics vary from semester to semester.
courses.subject: GLBL
courses.title: Current Topics in Global Studies (3)

courses.description: Preor corequisite, GLBL 381. This course links the Great Decisions lecture series with readings and analyses of international relations. Its purpose is to provide the students on the Great Decisions coordinating committee with a practical and intellectual engagement with United States foreign policy and global issues.
courses.subject: GLBL
courses.title: Great Decisions and International Relations (2)

courses.description: This course is an introduction to the history and contemporary politics of the post-Soviet region and explores topics of religious, ethnic, and identity politics; international influences; and civil society and social movements.
courses.subject: GLBL
courses.title: Soviet and Post-Soviet Politics and Institutions (3)

courses.description: This course explores some of the relationships between sports and globalization and will delve into sports as an important social and cultural practice within larger social, cultural, and political forces shaping studies of globalization.
courses.subject: GLBL
courses.title: Sports and Globalization (3)

courses.description: Current topics in global studies. Topics vary by semester.
courses.subject: GLBL
courses.title: Current Topics (3)

courses.subject: GLBL
courses.title: Global Migration And Labor Rts Lecture

courses.description: Continuation of proficiency-based instruction begun in Elementary Czech, continued.
courses.subject: CZCH
courses.title: Intermediate Czech (3)

courses.description: Permission of the instructor. Special readings and research in a selected field or topic under the direction of a faculty member.
courses.subject: DTCH
courses.title: Independent Readings in Dutch (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, DTCH 404. Permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisite. Ability to read and speak Dutch at intermediate to advanced level recommended. Introduction to Dutch literature from Middle Ages to the present. Survey of topics in Dutch culture.
courses.subject: DTCH
courses.title: Topics in Dutch Culture: A Literary Survey (3)

courses.subject: GERM
courses.title: So Africa In Lit Perspec Lecture

courses.description: See GERM 257 for description.
courses.subject: SOCI
courses.title: Society and Culture in Postwar Germany (GERM 257, HIST 257, POLI 257) (3)

courses.description: Permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisites. development of phonology and morphosyntax from ancient times to present. Political, social, and literary forces influencing the language.
courses.subject: GERM
courses.title: and 303

courses.description: Prerequisites, GerM 302 and 303. Permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisites. A study of current German structure and usage. Course strengthens the writing of graduate students and helps them confront the problems most frequently faced in speaking and teaching.
courses.subject: GERM
courses.title: Advanced German Grammar (3)

courses.description: Prerequisites, GerM 302 and 303. Permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisites. introduction to medieval German language and literature. readings in medieval German; lectures in english.
courses.subject: GERM
courses.title: Middle High German (3)

courses.description: Explores issues associated with various literary genres across various literary periods.
courses.subject: GERM
courses.title: Topics in Literary Genres (3)

courses.description: Permission of the instructor and the director of graduate studies. special readings and research in a selected field or topic outside the scope of current course offerings.
courses.subject: GERM
courses.title: Independent Readings (1–12)

courses.description: Central Europe, at the center of dramatic historical changes—WWI, emergence of independent nation states, WWII and Holocaust, Communism and its end, incorporation into the European Union—produced unprecedented cultural results. The creative voices of writers and filmmakers have relevance far beyond this region.
courses.subject: GSLL
courses.title: From Berlin to Budapest: Literature, Film, and Culture of Central Europe (3)

courses.description: This course studies magical realism in Central Euro53 First-Year Seminar: Early Germanic Culture: Myth, Magic, Murder, and Mayhem (3). Introduction to pre-Christian culture of Germany, Anglo-Saxon England, and Scandinavia from the late Roman Empire through the Viking Age, as preserved in myths, sagas, charms, inscriptions, and historical documents.
courses.subject: GSLL
courses.title: Magical Realism: Central European Literature in a Global Context (3)

courses.description: Continuation of the proficiency-based instruction begun in Elementary Hungarian, continued.
courses.subject: HUNG
courses.title: Intermediate Hungarian Language (3)

courses.description: Continuation of the proficiency-based instruction begun in Elementary Polish, continued.
courses.subject: PLSH
courses.title: Intermediate Polish (3)

courses.description: Continuation of the introductory course designed to lay the foundation of grammar and to convey basic reading and pronunciation skills.
courses.subject: RUSS
courses.title: Elementary Russian (4)

courses.description: Grammar-translation work with increasing proportions of free reading and oral work, continued.
courses.subject: RUSS
courses.title: Intermediate Russian (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, RUSS 204. Permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisite. Reading and discussion of selected authors in Russian aimed at improving reading skill and preparing the student for higher level work in Russian literature.
courses.subject: RUSS
courses.title: Introduction to Russian Literature (3)

courses.description: Russian writers and literary problems from the Revolution to the present. Lectures and readings in English.
courses.subject: RUSS
courses.title: Russian Literature after 1917 (3)

courses.description: Permission of the instructor. Directed readings in Russian on topics in literature and linguistics not normally covered in scheduled courses.
courses.subject: RUSS
courses.title: Selected Readings in Russian (1–12)

courses.description: Prerequisite, RUSS 321. Permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisite. Designed to develop conversational skills in a variety of situations and subjects. Russian used, except for a minimum of linguistic explanations or comment.
courses.subject: RUSS
courses.title: Russian Conversation (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, RUSS 406. Permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisite. A comprehensive review of Russian grammar on an advanced level, emphasizing reading and writing skills.
courses.subject: RUSS
courses.title: Advanced Russian Grammar (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, RUSS 411. Permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisite. Designed to develop conversational and writing skills in a variety of situations and subjects.
courses.subject: RUSS
courses.title: Advanced Russian Conversation and Composition (3)

courses.description: A survey of major works of Russian literature and culture in the Golden Age, an era of sociopolitical reform. Readings in English translation. Some readings in Russian for qualified students.
courses.subject: RUSS
courses.title: Great Novels and Cursed Questions: Russian Literature and Culture, 1850–1881 (3)

courses.description: Examines “The Absurd” in Russian literature and culture as it developed from the 19th century to the present. Through works by important Russian writers and representative films students encounter facets of “The Russian Absurd” viewed as literary, cultural, and social phenomena. Readings in Russian for majors, in English for nonmajors.
courses.subject: RUSS
courses.title: The Russian Absurd: Text, Stage, Screen (3)

courses.description: An introduction to the Russian short story. The readings, in English for nonmajors and in Russian for majors, include works from the 17th century to the present. Readings in Russian for majors, in English for nonmajors.
courses.subject: RUSS
courses.title: Russian Short Story (3)

courses.description: Pronunciation, structure of the language, and readings in modern Serbian and Croatian language, continued.
courses.subject: SECR
courses.title: Elementary Serbian and Croatian Language (3)

courses.description: This course examines the experiences of American writers who traveled and lived in European cities during the era between 1830 and 1930 with the goal of developing historical insights into these writers’ fascination with famous European cities and the experience of travel.
courses.subject: HIST
courses.title: First-Year Seminar: Traveling to European Cities: American Writers/Cultural Identities, 1830–1930 (3)

courses.description: This course will examine major films in Europe and America from 1908 to 1968 in terms of how they shaped the medium and reflected important social trends.
courses.subject: HIST
courses.title: First-Year Seminar: Film and History in Europe and the United States, 1908–1968 (3)

courses.description: This course explores diverse experiences of modernity among Jewish populations from the mid-18th century to the present under the influence of political, cultural, and socioeconomic changes. Diaries, memoirs, literature, and film challenge students to develop their own analyses while becoming familiar with arguments among scholars of Jewish life.
courses.subject: HIST
courses.title: First-Year Seminar: The Search for Modern Jewish Identity (3)

courses.description: A survey of Western Europe and the Mediterranean World, 300 to 1500.
courses.subject: HIST
courses.title: Medieval History (3)

courses.description: A survey of various aspects of American development during the colonial, revolutionary, and national periods, with stress upon major themes and interpretations.
courses.subject: HIST
courses.title: American History to 1865 (3)

courses.description: A survey of various aspects of American development during a century of rapid industrial, social, political, and international change, with stress upon major themes and interpretations.
courses.subject: HIST
courses.title: American History since 1865 (3)

courses.description: Comparative and interdisciplinary introduction to China and Japan in the 19th and 20th centuries, focusing on impact of the West, nation building, industrialization, and evolution of mass society.
courses.subject: HIST
courses.title: Modern East Asia (ASIA 134, PWAD 134) (3)

courses.description: A general introduction to Latin American society, culture, politics, and economics from a historical perspective. Focus will be on the events of the past two centuries.
courses.subject: HIST
courses.title: Latin America since Independence (3)

courses.description: European history from Greek antiquity to the mid-17th century.
courses.subject: HIST
courses.title: European History to 1650 (3)

courses.description: This course studies the history of the Jews of Europe and their relations with Christians. It explores the development and richness of Jewish life but also episodes of persecution. It investigates the impact of major religious and political events, such as the crusades or the Renaissance, on the Jews.
courses.subject: HIST
courses.title: Jewish History from the Crusades to the European Enlightenment (JWST 153) (3)

courses.description: Intellectual and social structures, dynamics of social and political change, principles of authority, and bases of revolution from the Reformation to the French Revolutionary and Napoleonic period.
courses.subject: HIST
courses.title: Early Modern European History, 1450–1815 (3)

courses.description: Between 862 and 1861 Russia expanded from agrarian settlements into Europe’s most formidable empire. Subjugated by Mongols in 1240, it recovered and absorbed territories from Poland to Alaska. Conquest came on the backs of an enserfed peasantry, whose emancipation began the next chapter in Russia’s history.
courses.subject: HIST
courses.title: Russia Becomes an Empire (3)

courses.description: This course surveys fundamental issues affecting the Russian/Soviet/postSoviet multinational empire in the last century and a half, emphasizing regime failures, revolutions, wars, and ethnic challenges.
courses.subject: HIST
courses.title: Russia under the Last Tsars and Soviet Commissars (3)

courses.description: The history of international politics from the fall of Napoleon to the end of the Second World War, with special attention to European nationalism, imperialism, the emergence of non-European great powers, the reasons for war, and the search for peace.
courses.subject: HIST
courses.title: International Relations, 1815–1945 (3)

courses.description: See GLBL 210 for description.
courses.subject: HIST
courses.title: Global Issues in the 20th Century (ANTH 210, GEOG 210, GLBL 210, POLI 210) (3)

courses.description: The influence of sea power on international affairs will be surveyed from ancient times to the present. Emphasis on United States naval history and its interaction with diplomacy, economics, and technology.
courses.subject: HIST
courses.title: History of Sea Power (PWAD 212) (3)

courses.description: Origins to the first two centuries CE. Focuses upon Rome’s growth as a world power and the shift from republican government to autocracy.
courses.subject: HIST
courses.title: History of Rome (3)

courses.description: This course introduces students to a tribally specific body of knowledge. The tribal focus of the course and the instructor change from term to term.
courses.subject: HIST
courses.title: Native American Tribal Studies (AMST 234, ANTH 234) (3)

courses.description: A comparative examination of the historical experiences of Latinos in the United States, from the 19th century to the present, drawing on experiences of Mexican Americans, Puerto Ricans, Dominicans, and Central Americans. Special emphasis on the events, people, and ideas that have made distinctive contributions.
courses.subject: HIST
courses.title: History of Latinos in the United States (3)

courses.description: See GERM 257 for description.
courses.subject: HIST
courses.title: Society and Culture in Postwar Germany (GERM 257, POLI 257, SOCI 257) (3)

courses.description: Anti-Semitism; the Jews of Europe; the Hitler dictatorship; evolution of Nazi Jewish policy from persecution to the Final Solution; Jewish response; collaborators, bystanders, and rescuers; aftermath.
courses.subject: HIST
courses.title: History of the Holocaust: The Destruction of the European Jews (JWST 262, PWAD 262) (3)

courses.description: See HIST 262 for description.
courses.subject: PWAD
courses.title: History of the Holocaust: The Destruction of the European Jews (HIST 262, JWST 262) (3)

courses.description: See HIST 262 for description.
courses.subject: JWST
courses.title: History of the Holocaust: The Destruction of the European Jews (HIST 262, PWAD 262) (3)

courses.description: Traces the development of sexual identities and changes in masculine and feminine ideals from Tsarist Russia through the post-Soviet period with emphasis on politics, society, and popular culture.
courses.subject: HIST
courses.title: Gender in Russian History (WMST 264) (3)

courses.description: Approaches the history of the Ottoman Empire from a world historical perspective. Situates the Ottoman imperial experience in relation to Muslim, Mongolian, and Byzantine traditions. Discusses the early modern and modern transformation of the Ottoman Empire and its legacy for contemporary Eastern Europe, the Middle East, and North Africa.
courses.subject: HIST
courses.title: History of the Ottoman Empire, 1300–1923 (3)

courses.description: Slavery in select African communities, economic and political foundations of the trans-Atlantic slave trade, and its impact on African and New World societies.
courses.subject: HIST
courses.title: The Trans-Atlantic Slave Trade (3)

courses.description: An examination of the origins of the Pacific War, the course of this bitter and momentous conflict, and its complex legacy for both Asia and the United States.
courses.subject: HIST
courses.title: The Pacific War, 1937–1945: Its Causes and Legacy (ASIA 281, PWAD 281) (3)

courses.description: China today is poised to become the next world superpower. What is the story of its modern transformation? This lecture course will introduce undergraduates to the history of 20th-century China, through a thematic approach to its culture, politics, and society. No prior coursework required.
courses.subject: HIST
courses.title: 20th-Century China (3)

courses.description: Dialogues between historiographic and fictional treatments of important historical problems. Explores works of history and literature to determine how different genres of writing give meaning to the past.
courses.subject: HIST
courses.title: Putting Literature and History in Dialogue (3)

courses.description: This team-taught course compares premodern empires, inquiring into rulers’ strategies and subject peoples’ experiences. Empires studied will depend on instructors’ areas of expertise, but may include Greeks, Romans, Chinese, Incas, West Africans, Mughals, and Ottomans, among others. We anticipate comparing three premodern empires in any given semester.
courses.subject: HIST
courses.title: Comparative Strategies of Empire (3)

courses.description: The history of warfare from its prehistoric origins to the present. The focus is on interactions between peoples around the world and particularly on the problems of innovation and adaptation.
courses.subject: HIST
courses.title: Global History of Warfare (3)

courses.description: See HIST 351 for description.
courses.subject: PWAD
courses.title: Global History of Warfare (HIST 351) (3)

courses.description: Course explores the historical significance of baseball in American life, using the history of the game to investigate topics such as industrialization, urbanization, and immigration; conflicts between labor and capital; racial prejudice and integration; patriotism and American identity; evolving gender ideals; and the role of myth in American culture.
courses.subject: HIST
courses.title: Baseball and American History (3)

courses.description: Study of the popular arts and entertainments of the 19th and 20th centuries and the ways in which they illuminate the values, assumptions, aspirations, and fears of American society.
courses.subject: HIST
courses.title: Popular Culture and American History (3)

courses.description: The history of North Carolina from the original Indian cultures to the end of the Civil War. Important topics include colonization, the American Revolution, evangelical religion, slavery, economic and political reform, the rise of sectionalism, and the Civil War.
courses.subject: HIST
courses.title: North Carolina History before 1865 (3)

courses.description: The history of North Carolina from the end of the Civil War to the present. Important topics include Reconstruction, agrarian protests, disfranchisement and segregation, industrialization and workers’ experience, the civil rights movement, and 20th-century politics.
courses.subject: HIST
courses.title: North Carolina History since 1865 (3)

courses.description: Diverse developments as interpreted within the framework of certain broad and open-ended themes, particularly individual freedom, social welfare, mass culture, and community.
courses.subject: HIST
courses.title: Politics and Society since the New Deal (3)

courses.description: Survey of African American history since emancipation in North America with some attention to experiences of people of African descent in Latin America and the Caribbean.
courses.subject: HIST
courses.title: History of African Americans, 1865 to Present (3)

courses.description: Subject matter will vary with instructor but will focus on some particular topic or historical approach. Course description available from departmental office. Closed to graduate students. Repeatable for credit.
courses.subject: HIST
courses.title: Special Topics in History (3)

courses.description: Permission of the department. The course is in general limited to 15 students. The subject matter will vary with the instructor. Each course will concern itself with a study in depth of some historical problem. Students will write a substantial research paper.
courses.subject: HIST
courses.title: Undergraduate Seminar in History (3)

courses.description: Focuses upon administrative, social, and economic themes. Conducted in considerable part by student reports and classroom discussions.
courses.subject: HIST
courses.title: The Early Roman Empire, 14 CE–193 CE (3)

courses.description: (3). A study of the people, culture, and intellectual achievements of the Italian Renaissance with emphasis on the interaction between culture and society.
courses.subject: HIST
courses.title: The Renaissance: Italy, Birthplace of the Renaissance, 1300– 1550

courses.description: This course examines the changes in German politics, culture, and society during the 20th century, with a focus on the Weimar Republic, the Third Reich and World War II, the reshaping of East and West Germany since the post-war era, and the unification in 1989.
courses.subject: HIST
courses.title: Germany since 1918: Politics, Society, and Culture (3)

courses.description: The main developments in European thought from the Enlightenment to the 20th century, with some attention to social context. Readings include Voltaire, Rousseau, Hegel, Marx, Tocqueville, Sand, Flaubert, Nietzsche, Freud.
courses.subject: HIST
courses.title: Modern European Intellectual History (3)

courses.description: See ARTH 483 for description.
courses.subject: HIST
courses.title: Art, Politics, and Society in France, 1850–1914 (ARTH 483) (3)

courses.description: A close study of Russia’s age of revolution from the reign of the last tsar to the turbulent Stalin Revolution of 1929, with emphasis on the revolutions of 1917.
courses.subject: HIST
courses.title: Revolution in Russia, 1900–1930 (3)

courses.description: Subject matter will vary with instructor but will focus on some particular topic or historical approach. Course description available from the departmental office.
courses.subject: HIST
courses.title: Special Topics in History (3)

courses.description: Permission of the director of undergraduate studies. Special reading and research, supervised by a member of the department, in a selected field of history. Prior coursework in the selected field is recommended.
courses.subject: HIST
courses.title: Independent Studies in History (1–3)

courses.description: A history of the sexual practices, desires, and understandings of Americans, from earliest colonial encounters to the late 20th century.
courses.subject: HIST
courses.title: The History of Sexuality in America (3)

courses.description: The course covers the history of black women in the United States from the 18th century to the present. It deals with such themes as work, family, community, sexuality, politics, religion, and culture.
courses.subject: HIST
courses.title: African American Women’s History (WMST 569) (3)

courses.description: See HIST 569 for description.
courses.subject: WMST
courses.title: African American Women’s History (HIST 569) (3)

courses.description: How the United States came to occupy a leading role in world affairs as a diplomatic, military, economic, and cultural power and what that role has meant to Americans and to other peoples, especially during the Cold War.
courses.subject: HIST
courses.title: United States Foreign Relations in the 20th Century (PWAD 577) (3)

courses.description: Using a classroom environment similar to HIST 581, constitutional adjustments and change are related to psychological, political, social, and economic factors, and to Supreme Court members.
courses.subject: HIST
courses.title: American Constitutional History since 1876 (3)

courses.description: Provides an introduction to teaching history. topics include the history of historical education, planning a course, the role of the teacher, goals and methods, using new technologies and evaluating students.
courses.subject: HIST
courses.title: Introduction to Historical Education (3)

courses.description: directed readings on American history from the Civil war to the present; required for students entering the field.
courses.subject: HIST
courses.title: Introductory Colloquium in United States History since 1865 (3)

courses.description: An introduction to the methods, issues, and literature of military history, including classic works and scholarship representative of a variety of approaches from history and other disciplines.
courses.subject: HIST
courses.title: Introduction to Military History (3)

courses.description: focus on the 19th and 20th centuries. Mixing theory, case studies, and comparisons, the readings reflect disciplinary diversity.
courses.subject: HIST
courses.title: Readings in Contemporary Global History (3)

courses.description: This course examines particular themes, events, and historiographical debates of Modern european History in a seminar setting.
courses.subject: HIST
courses.title: Topics in Modern European History (3)

courses.description: readings in and discussions of the major works in native American history.
courses.subject: HIST
courses.title: Readings in Native American History (AMST 878) (3)

courses.description: instructors use this course to focus on particular topics or historical approaches. specific course descriptions are available each semester on the departmental web site (www.unc.edu/depts/history).
courses.subject: HIST
courses.title: Topics in History for Graduates (3)

courses.description: Permission of the instructor. independent reading programs for graduate students whose needs are covered by no course immediately available. for students resident in Chapel Hill or vicinity.
courses.subject: HIST
courses.title: Independent Study for Graduate Students (3)

courses.description: intended to help students develop a plan of research and writing, select a bibliography, develop an understanding of the literature available for their topic, and articulatea problem or facet of the topic to which they can contribute original research in their M.A. thesis.
courses.subject: HIST
courses.title: Crafting a Historical Project (3)

courses.subject: HIST
courses.title: Ancient History (3)

courses.description: individual work on the M.A. thesis, pursued under the supervision of the M.A. advisor.

courses.title: Master’s Thesis (3)

courses.description: Content varies each semester.

courses.title: First-Year Seminar: Special Topics (3)

courses.description: A seminar in which faculty discuss their own work. Students will learn how topics are defined and investigated and how undergraduates can engage in discovery. Pass/Fail only.

courses.title: Modes of Inquiry (1)

courses.subject: ISP
courses.title: Exch In The Middle East Lecture

courses.description: Introduction to the formal analysis of human language, including sounds, words, sentences, and language meaning, plus child language acquisition, language change over time, social attitudes toward language, and similarities and differences among languages. Other topics may include writing systems, animal communication, and language analysis by computers.
courses.subject: LING
courses.title: Introduction to Language (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, LING 101. Description and analysis of sound patterns from languages around the world. Introduction to formal phonological models, written argumentation, and hypothesis testing.
courses.subject: LING
courses.title: Phonology (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, LING 101. Introduction to the goals and methods of transformational analysis, using English primarily, but examining how these techniques can be used to describe syntactic processes in other languages.
courses.subject: LING
courses.title: Syntax (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, LING 101. Provides an introduction to first-language acquisition, focusing on the acquisition of phonology, morphology, syntax, and semantics, as well as on the social context of language acquisition and issues of atypical language development.
courses.subject: LING
courses.title: Language Acquisition and Development (3)

courses.description: Comparative study of human language alongside selected nonhuman communication systems. Anatomy, acoustics, combinatorial structure, innateness and acquisition, evolution. Sizable lab and field component.
courses.subject: LING
courses.title: Human Language and Animal Communication Systems (3)

courses.description: Directed readings on linguistic topics not covered in specific courses.
courses.subject: LING
courses.title: Advanced Topics in Linguistics (3)

courses.description: Permission of the instructor for undergraduates. Methods and theory of grammatical analysis within the transformational generative framework. Special emphasis on analyzing syntactic and semantic structures of English.
courses.subject: LING
courses.title: Syntactic Theory I (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, LING 101. Introduction to topics in logic, set theory, and modern algebra with emphasis on linguistic application. Automata theory and the formal theory of grammar with special reference to transformational grammars. No previous mathematics assumed.
courses.subject: LING
courses.title: Mathematical Linguistics (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, LING 101 or 400. This course explores the phonological and morphological structure of selected Amerindian languages indigenous to the Americas. Emphasis is on the linguistic analysis of original as well as published primary data.
courses.subject: LING
courses.title: Native Languages of the Americas (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, linG 533. Permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisite. examination of recent developments in the theory and methods of syntactic analysis.
courses.subject: LING
courses.title: Advanced Methods in Syntax (3)

courses.description: Special topics course\. Content will vary each semester.
courses.subject: LTAM
courses.title: First Year Seminar: Special Topics (3)

courses.description: Independent project to be arranged with an instructor.
courses.subject: LTAM
courses.title: Independent Study (1–3)

courses.description: We will expand our horizons in biology by learningabout some of the most extreme microorganisms on the planet - microorganisms that thrive without oxygen, under high temperatures (e.g., in pressurized waterabove the boiling point), and under chemical stress factors that were once thought to be incompatible with life. Numerous representatives of thesemicroorganisms can be cultured in the laboratory; others have been observed in nature but have so far resisted being tamed. We will look into the unusualhabitats where these organisms are found, for example hot springs and volcanic areas on land (Yellowstone) and in the ocean (deep-sea hydrothermal vents).We will also study their evolution during EarthÀs early history, and learn about the potential of extreme microorganisms as model cases and analogs for lifeelsewhere in the universe. ABOUT THE INSTRUCTOR: Andreas Teske is a biochemist by training, but became fascinated by the microbial world of the oceans andfocused his Ph.D. research on the ecology and diversity of marine bacteria that catalyze the sulfur cycle. After completing his Ph.D.
courses.subject: MASC
courses.title: Fys Microorganisms Lecture

courses.description: An overview of the scientific basis for global warming, current and future impacts on society, options for mitigation and adaptation, and the role of politics and the media.
courses.subject: MASC
courses.title: Our Changing Planet: Science, Social Impacts, Solutions (3)

courses.description: Permission of a faculty research director. Directed readings with laboratory study on a selected topic.
courses.subject: MASC
courses.title: Undergraduate Research in Marine Sciences (2–4)

courses.description: Permission of the instructor. Directed readings on a selected topic.
courses.subject: MASC
courses.title: Independent Study in Marine Sciences (1–3)

courses.description: Required preparation, major in a natural science or two courses in natural sciences. Studies origin of ocean basins, seawater chemistry and dynamics, biological communities, sedimentary record, andoceanographic history. Term paper. Students lacking science background should see MASC 101. No credit for MASC 401 after receiving credit for MASC 101.
courses.subject: MASC
courses.title: Oceanography (BIOL 350, ENVR 417, GEOL 403) (3)

courses.description: What are the linkages between rivers and global change? This course examines the hydrological, geological, and biogeochemical processes that control material flux from land to the oceans via rivers.
courses.subject: MASC
courses.title: Major Rivers and Global Change: Mountains to the Sea (3)

courses.description: This course introduces students to the physiological, morphological, and behavioral factors employed by marine organisms to cope with their physical environment. Emphasis will be placed on the response of marine organisms to environmental factors such as seawater temperature, light, water salinity, ocean acidification, etc.
courses.subject: MASC
courses.title: Marine Physiological Ecology (3)

courses.description: See ENEC 450 for description.
courses.subject: MASC
courses.title: Biogeochemical Processes (ENEC 450, GEOL 450) (4)

courses.description: Prerequisite, MATH 232. Permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisite. Principles and applications of fluid dynamics to flows of air and water in the natural environment. Conservation of momentum, mass, and energy applied to lakes, rivers, estuaries, and the coastal ocean. Dimensional analysis and scaling emphasized to promote problem-solving skills.
courses.subject: MASC
courses.title: Fluid Dynamics of the Environment (3)

courses.description: For graduate students; undergraduates need permission of the instructor. Marine ecosystem processes pertaining to the structure, function, and ecological interactions of biological communities; management of biological resources; taxonomy and natural history of pelagic and benthic marine organisms. Three lecture and one recitation hours per week. Two mandatory weekend fieldtrips.
courses.subject: MASC
courses.title: Biological Oceanography (BIOL 657, ENVR 520) (4)

courses.description: Graduate students only; undergraduates must have permission of the instructor. Overview of chemical processes in the ocean. Topics include physical chemistry of seawater, major element cycles, hydrothermal vents, geochemical tracers, air-sea gas exchange, particle transport, sedimentary processes, and marine organic geochemistry. Three lecture and two recitation hours per week.
courses.subject: MASC
courses.title: Chemical Oceanography (ENVR 505, GEOL 505) (4)

courses.description: Prerequisite, PHYS 301. Permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisite. The physical properties of fluids, kinematics, governing equations, viscous incompressible flow, vorticity dynamics, boundary layers, irrotational incompressible flow.
courses.subject: MASC
courses.title: Fluid Dynamics (ENVR 452, GEOL 560, PHYS 660) (3)

courses.description: discussion of theories and contemporary research in ocean systems. topics stress interactions between physical, chemical, geological, and biological processes in the sea. for graduate students in marine sciences. students who enroll must present an interdisciplinary seminar.
courses.subject: MASC
courses.title: Seminar in Oceanography (1)

courses.description: Prerequisites, MAsC 506 and 560. Physics of sub-mesoscale processes in the ocean. nonequilibrium thermodynamics. Air-sea interaction. Mixing in the ocean boundary layer, convection, double diffusion. near-inertial and high frequency internal waves. Three lecture hours a week.
courses.subject: MASC
courses.title: Small-Scale Physics of the Ocean (3)

courses.description: see MAtH 769 for description.
courses.subject: MASC
courses.title: Mathematical Modeling II (MATH 769, ENVR 764) (3)

courses.description: 993 Master’s Thesis (3–21).
courses.subject: MASC
courses.title: Research in Marine Sciences (2–21)

courses.description: Students will explore the relevance of mathematical ideas to fields typically perceived as “nonmathematical” (e.g., art, music, film, literature) and how these “nonmathematical” fields influence mathematical thought.
courses.subject: MATH
courses.title: First-Year Seminar: Math, Art, and the Human Experience (3)

courses.description: Students will discuss combinatorics’ deep roots in history, its connections with the theory of numbers, and its fundamental role for natural science, as well as various applications, including cryptography and the stock market.
courses.subject: MATH
courses.title: First-Year Seminar: Combinatorics (3)

courses.description: Special topics course. Content will vary each semester.
courses.subject: MATH
courses.title: First-Year Seminar: Special Topics (3)

courses.description: Placement by achievement test. Provides a onesemester review of the basics of algebra. Basic algebraic expressions, functions, exponents, and logarithms are included, with an emphasis on problem solving. This course should not be taken by those with a suitable score on the achievement test.
courses.subject: MATH
courses.title: Algebra (3)

courses.description: Provides an introduction in as nontechnical a setting as possible to the basic concepts of calculus. The course is intended for the nonscience major. A student may not receive credit for this course after receiving credit for MATH 152, 231, or 241.
courses.subject: MATH
courses.title: Intuitive Calculus (3)

courses.description: Introduction to basic concepts of finite mathematics, including topics such as counting methods, finite probability problems, and networks. The course is intended for the nonscience major.
courses.subject: MATH
courses.title: Aspects of Finite Mathematics (3)

courses.description: Introduction to mathematical topics of current interest in society and science, such as the mathematics of choice, growth, finance, and shape. The course is intended for the nonscience major.
courses.subject: MATH
courses.title: Aspects of Modern Mathematics (3)

courses.description: Provides an introduction to the use of mathematics for modeling real-world phenomena in a nontechnical setting. Models use algebraic, graphical, and numerical properties of elementary functions to interpret data. This course is intended for the nonscience major.
courses.subject: MATH
courses.title: Introduction to Mathematical Modeling (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, MATH 110. Covers the basic mathematical skills needed for learning calculus. Topics are calculating and working with functions and data, introduction to trigonometry, parametric equations, and the conic sections. A student may not receive credit for this course after receiving credit for MATH 231.
courses.subject: MATH
courses.title: Precalculus Mathematics (3)

courses.description: Requires a grade of Cor better in MATH 231 or 241 or placement by the department. Calculus of the elementary transcendental functions, techniques of integration, indeterminate forms, Taylor’s formula, infinite series.
courses.subject: MATH
courses.title: Calculus of Functions of One Variable II (3)

courses.description: Requires a grade of Cor better in either MATH 231 or 241, or placement by the department. Techniques of integration, indeterminate forms, Taylor’s series; introductionto linear algebra, motivated by and applied to ordinary differential equations; systems of ordinary differential equations used to model various biological processes. A student cannot receive credit for this course after receiving credit for MATH 383.
courses.subject: MATH
courses.title: BioCalculus II (3)

courses.description: Permission of the director of undergraduate studies. Experimentation or deeper investigation under the supervision of a faculty member of topics in mathematics that may be, but need not be, connected with an existing course. No one may receive more than seven semester hours of credit for this course.
courses.subject: MATH
courses.title: Directed Exploration in Mathematics (0–3)

courses.description: Central to teaching precollege mathematics is the need for an in-depth understanding of real numbers and algebra. This course explores this content, emphasizing problem solving and mathematical reasoning.
courses.subject: MATH
courses.title: Revisiting Real Numbers and Algebra (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, MATH 232 or 283. This course serves as a transition from computational to more theoretical mathematics. Topics are from the foundations of mathematics: logic, set theory, relations and functions, induction, permutations and combinations, recurrence.
courses.subject: MATH
courses.title: Discrete Mathematics (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, MATH 233. Introductory ordinary differential equations, firstand second-order differential equations with applications, higher-order linear equations, systems of first-order linear equations (introducing linear algebra as needed).
courses.subject: MATH
courses.title: First Course in Differential Equations (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, MATH 233. Introductory ordinary differential equations, firstand second-order differential equations with applications, higher-order linear equations, systems of first-order linear equations (introducing linear algebra as needed).
courses.subject: MATH
courses.title: First Course in Differential Equations (3)

courses.description: Study of how people learn and understand mathematics, based on research in mathematics, mathematics education, psychology, and cognitive science. This course is designed to prepare undergraduate mathematics majors to become excellent high school mathematics teachers. It involves fieldwork in both the high school and college environments.
courses.subject: MATH
courses.title: Teaching and Learning Mathematics (4)

courses.description: Permission of the instructor. An investigation of various ways elementary concepts in mathematics can be developed. Applications of the mathematics developed will be considered.
courses.subject: MATH
courses.title: Developing Mathematical Concepts (3)

courses.description: Prerequisites, MATH 233 and 381. The real numbers, continuity and differentiability of functions of one variable, infinite series, integration.
courses.subject: MATH
courses.title: Advanced Calculus I (3)

courses.description: Prerequisites, MATH 383 and 521. Functions of several variables, the derivative as a linear transformation, inverse and implicit function theorems, multiple integration.
courses.subject: MATH
courses.title: Advanced Calculus II (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, MATH 383. The algebra of complex numbers, elementary functions and their mapping properties, complex limits, power series, analytic functions, contour integrals, Cauchy’s theorem and formulae, Laurent series and residue calculus, elementary conformal mapping and boundary value problems, Poisson integral formula for the disk and the half plane.
courses.subject: MATH
courses.title: Functions of a Complex Variable with Applications (3)

courses.description: Prerequisites, MATH 383; and PHYS 104 and 105, or PHYS 114 and 115, or PHYS 116 and 117, or PHYS 118 and 119. Theory and applications of Laplace transform, Fourier series and transform, SturmLiouville problems. Students will be expected to do some numerical calculations on either a programmable calculator or a computer. This course has an optional computer laboratory component: MATH 528L.
courses.subject: MATH
courses.title: Mathematical Methods for the Physical Sciences I (3)

courses.description: Prerequisites, MATH 383; and PHYS 104 and 105, or PHYS 114 and 115, or PHYS 116 and 117, or PHYS 118 and 119. Theory and applications of Laplace transform, Fourier series and transform, SturmLiouville problems. Students will be expected to do some numerical calculations on either a programmable calculator or a computer. This course has an optional computer laboratory component: MATH 528L.
courses.subject: MATH
courses.title: Mathematical Methods for the Physical Sciences I (3)

courses.description: Prerequisites, PHYS 104 or 114, PHYS 105 or 115, and one of MATH 521, 524, or 528. Introduction to boundary value problems for the diffusion, Laplace and wave partial differential equations. Bessel functions and Legendre functions. Introduction to complex variables including the calculus of residues. This course has an optional computer laboratory component: MATH 529L.
courses.subject: MATH
courses.title: Mathematical Methods for the Physical Sciences II (3)

courses.description: Prerequisites, PHYS 104 or 114, PHYS 105 or 115, and one of MATH 521, 524, or 528. Introduction to boundary value problems for the diffusion, Laplace and wave partial differential equations. Bessel functions and Legendre functions. Introduction to complex variables including the calculus of residues. This course has an optional computer laboratory component: MATH 529L.
courses.subject: MATH
courses.title: Mathematical Methods for the Physical Sciences II (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, MATH 381. Binary operations, groups, subgroups, cosets, quotient groups, rings, polynomials.
courses.subject: MATH
courses.title: Elements of Modern Algebra (3)

courses.description: See STOR 435 for description.
courses.subject: MATH
courses.title: Introduction to Probability (STOR 435) (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, MATH 233. Introduction to the mathematical theory of probability, covering random variables; moments; binomial, Poisson, normal and related distributions; generating functions; sums and sequences of random variables; and statistical applications.
courses.subject: STOR
courses.title: Introduction to Probability (MATH 535) (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, MATH 381. Topics chosen from generating functions, Polya’s theory of counting, partial orderings and incidence algebras, principle of inclusion-exclusion, Moebius inversion, combinatorial problems in physics and other branches of science.
courses.subject: MATH
courses.title: Combinatorial Mathematics (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, MATH 383. Topics will vary and may include iteration of maps, orbits, periodic points, attractors, symbolic dynamics, bifurcations, fractal sets, chaotic systems, systems arising from differential equations, iterated function systems, and applications.
courses.subject: MATH
courses.title: Introduction to Dynamics (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, MATH 283 or 383. Requires some knowledge of computer programming. Model validation and numerical simulations using differential equations, probability, and iterated maps. Applications may include conservation laws, dynamics, mixing, geophysical flows and climate change, fluid motion, epidemics, ecological models, population biology, cell biology, and neuron dynamics.
courses.subject: MATH
courses.title: Mathematical Modeling (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, MATH 547 or 577. Permutation groups, matrix groups, groups of linear transformations, symmetry groups; finite abelian groups. Residue class rings, algebra of matrices, linear maps, and polynomials. Real and complex numbers, rational functions, quadratic fields, finite fields.
courses.subject: MATH
courses.title: Algebraic Structures (3)

courses.description: See STOR 635 for description.
courses.subject: MATH
courses.title: Probability (STOR 635) (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, MATH 653. A rigorous treatment of complex integration, including the Cauchy theory. Elementary special functions, power series, local behavior of analytic functions.
courses.subject: MATH
courses.title: Complex Analysis (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, MATH 653. Requires knowledge of linear algebra. Existence and uniqueness theorems, linear and nonlinear systems, differential equations in the plane and on surfaces, Poincare-Bendixson theory, Lyapunov stability and structural stability, critical point analysis.
courses.subject: MATH
courses.title: Qualitative Theory of Differential Equations (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, MATH 661. Theory and practical issues arising in linear algebra problems derived from physical applications, e.g., discretization of ODEs and PDEs. Linear systems, linear least squares, eigenvalue problems, singular value decomposition.
courses.subject: MATH
courses.title: Scientific Computation II (COMP 662, ENVR 662) (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, MATH 668. Perturbation methods for ODEs and PDEs, WKBJ method, averaging and modulation theory for linear and nonlinear wave equations, long-time asymptotics of Fourier integral representations of PDEs, Green’s functions, dynamical systems tools.
courses.subject: MATH
courses.title: Methods of Applied Mathematics II (ENVR 669) (3)

courses.description: Internal structure of groups, Sylow theorems, generators and relations, group representations, fields, Galois theory, category theory.
courses.subject: MATH
courses.title: Groups, Representations, and Fields (3)

courses.description: Prerequisites, MATH 653 and 680. Topological spaces, connectedness, separation axioms, product spaces, extension theorems. Classification of surfaces, fundamental group, covering spaces.
courses.subject: MATH
courses.title: Introductory Topology (3)

courses.description: Prerequisites, MAtH 668, 669, 661, and 662. Current modelsin science and technology: topics ranging from material science applications (e.g., flow of polymers and lCPs); geophysical applications (e.g., ocean circulation, quasi-geostrophic models, atmospheric vortices).
courses.subject: MATH
courses.title: Mathematical Modeling II (ENVR 764, MASC 784) (3)

courses.description: Prerequisites, MAtH 681 and 676. Homotopy and homology; simplicial complexes and singular homology; other topics may include cohomology, universal coefficient theorems, higher homotopy groups, fibre spaces.
courses.subject: MATH
courses.title: Algebraic Topology (3)

courses.description: Advance topics in current research in statistics and operations research.
courses.subject: MATH
courses.title: Special Topics (1–3)

courses.description: Prerequisites, MAtH 661 and 662. topics may include: finite element method; numerical methods for hyperbolic conservation laws, infinite dimensional optimization problems, variational inequalities, inverse problems.
courses.subject: MATH
courses.title: Topics in Computational Mathematics (3)

courses.description: 921 Seminar (3).
courses.subject: MATH
courses.title: Seminar and Directed Readings (1–3)

courses.description: Drill and ceremony, marksmanship, land navigation exercises, first aid, small unit tactics, and confidence course training. Strongly encouraged for all basic course students and required for all advanced course students.
courses.subject: ARMY
courses.title: Leadership Laboratory (0)

courses.description: Builds on ARMY 101 by offering an introduction to basic leadership theories and techniques common to both corporate America and the Army: understanding your own cognitive preferences and learning style, active listening, developmental counseling, problem solving, types and formats of briefings, communicating orally and in writing, leader values.
courses.subject: ARMY
courses.title: Adventures in Leadership (1)

courses.description: Permission of the department. A detailed examination of current topics regarding the United States Army. Provides a course for Army ROTC cadets who require additional coursework to meet commissioning and/or scholarship requirements due to extenuating circumstances.
courses.subject: ARMY
courses.title: Seminar in Selected Topics of Military Science (1–3)

courses.description: Introduction to planning, organizing, and leading small unit offensive and defensive operations. Also study of how application of leadership principles forges Army teams. Required for cadets.
courses.subject: ARMY
courses.title: Tactical Leadership (2)

courses.description: Prerequisite, ARMY 301. Permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisite. Study of doctrine, organization, equipment, and training of threat forces around the world. Continued development of abilities to conduct offensive and defensive operations building to platoon level. Required for cadets.
courses.subject: ARMY
courses.title: Advanced Military Operations (3)

courses.description: Permission of the department. introduction to materials fabrication techniques. includes single crystal growth, thin film deposition, synthesis of quantum dots and nanotubes/ nanowires, dielectric and electron emissive materials, nanocomposites, bioceramics, and energy storage materials.
courses.subject: MTSC
courses.title: Materials Fabrication (3)

courses.description: Permission of the department. lecture and laboratory in materials analysis techniques, including optical microscopy, scanning electron microscopy, transmission electron microscopy, X-ray diffraction, fluorescence, nuclear magnetic resonance, raman spectroscopy, thermal analysis, XPs, channeling and rbs.
courses.subject: MTSC
courses.title: Techniques in Materials Science (3)

courses.description: Permission of the department.
courses.subject: MTSC
courses.title: Master’s Thesis (3–6)

courses.title: Fundamentals of Music I (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, MUSC 123. Basic principles of diction for singers in German.
courses.subject: MUSC
courses.title: Diction for Singers III (German) (1)

courses.description: Corequisite, MUSC 131 or 131H. Basic musicianship skills, including music notation, basic composition, score analysis, keyboard, sight singing, and ear training.

courses.title: Musicianship Skills I (1)

courses.title: Theory I (3)

courses.description: May not count for music or general elective credit for music majors. The study of selected works from the Western art tradition, with an emphasis on critical understanding.

courses.title: Great Musical Works (3)

courses.description: An introductory hands-on study of the composition of electronic instrumental tracks for hip-hop and dance music. Students make beats, learn about the history and culture of the art form, and examine beat making as a case study in entrepreneurship.

courses.title: Beat Making Lab (3)

courses.description: An introduction to issues of performance practice in rock music and related styles and genres including, but not limited to, soul, funk, new wave, and punk. Through intensive coaching and rehearsal students learn performance, transcription, arranging, and improvisation.
courses.subject: MUSC
courses.title: Rock Lab (3)

courses.description: Prerequisites, MUSC 130, and 131 or 131H. The study of compositional techniques and the development of individual creative styles through imitative and original writing.
courses.subject: MUSC
courses.title: Introduction to Composition (3)

courses.description: Advanced individual lessons in piano, organ, or harpsichord. Sections by instructor.

courses.title: Advanced Individual Lessons in Keyboard (2)

courses.description: Advanced individual lessons in violin, viola, cello, string bass, harp, or guitar. Sections by instructor.

courses.title: Advanced Individual Lessons in Strings (2)

courses.description: Advanced individual lessons in flute, oboe, clarinet, saxophone, or bassoon. Sections by instructor.

courses.title: Advanced Individual Lessons in Woodwinds (2)

courses.description: Advanced individual lessons in horn, trumpet, trombone, tuba or euphonium. Sections by instructor.

courses.title: Advanced Individual Lessons in Brass (2)

courses.description: Sections by instructor.

courses.title: Advanced Individual Lessons in Percussion (2)

courses.description: Sections by ensemble: Symphony Orchestra, Band, Carolina Choir, Chamber Singers, Men’s Glee Club, Women’s Glee Club, Piano Ensemble I, Piano Ensemble II, Collaborative Piano, Guitar Ensemble, Jazz Band.

courses.title: Ensemble I (1)

courses.description: Sections include Opera Workshop, Percussion Ensemble, Gamelan, Charanga Carolina, Global Rhythms.

courses.title: Ensemble II (1)

courses.description: Primarily for students pursing teacher licensure. An introduction to basic performance skills on representative woodwind, brass, percussion, and string instruments.
