courses.description: Primarily for students pursuing teacher licensure. An introduction to basic performance skills in voice and piano, and approaches to teaching elementary music.
courses.subject: MUSC
courses.title: Keyboard, Vocal, and Elementary Music Techniques (3)

courses.description: Prerequisites, MUSC 120 and 131. Through the use of various ethnomusicological methodologies, students explore a range of non-Western musical systems in their cultural contexts. Topics of study may include aesthetic theories, cultural meaning, and conflict.
courses.subject: MUSC
courses.title: World Musics in Theory and Practice (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, MUSC 136. Continues the development of keyboard skills established in MUSC 136.
courses.subject: MUSC
courses.title: Keyboard Skills II (1)

courses.description: The study of music in its historical and cultural contexts in the medieval and early modern eras.
courses.subject: MUSC
courses.title: Studies in Medieval and Early Modern Music (3)

courses.description: Prerequisites, MUSC 132 and 254. Permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisites. A continuation of MUSC 254, surveying music of the period since 1750 in its stylistic, geographical, political, social, and cultural contexts.
courses.subject: MUSC
courses.title: Studies in Music History II, 1750 to the Present (3)

courses.description: Prerequisites, MUSC 135 and 163. Composing and arranging for smalland large-group jazz ensembles.
courses.subject: MUSC
courses.title: Jazz Composition and Arranging (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, MUSC 166. May be repeated for credit. Original compositions in various forms.
courses.subject: MUSC
courses.title: Composition (3)

courses.description: Connecting academic inquiry in community music with an experiential project in the making, organization, or documentation of music locally.
courses.subject: MUSC
courses.title: Music in the Community (3)

courses.description: May be repeated for credit if on a different topic. May not count for music or general elective credit for music majors. Music in the framework of its social, political, economic, and cultural contexts.
courses.subject: MUSC
courses.title: Music as Culture (3)

courses.subject: MUSC
courses.title: Sounds Of War And Revolution Lecture

courses.description: The relationship between music and politics studied through a global range of historical and geographical contexts. The course covers specific musical and political manifestations as well as theoretical approaches to the issue.
courses.subject: MUSC
courses.title: Music and Politics (3)

courses.description: Available only to music majors by permission of the director of undergraduate studies. Intensive study on a particular topic under faculty supervision.
courses.subject: MUSC
courses.title: Special Studies for Undergraduates (1–3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, MUSC 200. Advanced individual keyboard lessons leading to a public recital.
courses.subject: MUSC
courses.title: Advanced Keyboard Lessons and Recital (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, MUSC 202. Advanced individual voice lessons leading to a public recital.
courses.subject: MUSC
courses.title: Advanced Voice Lessons and Recital (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, MUSC 203. Advanced individual string lessons leading to a public recital.
courses.subject: MUSC
courses.title: Advanced String Lessons and Recital (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, MUSC 204. Advanced individual woodwind lessons leading to a public recital.
courses.subject: MUSC
courses.title: Advanced Woodwind Lessons and Recital (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, MUSC 205. Advanced individual brass lessons leading to a public recital.
courses.subject: MUSC
courses.title: Advanced Brass Lessons and Recital (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, MUSC 206. Advanced individual percussion lessons leading to a public recital.
courses.subject: MUSC
courses.title: Advanced Percussion Lessons and Recital (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, MUSC 168. Intermediate conducting for instrumental or vocal ensembles.
courses.subject: MUSC
courses.title: Intermediate Lessons in Conducting (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, MUSC 308. May be repeated for up to six hours of credit. Advanced conducting for instrumental or choral ensembles.
courses.subject: MUSC
courses.title: Advanced Lessons in Conducting (3)

courses.description: Prerequisites, MUSC 132 and 232. The study of analytical techniques as applied to significant works of the period.
courses.subject: MUSC
courses.title: Analysis of Music since 1900 (3)

courses.description: Prerequisites, MUSC 132 or 132H, and 133; corequisite, MUSC 232. A continuation of MUSC 133, with emphasis on intermediateto advanced-level musicianship skills.
courses.subject: MUSC
courses.title: Musicianship Skills III (1)

courses.description: Prerequisite, MUSC 254. Course will address a particular genre, composer, compositional issue, or repertoire, including non-Western and popular musics. Subject matter will vary with the instructor. May be repeated for credit if on a different topic.
courses.subject: MUSC
courses.title: History and Culture of Music (3)

courses.description: Advanced study of selected performance issues. Maybe repeated for credit.
courses.subject: MUSC
courses.title: Instrumental Performance Repertory (3)

courses.description: Permission of the director of undergraduate studies. Internship directly related to the study, practice, or the business of music. Students must complete at least 100 hours and submit a journal and report upon completion of the internship.
courses.subject: MUSC
courses.title: Music Internship (3)

courses.description: Co-requisite, MUsC 991.
courses.subject: MUSC
courses.title: Doctoral Dissertation (3)

courses.description: A study of organizational principles, management theory, and leadership styles, with emphasis on applications in the Navy and Department of Defense.
courses.subject: NAVS
courses.title: Naval Leadership and Management (3)

courses.description: A descriptive survey course in engineering aspects of ships weapons guidance, control, and propulsion systems and characteristics of ships weapons systems.
courses.subject: NAVS
courses.title: Naval Weapons Systems (3)

courses.description: A study of the maneuvering of ships in formation, and the operations in which naval vessels engage daily.
courses.subject: NAVS
courses.title: Naval Operations (4)

courses.description: The goal of the course is to get a mature and correctunderstanding of race, racism, and affirmative action. ABOUT THE INSTRUCTOR: Bernard Boxill is the Pardue Distinguished Professor in the Department ofPhilosophy. Professor Boxill works in social and political philosophy and African American philosophy.
courses.subject: PHIL
courses.title: Fys Race & Affirm Action Lecture

courses.description: This seminar examines theoretical issues, relativism, utilitarianism, deontological ethics, and virtue ethics.
courses.subject: PHIL
courses.title: First-Year Seminar: Ethics: Theoretical and Practical (3)

courses.description: An introduction to philosophy focusing on a few central problems, for example: free will, the basis of morality, the nature and limits of knowledge, and the existence of God.
courses.subject: PHIL
courses.title: Introduction to Philosophy: Main Problems (3)

courses.description: A course on how to identify, analyze, and evaluate arguments by other people and how to construct arguments. Topics include argument reconstruction, informal logic, fallacies, introductory formal logic, probabilistic reasoning.
courses.subject: PHIL
courses.title: Critical Thinking (3)

courses.description: A philosophical inquiry into the problems of religious experience and belief, as expressed in philosophic, religious, and literary documents from traditional and contemporary sources.
courses.subject: PHIL
courses.title: Philosophy of Western Religion (RELI 126) (3)

courses.description: See PHIL 134 for description.
courses.subject: RELI
courses.title: Philosophy of Western Religion (PHIL 134) (3)

courses.description: Introduces the theory of deductive reasoning, using a symbolic language to represent and evaluate patterns of reasoning. Covers sentential logic and first-order predicate logic.
courses.subject: PHIL
courses.title: Introduction to Mathematical Logic (3)

courses.description: Exploration of different philosophical perspectives about right and wrong, personal character, justice, moral reasoning, and moral conflicts. Readings drawn from classic or contemporary sources. Critical discussion emphasized.
courses.subject: PHIL
courses.title: Introduction to Ethics (3)

courses.description: Exploration of different philosophical perspectives about right and wrong, personal character, justice, moral reasoning, and moral conflicts. Readings drawn from classic or contemporary sources. Critical discussion emphasized.
courses.subject: PHIL
courses.title: Introduction to Ethics (3)

courses.description: Topics may include war, medical ethics, media ethics, sexual ethics, business ethics, racism, sexism, capital punishment, and the environment.
courses.subject: PHIL
courses.title: Practical Ethics (3)

courses.description: An examination of ethical issues in the life sciences and technologies, medicine, public health and/or human interaction with nonhuman animals or the living environment.
courses.subject: PHIL
courses.title: Bioethics (3)

courses.description: An examination of major issues in political philosophy, e.g., liberty, individual rights, social responsibility, legal authority, civil authority, civil disobedience. Readings include classical and contemporary writings.
courses.subject: PHIL
courses.title: Social Ethics and Political Thought (3)

courses.description: An examination of major issues in political philosophy, e.g., liberty, individual rights, social responsibility, legal authority, civil authority, civil disobedience. Readings include classical and contemporary writings.
courses.subject: PHIL
courses.title: Social Ethics and Political Thought (3)

courses.description: The emergence of philosophy in Greece during the sixth century BCE and its development during the classical period. The major figures studied are the Pre-Socratic philosophers, Socrates, Plato, and Aristotle.
courses.subject: PHIL
courses.title: Ancient Greek Philosophy (3)

courses.description: An analysis of the moral significance of sports, the nature of sport and competition, and issues such as racism, gender equity, violence, and performance-enhancing drugs.
courses.subject: PHIL
courses.title: Ethics of Sports (3)

courses.description: An analysis of ethical issues that arise in peace, war, and defense, e.g., the legitimacy of states, just war theory, terrorism, weapons of mass destruction.
courses.subject: PHIL
courses.title: The Ethics of Peace, War, and Defense (POLI 272, PWAD 272) (3)

courses.description: See PHIL 272 for description.
courses.subject: PWAD
courses.title: The Ethics of Peace, War, and Defense (PHIL 272, POLI 272) (3)

courses.description: Race, identity, discrimination, multiculturalism, affirmative action, and slave reparations in the writings of Walker, Delany, Douglass, Cooper, DuBois, King, and Malcolm X.
courses.subject: PHIL
courses.title: African American Political Philosophy (3)

courses.description: Required preparation, two prior courses in philosophy and permission of the instructor. This course combines on-campus structured learning with substantial on-site field work incorporating philosophy into the primary and/or secondary school curriculum. Philosophy subjects and school partners will vary by semester.
courses.subject: PHIL
courses.title: Introducing and Integrating Philosophy into Primary and Secondary Schools (3)

courses.description: The mind-body problem, the nature of thinking, the puzzles of consciousness, and the qualitative character of felt experience.
courses.subject: PHIL
courses.title: Philosophy of Mind (3)

courses.description: See PHYS 354 for description.
courses.subject: PHIL
courses.title: Quantum Mechanics, Weirdness, and Reality (PHYS 354) (3)

courses.description: Prerequisites, MATH 231 and any PHYS course numbered 100 or greater. Permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisites. An interdisciplinary course on the weirdness of quantum mechanics and the problem of interpreting it. Nonlocality, the measurement problem, superpositions, Bohm’s theory, collapse theories, and the many-worlds interpretation.
courses.subject: PHYS
courses.title: Quantum Mechanics, Weirdness, and Reality (PHIL 354) (3)

courses.description: PHIL 160 recommended. Major developments in the history of moral philosophy, from Plato to Nietzsche.
courses.subject: PHIL
courses.title: History of Ethics (3)

courses.description: Intensive exploration and discussion of selected topics in philosophy.
courses.subject: PHIL
courses.title: Seminar in Selected Topics (3)

courses.description: Permission of the instructor. See the director of undergraduate studies of the department.
courses.subject: PHIL
courses.title: Directed Readings (1–3)

courses.description: Students will present papers on selected topics for critical discussion. Recommended for philosophy majors in their junior year.
courses.subject: PHIL
courses.title: Colloquium for Philosophy Majors (3)

courses.description: An examination of some representative works of Aristotle, with reference to common emphases and basic problems, together with an analysis of their philosophic content.
courses.subject: PHIL
courses.title: Aristotle (3)

courses.description: Two courses in philosophy other than PHIL 155 strongly recommended. Frege, Russell, Moore, and Wittgenstein among others are considered.
courses.subject: PHIL
courses.title: The Beginnings of Analytic Philosophy (3)

courses.description: The natureof historical explanation, structural and functional explanation, the weighing of historical testimony, the concept of meaning, normative judgments, and predictions in the social sciences.
courses.subject: PHIL
courses.title: Philosophy, History, and the Social Sciences (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, PHil 384. This capstone course advances PHil 384, focusing on such theoretical and philosophical issues as the analysis of rights or distributive justice and the institutional implications of moral forms.
courses.subject: PHIL
courses.title: Philosophy, Politics, and Economics II: Capstone Course (ECON 698, POLI 698) (3)

courses.subject: PHIL
courses.title: Research Seminar in Philosophy of Mind (3)

courses.description: Celestial motions of the earth, sun, moon, and planets; nature of light; ground and space-based telescopes; comparative planetology; the earth and the moon; terrestrial and gas planets and their moons; dwarf planets, asteroids, and comets; planetary system formation; extrasolar planets; the search for extraterrestrial intelligence (SETI).
courses.subject: ASTR
courses.title: Introduction to Astronomy: The Solar System (3)

courses.description: Celestial motions of the earth, sun, moon, and planets; nature of light; ground and space-based telescopes; comparative planetology; the earth and the moon; terrestrial and gas planets and their moons; dwarf planets, asteroids, and comets; planetary system formation; extrasolar planets; the search for extraterrestrial intelligence (SETI).
courses.subject: ASTR
courses.title: Introduction to Astronomy: The Solar System (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, ASTR 101. The sun, stellar observables, star birth, evolution, and death, novae and supernovae, white dwarfs, neutron stars, black holes, the Milky Way galaxy, normal galaxies, active galaxies and quasars, dark matter, dark energy, cosmology, early universe.
courses.subject: ASTR
courses.title: Introduction to Astronomy: Stars, Galaxies, and Cosmology (3)

courses.description: Prerequisites, ASTR 301, MATH 383, and PHYS 331. Permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisites. An introduction to the study of stellar structure and evolution. Topics covered include observational techniques, stellar structure and energy transport, nuclear energy sources, evolution off the main-sequence, and supernovae.
courses.subject: ASTR
courses.title: Astrophysics I (Stellar Astrophysics) (3)

courses.description: Prerequisites, ASTR 301 and MATH 383; preor corequisite, PHYS 331. An introduction to modern research in astrophysics based onscientific journal articles addressing a current topic of interest in galactic or extragalactic astrophysics, including training in computer modeling and statistical analysis, culminating in the completion of a research project.
courses.subject: ASTR
courses.title: Astrophysics II (Modern Research in Astrophysics) (3)

courses.description: Corequisites, ASTR 102 and PHYS 117. Stellar observables; galaxies; novae; cosmology; the early universe. This one-credit course can be taken with ASTR 102 for students who wish to major or minor in astrophysics.
courses.subject: ASTR
courses.title: Stars, Galaxies, and Cosmology (1)

courses.description: Prerequisites, ASTR 301 and PHYS 301; preor corequisite, PHYS 321. An introduction to modern cosmology: the study of the contents and evolution of the universe. Covers expanding spacetime, the thermal history of the early universe, including nucleosynthesis and the cosmic microwave background, the inflationary model for the origins of cosmic structure, and the growth of that structure though time.
courses.subject: ASTR
courses.title: Cosmology (3)

courses.description: stellar structure and evolution including: equations of stellar structure, stellar models, star and planet formation, fusion and nucleosynthesis, stellar evolution, stellar remnants, and the comparison of theory to observations.
courses.subject: ASTR
courses.title: Stellar Interiors, Evolution, and Populations (3)

courses.description: This seminar provides a general introduction to nanoscience and nanotechnology, focusing on recent advances in molecular electronics, nanomaterials, and biomedical research. Course activities include group model-building projects, presentations, and discussions of reading material.
courses.subject: PHYS
courses.title: First-Year Seminar: Handcrafting in the Nanoworld: Building Models and Manipulating Molecules (3)

courses.description: Students watch and analyze short movie clips that demonstrate interesting, unusual, or impossible physics. Group analysis emphasized.
courses.subject: PHYS
courses.title: First-Year Seminar: Physics of Movies (3)

courses.description: Preor corequisite, MATH 130. Permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisite. Only one of PHYS 104 and 116 may be taken for credit. Three lecture hours and two laboratory hours a week.
courses.subject: PHYS
courses.title: General Physics I (4)

courses.description: Prerequisite, PHYS 104. Only one of PHYS 105 and 117 may be taken for credit. Three lecture hours a week and two laboratory hours a week.
courses.subject: PHYS
courses.title: General Physics II (4)

courses.description: Prerequisite, MATH 231. Basic principles of physics, including forces, energy, oscillations, sound, diffusion, and heat transfer, and applications to biological systems. Intended to meet the needs of, but not restricted to, students majoring in the life sciences. Students may not receive credit for PHYS 114 in addition to PHYS 104, 116, or 118.
courses.subject: PHYS
courses.title: General Physics I: For Students of the Life Sciences (4)

courses.description: Prerequisite, PHYS 114. Basic principles of physics, including fluids, electricity, magnetism, optics, quantum physics, and nuclear physics, and applications to biological systems. Intended to meet the needs of, but not restricted to, students majoring in the life sciences. Students may not receive credit for PHYS 115 in addition to PHYS 105, 117, or 119.
courses.subject: PHYS
courses.title: General Physics II: For Students of the Life Sciences (4)

courses.description: Prerequisites, MATH 232 and PHYS 116; preor corequisite, MATH 233. Permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisites. Only one of PHYS 105 and 117 may be taken for credit. Electricity and magnetism; laws of Coulomb, Ampere, and Faraday. Electromagnetic oscillations and waves. Light; diffraction and interference. Lecture, recitation, and laboratory.
courses.subject: PHYS
courses.title: Electromagnetism and Optics (4)

courses.description: Prerequisite, MATH 231; preor corequisite, MATH 232. Permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisites. Mechanics of particles and rigid bodies. Newton’s laws; mechanical and potential energy; mechanical conservation laws; frame-dependence of physical laws; Einstein’s Theory of Relativity. Lecture and studio. Students may not receive credit for PHYS 118 in addition to PHYS 104, 114, or 116.
courses.subject: PHYS
courses.title: Introductory Calculus-based Mechanics and Relativity (4)

courses.description: Prerequisites, MATH 232 and PHYS 118; preor corequisite, MATH 233. Permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisites. Unification of the laws of electricity and magnetism; electromagnetic waves; the particle-wave duality; fundamental principles and applications of quantum mechanics. Lecture and studio. Students may not receive credit for PHYS 119 in addition to PHYS 105, 115, or 117.
courses.subject: PHYS
courses.title: Introductory Calculus-Based Electromagnetism and Quanta (4)

courses.description: Prerequisite, PHYS 117; corequisite, PHYS 128L. Permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisite. Special relativity theory, black body radiation, photons and electrons; wave particle duality. Elements of atomic theory, nuclei and fundamental particles. Three lecture hours a week.
courses.subject: PHYS
courses.title: Modern Physics (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, PHYS 117; corequisite, PHYS 128L. Permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisite. Special relativity theory, black body radiation, photons and electrons; wave particle duality. Elements of atomic theory, nuclei and fundamental particles. Three lecture hours a week.
courses.subject: PHYS
courses.title: Modern Physics (3)

courses.description: Prerequisites, MATH 232 and PHYS 104 or 116. Permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisites. A one-semester course in statics, kinematics, simple harmonicmotion, central forces, and applications from modern physics.
courses.subject: PHYS
courses.title: Basic Mechanics (3)

courses.description: Research with a faculty mentor. Approved learning contract required.
courses.subject: PHYS
courses.title: Research with Faculty Mentor I (1–12)

courses.description: Preor corequisites, MATH 383 and PHYS 331. Permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisites. Particle kinematics, central forces, planetary motions. Systems of particles, conservation laws, nonlinearity. Statics, motion of rigid bodies. Langrange’s and Hamilton’s equations. Euler’s equations. Vibrations and waves.
courses.subject: PHYS
courses.title: Mechanics I (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, PHYS 311. Permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisite. Brief treatment of DC and AC circuit theory. Electrostatics: dielectrics; the magnetic field; magnetic materials. Maxwell’s equations and their application to electromagnetic waves.
courses.subject: PHYS
courses.title: Electromagnetism II (3)

courses.description: Prerequisites, MATH 383, and MATH 547 or PHYS 331; preor corequisite, PHYS 301. Permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisites. Origins of quantum theory. Uncertainty principle. Schroedinger equation for simple systems, including hydrogen atom. Perturbation theory. Spin. Identical particles.
courses.subject: PHYS
courses.title: Introduction to Quantum Mechanics (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, PHYS 105 or 116; preor corequisite, MATH 233. Applications of calculus, vector analysis, differential equations, complexnumbers, and computer programming to realistic physical systems. Three lecture and two computational laboratory hours per week.
courses.subject: PHYS
courses.title: Introduction to Numerical Techniques in Physics (4)

courses.description: Prerequisite, PHYS 351. Permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisite. Introduction to digital circuits: gates, flip-flops, and counters. Computers and device interconnections, converters and data acquisition. Signal analysis and digital filters. Graphical (LabVIEW) programming and computer interfacing. Individual projects and practical applications.
courses.subject: PHYS
courses.title: Electronics II (4)

courses.description: To be taken by seniors with permission of the department.
courses.subject: PHYS
courses.title: Senior Seminar (1–21)

courses.description: Research with a faculty mentor. Approved learning contract required. Additionally, students write and submit a proposal to an internal or external competition for funding intended for students. They also give a poster or oral presentation on the topic of their research at an appropriate symposium or meeting.
courses.subject: PHYS
courses.title: Research with Faculty Mentor II (1–12)

courses.description: Prerequisites, PHYS 116 and 117. Permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisites. Learning how to teach physics using current research-based methods. Includes extensive fieldwork in high school and college environments. Meets part of the licensure requirements for North Carolina public school teaching.
courses.subject: PHYS
courses.title: Teaching and Learning Physics (4)

courses.description: Prerequisites, PHYS 311 and 312. Permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisites. Elements of geometrical optics; Huygens’ principles, interference, diffraction, and polarization. Elements of the electromagnetic theory of light; Fresnel’s equations, dispersion, absorption, and scattering. Photons. Lasers and quantum optics.
courses.subject: PHYS
courses.title: Optics (3)

courses.description: How students learn and understand physics and astronomy. How to teach using current research-based methods.
courses.subject: PHYS
courses.title: Seminar for Physics and Astronomy Teaching Assistants (1)

courses.description: Prerequisite, PHys 321. Permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisite. Crystal symmetry, types of crystalline solids; electron and mechanical waves in crystals, electrical and magnetic properties of solids, semiconductors; low temperature phenomena; imperfections in nearly perfect crystals.
courses.subject: PHYS
courses.title: Introductory Solid State Physics (MTSC 573) (3)

courses.description: See MASC 560 for description.
courses.subject: PHYS
courses.title: Fluid Dynamics (ENVR 452, GEOL 560, MASC 560) (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, PHys 711. Plane electromagnetic waves and wave propagation, wave guides and resonant cavities, simple radiating systems, scattering and diffraction, special theory of relativity, radiation by moving charges.
courses.subject: PHYS
courses.title: Electromagnetic Theory II (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, PHys 321. review of nonrelativistic quantum mechanics. spin, angular momentum, perturbation theory, scattering, identical particles, Hartree-fock method, dirac equation, radiation theory.
courses.subject: PHYS
courses.title: Quantum Mechanics (3)

courses.description: Prerequisites, PHys 701 and 721. Classical and quantal statistical mechanics, ensembles, partition functions, ideal fermi and bose gases.
courses.subject: PHYS
courses.title: Statistical Mechanics (3)

courses.description: 993 Master’s Thesis (3–6).
courses.subject: PHYS
courses.title: Master’s Research Project (3–6)

courses.description: After studying the forces that have produced the American urban landscape, we will explore the city from the normative perspectives of urban historians, planners and architects, social scientists, social critics, and futurists, as a way for each student to develop her/his own perspective about what a “good city” might be.
courses.subject: PLAN
courses.title: First-Year Seminar: What Is a Good City? (3)

courses.description: Content varies each semester.
courses.subject: PLAN
courses.title: First-Year Seminar: Special Topics (3)

courses.description: Introduction to the evolution of cities in history, to the concept of urban morphology or form, and to the different elements or subsystems of the urban system and how they have changed over time.
courses.subject: PLAN
courses.title: Cities of the Future (3)

courses.description: See ENEC 330 for description.
courses.subject: PLAN
courses.title: Principles of Sustainability (ENEC 330) (3)

courses.description: See ENEC 420 for description.
courses.subject: PLAN
courses.title: Community Design and Green Architecture (ENEC 420) (3)

courses.description: Introduces students to the political economy of poverty alleviation programs. Uses comparative cases to explore what types of projects, tasks, and environments lead to effective and equitable outcomes, and why.
courses.subject: PLAN
courses.title: Political Economy of Poverty and Inequality (3)

courses.description: Original research, fieldwork, readings, or discussion of selected planning issues under guidance of a member of the faculty.
courses.subject: PLAN
courses.title: Special Topics Seminar (1–9)

courses.description: Alternative public urban transportation systems including mass transit, innovative transit services, and paratransit, examined from economic, land use, social, technical, and policy perspectives.
courses.subject: PLAN
courses.title: Public Transportation (3)

courses.description: This graduate-level course examines the importance of multimodal transportation planning and provides a comprehensive overview of best planning practices to support increased walking and bicycling.
courses.subject: PLAN
courses.title: Pedestrian and Bike Transportation (3)

courses.description: Lecture course on comparative urbanism and the global evolution of the city form. Examines values and ideals embedded in urban landscapes, seeking to understand how social, economic, and political forces have influenced the development of cities through history.
courses.subject: PLAN
courses.title: Urban Form and the Design of Cities (3)

courses.description: Permission of the instructor. Seminar on policy and planning approaches for improved community water and sanitation services in developed countries. Topics include the choice of appropriate technology and level of service; cost recovery; water venting; community participation in the management of watersystems; and rent-seeking behavior in providing water supplies.
courses.subject: PLAN
courses.title: Water and Sanitation Planning and Policy in Less Developed Countries (ENVR 685) (3)

courses.description: see PlAn 685 for description.
courses.subject: ENVR
courses.title: Water and Sanitation Planning and Policy in Developing Countries (PLAN 685) (3)

courses.description: The logic of planning as a professional activity. Critical overview of current process theories leading students to develop a personal philosophy applicable to their work as planners.
courses.subject: PLAN
courses.title: Theory of Planning I (3)

courses.description: Permission of the instructor for undergraduates. More in-depth treatment of topics covered in PlAn 720. Particular emphasis on techniques of multiple regression analysis, forecasting, categorical data analysis, and spatial data analysis.
courses.subject: PLAN
courses.title: Advanced Planning Methods (3)

courses.description: Contemporary methods of resolving development disputes through negotiation, bargaining, and mediation. techniques and skills applicable to solving controversies over planning and implementation of public and private development projects.
courses.subject: PLAN
courses.title: Development Dispute Resolution (3)

courses.description: Permission of the instructor for undergraduates. The transportation planning process; data collection, trip generation, modal choice, trip distributionand assignment. social, economic, and environmental impacts of transportation. innovative modeling techniques.
courses.subject: PLAN
courses.title: Transportation Planning Models (3)

courses.description: Methods of land use planmaking. Use of Gis and spreadsheets to analyze land suitability and spatial needs. Preparation of land classification plans, land use design plans, and development management programs.
courses.subject: PLAN
courses.title: Land Use and Environmental Planning (3)

courses.description: Concepts, processes, and policies for historic preservation; its role in the community planning and development process.
courses.subject: PLAN
courses.title: Planning for Historical Preservation (3)

courses.subject: PLAN
courses.title: Real Estate Investment and Affordable Housing (3)

courses.description: Analyzes central cities over past 20 years and factors affecting their growth or decline. Analyzes how economic, social, physical conditions of central cities can be improved through large-scale urban-planning efforts.
courses.subject: PLAN
courses.title: Central City Revitalization (3)

courses.description: intermediate and advanced techniques for analyzing the development of local and regional economies. social accounts, indicator construction, regional input-output models, economic and fiscal impact analysis, labor market analysis, and regional economic forecasting techniques.
courses.subject: PLAN
courses.title: Development Planning Techniques (3)

courses.description: water resources planning and management. federal and state water resources policies. Analytical skills to identify environmental problems associated with urban water resources development.
courses.subject: PLAN
courses.title: Water Resources Planning and Policy Analysis (ENVR 781) (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, PlAn 710. basic theory, process, and techniques of public investment planning and decision making, involving synthesis of economic, political, and technologic aspects. Theory underlying benefit-cost analysis, adaptation to a descriptive and normative model for planning public projects and programs.
courses.subject: PLAN
courses.title: Public Investment Theory (ENVR 785, PLCY 785) (3)

courses.description: see PlCy 798 for description.
courses.subject: PLAN
courses.title: Advanced Economic Analysis for Public Policy II (PLCY 789) (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, PlCy 788. further applications of ecenomic theoryto public policy including risk and uncertainty, general equilibrium and welfare policy, market failure, public goods and taxation, and game theory.
courses.subject: PLCY
courses.title: Advanced Economic Analysis for Public Policy II (PLAN 789) (3)

courses.description: original research, fieldwork, readings, or discussion of selected planning issues under guidance of a member of the faculty.
courses.subject: PLAN
courses.title: Planning Seminar (1–21)

courses.description: Problem-solving, client-based courses designed to give students experience in applying planning theoryand methods to actual problem situations in economic development, housing and community development, real estate, environmental planning, and land use and transportation.

courses.title: Planning Workshop (3)

courses.description: This course permits full-time graduate students enrolled in the department of City and regional Planning who wish to pursue independent research or an independent project to do so under the direction of a member of the department faculty.

courses.title: Independent Study (1–21)

courses.description: Research Seminar (1–21). original research, fieldwork, readings, or discussion of selected planning issues under guidance of a member of the faculty.
courses.subject: PLAN
courses.title: Ph

courses.description: The master’s project is original work, involving a substantial degree of independent research and/or analysis. May be a research paper, critical essay, development and evaluation of a program, project, or plan.
courses.subject: PLAN
courses.title: Master’s Project (3)

courses.description: This firstyear seminar provides an introduction to contemporary policy issues in higher education. Students will discuss challenges to current models of higher education, including accessibility, academic freedom, safety and security, and athletics.
courses.subject: PLCY
courses.title: First-Year Seminar: Higher Education Policy (3)

courses.description: This seminar will define a policy entrepreneurand examine strategies used by policy entrepreneurs to achieve policy change or innovation in the policy making process. We will also explore models of innovative public-private partnerships in the delivery of public goods.
courses.subject: PLCY
courses.title: First-Year Seminar: Policy Entrepreneurship and Public/Private Partnerships (3)

courses.description: This seminar provides an introduction to entrepreneurship and innovation and considers their relationship to economic growth.
courses.subject: PLCY
courses.title: First-Year Seminar: Innovation, Entrepreneurship, and Economic Growth (3)

courses.description: In this course we will examine the main problems that are occurring in America’s high schools and three popular reform strategies: increasing resources; improving leadership and teacher working conditions; and structural reforms.
courses.subject: PLCY
courses.title: First-Year Seminar: Reforming America’s High Schools (3)

courses.description: Overview of the policy-making process and of major public policy issues. Study of policy and political challenges in areas such as economic and tax policy, the social safety net, income support and the minimum wage, health care, education, environment and energy, foreign policy and national security, and homeland security.
courses.subject: PLCY
courses.title: Making Public Policy (PWAD 101) (3)

courses.description: See PLCY 101 for description.
courses.subject: PWAD
courses.title: Making Public Policy (PLCY 101) (3)

courses.description: Global issues are challenges whose sources, impacts, and solutions extend beyond the borders of any one country. This course introduces students to some of the most pressing issues facing populations around the globe and to possible policy responses.
courses.subject: PLCY
courses.title: Global Policy Issues (3)

courses.description: A student-driven, instructor-aided workshop open only to students who have received the APPLES Bryan Social Innovation Fellowship. Each fellowship team develops a project’s underlying theory of change and the skills necessary for successful implementation. Students study the theories and implementation of one another’s projects and external case studies.
courses.subject: PLCY
courses.title: Getting It Done: Project Management for Social Innovation (1)

courses.description: Students will develop a working knowledge of the foundational theories of the public policy discipline and the integral institutions of public policy. Incorporates current substantive issues in the United States and international policy. Students will explore, summarize, and evaluate alternative policy solutions.
courses.subject: PLCY
courses.title: Policy Innovation and Analysis (3)

courses.description: Examines approaches to American politics and public policy and analyzes why government responds to problems in predictable ways.
courses.subject: PLCY
courses.title: The Politics of Public Policy (PWAD 220) (3)

courses.description: See PLCY 220 for description.

courses.title: The Politics of Public Policy (PLCY 220) (3)

courses.description: Examines approaches to American politics and public policy and analyzes why government responds to problems in predictable ways.
courses.subject: PLCY
courses.title: The Politics of Public Policy (PWAD 220) (3)

courses.description: Special topics in public policy for undergraduates.
courses.subject: PLCY
courses.title: Special Topics in Public Policy (3)

courses.description: For public policy majors and minors. Permission of the instructor. Provides participants opportunities to work in policy-related internships for a semester. Internship sites range from governmental agencies to nonprofit organizations. Students assume active roles in their organizations and gain valuable knowledge that prepares them for the labor market after graduation.
courses.subject: PLCY
courses.title: Internship in Public Policy (3)

courses.description: Students choose a societal problem and communicate the problem as demanded by governmental process. Course focuses on simulated public hearings; writing/revising documents (problem definition memo, witness testimony); writing/revising an organization’s public comment on proposed legislation/regulation.
courses.subject: PLCY

courses.description: This seminar explores arguments about moral issues in public policy. Students examine both the means used to implement policies and policy ends through discussions of case studies of policy choice.
courses.subject: PLCY
courses.title: Justice in Public Policy (3)

courses.description: A range of public policy topics at the state and local level.
courses.subject: PLCY
courses.title: State and Local Politics (3)

courses.description: An analysis of the evolution of American medical care with special emphasis on current health carepolicy issues and debates about future directions. Compares other national models to those of the United States.
courses.subject: PLCY
courses.title: Health Policy and Politics (3)

courses.description: Special topics in public policy for undergraduate students.
courses.subject: PLCY
courses.title: Special Topics in Public Policy (Undergraduate) (3)

courses.description: Permission of the instructor. The clinic provides an opportunity for students to solve a public policy problem for local nonprofits and governmental agencies. Working in small consulting teams with faculty assistance, students will learn how to use their knowledge and skills to propose solutions to complex problems.
courses.subject: PLCY
courses.title: Public Policy Clinic (3)

courses.description: By special arrangement and permission of the instructor. Independent reading in public policy.
courses.subject: PLCY
courses.title: Independent Study/Reading in Public Policy (1–6)

courses.description: Course explores contemporary threats to national security, approaches to national security strategy, policy instruments, the role of military force, and the policymaking process.
courses.subject: PLCY
courses.title: Analysis of National Security Policy (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, ECON 400, PSYC 210, SOCI 252, or STOR 155. Application of statistical techniques, including regression analysis, in public policy program evaluation, research design, and data collection and management.
courses.subject: PLCY
courses.title: Quantitative Analysis for Public Policy (4)

courses.description: This course examines the political and economic dimensions of the food we eat, how it’s produced, who eats what, and the related social and environmental issues, both domestic and international, affecting the production, pricing, trade, distribution, and consumption of food.
courses.subject: PLCY
courses.title: Political Economy of Food (3)

courses.description: Coursework will focus on public policy approaches to global health, employing interdisciplinary methodologies to understand selected public health policies, programs, and interventions. For students who have a basic understanding of public health.
courses.subject: PLCY
courses.title: Global Health Policy (3)

courses.description: An introduction to some of the sectors within which social change work occurs: education, healthcare, local policy, philanthropy and nonprofit directservice. Students will learn the fundamental systems of governance and accountability that guide them, and the opportunities or barriers that motivate and de-motivate people working within them.
courses.subject: PLCY
courses.title: Implementing Change: Barriers and Opportunities in Policy, Government, and the Nonprofit Sector (3)

courses.description: Preor corequisite, PLCY 460. Students will explore the scientific method as applied to policy research. They will formulate testable policy research questions, become familiar with methods for conducting policy research, and learn to think critically about causal inference.
courses.subject: PLCY
courses.title: Research Design for Public Policy (3)

courses.description: This course analyzes the politics of public policy with an emphasis on the role of political institutions. The course combines theory, empirical research, methodological approaches to institutions, and case studies in substantive areas of policy with a global dimension. This is a required core course for the Public Policy Ph.d.
courses.subject: PLCY
courses.title: Political Institutions: Macro-Level Processes, Nesting, and Institutional Dynamics (3)

courses.description: weekly forum for public policy scholars and officials to discuss the relationships between policy research and policy outcomes. Presentations by invited speakers and doctoral students.
courses.subject: PLCY
courses.title: Public Policy Seminar (1)

courses.description: This course allows graduate students in public policy analysis to receive credit for work on individual projects, designed in conjunction with a faculty supervisor. it is intended for students who are interested in pursuing academic topics not covered in scheduled courses.
courses.subject: PLCY
courses.title: Independent Study (1–21)

courses.description: The face of the American worker is changing and thechallenges American workers face are ever evolving. In the wake of recent events like the Occupy Wall Street protests, the public in general is becomingmore aware of issues like income inequality, living wages, and the role of unions in the workplace. This seminar will explore the American worker from alegal, economic, and social justice perspective. Additionally, the legal framework Americans operate within in respect to labor law will be compared andcontrasted with international standards and labor rights. The seminar will also feature an analysis of the American worker through classic film andfictional literature. ABOUT THE INSTRUCTOR: Michele M. Hoyman teaches in the Political Science Department and in the Master of Public Administrationprogram. She received her Ph.D. in Political Science from the University of Michigan. Professor HoymanÀs interests are in economic development, sustainabledevelopment, industrial labor relations, and public sector personnel. On a personal level, she is an avid UNC basketball fan and spends her spare time beingwalked in the park by her dog, Tilly. She is afflicted with an unrelenting sense of humor.
courses.subject: POLI
courses.title: Fys The American Worker Lecture

courses.description: This interdisciplinary seminar is designed for students who wish to learn about Latin America in the disciplines of history and political science.
courses.subject: POLI
courses.title: First-Year Seminar: The United States and Cuba: Making Sense of United States Foreign Policy (3)

courses.description: Unconventional collective political behavior: mass movements, riots, demonstrations, revolts, and revolution.
courses.subject: POLI
courses.title: First-Year Seminar: Social Movements and Political Protest and Violence (3)

courses.description: Humans and animals have always lived together. Increasingly, philosophers question the exclusion of animals from political life. We explore theircentrality to political thought and consider important aspects of human-animal relationships today. Finally, we reexamine the claim that animal life is incongruent with political life.
courses.subject: POLI
courses.title: First-Year Seminar: Politics and Animal Life (3)

courses.description: Course content will vary each semester.

courses.title: First-Year Seminar: Special Topics (3)

courses.title: Introduction to Government in the United States (3)

courses.description: An introductory course on the government, politics, and policies at the state and local levels of the United States federal system.
courses.subject: POLI
courses.title: State and Local Government in the United States (3)

courses.description: This course highlights the comparative method by seeking to understand differences among diverse states on several continents.

courses.title: Introduction to Comparative Politics (3)

courses.description: The analysis of politics among nations.

courses.description: The analysis of politics among nations.
courses.subject: POLI
courses.title: International Relations and World Politics (PWAD 150) (3)

courses.description: An analysis of the dynamics of party alignment and realignment and of nomination and election to public office in American national government.
courses.subject: POLI
courses.title: Political Parties and Elections (3)

courses.description: A study of forces affecting public opinion and its expression in various political activities. Emphasis on gathering and analyzing opinion data. Course may be taught in the computer classroom.

courses.title: Analyzing Public Opinion (3)

courses.description: See GLBL 210 for description.
courses.subject: POLI
courses.title: Global Issues in the 20th Century (ANTH 210, GEOG 210, GLBL 210, HIST 210) (3)

courses.description: Findings of the behavioral sciences are examined as they relate to politics. Includes such issues as human nature, community, political socialization, alienation, mass movements, belief systems, and personality.
courses.subject: POLI
courses.title: Political Psychology: An Introduction (3)

courses.description: A survey of the events, institutions, and issues that have dominated relations between Latin America and the United States.

courses.title: Latin America and the United States in World Politics (3)

courses.description: An introduction to contemporary UK politics emphasizing the political battle betweensocialist and conservative ideologies.
courses.subject: POLI
courses.title: Politics of the United Kingdom (3)

courses.title: Society and Culture in Postwar Germany (GERM 257, HIST 257, SOCI 257) (3)

courses.title: The Ethics of Peace, War, and Defense (PHIL 272, PWAD 272) (3)

courses.description: An examination of major issues in political thought, including equality; obedience; violence and nonviolence; justice; forms of social, economic, and political life; liberty; and human nature and politics.

courses.title: Major Issues in Political Theory (3)

courses.description: A survey course in American political ideas from the 17th century to the present, with emphasis on the role of politics, society, and economy in American thought.

courses.description: An introduction to 1) conceptual foundations of scientific study of politics, 2) research design, 3) descriptive statistics, and 4) inferential statistics. To accomplish these goals, the course employs class lectures, readings, and problem set assignments.

courses.description: This course explores how presidents select policy options, how they decide timing, what shapes their congressional support, and how they build successful coalitions.

Students explore topics such as police brutality, immigration, the education system, and coalition politics.

courses.title: Race, Immigration, and Urban Politics (3)

courses.title: The Constitution of the United States (3)

courses.description: An analysis of the complex political problems created by the expansion of protection for individual liberties in the United States. Emphasis will be on contemporary problems with some supplemental historical background.

courses.title: Civil Liberties under the Constitution (3)

courses.description: Analysis of the structure and functions of judicial systems emphasizing the organization, administration, and politics of judicial bureaucracies and roles of judges, juries, counsel, litigants, and interested groups in adjudication processes.
courses.subject: POLI
courses.title: Constitutional Policies and the Judicial Process (PWAD 416) (3)

courses.description: See POLI 416 for description.

courses.title: Constitutional Policies and the Judicial Process (POLI 416) (3)

courses.description: Examines in greater depth issues in the field of political psychology, including conflict and conflict resolution, socialization, attitude formation, mass movements, leader-follower relationships, and psychobiography.

courses.title: Advanced Political Psychology (3)

courses.description: Restricted to juniors and seniors. Surveys the vast literature on race and politics in the contemporary United States and examines the complex relationship between racial and ethnic identity and political outcomes. It explores broad political science concepts in the context of racial and ethnic groups.
courses.subject: POLI
courses.title: Race and Politics in the Contemporary United States (3)

courses.description: Examines the politics of the United States Congress. Emphasis on representation, the legislative process, and policy making.
courses.subject: POLI
courses.title: Legislative Politics (3)

courses.description: This course will focus on the process by which policies get framed, or defined, in public discussions. Framing is focusing attention on some elements of a complex public problem rather than others. Readings combine psychological background with case histories of United States and comparative public policy changes over time.
courses.subject: POLI
courses.title: Framing Public Policies (3)

courses.description: This course will compare the theory and practice of tolerance in the United States and Europe, with particular attention to Great Britain and France.
courses.subject: POLI
courses.title: Tolerance in Liberal States (3)

courses.description: Examines the politics and political economy of institutional change and policy making in the European Union in comparative perspective.
courses.subject: POLI
courses.title: Politics of the European Union (3)

courses.description: Prerequisites, ECON 101 and POLI 150. Theories of international political economy, major trends in international economic relations, selected contemporary policy issues.
courses.subject: POLI
courses.title: International Political Economy (EURO 442) (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, POLI 150. Examines the management and resolution of international and civil wars.
courses.subject: POLI
courses.title: International Conflict Management and Resolution (3)

courses.description: Focuses on ethnic and political conflicts in the former Yugoslavia and efforts by the international community to end conflict and promote peace and reconstruction.
courses.subject: POLI
courses.title: Conflict and Intervention in the Former Yugoslavia (PWAD 469) (3)

courses.description: See POLI 469 for description.
courses.subject: PWAD
courses.title: Conflict and Intervention in the Former Yugoslavia (POLI 469) (3)

courses.description: Examines the relationship between religion and politics, with emphasis on the United States. Topics include church-state issues, religious-political movements, religion and public policy, religion and voting.
courses.subject: POLI
courses.title: Religion and Politics (3)

courses.description: Examines in greater depth and complexity current issues in feminist political theory. Topics: theories of subjectivity and solidarity, feminist poststructuralist and post-Marxist thinking, gender in the public sphere.
courses.subject: POLI
courses.title: Advanced Feminist Political Theory (WMST 477) (3)

courses.description: See POLI 477 for description.
courses.subject: WMST
courses.title: Advanced Feminist Political Theory (POLI 477) (3)

courses.description: Increasingly, political and social scientists are using game theory to analyze strategic interactions across different settings. This course aims to give students a deep technical understanding of the most relevant concepts of game theory and how these concepts have been applied to the study of political and economic phenomena.
courses.subject: POLI
courses.title: Advanced Game Theory (3) Prerequisite, POLI 287 or 288

courses.description: A detailed examination of advanced special topics in political science.
courses.subject: POLI
courses.title: Advanced Undergraduate Seminar (3)

courses.description: This course examines diverse theoretical perspectives on national institutional change and stability, using as our institutional focus the United states Congress between 1789 and 1989.
courses.subject: POLI
courses.title: Congress and Theory Building (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, Poli 711. This course surveys and evaluates current and past research in political psychology. topics may include: personality, attitudes and values, socialization, political reasoning, information processing, decision making, political identity, and political affect.
courses.subject: POLI
courses.title: Seminar on Political Psychology (3)

courses.description: This class will focus on the theoretical and empirical studies of individual and collective framing. readings will be from journalism, sociology, psychology, and political science and will include both Us-based and comparative studies. Assignments include participation in seminar discussion, short papers on readings, and substantial original research paper.
courses.subject: POLI
courses.title: Framing (3)

courses.description: The theories, concepts and mechanisms of political change, with particular attention to processes of development and modernization in the new nations of Africa, Asia, and latin America.
courses.subject: POLI
courses.title: The Politics of Development and Change (3)

courses.description: reviews major works and theoretical perspectives in the literature, assesses contemporary political science research on latin America, and examines problems of field research.
courses.subject: POLI
courses.title: Latin American Politics: Research and Analysis (3)

courses.description: introduction to the central issues and major theoretical developments in the field of international relations, focusing on system structure, political and security issues, and decision making.
courses.subject: POLI
courses.title: Theories of International Relations I (3)

courses.description: The goal of this course is to acquire a command of the fundamentals of economic development from the community’s perspective. This is done by reading and absorbing the theoretical literature on economic development from the fields of urban politics, planning, sociology, economics, political science, and sociology.
courses.subject: POLI
courses.title: Community Economic Development: Strategies and Choices (PUBA 770) (3)

courses.description: An introduction to the major issues of political theory, with emphasis on the major thinkers in the history of western political thought.
courses.subject: POLI
courses.title: Major Issues in Political Theory (3)

courses.description: This course extends the coverage of Poli 281. topics to be covered include analysis of variance, multiple and partials correlation, and multiple regression.
courses.subject: POLI
courses.title: Intermediate Statistics (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, Poli 784. Permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisite. discusses the problems that arise when regression methodologies are applied to time series and pooled time series data.
courses.subject: POLI
courses.title: Time Series Analysis of Political Data (3)

courses.description: This class provides graduate students with an introduction to game theoretic modeling, focusing on noncooperative game theory. topics covered include normal form games, extensive-form games, and games of incomplete information.
courses.subject: POLI
courses.title: Game Theory (3)

courses.subject: POLI
courses.title: Pol Econ Of Intl Money/Finance Lecture

courses.description: Examines how language use is affected by one’s reasoning about the mental activities of others. We will examine the development of language, adult language use, and the language of autistic individuals, who are known to have difficulty reasoning about others’ minds. This seminar will follow a discussion format.
courses.subject: PSYC
courses.title: First-Year Seminar: The Psychology of Mental States and Language Use (3)

courses.description: The course will tackle questions through classroom discussions, lectures, movies, writing assignments, and a visit to a research laboratory and a treatment facility. Students will be introduced to fundamental concepts in addiction research.
courses.subject: PSYC
courses.title: First-Year Seminar: Drug Addiction: Fact and Fiction (3)

courses.description: Students will learn about anorexia and bulimia nervosa, as well as prevention and treatment efforts. The course explores factors related to these disorders and body image from a psychosocial perspective. Learning will occur through discussions, readings, videos, guest speakers, experimental assignments, writing assignments, and research projects.
courses.subject: PSYC
courses.title: First-Year Seminar: Eating Disorders and Body Image (3)

courses.description: A survey of major principles of psychology and an introduction to scientific modes of thought about behavior. Students participate in ongoing psychological research in the department. PSYC 101 is a prerequisite for all psychology courses.
courses.subject: PSYC
courses.title: General Psychology (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, PSYC 101. Consideration of the methodological principles underlying psychological research, descriptive and inferential techniques, and the manner by which they may be employed to design psychological experiments and analyze behavioral data. Three lecture hours and one laboratory hour a week.
courses.subject: PSYC
courses.title: Statistical Principles of Psychological Research (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, PSYC 101. Study of the biological basis of behavior. Emphasis will be placed on human findings and applications.
courses.subject: PSYC
courses.title: Biopsychology (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, PSYC 101. Topics in conditioning, verbal learning, memory, and problem solving.
courses.subject: PSYC
courses.title: Learning (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, PSYC 101. Topics in vision, audition, and the lower senses. Receptor mechanisms, psychophysical methods, and selected perceptual phenomena will be discussed.
courses.subject: PSYC
courses.title: Sensation and Perception (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, PSYC 101. Topics in attention; memory; visual, auditory, and other forms of information processing; decision making; and thinking.
courses.subject: PSYC
courses.title: Cognitive Psychology (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, PSYC 101. Overview of clinical psychology: history, scientific basis, and major activities and concerns, including assessment, psychotherapy and other psychological interventions, community psychology, ethics, and professional practice. Students may not receive credit for both PSYC 242 and 505.
courses.subject: PSYC
courses.title: Introduction to Clinical Psychology (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, PSYC 101. Major forms of behavior disorders in children and adults, with an emphasis on description, causation, and treatment.

courses.title: Abnormal Psychology (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, PSYC 101. Major forms of behavior disorders in children and adults, with an emphasis on description, causation, and treatment.

courses.title: Abnormal Psychology (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, PSYC 101. Study of the development of social and intellectual behavior in normal children and the processes that underlie this development. Emphasis is typically on theory and research.
courses.subject: PSYC
courses.title: Child Development (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, PSYC 101. Introductory survey of experimental social psychology covering attitudes, interpersonal processes, and small groups.
courses.subject: PSYC
courses.title: Social Psychology (3)

courses.description: Prerequisites, PSYC 101, and 210 or 215. Experiments in biological, behavioral, cognitive, developmental, personality, and social psychology will be discussed, prepared, performed, and reported. One lecture hour and four laboratory hours per week.
courses.subject: PSYC
courses.title: Laboratory Research in Psychology (4)

courses.description: Permission of the instructor. Service-learning component for students enrolled in psychology APPLES courses. May not count toward the major.
courses.subject: PSYC
courses.title: Service Learning in Psychology: APPLES (1–3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, PSYC 101. Also required, two additional psychology courses, at least one of which must be numbered 200 or greater, a minimum of a 2.5 grade point average, and permission of the instructor. Supervised research resulting in a written report. May be repeated for credit up to six hours.
courses.subject: PSYC
courses.title: Independent Research (1–3)

courses.description: Prerequisites, PSYC 101, and 210 or 215. An introduction to the interdisciplinary study of the mind, intelligent behavior, information processing, and communication in living organisms and computers.
courses.subject: PSYC
courses.title: Introduction to Cognitive Science (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, PSYC 101. Simple mathematical and psychological models of judgment and choice, and related experiments, are treated, as are applications to real world problems in medical, environmental, policy, business, and related domains.
courses.subject: PSYC
courses.title: Behavioral Decision Theory (3)

courses.description: Prerequisites, PSYC 101, and 210 or 215; and one of PSYC 220, 222, 225, 230, or BIOL 450, 455. Introduction to cognitive neuroscience. Higher mental processes including attention, memory, language, and consciousness will be covered, with an emphasis on the neural mechanisms that form the substrates of human cognition.
courses.subject: PSYC
courses.title: Cognitive Neuroscience (3)

courses.description: Prerequisites, PSYC 101 and 220. BIOL 101 recommended. This course surveys current knowledge about and research into the neurobiological basis of learning and memory. Using a combination of lectures and student-led discussions, we will critically evaluate the molecular, cellular, systems, and behavioral research that strives to explain how the brain learns and remembers.
courses.subject: PSYC
courses.title: Neurobiology of Learning and Memory (3)

courses.description: Prerequisites, PSYC 101 and 250, and 210 or 215. Developmental processes during early childhood as these relate to social behavior and personality.
courses.subject: PSYC
courses.title: Development of Social Behavior and Personality (3)

courses.description: Various special areas of psychological study, offered as needed. Course may be repeated for credit.
courses.subject: PSYC
courses.title: Current Topics in Psychology (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, PSYC 101. Required preparation, minimum of two other psychology courses and junior/senior standing. Designed for highly motivated psychology majors interested in exploring professional opportunities in psychology-related areas. Students complete hands-on internships at community sites for approximately 120 hours across the semester. Students also attend a weekly one-hour class with other interns.
courses.subject: PSYC
courses.title: Internship in Psychology (3)

courses.description: Prerequisites, PSYC 101, 245, and 250. A survey of theories bearing on atypical development and disordered behavior, and an examination of major child and adolescent behavior problems and clinical syndromes.
courses.subject: PSYC
courses.title: Developmental Psychopathology (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, PSYC 101. An in-depth coverage of the traditional clinically based personality theories of the early 20th century contrasted with more recent empirically based perspectives.
courses.subject: PSYC
courses.title: Theoretical, Empirical Perspectives on Personality (3)

courses.description: Prerequisites, PSYC 101 and 250. A developmental approach to the study of adulthood, from young adulthood through death. Topics include adult issues in personality, family dynamics, work, leisure and retirement, biological and intellectual aspects of aging, dying, and bereavement.
courses.subject: PSYC
courses.title: Psychology of Adulthood and Aging (3)

courses.description: Prerequisites, PSYC 101 and 245. An in-depth coverage of psychological, biological, and social factors that may be involved with health.
courses.subject: PSYC
courses.title: Health Psychology (3)

courses.description: Prerequisites, PSYC 101 and 260, and 210 or 215. Intensive coverage of normal interpersonal processes, focusing on the dyad.
courses.subject: PSYC
courses.title: Interpersonal Processes (3)

courses.description: Prerequisites, PSYC 101 and 260, and 210 or 215. A detailed consideration of the theoretical issues in attitude and belief change.
courses.subject: PSYC
courses.title: Attitude Change (3)

courses.description: Prerequisites, PSYC 101, 260, and 270. Surveys cutting-edge research across the field of social psychology and how it matters for everyday life. Topics include morality, mind perception, judgment and decision making, happiness, affective forecasting, emotion, relationships, negotiation, personality, free will, stress/health, and religion. Clear communication of research also emphasized through figures, presentations, and papers.
courses.subject: PSYC
courses.title: Practical Wisdom from Advanced Social Psychology (3)

courses.description: Prerequisites, PSYC 101, and 210 or 215. Examines the legal system from the perspective of psychology methods and research, with a focus on criminal law. Discusses dilemmas within the law and between the legal system and psychology.
courses.subject: PSYC
courses.title: Psychology and Law (3)

courses.description: A survey of psychological and biological approaches to the study of basic learning and higher integrative processing.
courses.subject: PSYC
courses.title: Behavior and Its Biological Bases II (NBIO 702A) (3)

courses.subject: PSYC
courses.title: Res Sem In Exp Psyc Lecture

courses.description: Permission of the instructor. discussion and critical evaluation of various theories of thinking; theories of concept formation, problem solving and reasoning.
courses.subject: PSYC
courses.title: Seminar in Cognitive Psychology (1–3)

courses.description: Graduate standing in psychology required. This course will introduce the major issues in attention research and highlight recent work examining the neural mechanisms of attention and its interactions with other cognitive and social-cognitive processes.
courses.subject: PSYC
courses.title: Attention (3)

courses.description: Permission of the instructor. intensive study of selected topics in developmental psychology.
courses.subject: PSYC
courses.title: Seminar in Developmental Psychology (3)

courses.description: Permission of the instructor. intensive study of selected topics in human development that are being explored by members of the Carolina Consortium on Human development staff.
courses.subject: PSYC
courses.title: Proseminar in Developmental Science (3)

courses.description: specific training in presentational and interpersonal skills needed by college teachers, such as planning, lecturing, discussing, motivating and evaluating.
courses.subject: PSYC
courses.title: Laboratory in College Teaching (1)

courses.description: Graduate standing in clinical psychology required. Analysis of clinical and personality research in terms of their contribution to knowledge, their limitations, possibilities for their improvement, further research they suggest, etc. Preparation of individual research proposals for class presentation and critical evaluation. Three hours a week.
courses.subject: PSYC
courses.title: Clinical Research Methods (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, PsyC 806. Graduate standing in clinical psychology required. designing and presenting research proposals in individual students’ research areas in oral and written form. Critiquing research proposals. research ethics and preparing and evaluating protocols for ethical review.
courses.subject: PSYC
courses.title: Clinical Research Seminar (1)

courses.description: second-year graduate status in clinical psychology required. supervised experience in psychological assessment and psychotherapy. six to eight laboratory hours a week.
courses.subject: PSYC
courses.title: Adult Practicum (3)

courses.description: second-year graduate status in clinical psychology required. supervised experience in psychological assessment and psychotherapy. six to eight laboratory hours a week.
courses.subject: PSYC
courses.title: Child and Adolescent Practicum (3)

courses.description: Graduate standing in clinical psychology required. Consideration of how various forms of assessment data can be utilized in understanding the structure and dynamics of adult personalities; problems of differential diagnosis, brain damage, etc., are also considered. two lecture and two laboratory hours a week.
courses.subject: PSYC
courses.title: Advanced Adult Assessment (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, PsyC 808. Theory, research, and application of objective and projective techniques for behavioral, emotional, psychiatric, interpersonal, and social cognitive assessment of children and adolescents. two lecture and two laboratory hours a week.
courses.subject: PSYC
courses.title: Advanced Child Assessment (3)

courses.description: Graduate standing in clinical psychology required. A survey and discussion of the ethical and legal issues that clinical psychologists confront in a variety of professional settings.
courses.subject: PSYC
courses.title: Ethics and Practice in Clinical Psychology (3)

courses.description: Prerequisites, PsyC 811 and 812. supervised clinical work in an area of particular interest to the student. Clinical activity is coordinated with reading and discussion of literature or professional ethics.
courses.subject: PSYC
courses.title: Advanced Adult Practicum and Professional Ethics (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, PsyC 817. individualized clinical practicum for advanced doctoral students in clinical psychology. supervised experience in psychotherapy, psychological assessment, and consultation.
courses.subject: PSYC
courses.title: Advanced Clinical Practicum (3)

courses.description: Graduate standing in psychology and permission of the instructor. This course provides students with an opportunity to integrate their academic foundation in clinical psychology assessment knowledge skills, ethics, and values in an applied practice setting with diverse clients.
courses.subject: PSYC
courses.title: Child/Adolescent Assessment Practicum (1)

courses.description: Prerequisite, PsyC 830. statistical estimation and hypothesis testing for linear models (AnovA, AnCovA, regression analysis); statistical models in the design and analysis of experiments.
courses.subject: PSYC
courses.title: Statistical Methods in Psychology II (4)

courses.description: Prerequisite, PsyC 844. Permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisite. latent curve modeling is a structural equations-based method for analyzing longitudinal data. equal emphasis is placed on the statistical model and applications to real data.
courses.subject: PSYC
courses.title: Latent Curve Modeling (3)

courses.description: Presentations of research by faculty, students, and visitors; discussion of professional topics such as ethics, the publication process, research funding, and the reviewing of articles.
courses.subject: PSYC
courses.title: Quantitative Psychology Forum (1)

courses.description: lectures, discussions, and seminar presentations on current topics in quantitative psychology.
courses.subject: PSYC
courses.title: Seminar in Quantitative Psychology (3)

courses.description: Graduate status in social psychology or permission of the instructor. directed research problems and seminar discussion of related issues.
courses.subject: PSYC
courses.title: Directed Research Seminar in Social Psychology (3)

courses.description: six laboratory hours a week. 993 Master’s Thesis (3–6).
courses.subject: PSYC
courses.title: Advanced Research (3)

courses.description: See HIST 212 for description.
courses.subject: PWAD
courses.title: History of Sea Power (HIST 212) (3)

courses.description: See MUSC 289 for description.
courses.subject: PWAD
courses.title: Sounds of War and Revolution (MUSC 289) (3)

courses.description: Introduction to the problem of war and violent conflict in human experience and the contemporary world, and efforts to prevent, avoid, or ameliorate war and its effects. Content will vary by instructor and disciplinary perspective but will include causes of war, deterrence, irregular war, and the future of war.
courses.subject: PWAD
courses.title: National and International Security (3)

courses.description: This course reviews the historic development of intelligence organizations and operations. The primary focus is on the modern world and the correlation between intelligence and national security concerns.
courses.subject: PWAD
courses.title: History of Intelligence Operations (3)

courses.description: Students are encouraged to undertake unpaid internships with branches of the federal government, international organizations, and selected nongovernment organizations. Pass/Fail only, with the written approval of the department chair. Does not count as a course in the major, but can be combined with an independent study such as PWAD 396.
courses.subject: PWAD
courses.title: Internship in Peace, War, and Defense (3–6)

courses.description: Permission of the instructor. Independent study and reading. Special reading and research activities in a selected field under the supervision of a faculty member.
courses.subject: PWAD
courses.title: Independent Study in Peace, War, and Defense (1–6)

courses.description: See GEOG 453 for description.
courses.subject: PWAD
courses.title: Political Geography (GEOG 453) (3)

courses.description: Permission of the instructor. Course investigates the intelligence function associated with United States national security, focusing on how national security decision makers (Congress and the Executive Branch) have designed and employed the intelligence apparatus as a component of nationalpower. Case studies and in-class simulations complement the readings and seminar discussions.
courses.subject: PWAD
courses.title: Intelligence for National Security (3)

courses.description: Examines the history of the British Empire and the role of peace, war, defense, diplomacy, and letters in shaping Britain’s presence on the world stage.
courses.subject: PWAD
courses.title: Empire and Diplomacy (3)

courses.description: Subject matter will vary with instructor, but will focus on some particular topic or historical approach. Course description available from departmental office.
courses.subject: PWAD
courses.title: Special Topics in Peace, War, and Defense (3)

courses.description: See HIST 577 for description.
courses.subject: PWAD
courses.title: United States Foreign Relations in the 20th Century (HIST 577) (3)

courses.description: See LAW 252 for description.
courses.subject: PWAD
courses.title: International Law (LAW 252) (3)
