courses.description: The course addresses the questions of the sources of international law; the formation of customary law; the law of treaties; some issues of interaction between international law and the law of the United States; the law of statehood; rules regarding the place of individuals in international law, without, however, special emphasis on international human rights rules; international legal restrictions on state jurisdiction; international legal restrictions on the use of force; the rights of states to protect their nationals, including corporations, from mistreatment by other states; international criminal law and the law of the sea. The course seeks to direct students' attention regarding the nature of law, and to focus - with respect to particular legal topics - on the basis for any assertion that rules whose existence is asserted are legal rules.
courses.subject: LAW
courses.title: International Law

courses.description: See ENGL 659 for description.
courses.subject: PWAD
courses.title: War in 20th-Century Literature (ENGL 659) (3)

courses.description: Undergraduate research seminar intended to provide an intensive research and writing experience for juniors and seniors in the major. Topic will vary by instructor. This course will emphasize developing research, writing, and presentation skills in topics relevant to the study of the problems of peace and security.
courses.subject: PWAD
courses.title: Research Seminar in Peace, War, and Defense (3)

courses.description: See RELI 110 for description.
courses.subject: JWST
courses.title: The Archaeology of Palestine in the New Testament Period (CLAR 110, RELI 110) (3)

courses.description: See HIST 153 for description.
courses.subject: JWST
courses.title: Jewish History from the Crusades to the European Enlightenment (HIST 153) (3)

courses.description: See ENGL 289 for description.
courses.subject: JWST
courses.title: Jewish American Literature and Culture of the 20th Century (ENGL 289) (3)

courses.description: See RELI 444 for description.
courses.subject: JWST
courses.title: Gender and Sexuality in Contemporary Judaism (RELI 444) (3)

courses.description: An introduction to the Islamic religious tradition, focusing on major themes of Islamic religious thought and bringing out both traditional spirituality and the critical issues confronting Muslims today.
courses.subject: RELI
courses.title: First-Year Seminar: Reintroducing Islam (3)

courses.description: This seminar asks why some people choose to take life (their own or another’s) for religious purposes and how texts, practices, and communities shape these motives. Focuses on martyrological traditions in Western religions, but also tracks idioms of war, sacrifice, and ritualized suffering in other religious contexts and secular discourses.
courses.subject: RELI
courses.title: First-Year Seminar: Martyrs and Warriors: Religion and the Problem of Violence (3)

courses.description: This course introduces students to New Testament literature and to the faith of the early Christian communities, focusing on Jewish and Greco-Roman background, the development of the gospel traditions, the life and ministry of Jesus, the ministry of Paul, the post-Pauline era, and the literature of the Johannine circle.
courses.subject: RELI
courses.title: Introduction to New Testament Literature (3)

courses.description: This course will explore Jewish literary works that are considered “fundamental,” “classic,” “traditional” (often, all of the above), including the Hebrew Bible, the Mishnah, the Babylonian Talmud, midrashic collections, works by Maimonides, major codes of Jewish law, major kabbalistic, philosophic, poetic, and ethical works, hassidic compositions, and more.
courses.subject: RELI
courses.title: Classic Jewish Texts: From Bible and Dead Sea Scrolls to Kabbalah and Hassidism (3)

courses.description: This course surveys the archaeology of Palestine (modern Israel and Jordan) from the Persian period (ca. 586 BCE) to the Muslim conquest (640 CE).
courses.subject: RELI
courses.title: The Archaeology of Palestine in the New Testament Period (CLAR 110, JWST 110) (3)

courses.description: (3). An overview of the history and culture of the ancient Near East, from the birth of writing through the first millennium BCE, covering the regions of Mesopotamia, Egypt, Anatolia, and Syria-Palestine.
courses.subject: RELI
courses.title: Culture of the Ancient Near East

courses.description: An introductory course that explores relations between religion and culture through the examination of social theory and the analysis of case studies. The case studies focus on such issues as visual culture, ritual, media, gender, and politics.
courses.subject: RELI
courses.title: Introduction to Religion and Culture (3)

courses.description: An introduction to philosophical approaches to the study of religion, exploring such topics as religious language and experience, the problem of evil, the relation between religious belief and practice, and issues of religious diversity.
courses.subject: RELI
courses.title: Introduction to Philosophical Approaches to Religion (3)

courses.description: An introduction to the history, themes, and issues in American religion from the precolonial period to the present.
courses.subject: RELI
courses.title: Religion in America (3)

courses.description: Analysis of continuities and innovations in the history of Western Christian traditions in the West and globally.
courses.subject: RELI
courses.title: Introduction to the History of Christian Traditions (3)

courses.description: Comparative study of mysticism in several religious traditions, Eastern and Western.
courses.subject: RELI
courses.title: Mysticism (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, RELI 211. This course explores the linguistic background of the Hebrew Bible, giving special attention to the literary aspect of biblical interpretation. Specific topics include the forms of the Hebrew verb, prose and poetic genres in the Hebrew Bible, wordplay and repetition, narration and dialogue.
courses.subject: RELI
courses.title: Classical Hebrew II: A Linguistic Introduction to the Hebrew Bible (3)

courses.description: This course explores the range of cultural manifestation of Christianity in the modern world, focusing particularly on differences of race, ethnicity, gender, geography, and class.
courses.subject: RELI
courses.title: Christian Cultures (3)

courses.description: An introduction to religion and visual culture in the United States. The course focuses on painting, ritual objects, and architecture.
courses.subject: RELI
courses.title: Religious Things (3)

courses.description: An examination of the development of teachings on issues of gender and sexuality through the history of Western Christianity, with particular focus on contemporary controversies.
courses.subject: RELI
courses.title: Gender and Sexuality in Western Christianity (WMST 244) (3)

courses.description: See RELI 244 for description.
courses.subject: WMST
courses.title: Gender and Sexuality in the Western Christian Tradition (RELI 244) (3)

courses.description: This course examines accounts of supernatural beings such as zombies and vampires and aims to understand them as popular ways of making sense of the world in the context of uneven and frequently unsettling processes of modernization, neoliberalism, and globalization.
courses.subject: RELI
courses.title: Supernatural Encounters: Zombies, Vampires, Demons, and the Occult in the Americas (3)

courses.description: This course surveys Muslim communities in North America in their religious, historical, political, social, and cultural dimensions. Discussion frames include methods for the study of American Muslims, the role of public and media representations of Islam and Muslims, and the place of American Muslims within the larger American religious landscape.
courses.subject: RELI
courses.title: Introduction to American Islam (3)

courses.description: Survey of the major religious traditions in modern and contemporary Japan: Shinto, Buddhism, and the New Religions.
courses.subject: RELI
courses.title: Modern Japanese Religions (ASIA 302) (3)

courses.description: An introduction the life and significance of the Prophet Muhammad and the sacred scripture of Islam, the Qur’an. It offers discussion of textual sources for Muhammad’s biography; his emulation and veneration in Muslim societies, and the nature, compilation, reception history, and range of interpretations of the Qur’an.
courses.subject: RELI
courses.title: Muhammad and the Qur’an (3)

courses.description: This course examines the archaeological context of Greek religion, cults, and associated rituals from the Bronze Age until the Hellenistic period with emphasis on urban, rural, and panhellenic sanctuaries, and methods of approaching ancient religion and analyzing cult practices.
courses.subject: RELI
courses.title: The Archaeology of Cult: The Material Culture of Greek Religion (CLAR 375) (3)

courses.description: Permission of the instructor. Subject matter will vary with instructor but will always be focused on a particular problem or issue.
courses.subject: RELI
courses.title: Topics in the Study of Religion (3)

courses.description: This course explores the complex relation between religion and science in the modern world. Public disputes over teaching evolution in American schools serve as a central case study of this.
courses.subject: RELI
courses.title: Religion and Science (3)

courses.description: See ANTH 428 for description.
courses.subject: RELI
courses.title: Religion and Anthropology (ANTH 428, FOLK 428) (3)

courses.description: The seminar examines the developments in gender roles and in sexuality in contemporary Judaism.
courses.subject: RELI
courses.title: Gender and Sexuality in Contemporary Judaism (JWST 444) (3)

courses.description: This course approaches questions of sexuality and marriage in Muslim discourse and practice in historical and geographical contexts. It focuses on gender as a category of inquiry and considers issues such as Muslim family law, normative sexuality, marriage practices, and religiously defined family values in their changing interpretations and applications.
courses.subject: RELI
courses.title: Marriage and Sexuality in Islam (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, RELI 110. Permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisite. This is a course on ancient synagogues in Palestine and the Diaspora from the Second Temple period to the seventh century CE.
courses.subject: RELI
courses.title: Ancient Synagogues (CLAR 512, JWST 512) (3)

courses.description: The course will examine the evangelical tradition from a global perspective, exploring the tradition from its early rise in Europe to its impact on the Americas, Africa, and Asia.
courses.subject: RELI
courses.title: Global Evangelicalism (3)

courses.description: The course examines the interaction between the values and messages of the counterculture and religious groups, ideas, and practices during the Vietnam War era. It also investigates the impact of countercultural norms and styles on the current American religious scene.
courses.subject: RELI
courses.title: Religion and the Counterculture (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, RELI 104, 207, or 208. Permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisite.
courses.subject: RELI
courses.title: Problems in Early Christian Literature and History (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, RELI 162. Permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisite. This course explores the history of the Second Council of the Vatican (Vatican II, 1962–1965), crucial for understanding contemporary Catholicism.
courses.subject: RELI
courses.title: Advanced Seminar in Contemporary Catholicism (3)

courses.description: Permission of the instructor. Study of selected religious, literary, and historical texts in Arabic, Persian, or Urdu.
courses.subject: RELI
courses.title: Readings in Islamicate Literatures (ARAB 681, ASIA 681) (3)

courses.description: Majors only. Concentrating on a different theme each year, this departmental seminar introduces the different areas and approaches in religious studies.
courses.subject: RELI
courses.title: Capstone: Undergraduate Seminar (3)

courses.description: Permission of the instructor. An examination of the main varieties of pre-rabbinic Judaism: Hellenistic Judaism, apocalyptic Judaism, and the Judaism of the dead sea scrolls.
courses.subject: RELI
courses.title: Early Jewish History and Literature (3)

courses.description: Permission of the instructor. exploration of one enduring issue in the history of the western Christian tradition. The instructor selects several case studies that illustrate both the topic and the developments within traditions.
courses.subject: RELI
courses.title: Methods and Topics in the Study of Western Religious Traditions (3)

courses.subject: RELI
courses.title: Buddhist Studies and the Construction of Buddhism (3)

courses.description: Permission of the instructor. 990 Preliminary Preparation (1–21).
courses.subject: RELI
courses.title: Readings and Research (3–9)

courses.description: Introduces the essential elements of French structure and vocabulary and aspects of French and francophone culture. Aural comprehension, speaking, reading, and writing.
courses.subject: FREN
courses.title: Elementary French I (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, FREN 101. Continues the study of essential elements of French structure, vocabulary, and aspects of French and francophone culture. Aural comprehension, speaking, reading, and writing.
courses.subject: FREN
courses.title: Elementary French II (3)

courses.description: Accelerated course that covers FREN 101 and 102 for students with previous study of French. Aural comprehension, speaking, reading, and writing.
courses.subject: FREN
courses.title: French for High Beginners (4)

courses.description: Prerequisite, FREN 102, 105, 111, or 401. Develops language skills for communication. Review of elementary French with increasing emphasis on reading and writing in the context of contemporary French and francophone culture.
courses.subject: FREN
courses.title: Intermediate French I (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, FREN 203. Continued development of language skills for communication through reading and discussion of literary and cultural texts. Emphasis on accurate grammar in written and oral expression.
courses.subject: FREN
courses.title: Intermediate French II (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, FREN 204, 212, or 402. Introductory conversation for building oral proficiency while increasing awareness of French culture. Emphasis on vocabulary and grammatical accuracy; writing activities support speaking.
courses.subject: FREN
courses.title: Conversation I (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, FREN 204, 212, or 402. Skills for further literary studies through French poetry, theater, and prose from Renaissance to the present. Lectures, discussions, and written assignments.
courses.subject: FREN
courses.title: Introduction to French Literature (3)

courses.description: Exploration of questions related to sex and gender during the French Revolution and their reflection in literature, philosophy, and art.
courses.subject: FREN
courses.title: Sex, Philosophy, and Politics: Revolutions in French Literature, 1721–1834 (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, FREN 204, 212, or 402. Recommended preparation, FREN 250, 255, or 260. Intensive grammar review and composition to improve accuracy and develop writing skills, using process and task-oriented approaches.
courses.subject: FREN
courses.title: French Composition and Grammar Review (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, FREN 250, 255, or 260. Practice of vocabulary and discourse strategies pertinent to businessrelated activity in French. Readings and discussions emphasize cultural awareness for interaction in cross-cultural settings.
courses.subject: FREN
courses.title: Business French (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, FREN 300. Oral communication and composition on contemporary topics in French and francophone cultures. Study of cultural texts, articles from the French press, and video documents.
courses.subject: FREN
courses.title: Advanced Oral and Written French (3)

courses.description: Prerequisites, FREN 260 or 312, and 300. A survey of major authors and the genres they represent in French literature of the 17th and 18th centuries.
courses.subject: FREN
courses.title: Survey of French Literature II (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, FREN 300. Interdisciplinary studies of France’s role in the construction of European identity.
courses.subject: FREN
courses.title: The Role of France in Europe Today (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, FREN 300. Required preparation, two major-level courses. Topic to be announced at registration (consult with French undergraduate advisor).
courses.subject: FREN
courses.title: Undergraduate Seminar in French (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, FREN 102, 105, 111, or 401. Covers second-year material in one semester. Develops skills, with increasing emphasis on reading and writing. Prepares for more advanced courses. May not be used to satisfy the Foundations foreign language requirement.
courses.subject: FREN
courses.title: Intermediate Accelerated French (3)

courses.description: Interdisciplinary seminar on a cultural topic or a theme through readings in literary and nonliterary texts.
courses.subject: FREN
courses.title: Studies in French Renaissance (3)

courses.description: In-depth study of the genealogy of the concept of libertinage as a philosophical discourse and aesthetic manifestation.
courses.subject: FREN
courses.title: Libertinism (3)

courses.description: Evolution of identity and nationhood in Québécois literature from the 1960s to the present, including the study of the literature of immigration (diasporic or littrature migrante).
courses.subject: FREN
courses.title: Diaspora and Transculturalism in Québécois Literature (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, ITAL 101. Continues study of essential elements of Italian structures, vocabulary, and aspects of Italian culture. Aural comprehension, speaking, reading, and writing are stressed in that order.
courses.subject: ITAL
courses.title: Elementary Italian II (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, ITAL 102 or 401. Develops language skills for communication. Reviews and expands grammar of elementary Italian with increasing emphasis on reading and writing in the context of Italian culture.
courses.subject: ITAL
courses.title: Intermediate Italian I (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, ITAL 203. Continued development of language skills for oral and written communication through reading and discussion of literature and expository texts. Further study of grammar.
courses.subject: ITAL
courses.title: Intermediate Italian II (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, ITAL 204 or 402. Designed to expand speaking skills through vocabulary building, discussion of selected texts, and activities that produce conversation. Ongoing development of writing skills.
courses.subject: ITAL
courses.title: Italian Conversation (3)

courses.description: Themes in Italian cinema: literary adaptation, neorealism, a single auteur or period, representations of fascism, the city, the country, industrialization, social space, north/ south difference, regionalism, gender, and sexuality.
courses.subject: ITAL
courses.title: Themes in Italian Film (3)

courses.description: A seminar on a previously announced subject.
courses.subject: ITAL
courses.title: Undergraduate Seminar in Italian (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, ITAL 102 or 401. Covers second-year material in one semester. Develops skills, with increasing emphasis on reading and writing. Prepares students for more advanced courses. May not be used to satisfy the Foundations foreign language requirement.
courses.subject: ITAL
courses.title: Intermediate Accelerated Italian (3)

courses.description: special study and research in set topics; e.g., seicento and baroque, autobiography, renaissance theater, literature, and film.
courses.subject: ITAL
courses.title: Seminar (3)

courses.description: Introduces the essential elements of Portuguese structure and vocabulary and aspects of Brazilian and Portuguese culture. Aural comprehension, speaking, reading, and writing are stressed in that order.
courses.subject: PORT
courses.title: Elementary Portuguese I (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, PORT 101. Continues study of essential elements of Portuguese structure, vocabulary, and aspects of Brazilian and Portuguese culture. Aural comprehension, speaking, reading, and writing are stressed in that order.
courses.subject: PORT
courses.title: Elementary Portuguese II (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, PORT 102, 111, or 401. Further development of language with emphasis on speaking, writing, and a review of grammar. Includes advanced Portuguese structures, cultural and literary texts.
courses.subject: PORT
courses.title: Intermediate Portuguese I (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, PORT 203. Continued development of language skills for communication. Further study of grammar.
courses.subject: PORT
courses.title: Intermediate Portuguese II (3)

courses.description: This course is devoted to the study of Brazilian culture through representative works of 19thand 20th-century literature.
courses.subject: PORT
courses.title: Modern Brazilian Literature in English Translation (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, PORT 204 or 402. Emphasizes the learning of Portuguese through cultural context. Language, society, and miscegenation will be approached through texts and films. Focus on important aspects of religion, festivities, and popular music from the Portuguese-speaking countries of three continents.
courses.subject: PORT
courses.title: Cultures of Brazil, Portugal, and Portuguese Africa (3)

courses.description: Study of the literary and cultural film production of the Portuguesespeaking world on three continents. Films in Portuguese with English subtitles.
courses.subject: PORT
courses.title: Portuguese, Brazilian, and African Identity in Film (3)

courses.description: A seminar on a previously announced subject.
courses.subject: PORT
courses.title: Undergraduate Seminar in Portuguese (3)

courses.description: For students who have fulfilled their foreign language requirement with another language. Covers first-year material in one semester. Introduction to spoken Portuguese with literary and cultural readings. May not be used to satisfy the Foundations foreign language requirement.
courses.subject: PORT
courses.title: Accelerated Brazilian Portuguese I (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, PORT 102, 111, or 401. Covers second-year material in one semester. Further study of spoken Portuguese with literary and cultural readings. May not be used to satisfy the Foundations foreign language requirement.
courses.subject: PORT
courses.title: Accelerated Brazilian Portuguese II (3)

courses.description: This course explores the concept of harmony in selected Italian writers from Dante to contemporary film directors.
courses.subject: ROML
courses.title: First-Year Seminar: Italians in Search of Harmony (3)

courses.description: Participants read poems, letters, stories, and short novels by Mexican women of the 20th century. Focus on gender and transgression, feminism, identity formation, and marginality. Selections from Elena Poniatowska, Sandra Cisneros, Cristina Rivera Garza, Ana Clavel, and Ángeles Mastretta, among others.
courses.subject: ROML
courses.title: First-Year Seminar: Mexican Women across Borders and Genres (3)

courses.description: Introduces the essential elements of Spanish structure and vocabulary and cultural aspects of the Spanishspeaking world. Aural comprehension, speaking, reading, and writing are stressed.
courses.subject: SPAN
courses.title: Elementary Spanish I (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, SPAN 100 or 101. Continues the study of the essential elements of Spanish structure, vocabulary, and the cultural aspects of the Spanish-speaking world. Aural comprehension, speaking, reading, and writing.
courses.subject: SPAN
courses.title: Elementary Spanish II (3)

courses.description: Accelerated course that covers SPAN 101 and 102 for students with previous study of Spanish. Aural comprehension, speaking, reading, and writing.
courses.subject: SPAN
courses.title: Spanish for High Beginners (4)

courses.description: Prerequisite, SPAN 102, 104, 105, 111, or 401. Develops language skills for communication. Review of elementary Spanish. Expands awareness of the Spanish-speaking world through readings and discussion of representative texts.
courses.subject: SPAN
courses.title: Intermediate Spanish I (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, SPAN 203. Continued development of language skills for communication. Considers finer points of linguistic structure. Expands awareness of Spanish culture through reading, inquiry, and class discussion.
courses.subject: SPAN
courses.title: Intermediate Spanish II (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, SPAN 204, 212, or 402. Develops skills for further literary studies while increasing Spanish language proficiency and providing different world views through literature. Native speakers need permission of the instructor.
courses.subject: SPAN
courses.title: Introduction to Spanish and Spanish American Literature (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, SPAN 204, 212, or 402. Develops skills for further literary studies while increasing Spanish language proficiency and providing different world views through literature. Native speakers need permission of the instructor.
courses.subject: SPAN
courses.title: Introduction to Spanish and Spanish American Literature (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, SPAN 204. All-skills course geared toward the language of various professions including business, journalism/mass communications, medicine, law. Emphasizes cultural knowledge to enhance professional work in the United States Hispanic community. Open only to students in the minor in Spanish for the professions.
courses.subject: SPAN
courses.title: Spanish Language and Culture for the Professions (3)

courses.description: Permission of the program director based on oral proficiency interview. Students must have advanced proficiency in Spanish. Students learn and implement fundamentals of foreign language instruction as peer tutors for elementary Spanish courses. Students may take course twice for credit. May not count toward the major or minor in Spanish.
courses.subject: SPAN
courses.title: Spanish Peer Tutoring (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, SPAN 250, 255, or 260. Intensive grammar review and composition designed to improve accuracy and develop writing skills, using process and task-oriented approaches.
courses.subject: SPAN
courses.title: Spanish Composition and Grammar Review (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, SPAN 265. All-skills course with review of grammar and extensive writing and speaking practice. Vocabulary, readings, and activities geared toward the language of business professions in the context of the United States Hispanic community.
courses.subject: SPAN
courses.title: Spanish for Business (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, SPAN 265. All-skills course with review of grammar, extensive writing and speaking practice. Vocabulary, readings, and activities geared toward the language of health care professions in the context of the United States Hispanic community. Open only to students in the minor in Spanish for the professions.
courses.subject: SPAN
courses.title: Spanish for the Medical Professions (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, SPAN 265. All-skills course with review of grammar and extensive writing and speaking. Vocabulary, readings, and activities geared toward the language of legal professions within the context of the Hispanic community. Open only to students in the minor in Spanish for the professions.
courses.subject: SPAN
courses.title: Spanish for the Legal Professions (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, SPAN 255 or 266. Study of language and society from the perspective of Spanish speakers in the United States, focusing on vocabulary building through situational practice, review of basic grammar, and practice in reading and writing.
courses.subject: SPAN
courses.title: Spanish Grammar and Composition for Heritage Speakers (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, SPAN 320, 321, 322, 323, or 327. Seventh-semester capstone course applying skills in Spanish language and cultures to professional and community contexts. Assignments include professional documents, community service work and projects, and a research project. Open only to students in the minor in Spanish for the professions.
courses.subject: SPAN
courses.title: Spanish for Professional and Community Engagement (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, SPAN 300 or 326. History and cultures of the Hispanic world from the beginnings to the mid-16th century. Explores the peculiarities that give each of the regions of Spain and Spanish America its distinctive character, as well as the elements that have shaped their societies and cultural traditions during the periods studied.
courses.subject: SPAN
courses.title: Cultural History of the Hispanic World (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, SPAN 300 or 326. History and cultures of Spain and Spanish America from the 16th century to the beginnings of the 20th century. Explores the distinctive character of regions of Spain and Spanish America, as well as the elements that have shaped their societies and cultural traditions during the periods studied.
courses.subject: SPAN
courses.title: Cultural History of the Hispanic World II (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, SPAN 250, 255, or 260. Students expand their speaking, writing, vocabulary, and grammar through analysis of Hispanic film. Discussion of global issues (drugs, immigration, cultural adaptations) and diversity (gender issues, class, regional and religious differences) in Spanishspeaking countries. Students may enroll in SPAN 293 for additional EE credit.
courses.subject: SPAN
courses.title: Cinema for Spanish Conversation (3)

courses.description: The immigration experience of the United States Hispanic community. Increases students’ cultural sensitivity through cultural simulations and other activities. Open only to students in the minor in Spanish for the professions.
courses.subject: SPAN
courses.title: United States Hispanic Community (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, SPAN 300 or 326. Recent trends in thought, art, film, music, and social practices. Highlights regions such as Galicia, the Basque country, Catalonia, and Andalusia. Topics include nationalism, ethnicity, gender, migration, and popular culture.
courses.subject: SPAN
courses.title: Cultures of Contemporary Spain (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, SPAN 300, 320, 321, 322, 323, or 326. Recent trends in thought, art, film, music, social practices, etc. Topics may include colonialism, race, ethnicity, modernization, ecology, religion, gender, and popular culture.
courses.subject: SPAN
courses.title: Contemporary Latin America: Mexico, Central America, and the Andean Region (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, SPAN 300 or 326. Recent trends in thought, art, film, music, social practices, etc. Topics include colonialism, race, ethnicity, modernization, ecology, religion, gender, and popular culture.
courses.subject: SPAN
courses.title: Contemporary Latin America: The Caribbean and the Southern Cone (3)

courses.description: Literature of the Mayas, Aztecs, and their neighbors from the pre-Columbian period to the present. Historical, cultural, and religious information with discussions of the complexity and variation of intercultural ways of life. A comparative approach includes the aesthetic similarities, differences, and rhetorical strategies employed by indigenous writers.
courses.subject: SPAN
courses.title: Mesoamerica through Its Literature (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, SPAN 300 or 326. Refines speaking skills through discussion of contemporary topics of the Spanish-speaking world using current periodicals, literature, etc. Includes significant writing component, review of grammar.
courses.subject: SPAN
courses.title: Advanced Conversation and Composition (3)

courses.description: Prerequisites, SPAN 260, and 300 or 326. The literature of Spain through 1700. Representative authors of Spanish literature from the medieval, Renaissance, and Golden Age.
courses.subject: SPAN
courses.title: Survey of Spanish Literature to 1700 (3)

courses.description: Prerequisites, SPAN 260, and 300 or 326. Main trends and movements in modern Spanish literature. Designed to familiarize students with methods of literary analysis and literary history. Readings and classes are in Spanish.
courses.subject: SPAN
courses.title: Survey of Spanish Literature since 1700 (3)

courses.description: Prerequisites, SPAN 260, and 300 or 326. The literature of Spanish America from pre-Colombian times to the present. Representative authors and texts from various literary movements will be studied in their sociohistorical contexts.
courses.subject: SPAN
courses.title: Survey of Spanish American Literature (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, SPAN 300 or 326. Introduction to the description of sound systems with a focus on Spanish. Includes the study of the historical development of Spanish and its areal and social variation in Spain, Latin America, and the United States.
courses.subject: SPAN
courses.title: Phonetics and Phonology (LING 376) (3)

courses.description: Prerequisites, SPAN 300 or 326, and 376. Introduction to the linguistic study of meaning, grammatical form, and dialectal and sociolinguistic variation, with a particular focus on modern Spanish and the languages of Spain and Latin America.
courses.subject: SPAN
courses.title: Grammatical Structure of Spanish (LING 377) (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, SPAN 376 or 377. Introduction to the study of Spanish in contact with African languages in the Iberian Peninsula and Latin America since the beginning of the slave trade. Linguistic analysis of literary texts from a variety of eras will assess how contact with the African diaspora has had a permanent impact on contemporary Spanish.
courses.subject: SPAN
courses.title: Afro-Hispanic Language Contacts (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, SPAN 371. A survey of lyric poetry, drama, prose, and genres peculiar to the literature before 1500.
courses.subject: SPAN
courses.title: Medieval Spanish Literature (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, SPAN 371. A survey of poetry, drama, and prose of the 16th century.
courses.subject: SPAN
courses.title: Spanish Literature of the Renaissance (3)

courses.description: Prerequisites, SPAN 300 or 326, and 371, 372, or 373. Workshop designed to develop critical communication skills through student short-story writing in Spanish, with an introduction to influential texts on the craft of writing by authors such as Horacio Quiroga, Julio Garmendia, Felisberto Hernández, Augusto Roa Bastos, Juan Bosch, Jorge Luis Borges, and Julio Cortázar.
courses.subject: SPAN
courses.title: Creative Writing in Spanish (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, SPAN 376 or 377. Seminar on a previously announced topic.
courses.subject: SPAN
courses.title: Undergraduate Seminar in Language and Linguistics (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, SPAN 102, 105, 111, or 401. Covers second-year material in one semester. Continued development of all skills. Spanish 402 prepares students for more advanced courses. May not be used to satisfy the Foundations foreign language requirement.
courses.subject: SPAN
courses.title: Intermediate Accelerated Spanish (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, SPAN 414. Continuation of the study of the language and culture of one of the languages of Spain other than Spanish. Selection will vary according to term: Catalan, Euskera, Galician.
courses.subject: SPAN
courses.title: Languages of Spain II (3)

courses.description: Panoramic view of indigenous literatures in the Américas through a study of a variety of indigenous textual production including chronicles, manifestos, novels, testimonial narratives, short stories, poetry, artistic production, and film.
courses.subject: SPAN
courses.title: Indigenous Literatures and Cultures of the Américas (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, SPAN 376, 377, or 378. Interdisciplinary approach to studying the Spanish language as a social and cultural phenomenon. Explores the relationship betweenlanguage and culture, communicative competence and pragmatics, social and linguistic factors in language variation and change, attitudes toward language and language choice, linguistic prejudice and language myths, and language and identity.
courses.subject: SPAN
courses.title: Spanish Sociolinguistics (3)

courses.description: An examination of the histories, chronicles, and other documents written in spain and spanish American, with special emphasis on the literature of exploration.
courses.subject: SPAN
courses.title: Nonfiction Prose of the 16th and 17th Centuries (3)

courses.description: readings from 18th and 19th-century spanish authors in various genres.
courses.subject: SPAN
courses.title: Enlightenment and Romanticism in Spain (3)

courses.description: see Poli 469 for description.
courses.subject: RUES
courses.title: Conflict and Intervention in the Former Yugoslavia (POLI 469, PWAD 469) (3)

courses.subject: RUES
courses.title: Selected Topics in Russian and East European Studies (3)

courses.description: Allows students to undertake advanced research under the supervision of a faculty member.
courses.subject: RUES
courses.title: Independent Study in Russian and East European Studies (1–21)

courses.description: See ECON 310 for description.
courses.subject: MNGT
courses.title: Microeconomics: Theory and Applications (ECON 310) (3)

courses.description: See SOCI 410 for description.
courses.subject: MNGT
courses.title: Formal Organizations and Bureaucracy (SOCI 410) (3)

courses.description: See SOCI 412 for description.
courses.subject: MNGT
courses.title: Social Stratification (SOCI 412) (3)

courses.description: See SOCI 415 for description.
courses.subject: MNGT
courses.title: Economy and Society (SOCI 415) (3)

courses.description: Examination of the structure and operation of institutions where economy and society intersect and interact, such as education, industrial organizations, on-the-job training, labor markets, and professional associations. Emphasis on the contemporary United States, with selected comparisons with Western Europe and Japan.
courses.subject: SOCI
courses.title: Economy and Society (MNGT 415) (3)

courses.description: See SOCI 427 for description.
courses.subject: MNGT
courses.title: The Labor Force (SOCI 427) (3)

courses.description: Supply and characteristics of labor and of jobs, including industrial and occupation changes, education and mobility of labor, and changing demography of the workforce.
courses.subject: SOCI
courses.title: The Labor Force (MNGT 427) (3)

courses.description: Provides tools for comprehensive, frank, civil conversations on controversial topics.
courses.subject: SOCI
courses.title: First-Year Seminar: Difficult Dialogues (3)

courses.description: Introduction to sociology as a discipline that includes study of differences and equality, social structure and institutions, culture, social change, individuals and populations, and social psychology.
courses.subject: SOCI
courses.title: Sociological Perspectives (3)

courses.description: Introduction to comparative sociology. The major types of society that have existed or now exist are analyzed, together with major patterns of social change.
courses.subject: SOCI
courses.title: Human Societies (3)

courses.description: Social and economic causes of population structure and change. Illustrations drawn from developing countries and the less developed regions and sections of the United States.
courses.subject: SOCI
courses.title: Population Problems (3)

courses.description: Examination of domination and subordination in general and in specific institutional areas (e.g., economy, polity) along racial and ethnic lines. Causes of changes in the levels of inequality and stratification are also studied.
courses.subject: SOCI
courses.title: Race and Ethnic Relations (3)

courses.description: Comparative analysis of kinship systems and family relations. Courtship, marriage, and parent-child relations viewed within a life-cycle framework. Students may not receive credit for both this course and SOCI 425.
courses.subject: SOCI
courses.title: Family and Society (3)

courses.description: Meaning and content of work in modern industrial society. Preparation for work; autonomy and control; inequality; consequences for health, safety, and family life.
courses.subject: SOCI
courses.title: Social Relations in the Workplace (MNGT 131) (3)

courses.description: Required of sociology majors. A study of theoretical perspectives in sociology, their relation to contemporary social issues, and their roots in classical social thought. Students may not receive credit for both SOCI 250 and SOCI 253.
courses.subject: SOCI
courses.title: Sociological Theory (3)

courses.description: Required of sociology majors. Methods of data collection, with attention to problem selection, sources of information, choice of methods, and research design. Operationalization and measurement; sampling, construction of questionnaires, and interviewing; observation techniques; experimentation.
courses.subject: SOCI
courses.title: Measurement and Data Collection (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, SOCI 251. Required of sociology majors. Methods of data analysis: descriptive and inferential statistics and multivariate analysis to permit causal inference. Attention to problems of validity and reliability and to index construction.
courses.subject: SOCI
courses.title: Data Analysis in Sociological Research (3)

courses.description: Covers theory and practice of social and economic justice, including analyses of racial, gender, sexual, class, national, and other forms of justice, the history of influential movements for justice, and strategies of contemporary struggles. This course has a 30-hour servicelearning component. Students may not receive credit for both SOCI 273 and SOCI 274.
courses.subject: SOCI
courses.title: Social and Economic Justice, Experiential Education (3)

courses.description: Covers theory and practice of social and economic justice, including analyses of racial-gender-sexual-class-national and other forms of justice, the history of influential movements for justice, and strategies of contemporary struggles. Students may not receive credit for both SOCI 273 and SOCI 274.
courses.subject: SOCI
courses.title: Social and Economic Justice (3)

courses.description: Permission of the department. This course is an internship experience directly relevant to the student’s academic progress in sociology and/or management and society. Pass/Fail only.
courses.subject: SOCI
courses.title: Independent Experiential Internship (1–3)

courses.description: Permission of the director of undergraduate studies. Special reading and research in a selected field under the direction of a member of the department faculty.
courses.subject: SOCI
courses.title: Independent Study and Reading (1–6)

courses.description: Varieties of organizational forms, their structures and processes; creation, persistence, transformation, and demise; role of organizations in contemporary society.
courses.subject: SOCI
courses.title: Formal Organizations and Bureaucracy (MNGT 410) (3)

courses.description: Study of nonroutine collective actions such as demonstrations, strikes, riots, social movements, and revolutions, with an emphasis on recent and contemporary movements. Students may not receive credit for both SOCI 411 and SOCI 413.
courses.subject: SOCI
courses.title: Social Movements and Collective Behavior (3)

courses.description: Analysis of social structure and stratification in terms of class, status, prestige, and rank. Attention to social roles of elites, professionals, the middle class, and the working class and to comparative topics.
courses.subject: SOCI
courses.title: Social Stratification (MNGT 412) (3)

courses.description: The city as a social, spatial, and political-economic phenomenon in the modern world. Analysis of urban demographic trends, spatial characteristics, and economic functions. substantive topics include segregation, social turmoil, unemployment, fiscal problems, suburbanization, and urban public policy. students may not receive credit for both soCi 414 and soCi 417.
courses.subject: SOCI
courses.title: The City and Urbanization, Experiential Education (3)

courses.description: Analysis of the reciprocal influences of state and social organizations upon each other; the social bases of political authority and stability, of revolution and counterrevolution.
courses.subject: SOCI
courses.title: Political Sociology (3)

courses.description: Course examines uniqueness of the sociological perspective in understanding mental health and illness. It draws upon various fields to explain mental illness in as broad a social context as possible. Attention focuses on how social factors influence definitions and perceptions of illness.
courses.subject: SOCI
courses.title: Sociology of Health and Mental Illness (3)

courses.description: A sociological analysis of comparative legal systems, the role of law in social change and in shaping social behavior. Topics may include the legal profession, property distribution, and the role of law in achieving racial and sexual justice.
courses.subject: SOCI
courses.title: Law and Society (3)

courses.description: An overview of theory and research on education and schooling, with an emphasis on inequalities in educational opportunities, education as a social institution, and the changing context of schools and schooling. Students may not receive credit for both SOCI 423 and SOCI 426.
courses.subject: SOCI
courses.title: Sociology of Education (3)

courses.description: Conceptualizations of gender, race, and class and how, separately and in combination, they are interpreted by the wider society. Emphasis on how black and working-class women make sense of their experiences at work and within the family.
courses.subject: SOCI
courses.title: Race, Class, and Gender (WMST 444) (3)

courses.description: The course focuses on how molecular genetics can enrich the social sciences. Topics include a brief overview of genetics and how genetic and social factors combine to predict behavior. We also consider the ethical, legal, and social issues that sometimes complicate the use of genetic data to study human behavior.
courses.subject: SOCI
courses.title: Society, Human Behavior, and Genomics (3)

courses.description: Provides an introduction to measurement theory and a review of various methods of datagathering. Gaining experience with a variety of techniques of measurement and preparing a pretested research proposal are required for all students.
courses.subject: SOCI
courses.title: Measurement and Data Collection (4)

courses.description: Permission of the instructor. The course description for a particular semester is available in the departmental office.
courses.subject: SOCI
courses.title: Seminar in Selected Topics (1–6)

courses.description: The course presents regression analysis and related techniques. The major topics are the assumptions of the regression model, dummy variables and interaction terms, outlier diagnostics, multicollinearity, specification error, heteroscedasticity and autocorrelation. The final section introduces path analysis, recursive models, and nonrecursive systems.
courses.subject: SOCI
courses.title: Linear Regression Models (4)

courses.description: Prerequisite, soCi 709 or 711. This course provides an introduction to event history analysis or survival analysis, random effects and fixed effects models for longitudinal data, multilevel models for linear and discrete multilevel data and growth curve models.
courses.subject: SOCI
courses.title: Longitudinal and Multilevel Data Analysis (3)

courses.description: A number of external speakers from government and industry will describe various problems they encounter in surveys. students will be challenged to develop proposals for addressing the problems, citing the literature as appropriate.
courses.subject: SOCI
courses.title: Case Studies in Surveys (3)

courses.description: Provides an intense introduction to the life course as a theoretical orientation and methodology (logic of inquiry).
courses.subject: SOCI
courses.title: The Life Course (3)

courses.description: A continuation of soCi 830. Materials covered include population growth and stable population theory, migration and distribution, population policy, and population estimates and projections.
courses.subject: SOCI
courses.title: Demography: Theory, Substance, Techniques, Part II (3)

courses.description: focuses on substantive and theoretical issues in this field and their intellectual origins. topics include organizations, art, religion, science, class, and politics. Quantitative and qualitative approaches are examined.
courses.subject: SOCI
courses.title: Sociology of Culture (3)

courses.description: Applied workshop in sample survey design and implementation. The student works in a data collection center under the guidance of the instructor. Course focuses on real world problems in data collection and their practical, cost-effective solutions.
courses.subject: SOCI
courses.title: Survey Practicum (1)

courses.description: doctoral candidacy in sociology or permission of the instructor. examines the teacher’s role and the teaching process, planning a course and constructing syllabi, testing for teaching or grading, evaluating teacher performance and the needs of different student populations.
courses.subject: SOCI
courses.title: Seminar on the Teaching of Sociology (3)

courses.description: individual research in a selected field under the direction of a member of the department.
courses.subject: SOCI
courses.title: Master’s Thesis (3–6)

courses.description: individual research in a selected field under the direction of a member of the department.
courses.subject: SOCI
courses.title: Doctoral Dissertation (3–9)

courses.description: Introduces basic concepts in finance and economics, useful tools for collecting and summarizing financial data, and simple probability models for quantification of market uncertainty.
courses.subject: STOR
courses.title: First-Year Seminar: A Random Walk down Wall Street (3)

courses.description: Special topics course. Content will vary each semester.
courses.subject: STOR
courses.title: First-Year Seminar: Special Topics (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, MATH 110. Elementary introduction to statistical reasoning, including sampling, elementary probability, statistical inference, and data analysis. STOR 151 may not be taken for credit by students who have credit for ECON 400 or PSYC 210.
courses.subject: STOR
courses.title: Basic Concepts of Statistics and Data Analysis I (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, MATH 110. Data analysis; correlation and regression; sampling and experimental design; basic probability (random variables, expected values, normal and binomial distributions); hypothesis testing and confidence intervals for means, proportions, and regression parameters; use of spreadsheet software.
courses.subject: STOR
courses.title: Introduction to Statistics (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, MATH 110. Introduction to basic concepts and techniques of decision making and information management in business, economics, and the social and physical sciences. Topics include discrete optimization, discrete probability, networks, decision trees, games, Markov chains.
courses.subject: STOR
courses.title: Introduction to the Decision Sciences (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, MATH 547. Linear, integer, nonlinear, and dynamic programming, classical optimization problems, network theory.
courses.subject: STOR
courses.title: Deterministic Models in Operations Research (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, STOR 455. Topics selected from design of experiments, sample surveys, nonparametrics, time series, multivariate analysis, contingency tables, logistic regression, and simulation. Use of statistical software packages.
courses.subject: STOR
courses.title: Statistical Methods II (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, STOR 445. Introduces concepts of random number generation, random variate generation, and discrete event simulation of stochastic systems. Students perform simulation experiments using standard simulation software.
courses.subject: STOR
courses.title: Simulation Analysis and Design (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, STOR 435. Short-term probability models for potential losses and their applications to both traditional insurance systems and conventional business decisions. Introduction to stochastic process models of solvency requirements.
courses.subject: STOR
courses.title: Short Term Actuarial Models (3)

courses.description: Permission of the director of undergraduate studies. This course is intended mainly for students working on honors projects. May be repeated for credit.
courses.subject: STOR
courses.title: Undergraduate Reading and Research in Statistics and Operations Research (1–3)

courses.description: Required preparation, calculus of several variables, linear or matrix algebra. The theory of linear programming, computational methods for solving linear programs, and an introduction to nonlinear and integer programming. Basic optimality conditions, convexity, duality, sensitivity analysis, cutting planes, and Karush-Kuhn-Tucker conditions.
courses.subject: STOR
courses.title: Linear Programming (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, STOR 634. Permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisite. Foundations of probability. Basic classical theorems. Modes of probabilistic convergence. Central limit problem. Generating functions, characteristic functions. Conditional probability and expectation.
courses.subject: STOR
courses.title: Probability (MATH 635) (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, stor 641. exponential distribution and Poisson process. birth-death processes, continuous-time Markov chains. transient and limiting behavior. Applications to elementary queueing theory. renewal processes and regenerative processes.
courses.subject: STOR
courses.title: Stochastic Models in Operations Research II (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, STOR 654. Point estimation. Hypothesis testing and confidence sets. Contingency tables, nonparametric goodness-of-fit. Linear model optimality theory: BLUE, MVU, MLE. Multivariate tests. Introduction to decision theory and Bayesian inference.
courses.subject: STOR
courses.title: Statistical Theory II (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, STOR 664. Permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisite. ANOVA (including nested and crossed models, multiple comparisons). GLM basics: exponential families, link functions, likelihood, quasi-likelihood, conditional likelihood. Numerical analysis: numerical linear algebra, optimization; GLM diagnostics. Simulation: transformation, rejection, Gibbs sampler.
courses.subject: STOR
courses.title: Applied Statistics II (3)

courses.description: This seminar course is intended to give Ph.d. students exposure to cutting edge research topics in statistics and operations research and assist them in their choice of a dissertation topic. The course also provides a forum for students to meet and learn from major researchers in the field.
courses.subject: STOR
courses.title: Statistics and Operations Research Colloquium (1)

courses.description: Prerequisites, stor 614, 641, and 762. Permission of the instructor. Gives students an opportunity to work on an actual operations research project from start to finish under the supervision of a faculty member. intended exclusively for operations research students.
courses.subject: STOR
courses.title: Operations Research Practice (3)

courses.description: Prerequisites, stor 435 and 555. introduction to time series: exploratory analysis, timedomain analysis and ArMA models, fourier analysis, state space analysis. introduction to multivariate analysis: principal components, canonical correlation, classification and clustering, dimension reduction.
courses.subject: STOR
courses.title: Time Series and Multivariate Analysis (3)

courses.description: Prerequisites, stor 555 and 641. familiarity with computer programming required. introduces students to modeling, programming and statistical concepts applicable to discrete event simulation on digital computers. emphasizes statistical analysis of simulation output. students model, program, and run simulations.
courses.subject: STOR
courses.title: Discrete Event Simulation (COMP 762) (3)

courses.subject: STOR
courses.title: Operations Research and Systems Analysis Student Seminar (1)

courses.description: Prerequisites, stor 635 and 654. Classical asymptotic distributional theory for maxima and order statistics from i.i.d. sequences, including extremal types theorem, domains of attraction, Poisson properties of high-level exceedances. stationary stochastic sequences and continuous time processes.
courses.subject: STOR
courses.title: Extreme Value Theory (3)

courses.description: Permission of the instructor. 891 Special Problems (1–3). Permission of the instructor.
courses.subject: STOR
courses.title: Special Problems (1–3)

courses.description: Permission of the instructor.
courses.subject: STOR
courses.title: Special Topics in Operations Research and Systems Analysis (1–3)

courses.description: Permission of the instructor.
courses.subject: STOR
courses.title: Directed Reading in Operations Research and Systems Analysis (1–21)

courses.description: students work with other organizations (industrial/Governmental) to gain practiced experience in statistics and operations research.
courses.subject: STOR
courses.title: Practicum (1–3)

courses.description: Permission of instructor. 993 Master’s Thesis (3–6). Permission of instructor.
courses.subject: STOR
courses.title: Master’s Substitute for Thesis (3–21)

courses.description: An interdisciplinary exploration of the intersections of gender, race, class, and sexuality in American society and internationally. Topics include work; sexuality; gender relations, and images of women in literature, art, and science; and the history of feminist movements. Course readings are drawn from the humanities and the social sciences.
courses.subject: WMST
courses.title: Introduction to Women’s Studies (3)

courses.description: This course introduces students to the broad range of disciplinary perspectives used by the field of sexuality studies to study, teach, and create knowledge about human sexuality in various functions and forms.
courses.subject: WMST
courses.title: Introduction to Sexuality Studies (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, WMST 101. Introduces students to feminist theorizing on debates over gender-based oppression. Gives students tools to pursue academic work in women’s studies and to understand the relationships among concepts, activism, and change. Required for majors. Strongly recommended for minors.
courses.subject: WMST
courses.title: Introduction to Feminist Thought (3)

courses.description: See GEOG 225 for description.
courses.subject: WMST
courses.title: Space, Place, and Difference (GEOG 225) (3)

courses.description: See ENGL 263 for description.
courses.subject: WMST
courses.title: Literature and Gender (ENGL 263) (3)

courses.description: See HIST 264 for description.
courses.subject: WMST
courses.title: Gender in Russian History, 1860–Present (HIST 264) (3)

courses.description: Through a diverse set of contemporary Latina/o texts, students will examine the response to and representation of gender and militarization in the Américas, examining in particular war, revolution, and the militarization of everyday life connected to spaces such as the United States-Mexico border and the United States prison industrial complex.
courses.subject: WMST
courses.title: Gender and Global Change: Militarization and Transnational Latina/o Literature (3)

courses.description: Course focuses on the history of women in African and Middle Eastern colonial and postcolonial legal systems. It examines “native” customary law, Islamic law, and human and women’s rights.
courses.subject: WMST
courses.title: Women and the Law in Africa and the Middle East (3)

courses.description: Examines interpersonal violence, the factors that enable it, and prevention strategies. The course examines violence on both individual and structural levels, considering perpetrators, victims/survivors, and bystanders and drawing upon the expertise of local organizers and service providers in the system of care.
courses.subject: WMST
courses.title: Leadership in Violence Prevention for Peer Educators (3)

courses.description: This course uses films, novels, and essays to engage with various notions of activism (as represented in art and social justice organizations) at play in hemispheric America.
courses.subject: WMST
courses.title: Spitting in the Wind: “American” Women, Art, and Activism (3)

courses.description: See ENGL 363 for description.
courses.subject: WMST
courses.title: Feminist Literary Theory (ENGL 363) (3)

courses.description: See ENGL 374 for description.
courses.subject: WMST
courses.title: Southern Women Writers (ENGL 374) (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, WMST 101. Permission of the instructor. Takes a feminist political-economy perspective on debates over current health issues of international concern, including abortion, population control, and sexually transmitted infections. Focuses on the United States, Mexico, and Kenya, as well as on international organizations and social movements.
courses.subject: WMST
courses.title: The International Politics of Sexual and Reproductive Health (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, WMST 101. Permission of the instructor. A supervised internship designed to provide experience working in organizations concerned with women’s or gender issues. Must be arranged with a faculty advisor during the semester prior to the internship. See the department’s Web site for important information.
courses.subject: WMST
courses.title: Practicum in Women’s and Gender Studies (3)

courses.description: Permission of the department chair. Faculty supervision required. Independent reading and research. Students can repeat the course as long as they work on a different topic each time they enroll.
courses.subject: WMST
courses.title: Independent Reading and Research (3)

courses.description: See SOCI 444 for description.
courses.subject: WMST
courses.title: Race, Class, and Gender (SOCI 444) (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, WMST 101. Permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisite. This course will present an overview of the variety and diversity of contemporary American women’s experiences of creative expressions. We explore how women have been historically excluded from the arts.
courses.subject: WMST
courses.title: Women and Creativity (3)

courses.description: See ENGL 666 for description.
courses.subject: WMST
courses.title: Queer Latina/o Photography and Literature (ENGL 666) (3)

courses.subject: WMST
courses.title: Sr Sem: Prin Fem Inquiry Lecture

courses.description: explores the complex interaction between women’s studies, feminist studies and gender studies as these fields have evolved within and across academic disciplines, intersecting with issues of race, class, ethnicity, masculinity, sexuality, and with practices of queer theory and cultural studies.
courses.subject: WMST
courses.title: Graduate Seminar in Women’s Studies (3)

courses.description: Permission of the instructor. intensive reading and research in a student’s chosen area of interest under faculty supervision. results in a written report.
courses.subject: WMST
courses.title: Graduate Independent Reading and Research (1-3)

courses.description: deals with the key methods of describing and evaluating literature and literature in performance.
courses.subject: COMM
courses.title: Performance Criticism (3)

courses.subject: GRAD
courses.title: Leadrshp In Sci Based Orgnztn Lecture

courses.subject: HPM
courses.title: Sem In Comp Effective Research Lecture

courses.description: Co-requisite, MUsC 994. forum for group discussion of on-going dissertation work and professional development.
courses.subject: MUSC
courses.title: Dissertation Colloquium (1

courses.description: Permission of the instructor. This seminar exposes students to a variety of issues related to journal publication in sociology, such as types of journals and collaboration, the experience of writing an article for submission to a journal, reviewing articles for journals, and responding to editorial decisions.
courses.subject: SOCI
courses.title: Publishing in Sociology (3)

courses.description: Elements of accounting for management planning, budgeting, and control. Emphasis is on management uses of accounting information.
courses.subject: BUSI
courses.title: Management Accounting (4)

courses.description: Open to business majors. Writingand speaking-intensive course that emphasizes professional communication. Provides opportunities to learn and apply the conventions and expectations for standard business documents and presentations. Features strategies for addressing informative, persuasive, and bad-news messages using a variety of media (print documents, electronic messages, and oral presentations).
courses.subject: BUSI
courses.title: Management and Corporate Communication (3)

courses.description: Analysis of the operations functions in both manufacturing and service organizations. Formulating operational policies that improve efficiency and support high-level business strategy. Developing remedies that mitigate uncertainty and variability in operational processes.
courses.subject: BUSI
courses.title: Operations Management (3)

courses.description: An introduction to the legal system and an examination of ethical issues that affect business.
courses.subject: BUSI
courses.title: The Legal and Ethical Environment of Business (1

courses.description: An introduction to leading and managing in organizations. Examines the impact of individual, group, and organizational factors on organizational performance and employee attitudes. Topics include leadership, perceptions, attitudes, motivation, group development, norms and cohesiveness, empowerment, conflict, negotiations, culture, structure, stress, innovation, and change.
courses.subject: BUSI
courses.title: Leading and Managing: An Introduction to Organizational Behavior (3)

courses.description: Introduction to marketing with emphasis on the social and economic aspects of distribution, consumer problems, marketing functions and institutions, marketing methods and policies.
courses.subject: BUSI
courses.title: Marketing (3)

courses.description: Students will acquire the tools to understand and analyze information presented in corporate financial statements. Financial accounting results and projected results are utilized in virtually every segment of the business world. Knowledge of financial accounting and analysis is necessary for managers, investors, bankers, financial analysts, and professional accountants.
courses.subject: BUSI
courses.title: Financial Accounting and Analysis (3)

courses.description: Prerequisites, BUSI 101 and ECON 410. Theoretical foundations of optimal financial policy. Problems and cases provide application of theory to financial decisions involving cash flow, capital structure, capital budgeting.
courses.subject: BUSI
courses.title: Corporate Finance (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, BUSI 408. A follow-up course to BUSI 408 that goes more deeply into the theory and application of financial management. Emphasis is placed on investment, financing, and dividend decisions.
courses.subject: BUSI
courses.title: Advanced Corporate Finance (1

courses.description: Prerequisite, STOR 155. While witnessing an explosion of data, most organizations tend to be awash with data but short on information. This course exposes students to techniques that will help them impact on an organization’s strategy, planning, and operations, working on applications spanning a number of fields, including operations management, finance, and marketing.
courses.subject: BUSI
courses.title: Business Analytics (3)

courses.description: Students analyze sources of competitive success in organizations using case analysis and written reports to develop analytical reasoning and strategic decision-making skills. Topics include industry analysis, business and corporate strategy, and international business.
courses.subject: BUSI
courses.title: Strategic Management (1

courses.description: Varied topics in business administration.
courses.subject: BUSI
courses.title: Business Topics (1

courses.description: Examines what it means to pursue business success as measured by the triple-bottom line of people, planet, and profit. Focuses on strategies that companies implement to reduce environmental impact internally and through the supply chain. Examines the responsibility of business to employees, consumers, the local community, and society at large.
courses.subject: BUSI
courses.title: Sustainable Business and Social Entrepreneurship (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, BUSI 408. This course will focus on the different ways to finance real estate property, and how different financing techniques impact the feasibility and investment benefits for equity investors.
courses.subject: BUSI
courses.title: Real Estate Finance (1

courses.description: Permission of the department. Supervised individual study and research in the student’s special field of interest.
courses.subject: BUSI
courses.title: Independent Study in Business (1

courses.description: Students gain an understanding of entrepreneurship and the tools and skills necessary to conceive, plan, execute, and scale a successful new venture. Students develop business ventures in teams through an experiential pedagogy.
courses.subject: BUSI
courses.title: Entrepreneurship and Business Planning (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, BUSI 406. Critical concepts and skills for selling products and services, and influencing others in business. Applicable to people considering sales or consulting as a career; to those thinking of starting an entrepreneurial company; or for those who want to understand how to influence peers, subordinates, and management.
courses.subject: BUSI
courses.title: Professional Selling Strategies and Skills (3)

courses.description: Helps the student understand the evolutionary stages in the life of afamily business and the challenges and opportunities that must be managed at each stage.
courses.subject: BUSI
courses.title: Family Business I: Introduction to Family Enterprise (1

courses.description: Prerequisite, BUSI 500. This is a cross-campus course for exceptional students, staff, and faculty, designed to help launch UNC–Chapel Hill start-ups. Only for students serious about launching in the next nine to 12 months. Admission by online application. More information at www.launch.unc.edu.
courses.subject: BUSI
courses.title: Launching the Venture (1

courses.description: Student teams engage in consulting projects to help local start-ups tackle entrepreneurial challenges. Data is collected through fieldwork, such as client meetings, customer surveys, interviews with thought leaders, site visits, product tests, and/or focus groups.
courses.subject: BUSI
courses.title: Consulting to Entrepreneurial Firms (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, BUSI 408. An introduction to the tools and skills necessary to recognize opportunities in high tech, biotech, and traditional start-ups. Local entrepreneurs come to class to pitch to students, who analyze the start-ups from the perspective of venture capitalists.
courses.subject: BUSI
courses.title: Venture Capital and Start-Ups (3)

courses.description: Recommended preparation, completion of BUSI 503. Helps the student understand specific ownership, stewardship, tax, transition, and wealth management issues that affect family enterprises.
courses.subject: BUSI
courses.title: Family Business II: Governance and Ownership (1

courses.description: Preor corequisite, BUSI 554. Student Teams Achieving Results (STAR) is a live management consulting project that leverages and integrates UNC Kenan–Flagler course curricula. Teams of five to seven M.B.A. and undergraduate students and one faculty member work with major corporations or not-for-profit entities to solve a major strategic issue.
courses.subject: BUSI
courses.title: STAR (4

courses.description: Prerequisite, BUSI 408. The objective of this course is to examine the changing world of private equity investments today. This is a survey course and will help prepare you to work for private equity and venture capital funds or to work for investment banks.
courses.subject: BUSI
courses.title: Private Equity and Debt Markets (1

courses.description: Primarily an online class. Use critical thinking and advanced Excel features to create spreadsheet models of common business problems. Topics include flexible design, problem-solving, statistical analysis, charting, logic, reference functions, financial analysis, organizing data for complex analysis, what-if analysis, enhanced decision-making tools, troubleshooting workbooks, and VBA.
courses.subject: BUSI
courses.title: Advanced Spreadsheet Modeling for Business (3)

courses.description: Focuses on improving students’ soft skills, such as presenting, expressiveness, and interviewing, by applying the principles and techniques of improvisational theater. Participants explore creativity, adaptation, awareness, self-confidence, risk taking, physicality, intuition, and teamwork. Students can stretch their abilities and discover things about themselves and others that are crucial to success.
courses.subject: BUSI
courses.title: Applied Improvisation for Business Communication (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, BUSI 401. This course is grounded in argument, persuasion, and visual rhetoric to give students skills needed to develop winning presentations. Students learn strategies to help their messages “stick” with their audiences and to develop slide decks for the boardroom and advanced media devices. The course emphasizes efficiency in presentation preparation.
courses.subject: BUSI
courses.title: Advanced Business Presentations (1

courses.description: Permission of the department. Provides student leaders with practical leadership frameworks and tools; creates opportunities to apply these on the job as leaders; and provides individualized coaching, feedback, and mentoring. This is an applied learning course taught by a seasoned practitioner designed to accelerate each student’s development and growth.
courses.subject: BUSI
courses.title: Leadership in Action (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, BUSI 403. Studies key challenges in effective service delivery through the analysis of staffing and scheduling, customer waiting, and revenue management. Case studies illustrate examples of effective service design and delivery in various service industries including professional services, banking, health care, hospitality, and entertainment. A simulation project is used.
courses.subject: BUSI
courses.title: Service Operations (3)

courses.description: Provides a broad scope of analytic experience across corporate functions that is beneficial in consulting environments.
courses.subject: BUSI
courses.title: Business Modeling with Excel (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, BUSI 403. Permission of the department. This course examines how organizations can use their operations to build a competitive advantage. Students may not receive credit for both BUSI 535 and MBA 709A.
courses.subject: BUSI
courses.title: Global Operations Strategy (1

courses.description: Prerequisite, BUSI 403. Permission of the department. This course prepares students to take part in and lead projects effectively. The goal is to equip individuals across any career concentration rather than extend the expertise of projectmanagement specialists. Students may not receive credit for both BUSI 536 and MBA 710.
courses.subject: BUSI
courses.title: Project Management (1

courses.description: Prerequisite, BUSI 403. Permission of the department. Examines developments in retailing and operations management principles applicable to these developments. Topics: consumer behavior, demand forecasting, logistics and distribution, store execution, international retailing, Internet-based retailing, performance assessment, and impact on financial performance. Students may not receive credit for both BUSI 537 and MBA 708.
courses.subject: BUSI
courses.title: Retail Operations (1

courses.description: Prerequisite, BUSI 403. This course explores the link between sustainability and the operations function of a firm. The course focuses on the following activities: product and process design; manufacturing; transportation; logistics and distribution; closed-loop/after-sales operations such as recycling, remanufacturing, and reuse; supply chain management.
courses.subject: BUSI
courses.title: Sustainable Operations (1

courses.description: Prerequisite, BUSI 405. This course enables students to develop their expertise in managing negotiations. It integrates existing theory and research with personal experiences and ideas. Using hands-on exercises, readings, and lively discussions, students build and hone their ability to understand, adapt to, and evaluate the personal, social, and situational dynamics of negotiations.
courses.subject: BUSI
courses.title: Negotiations (1

courses.description: Prerequisite, BUSI 406. This course provides students a thorough understanding and working knowledge of state-of-the-art tools that drive marketing strategies for launching and managing new products.
courses.subject: BUSI
courses.title: New Product Marketing (1

courses.description: Prerequisite, BUSI 406. Review of conceptual models and empirical research in consumer behavior. Topics include decision processes, social and cultural influences, information processing, and ethical issues.
courses.subject: BUSI
courses.title: Consumer Behavior (3)

courses.description: Prerequisites, BUSI 406 and 410. Marketing analytics is a systematic approach to harnessing these data to drive effective marketing decision making. We will learn to analyze historical data, market research data, and competitive information for making strategic marketing decisions. This course will be extensively based on case analysis and hands-on exercises.
courses.subject: BUSI
courses.title: Marketing Analysis and Decision Making (3)

courses.description: Permission of the department. Required in spring semester for senior undergraduate business majors who are admitted to the Kenan–Flagler Master of Accounting Program. The first of two courses designed to provide students with an in-depth knowledge of the practice and theory of financial accounting.
courses.subject: BUSI
courses.title: Financial Reporting A (3)
