courses.description: History and development of occupation-based services in community settings; evolution, structure, and operation of community programs; use of consulting and planning skills in a comprehensive and systematic planning model.
courses.subject: OCCT
courses.title: Evolution of Community-Based Practice: Development, Implementation and Evaluation (2)

courses.description: Prerequisites, oCCt 828, 750, and 751. A problem-based learning approach to the occupational therapy clinical reasoning process, assessments, interventions, and adaptations for children with disabilities.
courses.subject: OCCT
courses.title: Children: Occupations, Adaptation, and Technology III (3)

courses.subject: OCCT
courses.title: Independent Study: Occupational Therapy and Science (1–21)

courses.description: Collaborative research projects in occupational science or occupational therapy. emphasis on data collection, analysis and professional communications of research findings.
courses.subject: OCCT
courses.title: Applied Research Experience (3)

courses.description: independent study to pursue specific interests and topics under faculty supervision.
courses.subject: OCSC
courses.title: Independent Study in Occupational Science (1–3)

courses.description: Applied introduction to proposal and grant writing. Preparation to seek external funding for further graduate studies and future support. Consideration given to effective communication and writing for different audiences.
courses.subject: OCSC
courses.title: Grant Writing (3)

courses.subject: OCSC
courses.title: Seminar on Special Topics in Occupational Science (3)

courses.subject: PHYT
courses.title: Clin Ed Sem Ii / Iii Lecture

courses.description: Prerequisite, RADI 461. The course content prepares students for standard radiography of cranial bones, facial bones, and special cranial projections. Contrast studies include gastrointestinal, urinary, biliary, cardiovascular, and other special procedures. The course includes pathologies and gross, radiographic, and cross-sectional anatomy. Two lecture hours and two laboratory hours.
courses.subject: RADI
courses.title: Radiography II (3)

A detailed study of specific elements of the radiographic process, with an emphasis on the interrelationships of the radiographic parameters, refinement of image analysis and problem-solving skills, and quality control testing for evaluating the performance of the radiographic equipment and accessories. Three lecture hours and two laboratory hours.

courses.subject: RADI

courses.description: Prerequisite, RADI 660. This course involves students in situational problem solving and radiographic analysis. Integration of concepts and knowledge of anatomy, pathology, procedures, patient care, and imaging principles are emphasized. Four lecture hours.

courses.description: Majors only. The course covers issues related to healthcare systems, medicolegal ethics, and practice and quality assurance. Three lecture hours per week.

courses.description: Supervised undergraduate directed research on communication science topics of mutual interest to the student and a faculty member.

courses.title: Auditory Evoked Potentials I (3)

courses.description: Principles of vestibular function and dysfunction, clinical assessment and management.

courses.title: Macromolecular Equilibria (1

courses.title: Macromolecular Interactions (1)

courses.title: Macromolecular Spectroscopy (1)

courses.title: Advanced NMR Spectroscopy Course (1)

courses.description: Prerequisite, Gnet 621. students will learn about various topics that form the basis for understanding quantitative genetics of complex traits with biomedical and agricultural relevance. The ultimate goal of quantitative genetics in this postgenomic era is prediction of phenotype from genotype, namely deducing the molecular basis for genetic trait variation.

courses.subject: NBIO
courses.title: Gene-Brain-Behavior Interactions in Neurodevelopmental Disorders: Perspectives on Disease Mechanisms (1-5)

courses.description: This seminar will review the epidemiology, pathogenesis, diagnosis and treatment of neurodevelopmental syndromes and disorders. topics will range from single gene (e.g. fragile X syndrome and tuberous sclerosis) to complex genetic (e.g., autism, schizophrenia), to environmental disorders with varied phenotypes, pathogenetic mechanisms, and treatments.
courses.subject: NBIO
courses.title: Clinical Syndromes and Neurodevelopmental Disorders (1-5)

courses.description: Permission of the department. research in various aspects of neurobiology. six to 24 hours a week.
courses.subject: NBIO
courses.title: Research in Neurobiology (BIOL 951, PHCO 951, PHYI 951) (3–12)

courses.description: Course is designed to certify that the students have achieved a high level of knowledge competence in clinical and basic neurosciences, without the rigorous research experience required of a Ph.d.
courses.subject: NBIO
courses.title: Master’s Thesis (3–9)

courses.description: Hours, credits, and instructor to be arranged on an individual basis. Hands-on research experience in a predetermined instructor’s laboratory. Students learn and apply specific techniques and participate in investigations of molecular mechanisms responsible for disease processes (pathobiology). Contact the director of graduate studies in pathology for information. May be repeated.
courses.subject: PATH
courses.title: Experimental Pathology (1–9)

courses.description: Permission of the instructor. Course focuses on practical fundamentals of light microscopy including optics, contrast mechanisms, fluorescence, laser scanning confocal microscopy, photography, and digital imaging.
courses.subject: PATH
courses.title: Light Microscopy (3)

courses.description: Corequisite, PAtH 716l. A graduate-level course on systemic pathology, emphasizing the molecular and cellular pathogenesis of diseases of major organ systems. A follow-up to PAtH 713/714l. Three lecture hours (three credits) with a complementary two-and-a-half-hour laboratory (two credits) each week.
courses.subject: PATH
courses.title: Molecular and Cellular Pathophysiological Basis of Disease: Systemic Pathology (3)

courses.description: Permission of the instructor. A multi-disciplinary course providing students principles involved in translating basic science into clinically applicable diagnostics and therapies to improve human disease outcomes. The course is focused on bioinformatics, bioethics, trial design, fdA approval, and commercialization of laboratory diagnostics.
courses.subject: PATH
courses.title: Translational Pathology and Laboratory Medicine (2)

courses.description: Permission of the instructor. survey of classical and current literature on selected critical issues in carcinogenesis. students discuss experimental methods and observations as well as theories and generalizations. two seminar hours a week.
courses.subject: PATH
courses.title: Seminar in Carcinogenesis (TOXC 792) (2)

courses.description: Permission of the department. This is a research course in which advanced students in pathology carry on investigations on mechanisms of disease. six or more laboratory hours a week, to be arranged. May be repeated.
courses.subject: PATH
courses.title: Research in Pathology (2–12)

courses.description: Permissionof the instructor. Participants in the interdisciplinary vascular biology training Program only. students will be required to present their thesis work as a formal seminar, give an introductory lecture to introduce their project (in cooperation with their thesis advisor), and to attend and discuss the seminars of other students.
courses.subject: PATH
courses.title: Seminar in Interdisciplinary Vascular Biology (1)

courses.description: see toXC 707 for description.
courses.subject: PHCO
courses.title: Advanced Toxicology (ENVR 707, TOXC 707) (3)

courses.description: This is a series of seminar courses dealing with advanced topics in modern molecular pharmacology based mainly on discussion of current literature.
courses.subject: PHCO
courses.title: Seminar Courses in Pharmacology (1–3)

courses.description: see PHyi 723 for description.
courses.subject: PHCO
courses.title: Cellular and Molecular Neurobiology II (PHYI 723) (2–6)

courses.description: see PHyi 723 for description.
courses.subject: PHCO
courses.title: Cellular and Molecular Neurobiology II (PHYI 723) (2–6)

courses.description: see PHyi 723 for description.
courses.subject: PHCO
courses.title: Cellular and Molecular Neurobiology II (PHYI 723) (2–6)

courses.description: A lecture/discussion course on the biological bases of alcohol and substance abuse.
courses.subject: PHCO
courses.title: Neuropharmacology of Alcohol and Substance Abuse (3)

courses.description: students meet as a group with faculty members to develop skills in critical reading and to summarize and discuss selected aspects of current pharmacological literature. two hours a week.
courses.subject: PHCO
courses.title: Seminar in Recent Advances in Pharmacology (1)

courses.description: Prerequisite, PHCo 701. Permission of the instructor. A discussion course covering the elements of successful grant proposals and scientific ethics.
courses.subject: PHCO
courses.title: Grant Writing (2)

courses.description: This course will introduce computer vision methods for cell biology. each topic will be motivated with an explanation of a computational challenge, followed by a discussion of available techniques to address the need and practical examples for how to apply the techniques.
courses.subject: PHCO
courses.title: Introduction to Computer Vision Tools for Modern Microscopy (1)

courses.description: Permission of the department.
courses.subject: PHCO
courses.title: Research in Pharmacology (1–21)

courses.description: Prerequisites, CHEM 101 and 102 (or BIOC 107 and 108) and BIOL 252. A course in human physiology exploring physiological processes from molecular to organ systems levels including regulation and interrelationships. Five lecture hours a week.
courses.subject: PHYI
courses.title: Introduction to Physiology (5)

courses.description: Prerequisites, BIOL 101/101L and CHEM 101/101L. Permission of the instructor. Directed readings or laboratory study on a selected topic. Final written report required in each term. At least three hours of independent work per week for each unit of credit.
courses.subject: PHYI
courses.title: Undergraduate Research in Physiology (1–6)

courses.description: see Cbio 644 for description.
courses.subject: PHYI
courses.title: Cell Structure, Function, and Growth Control II (BIOC 644, CBIO 644, MCRO 644, PHCO 644) (3)

courses.description: Permission of the instructor. Molecular and cellular basis of organ system function; integration of systems to maintain the normal state. Understanding of normal physiology is amplified by examples from human disease and mouse models. Principles of cell, organ, and integrative physiology and how these principles apply to translational research.
courses.subject: PHYI
courses.title: Experimental Physiology of Human Health and Disease (4)

courses.description: Practice in oral and written communication evaluated by peers and faculty. includes delivery of coached presentations on topics in physiology and preparation of writing assignments typically encountered in scientific life.
courses.subject: PHYI
courses.title: Communicating Scientific Results (1)

courses.description: Permission of the director of graduate studies.
courses.subject: PHYI
courses.title: Seminar in Physiology (1)

courses.description: Prerequisite, PHCo 702. Permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisite. Cellular and physiological basis of toxicity of environmental chemicals, with emphasis on inhalation toxicology, developmental toxicology, immunotoxicology, radiation toxicology, renal toxicology, and neurotoxicology. Three lecture hours per week.
courses.subject: TOXC
courses.title: Advanced Toxicology (ENVR 707, PHCO 707) (3)

courses.description: Presentations byoutside invited speakers, local faculty, advanced graduate students, and postdoctoral trainees. topics will cover all areas of research in toxicology. one hour per week.
courses.subject: TOXC
courses.title: Toxicology Seminar III (ENVR 722) (1)

courses.description: see toXC 722 for description.
courses.subject: ENVR
courses.title: Toxicology Seminar III (TOXC 722) (1)

courses.description: see PAtH 792 for description.
courses.subject: TOXC
courses.title: Seminar in Carcinogenesis (PATH 792) (2)

courses.description: May be repeated. students register in this course as they formulate their doctoral research projects.
courses.subject: TOXC
courses.title: Research in Toxicology (3)

courses.description: May be repeated. Hours and credits to be arranged.
courses.subject: TOXC
courses.title: Master’s Thesis (3)

courses.description: Majors only. This course emphasizes a lifespan approach to theories and perspectives on individual growth and development. Content focuses on physical, cognitive, and socioemotional development, and risk factors from birth to death.
courses.subject: NURS
courses.title: Individual Development across the Lifespan (2)

courses.description: Majors only. This course involves the nursing application of nutritional concepts to the care of individuals, families, groups, and populations across the lifespan.
courses.subject: NURS
courses.title: Nursing Role in Normal Nutrition (2)

courses.description: Majors only. The course focuses on understanding basic nursing concepts. The development of communication, teaching, and psychomotor skills are emphasized in conjunction with nursing process. Research as a basis for practice is recognized.
courses.subject: NURS
courses.title: Concepts, Processes, and Skills for Evidence-Based Nursing (4)

courses.description: Majors only. This course is concerned with alterations involved in disruptions of normal physiology as well as pathophysiological principles underlying therapeutic interventions and outcomes.
courses.subject: NURS
courses.title: Pathophysiology (3)

courses.description: Majors only. Using the science of pharmacology and pharmacologic principles underlying therapeutic interventions, this course focuses on an introduction to nursing responsibilities regarding pharmacologic therapy across the lifespan.
courses.subject: NURS
courses.title: Pharmacology across the Lifespan (3)

courses.description: Majors only. This course addresses concepts and methods of comprehensive health assessment of children, adults, and elders. Emphasis will be on data collection as a basis for initiation of caring and decision making in nursing practice.
courses.subject: NURS
courses.title: Health Assessment (3)

courses.description: Preor corequisite, NURS 364. Permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisite. Students are introduced to key concepts of evidence-based nursing practice, including the research process, protection of human subjects, and retrieval and appraisal of evidence to maintain a scientifically sound practice.
courses.subject: NURS
courses.title: Nursing Inquiry and Evidence-Based Practice (3)

courses.description: Majors only. This course explores essential competencies in genetics and genomics for registered nurses. The learner gains knowledge about family assessment and the impact of genomic issues on individuals and families.
courses.subject: NURS
courses.title: Family-Centered Genomic Health Care (1)

courses.description: Prerequisites, NURS 364 and 371. Corequisites, NURS 472, 477, or 479. Majors only. Students apply public health concepts to community practice to improve health and reduce disparities across the lifespan, emphasizing interventions using partnership strategies at individual/family, organizational, and policy levels.
courses.subject: NURS
courses.title: Public Health Nursing (5)

courses.description: Prerequisite, NURS 364. Majors only. Nursing care of infants, children, and their families is explored. Knowledge from a variety of disciplines is applied through the nursing process to the direct care of infants and children.
courses.subject: NURS
courses.title: Nursing Care of Infants, Children, and Their Families (5)

courses.description: Prerequisites, NURS 253, 361, and 362. Corequisites, NURS 364 and 382. Majors only. Using theories of psychosocial development, psychopathology, therapeutic communication, and psychotherapy, this course requires students to examine the range and complexities of human emotional suffering and methods of effective intervention.
courses.subject: NURS
courses.title: Psychiatric Mental Health Concepts for Broad Clinical Application in Nursing (5)

courses.description: Prerequisite, NURS 364. Majors only. The course focuses on application of caring and critical thinking skills in providing evidence-based nursing care to childbearing families.
courses.subject: NURS
courses.title: Maternal/Newborn Nursing (5)

courses.description: Prerequisites, NURS 254 and 364. Majors only. Certification as a Nurse Aide I and Nurse Aide II are recommended. Practice in health care settings is the course focus. Students participate in a reflective experience that provides the context to integrate classroom and experiential learning into an evolving professional identity.
courses.subject: NURS
courses.title: Practicum in Nursing: Health Services Improvement Work Experience (3)

courses.description: Majors only. Prepares R.N. students for population-focused practice in community health nursing. Analyses and applications of selected theories; health promotion/protection and disease prevention strategies are emphasized.
courses.subject: NURS
courses.title: Community Health Nursing for the Public’s Health (3–6)

courses.description: Majors only. The focus of this course is the development of knowledge and experience related to research or service learning and its application to the practice of nursing and health care.
courses.subject: NURS
courses.title: Advanced Practicum in Nursing (1–3)

courses.description: Prerequisites, NURS 364, 371, and 487 or 489, and 472 or 477 or 479. Corequisite NURS 488. Majors only. This course explores organizational leadership and management practices and theories. Current social, economic, legal, ethical, and policy issues affecting practice, education, and the profession of nursing are examined.
courses.subject: NURS
courses.title: Leadership in Health Care Organizations (4)

courses.description: Prerequisites, NURS 364 and 371. Corequisite NURS 456. Majors only. This senior-level course focuses on applying critical thinking, clinical decision making, and evidence-based nursing practice to complex health problems of adults. Unique health needs of older adults are addressed.
courses.subject: NURS
courses.title: Nursing Care of Adults with Major Health Problems, II (8)

courses.description: This course provides service-learning opportunities to apply nursing practice within the context of interprofessional care for vulnerable populations by participating with Student Health Action Coalition (SHAC) activities.
courses.subject: NURS
courses.title: SHAC: Student Health Action Coalition (0)

courses.description: Majors only or permission of the instructor. A faculty led experiential learning opportunity focusing on development and knowledge related to research, health care systems, or service learning and its application to nursing and health care.
courses.subject: NURS
courses.title: Health Care in the Global Context (1)

courses.description: Pilot test for new courses in the nursing program.
courses.subject: NURS
courses.title: Experimental Courses (1–3)

courses.description: Permission of the instructor for nonmajors. Students from a variety of health sciences-related disciplines gain an understanding of issues in working with dying and bereaved individuals of all ages and their families.
courses.subject: NURS
courses.title: Care of the Dying and Bereaved throughout the Life Span (3)

courses.description: Prerequisites, nUrs 715, 726, and 727. Co-requisite, nUrs 720. Permission of the instructor for students lacking the preand corequisites. examines the principles of psychopharmacology and neurobiology for safe and effective psychotherapeutic management of individuals with psychiatric and mental health problems across the lifespan.
courses.subject: NURS
courses.title: Psychopharmacology in Psychiatric-Mental Health Advanced Practice Nursing (2)

courses.description: Prerequisite, nUrs 778. Permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisite. focuses on the translation of research evidence to support improved models of care delivery.
courses.subject: NURS
courses.title: Synthesis and Translation of Evidence (3)

courses.description: Prerequisites, nUrs 715, 720, 726, 810, and 811. This capstone course focuses on the management of complex health problems in adult populations for the adult nurse practitioner.
courses.subject: NURS
courses.title: Management of Complex Health Problems in Adults (6)

courses.description: Prerequisites, nUrs 810, 840, or 860. Permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisites. examines current advanced practice nursing roles issues, within the context of contemporary healthcare delivery, legal, and sociopolitical systems.
courses.subject: NURS
courses.title: Advanced Practice Nursing Role (1)

courses.description: Prerequisites, nUrs 688 and 689. Co-requisite, nUrs 820. Permission of instructor for students lacking the corequisite. focuses on evidence-based nursing and medical management issues relevant to the care of patients and their families across the cancer continuum and practice settings.
courses.subject: NURS
courses.title: Seminar in Advanced Oncology Nursing (0

courses.description: Prerequisites, nUrs 715, 720, 726, 810, 825, and 827. This course is the capstone practicum for family nurse practitioner students. it emphasizes the comprehensive clinical management of primary health care needs in the context of the individual, the family, and/or the community.
courses.subject: NURS
courses.title: Advanced Clinical Practicum in Primary Care of Families (4)

courses.description: Prerequisites, nUrs 710 and nUrs 725. Preor corequisite, nUrs 720. Permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisites. This course focuses on advanced practice nursing management of common clinical symptomatology and problems in pediatric primary care.
courses.subject: NURS
courses.title: Primary Care of Children (5)

courses.description: Preor corequisites, nUrs 710, 720, and 840. Permission of the instructor for students lacking the preor corequisites. This course prepares the advanced practice nurse to design, implement, and evaluate a coordinated system of interventions that aim to promote optimal health and maximize outcomes for infants, children, and adolescents with complex conditions.
courses.subject: NURS
courses.title: Management of Complex Conditions in Advanced Practice Pediatric Nursing (4)

courses.description: Prerequisite, nUrs 727. focuses on theories, techniques, and research related to providing individual psychotherapy. Contextual factors affecting the delivery of psychiatric-mental health nursing services are analyzed.
courses.subject: NURS
courses.title: Psychiatric Nursing Interventions with Individuals (5)

courses.description: Prerequisites, nUrs 715, 720, 722, 726, 727, 860, 864, and 865. Permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisites. This courses focuses on the management of complex psychiatric-mental health problems across the lifespan for the psychiatric-mental health nurse practitioner.
courses.subject: NURS
courses.title: Management of Complex Psychiatric-Mental Health Problems Across the Lifespan (6)

courses.description: This course examines health care and nursing practice organizations, and the influence of the external and internal environment on these organizations. roles and functions of nurses at different levels and in different types of health care settings are explored.
courses.subject: NURS
courses.title: Leadership and Advanced Practice Roles in Health Care Organizations (3)

courses.description: explores the knowledge and skills required for effective human resource management. Managerial behaviors that promote and maintain a professional nursing practice environment are emphasized.
courses.subject: NURS
courses.title: Human Resource Management (3)

courses.description: This online course examines foundations of contemporary nursing and health care education, including academic, staff development, patient education programs, and lifelong learning.
courses.subject: NURS
courses.title: Innovations in Nursing and Health Care Curricula (3)

courses.description: required preparation, all required courses for the HCs specialty or concurrent enrollment in final HCs coursework. Course provides students an opportunity to develop, implement, and evaluate advanced practice and leadership strategies in a Health Care systems area of focus.
courses.subject: NURS
courses.title: Health Care Residency and Integrative Seminar (5)

courses.description: Prerequisite, nUrs 715. Permission of the instructor. first of two courses preparing clinical nurse leaders. emphasis is on the use of evidence-based approaches from outcomes/quality, transitional care, and finance to improve nursing care delivery in clinical systems.
courses.subject: NURS
courses.title: Evidence-Based Care for Clinical Nurse Leaders I (5)

courses.subject: NURS
courses.title: Nursing, Health Organizations and Policy Making (3)

courses.description: examines the major theoretical paradigms, perspectives, and issues in organization theory, particularly as applied to organizations providing health care services.
courses.subject: NURS
courses.title: Organizational Theories (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, nUrs 941. seminar focused on design and implementation issues related to the practice inquiry project.
courses.subject: NURS
courses.title: Practice Inquiry Seminar II (1)

courses.description: Knowledge, theories, and skills necessary for transition into an academic teaching role in university schools of nursing. Particular emphasis on the teaching-learning process as used in higher education.
courses.subject: NURS
courses.title: Analysis of the Academic Role in Nursing Education (3)

courses.description: focuses on the analysis of contemporary ethical/legal dilemmas in health care and research. examines nurses’ ethical/legal responsibilities, law and the impact of judicial precedent upon clinical practice and research, the interface of law and ethics, and comparative theories/models of ethical reasoning and decision-making.
courses.subject: NURS
courses.title: Ethics and Law in Health Care and Research (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, nUrs 957. Permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisite. examines methodological, ethical, and practical issues in the design and implementation of theory-based intervention studies.
courses.subject: NURS
courses.title: Designing Intervention Studies (3)

courses.description: Proseminars are offered for one, two, or three credits. topics differ each semester.
courses.subject: NURS
courses.title: Proseminar in Nursing (1–3)

courses.subject: NURS
courses.title: Conducting Systematic Reviews and Writing Specific Aims (4)

courses.description: in this course, students apply principles and practices of writing to the preparation of manuscripts for publication.
courses.subject: NURS
courses.title: Writing for Publication (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, nUrs 671 or 777. Permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisite. This course will examine principles of bivariate and multiple regression and correlation, as well as univariate AnovA, multiple AnovA, AnCovA, and repeated measures AnovA. emphasis is on application of these techniques in the analysis of nursing and health-related data.
courses.subject: NURS
courses.title: Statistical Models for Health Research (4)

courses.description: directs students to develop research skills related to the dissertation and to their future research.
courses.subject: NURS
courses.title: Research Seminar and Practicum: Guided Individual Research Experience (1–5)

courses.description: discussions, workshops, and lectures to develop the student’s skills and abilities to make therapeutic recommendations, utilize drug literature, educate patients and health professionals, and record observations, plans, and actions in a problemoriented record.
courses.subject: DPET
courses.title: Advanced Clinical Pharmacy (3)

courses.description: required preparation, introductory biostatistics or general statistics. Graduate standing or permission of the instructor. This course reviews statistical concepts and discusses the most commonly used statistical methods for analysis of data from clinical studies or research experiments. students will analyze problem datasets using sAs.
courses.subject: DPET
courses.title: Quantitative Methods in Clinical Research (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, dPet 832. Permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisite. The goals of this course are to provide graduate students with an understanding of major genomic discovery methodologies and their application for solving translational research problems.
courses.subject: DPET
courses.title: Methods in Pharmacogenomics (2)

courses.description: Provides working knowledge of commonly-used processes, techniques, and methods involved in drug development processes, emphasizing preclinical aspects. lectures and in-class case-based interactive discussion. students will develop problem-solving skills, writing and presentation skills, and will be exposed to analytical and pharmaceutical methods and gain experience interpreting data for regulatory approval.
courses.subject: DPET
courses.title: Science and Methods in Drug Development (2)

courses.description: Prerequisite, MoPH 855. Permission of the instructor. Advanced treatment of contemporary pharmacokinetic theory and application, with emphasis on model development, analytical approaches to parameter estimation, and experimental design/data analysis.
courses.subject: DPET
courses.title: Advanced Pharmacokinetics and Pharmacodynamics (4)

courses.subject: CBMC
courses.title: Biochem Found Of Chem Bio Lecture

courses.subject: CBMC
courses.title: Found Chem Bio Journal Club Lecture

courses.description: Prerequisites, PHCy 442, 443, 444, 445, and 446. Provides comprehensive immunization education, discusses strategies to develop, implement, and maintain pharmacybased immunization services, and provides opportunities to practice administration of subcutaneous and intramuscular injections.
courses.subject: PACE
courses.title: Ambulatory Care (3)

courses.description: Prerequisites, PHCy 442, 443, 444, 445, and 446. This course examines the expanded role of pharmacists in the community setting with the focus on integrating their pharmacotherapy knowledge into the Medication Therapy Management role.
courses.subject: PACE
courses.title: Medication Therapy Management (2)

courses.description: Arrangements to be made with the faculty in each case. A course for students of public health who wish to make a study of some special problem in the statistics of the life sciences and public health.
courses.subject: BIOS
courses.title: Problems in Biostatistics (1–21)

courses.description: Permission of the instructor for nonmajors. Required preparation, basic familiarity with statistical software (preferably SAS able to do multiple linear regression) and introductory biostatistics, such as BIOS 600. Continuation of BIOS 600. Analysis of experimental and observational data, including multiple regression and analysis of variance and covariance.
courses.subject: BIOS
courses.title: Principles of Experimental Analysis (3)

courses.description: This course examines the relationship between environmental quality, human health and welfare, with particular attention to contamination in human environment; physical, biological, and social factors; trade-offs regarding prevention and remediation measures. Satisfies core School of Public Health requirement. Three lecture hours per week.
courses.subject: BIOS
courses.title: Environmental Health (3)

courses.description: See MATH 661 for description.
courses.subject: BIOS
courses.title: Scientific Computation I (MATH 661) (3)

courses.description: Required preparation, BIOS 662. Matrix-based treatment of regression, one-way and two-way ANOVA, and ANCOVA, emphasizing the general linear model and hypothesis, as well as diagnostics and model building. Reviews matrix algebra. Includes statistical power for linear models and binary response regression methods.
courses.subject: BIOS
courses.title: Intermediate Linear Models (4)

courses.description: Prerequisite, BIOS 550. Permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisite. Fundamental principles and methods of sampling populations, with emphasis on simple, random, stratified, and cluster sampling. Sample weights, nonsampling error, and analysis of data from complex designs are covered. Practical experience through participation in the design, execution, and analysis of a sampling project.
courses.subject: BIOS
courses.title: Sample Survey Methodology (STOR 358) (4)

courses.description: See MATH 669 for description.
courses.subject: BIOS
courses.title: Methods of Applied Mathematics II (MATH 669) (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, BIOS 661. Permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisite. Introduction to concepts and techniques used in the analysis of time to event data, including censoring, hazard rates, estimation of survival curves, regression techniques, applications to clinical trials.
courses.subject: BIOS
courses.title: Introductory Survivorship Analysis (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, bios 661. Theory and application of nonparametric methods for various problems in statistical analysis. includes procedures based on randomization, ranks and U-statistics. A knowledge of elementary computer programming is assumed.
courses.subject: BIOS
courses.title: Advanced Nonparametric Methods in Biometric Research (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, bios 760. Permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisite. elementary decision theory: admissibility, minimaxity, loss functions, bayesian approaches. Hypothesis testing: neyman-Pearson theory, UMP and unbiased tests, invariance, confidence sets, contiguous alternatives. elements of stochastic processes: Poisson processes, renewal theory, Markov chains, martingales, brownian motion.
courses.subject: BIOS
courses.title: Advanced Probability and Statistical Inference II (4)

courses.description: Prerequisite, bios 664. Continuation of bios 664 for advanced students: stratification, special designs, multistage sampling, cost studies, nonsampling errors, complex survey designs, employing auxiliary information, and other miscellaneous topics.
courses.subject: BIOS
courses.title: Advanced Survey Sampling Methods (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, bios 762. Permission of the instructor for nonmajors. Presents modern approaches to the analysis of longitudinal data. topics include linear mixed effects models, generalized linear models for correlated data (including generalized estimating equations), computational issues and methods for fitting models, and dropout or other missing data.
courses.subject: BIOS
courses.title: Longitudinal Data Analysis (4)

courses.description: Prerequisite, bios 670. required preparation, integral calculus. life table techniques; methods of analysis when data are deficient; population projection methods; interrelations among demographic variables; migration analysis; uses of population models.
courses.subject: BIOS
courses.title: Demographic Techniques II (3)

courses.description: The course will review major statistical methods for the analysis of Mri and its applications in various studies.
courses.subject: BIOS
courses.title: Statistical Analysis of MRI Images (3)

courses.subject: BIOS
courses.title: Stat Methods In Diagnostic Med Lecture

courses.subject: BIOS
courses.title: Causal Infer In Biomed Resrch Lecture

courses.description: Prerequisites, bios 661 and 663. Permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisites. Molecular biology, sequence alignment, sequence motifs identification by Monte Carlo bayesian approaches, dynamic programming, hidden Markov models, computational algorithms, statistical software, high-throughput sequencing data and its application in computational biology.
courses.subject: BIOS
courses.title: Introduction to Computational Biology (3)

courses.description: Prerequisites, bios 545. Permission of the instructor for nonmajors. An introduction to the statistical consulting process, emphasizing its nontechnical aspects.
courses.subject: BIOS
courses.title: Principles of Statistical Consulting (3)

courses.description: Prerequisites, bios 511, 545, 550, and 841. Permission of the instructor. Under supervision of a faculty member, the student interacts with research workersin the health sciences, learning to abstract the statistical aspects of substantive problems, to provide appropriate technical assistance, and to communicate statistical results.
courses.subject: BIOS
courses.title: Practice in Statistical Consulting (1–21)

courses.description: This seminar course is intended to give students exposure to cutting edge research topics and hopefully help them in their choice of a thesis topic. it also allows the student to meet and learn from major researchers in the field.
courses.subject: BIOS
courses.title: Seminar in Biostatistics (1)

courses.subject: BIOS
courses.title: Training in Statistical Teaching in the Health Sciences (1–21)

courses.description: individual arrangements may be made by the advanced student to spend part or all of his or her time in supervised investigation of selected problems in statistics.
courses.subject: BIOS
courses.title: Research in Biostatistics (1–21)

courses.description: Presents the results of ongoing research projects in the department of environmental sciences and engineering. topics and presenters are selected from among the departmental graduate students and faculty.
courses.subject: ENVR
courses.title: Seminar Series (1)

courses.description: see MAsC 401 for description.
courses.subject: ENVR
courses.title: Oceanography (BIOL 350, GEOL 403, MASC 401) (3)

courses.description: see PHnU 423 for description.
courses.subject: ENVR
courses.title: Industrial Toxicology (PHNU 423) (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, envr 422. An introduction to the health hazards associated with the various unit operations of industry. field trips to local industries planned.
courses.subject: ENVR
courses.title: Health Hazards of Industrial Operation (3)

courses.description: see MAsC 560 for description.
courses.subject: ENVR
courses.title: Fluid Dynamics (GEOL 560, MASC 560, PHYS 660) (3)

courses.description: Required preparation, one course in probability and statistics. Use of mathematical models and computer simulation tools to estimate the human health impacts of exposure to environmental pollutants. Three lecture hours per week.
courses.subject: ENVR
courses.title: Environmental Risk Assessment (ENST 470) (3)

courses.description: see MAsC 505 for description.
courses.subject: ENVR
courses.title: Chemical Oceanography (GEOL 505, MASC 505) (4)

courses.description: This course is intended to develop a student’s ability to operate the primary instruments for measuring these important pollutants, collect and process samples where necessary, record data, and process instrument data into final air concentration data.
courses.subject: ENVR
courses.title: Measurement of NOx, O3, and Volatile Organic Compounds (3)

courses.description: see MAsC 504 for description.
courses.subject: ENVR
courses.title: Biological Oceanography (BIOL 657, MASC 504) (4)

courses.description: A practical experience in a setting relevant to environmental health.
courses.subject: ENVR
courses.title: Undergraduate Practicum in Environmental Health Sciences (1–3)

courses.description: This course examines the relationship between environmental quality, human health and welfare, with particular attention to contamination in human environment; physical, biological, and social factors; trade-offs regarding prevention and remediation measures. satisfies core school of Public Health requirement. Three lecture hours per week.
courses.subject: ENVR
courses.title: Environmental Health (3)

courses.description: An introduction to relevant epidemiologic concepts that inform environmental science research. learning objectives include discussing basic epidemiologic concepts and measures of disease occurrence in populations, explaining epidemiological study designs for studying associations between risk factors or exposures in populations, evaluating epidemiologic evidence, and comprehending basic ethical principles.
courses.subject: ENVR
courses.title: Epidemiology for Environmental Scientists (3)

courses.description: see MAtH 662 for description.
courses.subject: ENVR
courses.title: Scientific Computation II (COMP 662, MATH 662) (3)

courses.description: see MAtH 669 for description.
courses.subject: ENVR
courses.title: Methods of Applied Mathematics II (MATH 669) (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, envr 671. second part of a graduate-level sequence in physical principles relevant to environmental systems. topics include turbulence, conservation of energy, multiscale methods, and thermodynamics. Applications are considered from natural and engineered systems and across all relevant media. focus is on development of mechanistic representation of environmental systems.
courses.subject: ENVR
courses.title: Environmental Physics II (3)

courses.description: directed readings or laboratory study. written reports are required. May be taken more than once for credit. Three to nine hours per week.
courses.subject: ENVR
courses.title: Undergraduate Research (1–3)

courses.description: see toXC 707 for description.
courses.subject: ENVR
courses.title: Advanced Toxicology (PHCO/TOXC 707) (3)

courses.description: required preparation, a previous or concurrent course in microbiology. Theory and practice of biological processes used to remove contaminants from environmental media, including water, wastewater, soil, and air.
courses.subject: ENVR
courses.title: Environmental Process Biotechnology (3)

courses.subject: ENVR
courses.title: Current Topics in Environmental Analytical Chemistry (1)

courses.description: required preparation, basic or general chemistry. emphasis on acquiring laboratory skills and hands-on experience with instrumentation including chromatography and mass spectrometry; sample handling and preparation; quality assurance and control. Three lecture hours or one lecture hour and four laboratory hours per week.
courses.subject: ENVR
courses.title: Instrumental Methods for the Chemical Analysis of Environmental Samples (3)

courses.description: Prerequisites, envr 419 and 451. Principles of disinfection, oxidation, coagulation, precipitation, sedimentation, filtration, adsorption, ion exchange, and membrane processes; applications to water and wastewater treatment. Three lecture hours per week.
courses.subject: ENVR
courses.title: Physical/Chemical Treatment Processes (3)

courses.description: see MAtH 762 for description.
courses.subject: ENVR
courses.title: Numerical ODE/PDE II (MASC 782, MATH 762) (3)

courses.description: see MAtH 764 for description.
courses.subject: ENVR
courses.title: Mathematical Modeling II (MASC 784, MATH 769) (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, envr 430. This course provides both practical and theoretical information on biological monitoring of chemical exposures and how to evaluate and interpret exposure data. Three lecture hours per week and a term paper (three credit hours).
courses.subject: ENVR
courses.title: Biological Monitoring (3)

courses.description: Air pollution is formed through thousands of chemical reactions. Computer models areused to simulate this complex chemistry and used to make policy. Current computational restraints force a simplified representation of atmospheric chemistry in these models, and the focus of this course is the implications of this on predictions.
courses.subject: ENVR
courses.title: Modeling Atmospheric Chemistry (3)

courses.subject: ENVR
courses.title: Water Resources Planning and Policy Analysis (PLAN 781) (3)

courses.description: see PlAn 785 for description.
courses.subject: ENVR
courses.title: Public Investment Theory (PLAN 785, PLCY 785) (3)

courses.description: Permission of the department. for students outside the department who wish to undertake individual study of a specific problem in environmental sciences and engineering. The subject and requirements of the project are arranged with the faculty in each individual instance. one or more hours per week.
courses.subject: ENVR
courses.title: Problems in Environmental Sciences and Engineering (1–21)

courses.description: A practical experience in public health/environmental health sciences.
courses.subject: ENVR
courses.title: Environmental Sciences Practicum (1–9)

courses.description: Consultation with the faculty and approval of subject and proposed program required. Permission of the instructor. May be repeated. Hours and credits to be arranged.
courses.subject: ENVR
courses.title: Research in Environmental Sciences and Engineering (1–9)

courses.description: The technical report requirement for M.s.P.H., M.P.H., and M.s.e.e. candidates is satisfied by the extensive study of a problem in environmental sciences and engineering.
courses.subject: ENVR
courses.title: Master’s Technical Report (3–6)

courses.description: An introductory course that considers the meaning, scope, and applications of epidemiology to public health practice and the uses of vital statistics data in the scientific appraisal of community health. one lecture and two lab hours per week.
courses.subject: EPID
courses.title: Principles of Epidemiology (3)

courses.description: Prerequisites, ePid 705, ePid 710 or 711. Corequisite, bios 545. required preparation, competence in sAs. Permission of the instructor required for nonmajors. An in-depth treatment of basic concepts and skills in epidemiologic research, including problem conceptualization, study design, research conduct, data analysis, and interpretation. four lecture hours per week.
courses.subject: EPID
courses.title: Theory and Quantitative Methods in Epidemiology (4)

courses.description: Corequisite, bios 600. Permission of the instructor for nonmajors. intensive introduction to epidemiological concepts and methods for students intending to engage in, collaborate in, or interpret the results of epidemiologic studies. An alternate to ePid 600 for satisfying the sPH core requirements. Three lecture and two seminar hours a week.
courses.subject: EPID
courses.title: Fundamentals of Epidemiology (4)

courses.description: An introduction to statistical analysis, programming, and data management, using the sAs programming language. two lecture hours and two lab hours per week.
courses.subject: EPID
courses.title: SAS and Data Management (3)

courses.description: Prerequisites, ePid 705, 710 or 711. Corequisite, ePid 715. required preparation, documented sAs proficiency. This course is a combined lecture/lab format where students get hands-on experience in the analysis and interpretation of data from cohort and case-control studies.
courses.subject: EPID
courses.title: Epidemiologic Data Analysis (2)

courses.description: Required preparation, previous or concurrent course in applied statistics. Permission of instructor for nonmajors. Introduction to use of computers to process and analyze data, concepts and techniques of research data management, and use of statistical programming packages and interpretation. Focus is on use of SAS for data management and reporting.
courses.subject: BIOS
courses.title: Introduction to Statistical Computing and Data Management (4)

courses.description: Corequisite, ePid 718 (fall); ePid 722 (spring). A discussion in journal-club format of readings in general epidemiologic methods, from problem conceptualization to application of results.
courses.subject: EPID
courses.title: Readings in Epidemiologic Methods (1)

courses.description: Prerequisite, ePid 718. required preparation, sAs software expertise. Course covers epidemiologic analysis of time-to-event data and emphasizes weighing threats to the accuracy of inferences. Class time is spent discussing weekly readings and homeworks..
courses.subject: EPID
courses.title: Epidemiologic Analysis of Time-to-Event Data (4)

courses.description: Prerequisites, ePid 715 and 725. Minimum secondyear standing in doctoral program or permission of the instructor. Majors only. A second-level course in the design and conduct of epidemiologic research. each student will comprehensively address the conceptual and practical aspects of developing a high-quality, detailed research proposal.
courses.subject: EPID
courses.title: Epidemiologic Research Methods (3)

courses.description: required preparation, introductory epidemiology and biostatistics. systematic overview of principles in design, implementation, and analysis of clinical trials. emphasis on applications in chronic disease epidemiology. in-depth discussion of case examples from cardiovascular disease epidemiology emphasized. Three lecture hours a week.
courses.subject: EPID
courses.title: Clinical Trials in Epidemiology (3)

courses.description: This course surveys the major issues relevant to the application of biomarkers in epidemiological research, including the logistical hurdles in biospecimen collection and storage, assessments of biomarker quality, analytic issues, and the interpretation of quantitative estimates.
courses.subject: EPID
courses.title: Biomarkers in Population-Based Research (2)

courses.description: Prerequisites, bios 545 and ePid 715. Permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisites. Concepts and methods of genetic epidemiology relevant to the study of complex human diseases, including segregation analysis, linkage analysis, and gene-environment interaction. includes whole genome approaches, as well as nonhuman systems. Three lecture hours a week.
courses.subject: EPID
courses.title: Genetic Epidemiology: Methods and Applications (3)

courses.description: Permission required for non-majors. objectives of the course are to: (1) understand the general principles of infectious disease epidemiology; (2) understand surveillance, prevention and control of infectious diseases; and (3) apply principles to specific infectious diseases. Course is part lecture and part group projects/discussion period per week.
courses.subject: EPID
courses.title: Introduction to Infectious Disease Epidemiology (3)

courses.description: Course will focus on epidemiological methods required to investigate urgent public health problems. Course covers the skills and tools needed to conduct outbreak investigations and communicate findings to the public. Three lecture hours per week.
courses.subject: EPID
courses.title: Methods in Field Epidemiology (3)

courses.description: Prerequisites, bios 600 and ePid 710. epidemiologic ideas and methods applied to evaluation and control of human health consequences of environmental hazards. Pollution of environmental media and global change are considered from a human-ecological perspective, with local and international examples. Three lecture hours per week.
courses.subject: EPID
courses.title: Environmental Epidemiology (3)

courses.description: Principles for conducting research within communities unduly burdened by environmental health threats are presented. topics include research ethics, community presentations, study design and implementation, and student research projects.
courses.subject: EPID
courses.title: Community-Driven Epidemiology and Environmental Justice (2)

courses.description: see PUbH 760 for description.
courses.subject: EPID
courses.title: Clinical Measurement/Evaluation (PUBH 760) (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, ePid 711. Clinical research majors only. The goal of this course is to develop a strong fundamental understanding of the design of clinical research studies, excluding traditional (Phase iii) randomized clinical trials.
courses.subject: EPID
courses.title: Design of Clinical Research (3)

courses.description: Prerequisites, ePid 805, ePid 711, PUbH 741. Permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisites. Proposal writing and study implementation skills. emphasis is given to niH style proposals for clinical and translational research.
courses.subject: EPID
courses.title: Clinical Research Skills IV -Proposal Development (2)

courses.description: Prerequisite, ePid 600. This course provides an overview of major issues in physical activity measurements, population distribution, correlates, impacts (physically and economically), and public health recommendations. interventions, including relevant theories, will be reviewed. Three lecture hours per week.
courses.subject: EPID
courses.title: Physical Activity Epidemiology and Public Health (NUTR 810) (3)

courses.description: see nUtr 813 for description.
courses.subject: EPID
courses.title: Nutritional Epidemiology (NUTR 813) (3)

courses.description: open to ePid majors, second-year or above. Provides epidemiology majors with supervised experience in teaching and course preparation. students act as assistants in departmental courses. two to eight seminar hours a week.
courses.subject: EPID
courses.title: Teaching Experience in Epidemiology (1–4)

courses.description: Permission of the instructor required. independent reading and tutorial guidance in special areas of epidemiology.
courses.subject: EPID
courses.title: Readings in Epidemiology (1-3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, ePid 710. ePid majors only. topics are chosen to reflect emerging issues in the field, as well as those that meet the interests of the students and faculty in the department.
courses.subject: EPID
courses.title: Topics in Epidemiology Seminar (1)

courses.description: Students (1). A workshop for addressing special topics related to M.s.P.H. program including, but not limited to, research topic development, career planning, and public health ethics.
courses.subject: EPID
courses.title: Seminar for M

courses.description: Prerequisite, MHCH 756. This seminar will provide an opportunity for students to synthesize knowledge across disciplines and to developan interdisciplinary approach to addressing their identified health disparities research topic.
courses.subject: EPID
courses.title: Interdisciplinary Seminar in Health Disparities (MHCH 892) (1)

courses.description: required preparation, basic knowledge of epidemiology and biostatistics. This is a weekly seminar to explore current problems in pharmacoepidemiology. it supplements the introductory course, ePid 765. May be repeated. two seminar hours a week.
courses.subject: EPID
courses.title: Pharmacoepidemiology Seminar (1)

courses.description: required preparation, introductory epidemiology and biostatistics. detailed review of selected topics in infectious disease epidemiology. May be repeated for credit.
courses.subject: EPID
courses.title: Infectious Disease Seminar (1)

courses.description: Prerequisite, ePid 710. explores conceptual and methods issues in conducting epidemiologic investigations of oral conditions, specifically caries, periodontal disease, and oral cancer (topics rotate semesters).
courses.subject: EPID
courses.title: Seminar in Oral Epidemiology (1)

courses.description: Clinical and translational science Curriculum fellows or permission of the instructor. Practical clinical research and professional development topics presented by faculty, local experts, and CtsC fellows.
courses.subject: EPID
courses.title: Clinical Research and Professional Development Seminar (1)

courses.description: Permission of the instructor. review of substantive and methodological research in cardiovascular and cerebrovascular diseases. May be repeated for credit. two to six seminar hours a week.
courses.subject: EPID
courses.title: Advanced Seminar in Cardiovascular Research (1–3)

courses.description: designed to give epidemiology majors a supervised field experience in population health research.
courses.subject: EPID
courses.title: Epidemiology Practice (4)

courses.description: Permission of the instructor. independent investigation in consultation with an instructor who must assign or approve the subject of research. Credits vary according to the effort and rigor of the research.
courses.subject: EPID
courses.title: Research in Epidemiology (1–21)

courses.description: see JoMC 561 for description.
courses.subject: HBEH
courses.title: Medical Reporting for Electronic Media (,HPM 551, JOMC 561) (3)

courses.description: This course focuses on social and behavioral science theories, research and interventions aimed at promoting health of individuals, groups, communities and populations. two lecture hours per week.
courses.subject: HBEH
courses.title: Social and Behavioral Sciences in Public Health (3)

courses.description: This course will explore issues, theories and experiences relevant to social action, coalition building, and social change. The content of this course will be examined by confronting the possibilities and limitations of service and servicelearning as it relates to APPles Alternative spring break experiences.
courses.subject: HBEH
courses.title: Alternative Spring Break (2)

courses.description: in this course students learn about and experience the process of awarding grants to local agencies. in addition to participating in the grant-making process, students learn about the nonprofit sector and the philosophy and practice of philanthropy through readings, class exercises, and guest speakers.
courses.subject: HBEH
courses.title: Philanthropy as a Tool for Social Change (3)

courses.description: The spring semester will focus on knowledge and skills to manage programs with an emphasis on personnel and resources management. specific topics include: supervision, interviewing, salary negotiation, non-profit management, organizational culture, budgeting, and proposal development.
courses.subject: HBEH
courses.title: Program Management Part II (1)

courses.description: students are introduced to adult learning principles, effective training methods, course design and evaluation for international audiences and settings, and characteristics of culturally-competent trainers. students work in teams to: design a course and activity; facilitate the activity; and provide and incorporate feedback to foster peer sharing and learning.
courses.subject: HBEH
courses.title: Effective Training for Global Health (1–3)

courses.description: The nature and delineation of participatory action research and its relevance to concepts, principles, and practices of community empowerment. students learn methods (such as photovoice) through learning projects.
courses.subject: HBEH
courses.title: Community Capacity, Competence, and Power (3)

courses.description: Majors only. individual field training opportunity that serves as a bridge between a student’s academic training and applied public health practice..
courses.subject: HBEH
courses.title: MPH Practicum I (1–4)

courses.description: students must complete a mentored research practicum. The mentor and student will develop a contract to achieve the research. The practicum requires a total of two hundred hours of work starting in the second year of the program.
courses.subject: HBEH
courses.title: Research Practicum I (2)

courses.description: Prerequisite, HbeH 750. Approaches to designing qualitative research studies for the development and evaluation of public health programs. emphasis is on the practice of collecting and analyzing data from individual interviews, focus group discussions, and observations.
courses.subject: HBEH
courses.title: Qualitative Research Methods (NUTR 753) (3)

courses.description: Course will survey social support in health, including the nature and key processes of social support, cultural influences in different countries, and approaches to promoting peer support in health promotion around the world. term assignment will entail planning a peer support program or research project of the student’s choice.
courses.subject: HBEH
courses.title: Social and Peer Support in Health: An Ecological and Global Perspective (3)

courses.description: in this course, students use a comprehensive planning model to plan, implement, and evaluate an evidence-based intervention that addresses a public health problem within a defined population.
courses.subject: HBEH
courses.title: Planning Public Health Interventions (3)

courses.description: Permission of the instructor for nonmajors. A critical examination of the social determinants of health, health disparities, principles of individual and collective behavior and behavior change, and the role of health behavior in emerging public health issues.
courses.subject: HBEH
courses.title: Foundations of Health Behavior II (3)

courses.description: see JoMC 826 for description.
courses.subject: HBEH
courses.title: Interdisciplinary Health Communication Colloquium (JOMC 826) (1)

courses.description: designed to fulfill the research practicum for doctoral students, which may involve designing and implementing a research project, carrying out data analyses, writing manuscripts, or assuming responsibility for a project.
courses.subject: HBEH
courses.title: Primary Practicum for Doctoral Students (1–4)

courses.description: Practicum is designed to enhance knowledge and skills in teaching. student must be involved in teaching a twoor three-credit course. Co-teaching a course may satisfy this requirement.
courses.subject: HBEH
courses.title: Secondary Practicum for Doctoral Students (1–4)

courses.description: restricted to doctoral students in department. integration and application of detailed components of research methods to preparation and writing of a research grant proposal. introduction to proposal submission and review process for various funding agencies.
courses.subject: HBEH
courses.title: Research Proposal Development (3)

courses.description: An independent course designed for study areas of natural or planned change; personal and nonpersonal methods, in health related fields. to be arranged with faculty in each case.
courses.subject: HBEH
courses.title: Special Studies in Behavior Change (1–6)

courses.description: Capstone is a year-long, group-based, mentored, service-learning, field experience. The course focuses on building skills specific to these service-learning projects and provides students with opportunities to discuss and generalize learning from their Capstone project experiences. The products produced are a substitute for the required Master’s thesis.
courses.subject: HBEH
courses.title: MPH Capstone Project (3)

courses.description: This course will provide students with a working knowledge of the various forms of health care consulting, including internal consulting. Students will enhance their analytical, presentation, teamwork, and project management skills.
courses.subject: HPM
courses.title: Introduction to Strategic Planning and Marketing (3)

courses.subject: HPM
courses.title: Plcy Iss In Hlt Svcs Del Lecture

courses.description: HPM 352, in conjunction with HPM 350, provides an overview of the U.S. health services system, including such topics as quality of care and managed care. The course also introduces students to careers in the field of health policy and management and helps students develop necessary communication skills.
courses.subject: HPM
courses.title: Introduction to Health Services Systems II (3)

courses.description: Participants in this one-week experiential short course explore the structures, policies, challenges, and future directions of England’s National Health Service and compare this model with the United States. Class time is balanced with time in the field visiting London-area health facilities and historical sites and meeting with area experts.
courses.subject: HPM
courses.title: Health Systems around the World: Understanding England’s National Health Service (1)

courses.description: Explores issues of preparedness, response, recovery, mitigation, and research in disaster management. Students will participate in evacuation decision-making, volunteer management, and the development of a disaster exercise. Every other week, evening online sessions required with instructors.
courses.subject: HPM
courses.title: Emergency Management II Disaster Management (3)

courses.description: Permission of the instructor. Application of basic principles of marketing and marketing decision models to problems in health care and other notfor-profit organizations.
courses.subject: HPM
courses.title: Marketing for Not-for-Profit Organizations (3)

courses.description: Concepts and methods of the program evaluation paradigm as applied in health administration.
courses.subject: HPM
courses.title: Program Evaluation (3)

courses.description: Directed readings or research. Written reports are required.
courses.subject: HPM
courses.title: Readings in Health Policy and Management (1–3)

courses.description: Current issues pertaining to the health and wellbeing of older Americans, and how such issues influence family dynamics and choices about long-term care. Critical topics on chronic illness, family and community caregiving, ethnicity/culture, and socioeconomic status will be covered in the course.
courses.subject: HPM
courses.title: Aging, Family, and Long-Term Care: Cultural, Ethnic, and Racial Issues (3)

courses.description: See JOMC 561 for description.
courses.subject: HPM
courses.title: Medical and Science Video Storytelling (HBEH 561, JOMC 561) (3)

courses.description: Permission of the instructor. restricted to seniors. does not qualify as a core course or elective for HPM undergraduate majors. Provides an overview of the United states health system, emphasizing role of policy development and administrative decision making through case examples.
courses.subject: HPM
courses.title: Introduction to Health Policy and Management (2)

courses.description: This course develops systems reasoning in health policy and management students through the application of systems techniques and systems thinking to core public health concepts in health policy and management, environmental health, epidemiology, and health behavior.
courses.subject: HPM
courses.title: Public Health Concepts in a Systems Context (3)

courses.description: Focuses on implementing informatics programs and projects in health organizations. Informatics initiatives aim to facilitate effective information use for the purpose of improving the quality of health services and/or efficiency of processes. Therefore, these initiatives have implicationsfor various stakeholder groups, including consumers, practitioners, administrators, and policy makers.
courses.subject: HPM
courses.title: Implementing Health Informatics Initiatives (3)

courses.description: Globalization— its economic, environmental, political, technological, institutional, and sociocultural dimensions—historically and currently contributes to beneficial and adverse effects on population, community, and family and individual health.
courses.subject: HPM
courses.title: Globalization and Health (MHCH 664) (3)

courses.description: see HPM 664 for description.
courses.subject: MHCH
courses.title: Globalization and Health (HPM 664) (3)

courses.description: Special topics course for health policy and management undergraduate students.
courses.subject: HPM
courses.title: Special Topics in Health Policy and Management (0

courses.description: The capstone course is an “integrative exercise” for BSPH students prior to graduation. It is intended to simulate the integration of various disciplines—finance, human resources, ethics, policy, operations, and information technology—into a comprehensive and practical framework. Students work with health care organizations to solve financial or operational problems.
courses.subject: HPM
courses.title: BSPH Capstone (3)

courses.description: restricted to HPM majors. supervised professional training (fee is $500).
courses.subject: HPM
courses.title: Professional Training II (1)

courses.description: restricted to HPM majors. supervised professional training (fee is $500).
courses.subject: HPM
courses.title: Professional Training III (1–21)

courses.description: This course introduces students to strategic planning and marketing in health services organizations. students develop practical skills such as assessing the internal and external environment, competitor analysis, and evaluating strategic alternatives in different health care settings. it also explores the role the governing board plays in strategy development and management.
courses.subject: HPM
courses.title: Health Care Strategy and Marketing (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, HPM 734. required preparation, completion of master’s core (can be concurrent). restricted to HPM graduate students. integrating and building upon the HPM master’s core, this comprehensive course focuses on organization policymaking and administration from the perspective of the Ceo and top management.
courses.subject: HPM
courses.title: Advanced Concepts and Applications in Health Policy and Management (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, HPM 740. Permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisite. Covers selected topics in managerial accounting applied to health care. it is intended to provide in-depth coverage of managerial topics introduced in HPM 250.
courses.subject: HPM
courses.title: Management Accounting for Health Administrators (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, HPM 742. topics include financial analysis and forecasting, working capital distributions to owners, mergers, capitation, and financial risk.
courses.subject: HPM
courses.title: Health Care Finance II (3)

courses.description: This course focuses on the political and policy dynamics of health care reform.
courses.subject: HPM
courses.title: Health Reform: Political Dynamics and Policy Dilemmas (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, bios 600. Permission of the instructor. review of the systems analysis process in health care systems. deterministic and random models, mathematical programming, queuing, simulation, forecasting, and measurement. emphasis on model formulation and computer solution of decision models.
courses.subject: HPM
courses.title: Operations Research for Health Care Systems (3)

courses.subject: HPM
courses.title: Intro To Regression For Hsr Lecture

courses.description: second-year M.s.P.H. or firstyear M.P.H. students only. broad topics related to the development and management of a research project are covered. The major goal is the development and completion of a proposal to be submitted for an independent master’s paper.
courses.subject: HPM
courses.title: Master’s Paper Development (1)

courses.description: Permission of the instructor. discussion of recent papers in health economics. students must have solid knowledge of graduate microeconomics theory and econometrics.
courses.subject: HPM
courses.title: Graduate Health Economics Seminar (1)

courses.description: Problems and processes of teaching health policy and management, including supervised practicum experience.
courses.subject: HPM
courses.title: Seminar in Teaching Health Policy and Management (1)

courses.description: seminar on policy issues in health policy and management.
courses.subject: HPM
courses.title: Policy Seminar in Health Policy and Management (1)

courses.description: This seminar will develop core competencies through a: (1) journal club to develop competencies in research design and expose students to diverse content and methodologies; and (2) professional development series.
courses.subject: HPM
courses.title: Advanced Research Seminar in HPM (1)

courses.description: Prerequisite, HPM 882. This course is an introduction to the analysis of categorical data using maximum likelihood. topics covered: econometric models in which the dependent variable is not continuous, including logit, Probit, tobit, two-part, and duration models.
courses.subject: HPM
courses.title: Linear Regression Models (3)

courses.description: Prerequisites, HPM 881 and 882. Permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisites. research methodology as applied to understanding problems in health care delivery. topics include simultaneous equation models, factor analysis, limited dependent variables, and an introduction to event history analysis.
courses.subject: HPM
courses.title: Analysis of Categorical Data (3)

courses.description: Prerequisite, HPM 884.
